aethling to jerusalem in 1102 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- edgar commonly call aethling be son of edward the son of edmond ironside who be the brother of edward the confessor to whom consequently edgar be nephew edgar travel to jerusalem in 1102 in company with robert the son of godwin most valiant knight be present in rama when king baldwin be there besiege by the turk and not be able to endure the hardship of the siege he be deliver from that danger and escape through the midst of the hostile camp chiefly through the aid of robert who go before he make a lane with he sword slaying number of the turk in he heroic progress towards the close of this chivalric enterprize and become more fierce and eager as he advance robert unfortunately dropt he sword and while stoop to recover he weapon he be oppress by the multitude who throw themselves upon he and make he prisoner from thence as some say robert be carry to babylon in egypt or cairo and refuse to renounce he faith in christ he be tie to a stake in the market-place and transpierce with arrow edgar have thus lose he valiant knight return towards europe and be much honor with many gift by the emperor both of greece and germany both of whom would gladly have retain he at they court on account of he high lineage but he despise all thing from regard to he native england into which he return : and have be subject to many change of fortune as we have elsewhere related he _ now _ spend he extreme old age in private obscurity -lrb- 1 -rrb- hakluyt i 44 w malmsb iii 58 section iii _ some circumstance respect the siege of joppa about the year _ 1102 -lrb- 1 -rrb- in the second year of baldwin king of jerusalem joppa be besiege by the turk of cairo and baldwin embark from the town of assur in a vessel call a _ buss _ command by one goderic a english freebooter intend to proceed to the relief of the besiege fix the royal banner aloft on a spear that it might be see of the christian they sail boldly towards joppa with but a small company of armed man the king know that the christian in joppa be almost hopeless of he life and safety and he fear they might shamefully abandon the defense of the place or be constrain to surrender unless revive by he presence on perceive the approach of the royal banner of king baldwin the naval force of the turk to the number of twenty gally and thirteen ship usually call _ cazh _ endeavor to surround and capture the single vessel in which he be embark but by the aid of god the billow of the sea rage against they while the king ship glide easily and swiftly through the wave elude the enemy and arrive in safety into the haven of joppa to the great joy of the christian who have mourn he as if dead while the saracen continue the siege of joppa 200 sail of christian vessel arrive there with pilgrim who wish to perform they devotions at jerusalem of these the chief leader be bernard witrazh of galatium hardin of england otho of roge haderwerck one of the principal noble of westphalium and other this power by the blessing of god arrive to succor the distressed christian then besiege in joppa on the 3d of July 1102 in the second year of baldwin king of jerusalem when the numerous army of the saracen see that the christian thus reinforce boldly face they without the wall they remove they tent during the night above a mile from the town that they might consider whether to retreat to ascalon or to continue to harass the citizen of joppa with frequent assault but they confide in they number and continue to annoy the christian by severe and repeated attack have allow three day rest and refreshment to this powerful reinforcement baldwin issue out from joppa early in the morning of the sixth of July to the martial sound of trumpet and cornet with a strong force both of foot and horse march directly toward the saracen with loud shout and attack they army with great spirit the land attack be assist by the christian navy which approach the shore make a horrible noise and distract the attention of the saracen who fear to be attack in flank and rear after a sharp encounter the saracen flee towards ascalon many be slay in the battle and pursuit and other drown by leap into the sea to avoid be slay in this battle 3000 of the saracen perish with a very small loss on the side of the christian and the city of joppa be deliver from its enemy -lrb- 1 -rrb- hakluyt i45 chron hierosol ix ix xi xii section iv _ of the transaction of certain english danish and flemish pilgrim in the holy land in 1107 _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- in the seventh year of king baldwin a large fleet from england contain above 7000 man many of whom be soldier arrive at the harbor of joppa along with whom come other warrior from denmark flander and antwerp have receive permission and safe conduct from king baldwin together with a strong band of armed man as a safeguard they arrive in safety at jerusalem and all the other place of devotion free from all assault and ambush of the gentile and have pay they vow unto the lord in the church of the holy sepulchre they return with great joy and without molestation to joppa -lrb- 2 -rrb- finding king baldwin in that place they make offer to assist he in any military enterprize for which offer he give they great commendation say that he could not give a immediate answer without consult the patriarch and baron of he kingdom he therefore call together the lord patriarch hugh of tabarium gunfrid the governor of the tower of david and the other principal officer of the kingdom of jerusalem to consult together in the city of rame how best to employ this proferred assistance of so considerable a body of volunteer in that assembly it be agree upon to lay siege to the city of sagitta otherwise call sidon upon which have direct every one of the noble to go home that they might provide armor and all other necessaries for the siege he send messenger to the english require they not to remove they fleet and army from joppa but to wait there for he farther command inform they that he and he noble have resolve with they aid to lay siege to the city of sidon but it would require some time to provide the necessary engine and warlike instrument for assault the wall of that place the pilgrim answer that they would attend he order at joppa promise to be obedient to he in all thing even unto death the king go soon afterwards with the patriarch and all he attendant to the city of acre where during forty day he be busily employ in the construction of engine and many different kind of warlike instrument and of every thing necessary for the intended siege when this intended expedition come to the knowledge of the inhabitant of sidon and they understand that a powerful army of pilgrim lay in readiness at joppa to assist the king of jerusalem they be afraid of be subdue and destroy by the christian as caesarium assur acre caypha and tabarium have already be and they send secret emissary to the king offer a large sum of money in gold byzant and a considerable yearly tribute on condition that he would spare they life and refrain from the intended siege after a lengthen negotiation during which the inhabitant of sidon rise considerably in they offer the king be in great strait for means to discharge the pay of he soldier hearken willingly to the offer of the sidonian yet afraid of reproach from the christian he dare not openly to consent to they proposal in the meantime hugh of tabarium who be a principal warrior among the christian of palestine and indefatigable in assault the pagan on all occasion have gather together 200 horse and 400 infantry suddenly invade the country of a great saracen lord name suet on the frontier of the territory of damascus where he take a rich booty of gold and silver and many cattle which would have prove of great importance in assist the army at the siege of sidon on he return with this prey by the city of belinas otherwise call caesarium philippus the turk of damascus with the saracen inhabitant of the country gather together in great number and pursue the troops of hugh that they might recover the booty come up with they in the mountain over which the infantry belong to hugh of tabarium be drive they prey the turk prevail over the christian and the plunder be recover on receive this intelligence hugh who happen to be at some distance hasten with he cavalry to succor he footman and to recover the spoil : but happen to fall in with the turk in a strait and craggy place and rush heedlessly among the enemy unprovided with he armor he be shoot in the back by a arrow which pierce he liver and he die on the spot he soldier bring back the dead body of hugh to the city of nazareth near mount thabor where he be honourably inter gerard the brother of hugh lay at this time sick of a dangerous illness and die within eight day afterwards take advantage of the death of these two famous prince king baldwin agree to receive the money which have be offer to he by the city of sidon yet keep he intention of make peace private and send to joppa desire the chief of the english dane and fleming to come with they fleet and army to acre as if he have mean to prosecute the siege when they arrive he represent to they chief the great loss he have sustain by the death of two of he chief warrior on which account he be constrain to defer the siege to a more convenient opportunity and must now dismiss he army on this the stranger salute the king very respectfully and embark in they ship return to they own country -lrb- 1 -rrb- hakluyt i 47 chron hierosol the expedition of william longespee or long-sword earl of salisbury in the year 1248 under the banner of st loui king of france against the saracen _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- when loui king of france go against the saracen in 1248 william earl of salisbury with the bishop of worcester and other great man of the realm of england accompany he in the holy warfare -lrb- 2 -rrb- about the beginning of October 1249 the french king assault and take the city of damietta which be esteem the principal strong-hold of the saracen in egypt and have provide the place with a sufficient garrison under the duke of burgundy he remove he camp to penetrate farther eastward in this army william earl of salisbury serve with a choose band of englishman under he especial command but the french entertain a great dislike to he and he people whom they flout upon all occasion call they english _ tail _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- and other opprobrious name insomuch that the king of france have much ado to keep peace between they this quarrel originate from the follow circumstance : not far from alexandrium there be a strong castle belong to the saracen -lrb- 4 -rrb- in which they have place some of they principal lady and much treasure which fortress the earl and he english follower have the good fortune to take more by dexterous policy than by open force of arm through which capture he and he people be much enriched and when the french come to the knowledge of this exploit which have not be previously communicate to they they be much enrage against the english and could never speak well of they afterwards not long after this the earl get secret intelligence of a rich caravan of merchant belong to the saracen who be travel to a certain fair which be to be hold near alexandrium with a multitude of camel ass and mule and many cart all richly laden with silk precious jewel spice gold silver and other commodity besides provision and other matter of which the soldier be then in great want without give notice of this to the rest of the christian army the earl gather all the english troops and fall by night upon the caravan kill many of the people and make himself master of the whole cart and baggage cattle with they driver which he bring with he to the christian camp lose only one soldier in the skirmish and eight of he servant some of whom be only wound and bring home to be cure when this be know in the camp the frenchman who have loiter in they tent while the earl and he people be engage in the expedition come forth and forcibly take to themselves the whole of this spoil finding great fault with the earl and the english for leave the camp without order from the general contrary to the discipline of war though the earl insist that he have do nothing but what he would readily justify and that he intention be to have divide the spoil among the whole army but this being of no avail and very much displeased at be deprive in so cowardly a manner of what he have so adventurously gain he make he complaint to the king and be successfully oppose there by the pride of the count of artoi the king brother who thwart he claim with disdainful spite he declare that he would serve no longer in they army and bidding farewell to the king he and he people break up from the army and march for achon -lrb- 5 -rrb- upon they departure the count d'artoi say that the french army be well rid of these tail english which word speak in despite be ill take by many good man even of they own army but not long after when the governor of cairo who be offend with the soldan offer to deliver that place to the french king and even give he instruction now he might best conduct himself to accomplish that enterprize the king send a message in all haste to the earl of salisbury request he to return to the army under promise of redress all he grievance on which he come back and rejoin the french army the king of france now march towards cairo and come to the great river nile on the other side of which the soldan have encamp with he army on purpose to dispute the passage at this time there be a saracen in the service of the count of artoi who have be lately convert to the christian faith and who offer to point out a shallow ford in the river by which the army might easily cross over upon receive this intelligence artoi and the master of the knight templar with about a third of the army cross to the other side and be follow by salisbury and the english these be all join make a assault upon a part of the saracen army which remain in the camp and overthrow they the soldan be then at some distance with the greater part of he army after this easy victory artoi be so puff up with pride and elate by success that he believe nothing could withstand he and would need advance without wait for the come up of the main body of the army under the king of france vainly believe that he be able with the power he have to conquer the whole force of the saracen the master of the templar and other experienced officer endeavor to dissuade he from this rash conduct advise he rather to return to the main army satisfy with the signal advantage he have already achieve that thereby the whole army of the christian might act in concert and be the better able to guard against the danger of any ambush or other stratagem of war that might have be devise for they destruction they represent to he that the horse of this vanguard be already tired and the troops without food and besides that they number be utterly unable to withstand the vastly superior multitude of the enemy who besides have now obviously to fight for they last stake the capital of they dominion might be expect to exert they utmost effort to this salutary counsel the proud earl arrogantly answer with opprobrious taunt revile the whole templar as dastardly coward and betrayer of they country and even allege that the holy land of the cross might easily be win to christendom if it be not for the rebellious spirit of the templar and hospitaller and they follower : which indeed be a common belief among many to these contumelious remark the master of the templar angrily desire he in he own name and that of he follower to display he ensign when and where he dare and he should find they as ready to follow as he to lead the earl of salisbury now remonstrate with artoi advise he to listen to these experienced person who be much better acquaint with the country and people than he could be and endeavor to convince he that they advice be discreet and worthy to be follow he then address he discourse to the master of the templar prudently endeavor to sooth he anger against the arrogance of the count of artoi but artoi cut he short exclaim in anger with many oath away with these cowardly englishman with tail the army would be much better rid of these tail people and many other scandalous and disdainful expression to this the english earl reply well earl robert wherever you dare set you foot my step shall go as far as yours and i believe we shall go this day where you shall not dare to come near the tail of we horse and it so happen as earl william say : for earl robert of artoi persist to march forward against the soldan vainly hope to win all the glory to himself before the come up of the main body of the host he first enterprize be order a attack on a small castle or fortify village call mansor whence a number of the villager run out on see the approach of the christian make a great outcry which come to the ear of the soldan who be much nearer with he army than have be suppose in the mean time the christian make a assault on mansor with too little precaution and be repulse with considerable loss many of they be slay by large stone throw upon they as they enter the place by which the army not only lose a considerable number of man but be much dispirited by this unexpected repulse immediately on the back of this discomfiture the soldan come in sight with he whole army and see the christian in this divided state brother separate from brother joyfully seize the opportunity he have long wish for and inclose they on all side that none might escape attack they with great fury in this situation the earl of artoi sore repent of he headstrong rashness when it be too late and see earl william longespee fighting bravely against the chief brunt of the enemy he call out to he in a cowardly manner to flee as god fight against they but william bravely answer god forbid that my father 's son should flee from the face of a saracen earl robert turn out of the fight and flee away think to escape from death or captivity by the swiftness of he horse and take the river thafni -lrb- 6 -rrb- sink through the weight of he armor and be drown on the flight of earl robert the french troops lose heart and begin to give ground : but william longespee bear up manfully against the whole force of the enemy stand firm as long as he be able slaying and wound many of the saracen at length he horse be kill and he leg maim he fall to the ground yet he continue to mangle they leg and foot till at last he be slay with many wound be finally stone to death by the saracen after he death the saracen set upon the remainder of the army which they have surround on every side and destroy they all so that scarce a single man remain alive of the whole only two templar one hospitaller and one common soldier escape to bring the melancholy tiding to the king of france thus by the imprudent and foolish rashness of earl robert the french troops be utterly discomfited and the valiant english knight overpower and slay to the grief of all the christian and the glory of the saracen and as it afterwards fall out to the entire ruin of the whole french army they way to mansor -- e \* \* \* \* \* chap xxi _ discovery of madeira _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- although the era of modern discovery certainly commence under the auspicious direction of don henry of portugal who first conceive and execute the sublime idea of extend the knowledge and commerce of the globe by a judicious series of maritime expedition expressly for the purpose of discovery yet as madeira be say to have be visit and the canary be actually discover and settle before that era it appear necessary to give a previous account of these discovery before proceed to the second part of this work several author have leave account of the real or pretended original discovery of this island of madeira all of whom concur in assert that it be first discover by a englishman juan de barro the livy of portugal mention it briefly in the first decade of he asia the history of this discovery be write in latin by doctor manoel clemente and dedicate to pope clement v manoel tome compose a latin poem on the subject which he intitle _ insulana _ antonio galvano mention it in a treatise of discovery make chiefly by the spaniard and portuguese previously to the year 1550 -lrb- 2 -rrb- manoel de faria y sousa the illustrious commentator of camoen cite galvano in illustration of the fifth stanza in the fifth book of the immortal lusiad and likewise give a account of this discovery in he portuguese asia but the earliest and most complete relation of this discovery be compose by francisco alcaforado who be esquire to don henry the _ infant _ or prince of portugal the first great promoter of maritime discovery and to whom he present he work no person be more capable of give a exact account of that singular event than alcaforado as he be one of those who assist in make the second discovery he work be first publish in portuguese by don francisco manoel and be afterwards publish in french at paris in 1671 -lrb- 3 -rrb- from this french edition the follow account be extract because the original portuguese have not come to we knowledge neither can we say when that be print but as the anonymous french translator remark that don francisco _ keep _ the original m with great care it may be conclude that the portuguese impression do not long precede the french translation the french translator acknowledge that he have alter the style which be extremely florid and poetical and have expunge several useless and tedious digression etymology reflection and comparison but declare that he have strictly present the truth and substance of the history so as not to vary from it in the least or to omit the smallest material circumstance it be remarkable that there be no mention whatever in any of the english history of machin macham or marcham the suppose author of this discovery so that hakluyt be beholden to antonio galvano for the imperfect account he give of that transaction -lrb- 4 -rrb- by the follow abstract the complete history become we own and we shall be no longer stranger to a event which have for several age render a englishman famous in foreign country while wholly unknown in he own it must not however be omit to observe that some objection may be state against the authenticity of this history on account of certain circumstance which do not quadrate with the time assign for machin 's voyage by the author from these it be obvious either that the relation give by alcaforado be not genuine or that it have be interpolate how far this objection may be admit without prejudice to the authority of the whole story must be leave to the judgment of we reader we shall only add that so far as relate to macham it agree with the tradition of the inhabitant of madeira accord to alcaforada juan gonsalvo zarco a gentleman of the household of don henry be send out by that prince upon a expedition of discovery to the coast of africa make prize in the year 1420 of a spanish vessel fill with redeem captive on they way from morocco to spain in this vessel there be one john de morale a experienced and able pilot whom he detain as a acceptable present to he master don henry and set all the rest at liberty morale on be make acquaint with the cause of he detention enter freely into the service of the prince and give a account to gonsalvo of the adventure of machin and the situation and land-mark of the new discover island all of which he have learn from certain english captive in the jail of morocco who have accompany macham or machin in he expedition the year of this extraordinary adventure be not mention by galvano who only say that in 1344 pedro iv reign in arragon the chronicle of he age report that about this time the island of madeira be discover by one macham a englishman it must be confess that a objection arise against this history which be not easily remove we be tell that immediately after the death of macham he companion sail over to morocco and that morale be in prison when they arrive suppose the discovery by macham to have be make about 1344 as relate by galvano from the castilian chronicle morale must have be no less than seventy-six year a prisoner when redeem and when he be detain by gonsalvo in 1420 herbert place the adventure of macham in 1328 which would increase the captivity of morale to ninety-two year alcaforado place the event in the reign of edward iii of england which begin in 1327 and end in 1378 even suppose it to have happen in the last year of edward morale must have remain forty-two year in captivity which be not only highly improbable but be even contrary to the sense of the historian who suppose but a small space to have elapse between the two event besides the record quote by galvano be say expressly to assert that macham go himself into africa whence he be send to the king of castile this last circumstance may have be invent by the spaniard to give they a better title to the island of madeira : but the former objection remain in full force and can only be obviate by suppose that either morale advance a falsehood in assert that he have the account of this discovery from the english themselves instead of learn it from the other slave among whom the tradition might have be current for many year after the event or alcaforado may have mistake the report of morale in this particular the follow be the substance of the narrative as give by alcaforado in the glorious reign of edward iii robert a machin of macham a gentleman of the second degree of nobility whose genius be only equal by he gallantry and courage beheld and love the beautiful anna d'arfet -lrb- 5 -rrb- they attachment be mutual but the please indulgence of ardent hope gratify and betray the secret of they passion the pride of the illustrious family of d'arfet be insensible to the happiness of they daughter and they prefer the indulgence of they own ambition to the voice of love the feudal tyranny of the age be friendly to they cruelty and a royal warrant seem to justify the vanity of she parent the consolation of a ingenious mind support machin under confinement and enable he to seek after redress without yield to despondency on he releasement from prison he learn that the beloved cause of he persecution have be force to marry a nobleman whose name he could not discover but who have carry she to he castle near bristol the friend of machin make he misfortune they own and one of they have the address to get introduce into the service of the afflict anna under the character of a groom the prospect of the ocean during they ride suggest or mature the plan of escape and the hope of a secure asylum counteract the imagine danger of a passage to the coast of france under pretence of derive benefit from the sea air the victim of parental ambition be enable to elude suspicion and embark without delay in a vessel procure for the purpose along with she lover in the successful completion of this anxious design machin be alike insensible to the unfavourable season of the year and to the portentous sign of a approach storm which in a calmer moment he would have duly observe the gradual rising of a gale of wind render the astonished fugitive sensible of they rashness and as the tempest continue to augment the thick darkness of night complete the horror of they situation in they confusion the intended port be miss or could not be attain and they vessel drive at the mercy of the wind and wave in the morning they find themselves in the midst of a unknown ocean without skill to determine they situation and destitute of knowledge or experience to direct they course towards any known land at length after twelve anxious morning have dawn without sight of land with the earliest streak of day a object dimly appear to they eager watchfulness in the distant horizon and when the gray haze which have alternately fill they with hope and despondency be dissipate by the rise sun the certainty of have discover land be welcome by a general burst of joy a great luxuriancy of tree of unknown species be soon observe to overspread the land whence unknown bird of beautiful plumage come off in flock to the vessel and give the appearance of a please dream to they unexpected deliverance -lrb- illustration : chart of north western africa -rrb- the boat be hoist out to examine the new find island and return with a favourable account machin and he friend accompany they tremble charge on shore leave the mariner to secure the vessel at a anchor the wilderness and rich scenery of the adjacent country possess great charm to these thankful guest just escape from apparently inevitable destruction a opening in the extensive wood which be encircle with laurel and other flowering shrub present a delightful retreat to the tempest-worn voyager a venerable tree of ancient growth offer its welcome shade on a adjoining eminence and the first moment of liberty be employ in form a romantic residence with the abundant material which nature supply all around the novelty of every object they behold induce curiosity to explore they new discovery and they spend three day in wander about the wood when the survey be interrupt by a alarming hurricane which come on during the night and render they extremely anxious for the safety of they companion who have be leave in charge of the vessel the ensue morning destroy all prospect of be ever enable to get away from the island the vessel have break from she mooring by the violence of the storm and be wreck on the coast of morocco where all on board be immediately seize as slave the afflict machin find this last calamity too severe for he terrify and afflict companion to endure she susceptible mind and tender frame overcome by the severity of the scene she have go through and oppress by consciousness of have deviate from she duty sink under she afflictive situation from the moment it be report that the vessel have disappear she become dumb with sorrow and expire after a few day of silent despair this heavy stroke be too much for the inconsolable lover to support though watch over with the utmost solicitude by he afflict friend all attempt to administer consolation be entirely fruitless and he expire on the fifth day after the death of he beloved mistress with he parting breath he earnestly enjoin he survive companion to deposit he body in the same grave under the venerable tree which they have so recently make for the victim of he temerity and where the altar which have be raise to celebrate they deliverance would now mark they untimely tomb have perform this painful duty the survive companion of these unfortunate lover fix a large wooden cross over the grave on which they carve the inscription which machin have compose to record they melancholy adventure and add a request that if any christian should hereafter visit the spot they might erect a church in the same place and dedicate it to christ have thus accomplish the dictate of friendship and humanity the survivor fit out the boat which have remain ashore from they first landing and put to sea with the intention of return if possible to england but either from want of skill or owe to the current and unfavourable wind they likewise be drive on the coast of morocco and rejoin they former shipmate in slavery among the moor this story be report in a somewhat different manner by galvano already mention accord to he one macham a englishman flee from he country about the year 1344 with a woman of whom he be enamoured meaning to retire into spain but the vessel in which the lover be embark be drive by a storm to the island of madeira then altogether unknown and uninhabited the port in which macham take shelter be still call machico he mistress be sea-sick macham land with she and some of the people and the ship put to sea desert they oppressed with sickness and grief at see herself in this hopeless state of exile the lady die and macham who be extremely fond of she construct a chapel or hermitage dedicate to jesus the savior in which he deposit she remains and engrave both they name and the cause of they arrival on a rude monument which he erect to she memory he afterwards construct a boat or canoe which he hollow out from the trunk of a large tree in which he and those of he companion who have be leave on shore along with he pass over to the opposite coast of africa without the aid of oar sail or rudder he be make prisoner by the moor who present he to they king by whom he be send to the king of castile madeira in the portuguese language or madera in spanish signify _ wood _ and this island derive its name from the immense quantity of thick and tall tree with which it be cover when first discover one of the two capitania or province into which this island be divide be name machico as be likewise the principal town of that district suppose to have originate from the traditionary story of the misfortune of macham the other capitanium with its principal \* \* chap xxi _ account of the discovery and conquest of the canary island _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- the island of nivarium and other mention by pliny as know to juba king of mauritanium be most probably teneriffe and the other canary island for pliny notice that the summit of nivarium be generally cover with snow which be frequently the case with the peak of teneriffe and from this circumstance the name of nivarium be obviously derive they appear likewise to have be know in the middle age to the arab of morocco as the nubian geographer mention two island under the name of mastahan and laco as among the six fortunate island describe by ptolemy these probably be lancerota and fuertaventura the latter of which may be see in clear weather from the nearest coast of africa all knowledge however of these island have cease in europe till some time between the year 1326 and 1334 when a french ship happen to be drive among they by a storm upon this discovery don luis de la cerda count of claramonte whose father don alonzo have be deprive of he right to the inheritance of the crown of castile procure a grant of these island with the title of king from pope clement vi on condition of cause the gospel to be preach to the native -lrb- 2 -rrb- don lui equip a fleet from some of the port of the spanish kingdom of arragon in order to take possession of he new kingdom but the design fail and he die soon after in 1385 some biscayner and inhabitant of seville join in the equipment of five ship at cadiz in order to make descent for the sake of plunder upon the canary island and the adjacent coast of africa after coast along the african shore they sail westwards and fall in with the island now call lancerota where they land and after a skirmish with the native plunder the town front which they carry off a large booty of goat-skin tallow and sheep and 170 of the inhabitant whom they sell into slavery among these be guanareme king of the island and he wife tingua-faya a similar expedition in quest of plunder and captive be make to lancerota from seville in 1393 in the year 1400 john de betancor a gentleman of normandy and gadifer de sala a person of considerable fortune fit out three small vessel from rochelle in france contain 200 person exclusive of the mariner and make a descent upon lancerota where they erect a fort at a harbor to which they give the name of rubicon leave there a small garrison they pass over to the island of fuertaventura but be oppose by the native they prudently retire without fight betancor afterwards apply to don henry iii king of arragon for assistance to enable he to make a conquest of these island who make he a grant of they in due form with the title of king and supply he with money to defray the expence of a armament to accomplish they subjugation he easily effect the conquest of lancerota and divide its land among the french and spanish adventurer who have assist he in the expedition after the death of john de betancor he nephew mason de betancor sell the canary island to don henry de guzman count of nieblum who afterwards convey they to guillen paraza and from whom they fall by inheritance to diego de herrera who die in 1485 in 1487 the sovereignty be resume by the crown of castile with the title of a kingdom -lrb- 3 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- gla disc and conqu passim -lrb- 2 -rrb- the author of the in 1412 to that of george iii in 1760 chap i _ summary deduction of the discovery of the world from they first original to the year 1555 by antonio galvano _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction this treatise be write in the portuguese language by antonio galvano who have be governor of ternate the chief of the molucca island and be first translate into english by the celebrated richard hakluyt who dedicate it to sir robert cecil principal secretary of state to queen elizabeth it be afterwards insert in osborne or the oxford collection of voyage and travels and form a appendix to the first volume of clarke 's progress of maritime discovery and from these source the present edition have be carefully prepare of richard hakluyt the original translator the follow notice be worthy of be preserve the _ great _ richard hakluyt be descend from a ancient family at yetton in herefordshire and be educate at westminster school from whence he be elect a student of christ church in the university of oxford where he take the degree of bachelor and master of art enter into holy order he be first make a prebendary of bristol and afterwards of westminster and rector of witheringset in suffolk besides this translation he illustrate the eight decade of peter martyr angelericus _ de novo orbe _ with curious note he also translate from the portuguese _ virginium _ richly value by the description of florida she next neighbor and write note of certain commodity in good request in the east indy molucca and china but what have most deservedly perpetuate he name be he great pain and judgment in collect _ english voyage navigation traffick and discovery _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- both from the nature of this treatise on the origin and progress of maritime discovery and from respect to the memory of hakluyt the father of we english collection of voyage and travel it have be select for insertion in this place as a appropriate introduction to the _ second part _ of we arrangement because its author may be consider as almost a original authority for the early discovery of the portuguese and spaniard although it may be consider in some measure as not precisely conformable with we plan yet one portion of this summary be directly in point and the whole be curious and in no respect tedious it be here give entire change the antiquated english of hakluyt into modern language although say in its title to extend to the year 1555 the chronological series of galvano properly end in 1545 and the only subsequent incident be a very slight notice of the voyage of sir hugh willoughby and richard chancellor towards the white sea in 1553 in the original translation and in the oxford collection this treatise be precede by a dedication from hakluyt to _ sir robert cecil _ and another dedication from the portuguese editor francis de sousa tavare to don john duke of aveira both of which be here omit as have no directly useful tendency except so much of the latter as refer to the history of galvano besides the present discourse galvano compose a history of the molucca island of which he have be governor which work have unfortunately be lose or at least be unknown in this country he be likewise say to have publish at lisbon in 1555 a account of the different route by which the merchandize of indium have be convey into europe at different period antonio galvano the author of the follow summary of the discovery of the world be a portuguese gentleman who be several year governor of the molucca island and perform signal service to he country in that honorable station by dissipate a formidable league which have be enter into by the native prince of these island for the expulsion of the portuguese and though possess very inadequate resource for the protection of so important a commercial establishment he confirm and extend the dominion and influence of portugal in these island when first appoint to the command in the molucca galvano carry with he a private fortune of 10000 crusado all of which he expend in the public service though he add a clear revenue to the crown of 500000 crusado in consequence of he successful vigilant and pure administration he be so zealous in patronize the propagation of the christian religion among the island belong to he government that on he return to lisbon in 1540 he be reduce to such extreme poverty as to be under the necessity of take refuge in the _ hospital _ where he die in 1557 francis de sousa tavare the original portuguese editor of this treatise in a dedication of the work to don john duke of aveira give the follow account of the work and of its author : antonio galvano when on he death-bed leave I this book along with he other papers by he testament and as i be certain he design that it should be present to you highness i have think proper to fulfil he intention in that respect it be fitting that this treatise should be write by a native of portugal as it treat of the various way in which the spicery and other commodity of indium be formerly bring to we part of the world and give a account of all the navigation and discovery of the ancient and modern in both of which thing the portuguese have labor above all other nation in this treatise and in nine or ten other book concern indium and the molucca this true portuguese describe the unfortunate and sorrowful time before we day in which he have be engage when he be appoint to the command of the island and fortress of the molucca all the king and chief of these island have agree to make war against we nation and to drive they out of the country yet he fight against they all in tidore though he have only 130 portuguese soldier against they whole united power and give they a signal overthrow in which they king and one ternate the principal author of the war be both slay besides which he conquer they fortress and compel they all to submit to the obedience and service of we sovereign in this war two great and wonderful event take place : the _ first _ that all the chief and king of these island unite against we who use ever to be at variance among themselves and _ secondly _ that galvano with only the ordinary garrison should obtain the victory against so great a combination it have happen to other governor of the molucca with a extraordinary number of european troops and assist by all the other native lord to go to war with one king only and to come back with loss whereas he with a small and inadequate force successfully wage war against a confederacy of all the lord of these island three brilliant exploit have be perform in indium beyond all other the capture of muar by emanuel falcon the winning of bitam by peter mascarena and this victory obtain by galvano besides this great exploit he father and four brother be all slay in the king service and he be the last of he lineage carry with he about 10000 crusado into the molucca all of which he expend in propagate we holy faith and in preserve these valuable island use all he power and influence to bring all the clove into the king coffer by which he add 500000 crusado yearly to the royal revenue have he gather clove on he own account as other governor of the molucca have do he might have come home very rich but return poor and in the simplicity of he nature expect to be reward for he honest service he be entirely neglect and have to take refuge in a hospital where he remain seventeen year till he death when he be 2000 crusado in debt partly for demand upon he from indium and partly borrow from he friend to maintain he in the hospital after he death the cardinal desire I to give he other writings to damien de go promise to content I for they which otherwise i should not have do yet hitherto i have not receive any thing with which to execute he will yet for all this as in the prosperity of he victory he make no boast so in he adversity he always preserve a unabated spirit you grace therefore may perceive that this treatise and he other work be write under great affliction yet be he not willing to use the remedy of zelim the son of the great turk mahomet who take constantinople and die in rome who use to make himself drunk that he might forget the high estate from which he have fall neither would he follow the council of many of he friend in withdraw from the kingdom say he have rather resemble timocle the athenian than the roman coriolanus for all which this treatise ought to receive favor from you grace allow for any oversight of the author if there be any such as i be unfit to detect or correct then god prosper you grace with long life and increase of honor -lrb- 1 -rrb- oxford collection ii 353 clarke progr of marit disc i app 1 -lrb- 2 -rrb- oxford collection i viii section i _ epitome of the ancient and modern discovery of the world chiefly by means of navigation from the flood to the close of the fifteenth century _ when i first desire to compose a account of the ancient and modern discovery by sea and land with they true date and situation these two principal circumstance seem involve in such difficulty and confusion that i have almost desist from the attempt even in regard to the date of the flood the hebrew reckon that event to have happen 1656 year after the creation : while the seventy interpreter make it 2242 and st augustine extend the time to 2262 year -lrb- 1 -rrb- in regard to geographical situation likewise there be many difference for there never sail ten or a hundred pilot in one fleet but they make they reckoning in almost as many different longitude but consider that all these difficulty might be surmount by just comparison and the exercise of judgment i at length resolve to persist in my undertake some allege that the world be fully know in ancient time for as it be people and inhabit it must have be navigable and frequented and because the ancient people be of longer life and have all one law and one language they could not fail to be acquaint with the whole world other again believe that though the world might be once universally know by mankind yet by the wickedness of man and the want of justice among nation that knowledge have be lose but as all the most important discovery have be make by sea and that chiefly in we own time it be desirable to learn who be the first discoverer since the flood some allege the greek other the phenician while other say the egyptian the inhabitant of indium on the contrary pretend that they be the first navigator particularly the tabenco whom we now call chinese and allege in proof of this that they be lord of all the indy even to cape bona speranca and the island of st lawrence -lrb- 2 -rrb- which be inhabit by they as likewise all the coast of the indian sea also the java timore celebe macassar the molucca borneo mindanao luones lequeo the japan and many other island also the country of cochin-china lao brama -lrb- 3 -rrb- pegu arracone -lrb- 4 -rrb- till you come quite to bengalum besides all these new spain peru brazil the antille and all the adjoining land be possess by the same race as appear by the fashion and manners both of the man and woman who have small eye flat nose with other proportion resemble the chinese and to this day many of these island and country be call by such name as bato-china bocho-china and the like indicate the country of or belong to china it farther appear that the ark of noah rest upon the north part of the mountain of armenia in 40 degree of latitude or upward and that scythium be a high land and the first that appear out of the universal deluge be first peopled and as the province or country of the tabenco or chinese be one of the chiefest of all tartary its inhabitant may be consider as the most ancient nation and the oldest navigator they sea be calm and as lie between the tropics they day and night be nearly equal and they season differ little in temperature and as no outrageous wind swell they sea into storm navigation among they be safe and easy they small bark call catamoran have only a large bough of a tree set up in the middle serve as mast and sail the master steer only with a oar and the passenger sit on pole fasten to the bark it be say that the people of china be anciently lord of almost all scythium and be in use to sail along that coast which reach from east to west in seventy degree of north latitude cornelius nepo say that in the time when metellus the colleague of afranius be proconsul of gaul the king of the suevus send to he certain indian who come to he country in a ship by the north and the flat of germany -lrb- 5 -rrb- these people probably come from china as in that country in the latitudes of 20 30 and 40 degree they have strong and well-fastened ship which can bear the sea and encounter the severity of the northern climate cambaium also have ship and its inhabitant be say to have long use the sea but it be not likely they should have go to gaul for they only trade to cairo and be indeed a people of little trade and less clothing those who escape from the flood keep the hill not daring for a long time to descend into the plain and low country and nimrod a hundred and thirty year afterwards build the tower of babel intend it as a refuge in case of any future deluge -lrb- 6 -rrb- upon the whole it seem probable that the inhabitant of china and the east be the first sailor though other think the inhabitant of the west particularly of syrium be the first to use the sea -lrb- 7 -rrb- this contest about the antiquity of navigation i leave to the scythian and egyptian who each challenge the honor to themselves but leave all contest point in this matter i now apply to my propose deduction rest only upon what have be record in authentic history ancient history say that tubal in the hundred and forty-third year after the flood come by sea into spain -lrb- 8 -rrb- whence it appear that in these early time navigation be usual from ethiopium to we part of western europe it be also say that semiramis invade the country on the river indus whence the indian derive they name and give battle to king stabrobate in which he lose a thousand ship -lrb- 9 -rrb- by which it clearly appear there be then many ship in those part and that the sea be much frequent in the six hundred and fiftieth year after the flood there be a king in spain name hesperus -lrb- 10 -rrb- and gonsalvo fernandez de oviedo the chronicler of antiquity -lrb- 11 -rrb- affirm that he make discovery by sea as far as cape verde and the isle of st thoma of which he be prince and that in he time the island of the west indy be discover and call the hesperide after he name he allege many reason in proof of this assertion and even say particularly that these early navigator sail in forty day from cape verde to these island other say that the island of st thoma and de principe be the hesperide and not the antille which be the more probable as these ancient navigator only sail along the coast not daring to pass through the main ocean have no compass nor any means of take altitude for they guidance it be not to be deny that many country island cape isthmus and point the name of which be find in history be now unknown because in course of age the force of the water have waste and consume they and have separate country from each other formerly join both in europe asia africa new spain peru and other place in he dialogue call timaeus plato say there be anciently a great country and large island in the atlantic name atlantide greater than europe and africa and that the king of these part be lord of a great part of spain but that by the force of great tempest the sea have overflow the country leave nothing but bank of mud and gravel so that no ship could pass that way for long after it be also record by pliny -lrb- 12 -rrb- that close by the island of cadiz there be a well inhabit island call aphrodisia towards the strait of gibraltar abound in garden and orchard but we have now no knowledge of this island except from the bare mention of it in ancient author the isle of cadiz be say to have be anciently so large as to join the continent of spain the aores be hold to have be a continuation of the mountain of estrellum which join the sea coast beside the town of cintra and the sierra verde or green-mountain which reach the coast near the city of _ sasin _ in the land of _ cucu _ or the island of moudim in which algarbe be situate be suppose to have reach to porto santo and madeira for it be consider as a indubitable fact that all island derive they root from the firm land or continent however distant as otherwise they could not stand firm other author say that from spain to ceuta in barbary people sometimes travel on foot on dry land that the island of corsica and sardinium be once join that sicily be unite with italy and the negropont with greece -lrb- 13 -rrb- we read also of the hull of ship iron anchor and other remnant of shipping have be find on the mountain of susa far inland where there be now no appearance of the sea have ever be many writer affirm that in indium and malabar which now abound in people the sea once reach the foot of the mountain and that cape comorin and the island of ceylon be once unite also that sumatra once join with malacca by the shoal of caypasium and not far from thence there be a small island which only a few year ago be join to the opposite coast ptolemy advance the point of malacca three or four degree to the south of the line whereas its most southerly point now call jentana be in one degree of north latitude by which people pass daily the strait of cincapura to the coast of siam and china and the island of aynan be say to have formerly join the land of china the southern extremity of which ptolomey place far to the south of the line though it now only reach to twentieth degree of north latitude it may even have be that malacca and china as ptolemy set forth extend beyond the line to the south as malacca might join with the land call jentana and the island of bintam banca and salistre and the land might be all slime and ouze likewise china might be unite with the luones borneo lequeuo mindanao and other some be of opinion that sumatra join with java across what be now the strait of sunda and that java also join with the island of balus anjave cambava solor hogalcao maulva vintara rosalaguin and other in that range all of which be so near as to appear continuous when see from a small distance and they still be so near together that in pass through the channel which divide they the bough of the tree on each side may be touch by the hand it be not long since several of the island of banda in the east be drown by the sea overflow they and in china about 180 mile of firm land be say to have become a lake all these thing be to be consider as come within the limit of probability especially when we take into account what have be relate of similar event by ptolemy and other but which i here omit to return to my subject about 800 year after the deluge the city of troy be build by the dardanian and even before that time spice drug and many other kind of merchandize which be then more abundant than now be bring from indium to europe by the red sea hence if credit can be give to these account we may conclude that the sea of old be much frequent those of the east bring they commodity to the haven of arsinoe in the arabian gulf now call suez -lrb- 14 -rrb- in lat 30  n and at the northern extremity of the arabian gulf from whence the goods be carry by caravan upon camel ass and mule to cassou a city on the coast of the levant sea in lat 32  n allow seventeen league and a half to every degree of latitude these two city be say to have be 35 league or 105 -lrb- 15 -rrb- mile distant from each other on account of the heat these caravan or great company of carrier travel only in the night direct themselves by the star and by land-mark fix in the ground for that purpose but find this journey attend with many inconveniency the course be twice alter in search of a more commodious route -lrb- 16 -rrb- about nine hundred year after the flood and previous to the destruction of troy egypt be rule by a king name sesostri who cause a canal to be cut from the red sea to that arm of the nile which flow past the city of heroum that ship might pass and repass between indium and europe to avoid the expence and trouble of carry merchandize by land across the isthmus of suez and sesostri have large carak or ship build for this purpose -lrb- 17 -rrb- this enterprize however do not completely succeed for if it have africa would have be convert into a island as there be even now only twenty league or sixty mile of land between the red sea and the mediterranean about this time the grecian gather a fleet and army call the argonautic expedition under the command of jason and alceus -lrb- 18 -rrb- some say they sail from crete and other from greece but they pass through the proponti and the _ sleeve _ of st george into the euxine where some of the vessel perish and jason return back to greece alceus report that he be drive by a tempest to the palus maeoti where he be desert by all he company and those who escape have to travel by land to the german ocean where they procure shipping and sailing past the coast of saxony friesland holland flander france spain and italy return to the peloponnesus and greece after discover a great portion of the coast of europe strabo on the authority of aristonicus the grammarian say that king menelaus after the destruction of troy sail from the grecian sea to the atlantic coast along africa and guinea double the cape bona sperana and arrive in indium -lrb- 19 -rrb- concern which voyage many other particulars might be collect from the writings of the ancient this mediterranean sea be sometimes call the adriatic the aegean and the herculean sea and have other name accord to the land coast and island which it skirt till run through the strait of hercule between spain and africa it communicate with the great atlantic ocean thirteen hundred year after the flood solomon cause a navy to be construct at ezion-geber on the red sea which sail to tharsis and ophir which some believe to have be island in the east indy this fleet be three year on its voyage and on its return bring gold silver cypress-wood and other commodity -lrb- 20 -rrb- the island to which the navy of solomon trade be probably those we now call the luones the lequeo and -lrb- 21 -rrb- this they accomplish and sail along the coast of melinda quiloa and sofalum till they reach the cape of good hope which they double and continue they course to the north they sail along the coast of guinea all the way to the mediterranean and return to egypt after two year absence be the first who have circumnavigate africa in the year 590 before the incarnation a fleet belong to carthaginian merchant sail from cadiz through the ocean to the west in search of land -lrb- 22 -rrb- they proceed so far that they come to the island now call the antille and to new spain -lrb- 23 -rrb- this be give on the authority of gonzalo fernandez de oviedo in he general history who say that these country be then discover and that christopher columbus by he voyage in after time only acquire more exact knowledge of they and have leave we a more precise notice of they situation and of the way to they but all those historian who formerly write concern the antille as of doubtful and uncertain existence now plainly allow they to be the same with new spain and the west indy in the year 520 before christ cambys king of persium conquer egypt and be succeed by darius the son of hystaspe this latter prince determine upon complete the project of sesostri and necho by digging a canal between the red sea and the nile : but be assure that the red sea be higher than the nile and that its salt water would overflow and ruin the whole land of egypt he abandon he purpose lest that fine province should be destroy by famine and the want of fresh water -lrb- 24 -rrb- for the fresh water of the nile overflow the whole country and the inhabitant have no other water to drink it may not be too great a digression from the subject to say a few word concern egypt the native allege that they have in they country certain animal of which one half of they body seem earth and the other like rat one species of which keep continually in the water while another species live on the land in my opinion it be these animal which break the serpent egg of which there be many in the nile but which serpent be also call crocodile it be say that in ancient time these animal be inchant so that they could not do harm to any one : but since they have be free from the power of inchantment by the art and learning of the egyptian decay they have do much hurt by kill people wild beast and cattle more especially those which live in the water and come often on land those that live continually on the land become strongly venomous -lrb- 25 -rrb- the people beyond the city of cairo use to catch these animal and even to eat they set up they head on the wall of the city concern these crocodile it be related -lrb- 26 -rrb- that they often lie along the shore of the river with they mouth wide open on which occasion certain white bird little larger than we thrush fly into the mouth of the crocodile and pick out the filth from between he tooth to the great delight of the crocodile which however would surely close he mouth and devour the bird have not nature provide the bird with a sharp sting grow from the top of he head which prick the roof of the crocodile mouth and force he to gape so that the bird fly away unhurt in this manner by means of a succession of these bird the crocodile get they tooth cleanse in this same river there be many beast resemble horse and upon the land there be certain bird like we crane which continually make war upon the serpent which come thither out of arabium : which bird and likewise the rat which eat the egg of the crocodile be hold in great reverence and estimation by the egyptian but now to return to my subject of discovery in the year 485 before christ xerx king of persium send he nephew sataspi to discover indium who sail from the mediterranean through the strait of hercule and pass the promontory of africa which we now call the cape of good hope but weary of the length of the voyage he return back again as bartholomew diaz do in we day -lrb- 27 -rrb- in 443 a c hamilco and hanno two carthaginian commander who govern that part of spain now call andalusium sail from thence with two squadron hamilco sailing towards the north discover the coast of spain france england flander and germany and some allege that he sail to gothland and even to thule or iceland stand under the arctic circle in 64 degree north and continue he voyage during two year till he come to that northern island where the day in June continue for twenty-two hour and the night in December be of a similar length on account of which it be there wonderfully cold he brother hanno take he course to the south along the coast of africa and guinea and discover the fortunate island now the canary and the orcade hesperide and gorgade now call the cape de verde island proceed onward hanno double the cape of good hope and go along the eastern coast of africa to another cape call aromaticum now call gardafu and thence to the coast of arabium and be five year employ in this voyage before he return to spain -lrb- 28 -rrb- other allege that hanno proceed no farther than sierra leona which he colonize and afterwards discover as far as the equinoctial line but it would rather appear from the length of time he employ that he must have accomplish the more extended navigation it be report that the inhabitant of the country at the cape of good hope be great witch and by inchantment bring certain serpent so much under command that they preserve they church churchyard garden orchard barn and cattle both from wild beast and thief when these serpent see any person do or intend to do harm they wind themselves in such a manner around they as to make they prisoner and then command they young one to give notice to they master that they may come and secure the thief but if the thief be numerous or the wild beast of too much strength so that the serpent dare not encounter they they go to they master house and if it happen to be in the night they give many stroke with they tail so as to awaken they master that they may provide for they defense -lrb- 29 -rrb- a certain italian name aloisius cadamosta relate that when he be upon the discovery of guinea and reside in the house of bisboral the grandson of king budomel he hear one night when in bed a great noise and many blow give about the house upon which bisboral arise and go out and upon he return cadamosta demand of he where he have be and he answer that he have be with he cobra or snake which call he -lrb- 30 -rrb- in the indy there be many snake and some of they very full of poison yet the indian carry they about they neck and put they in they bosom and under they arm without fear or injury and at certain sound the snake will dance and do many other strange thing at command i be inform by a certain portuguese who have be beyond the cape of good hope towards sofalum quiloa and melinda that there be certain bird in that country which would come to the negro on a call and as the negro move on through the wood the bird would do the same from tree to tree till at length they would alight on a tree whence they would not remove : and on examine that tree the negro be sure to find wax and honey but know not whether it grow there naturally or not -lrb- 31 -rrb- in the same country they find much wax and honey in ant-hole make by the ant but somewhat bitter in the sea of that coast there be certain fish know to the fisherman which commonly swim upright in the water have the face and breast of woman -lrb- 32 -rrb- in the year 355 before christ the spaniard be say to have go by sea to the flat of indium arabium and the adjoining coast to which they carry various merchandize in great ship and sailing to the north - west they come to certain flat which be cover by the tide and leave bare by the ebb where they catch many _ tunny _ of great size which fishing turn out to they great profit as they be very abundant and much esteem -lrb- 33 -rrb- alexander who flourish 324 year before christ travel from europe into asia and africa pass through armenia assyrium persium and bactrium whence he descend by the mountain of imaus and the vally of parapomissus into indium and prepare a navy on the river indus with which he pass into the ocean he there turn by the land of gedrosium caramanium and persium to the great city of babylon leave the command of he fleet to onesicratus and nearchus who sail through the strait of the persian sea and up the river euphrate discover the whole coast between the indus and that river after the death of alexander ptolemy become king of egypt who by some be repute to have be the bastard son of philip the father of alexander : he imitate the before name king sesostri and darius cause dig a canal from the branch of the nile which pass by pelusium now by the city of damieta -lrb- 34 -rrb- this canal of ptolemy be a hundred foot broad and thirty foot deep and extended ten or twelve league in length till it come to the _ bitter well _ he mean to have continue it to the red sea but desist on the idea that the red sea be three cubit higher than the land of egypt and would have overflow all the country to its entire ruin ptolemy philadelphus in the year 277 before christ change the direction of the indian traffic the goods from europe by he order be carry up the nile from alexandrium to the city of coptus and convey across the desert from thence to the sea-port of myos-hormo on the red-sea -lrb- 35 -rrb- to avoid the excessive heat the caravan travel only in the night direct they course by the star and water be very scarce in the desert they have to carry a sufficient quantity with they for the journey afterwards to avoid this trouble deep well be dig at certain interval and in other place large cistern or reservoir be construct for the reception of rain water still later in consideration of the danger attend the port of myos-hormo on account of flat and island philadelphus send a army into troglodytica where he construct a haven call berenice in which the ship engage in the indian commerce take shelter as a place of greater security from thence the goods be transport to the city of coptus and afterwards to alexandrium which become rich and famous through its trade with indium beyond any other city in the world insomuch that it be assert that the custom of alexandrium yield every year to ptolemy aulete the father of cleopatra seven million and a half of gold though the traffic have then scarcely subsist in that direction for twenty year -lrb- 36 -rrb- after the reduction of egypt and alexandrium under the power of the roman the custom be say to have advance to double that amount and the trade be so great that 120 ship use to be send yearly from myos-hormo to india the ship set sail every year from myos-hormo about the middle of July and return back within the year -lrb- 37 -rrb- the merchandize they carry amount to the value of one million two hundred thousand crown and the return be a hundred for one and through this prodigious increase of wealth the matron and noble lady of those day in alexandrium be exceedingly profuse in decorate themselves with purple pearl and precious stone and in the use of musk amber and other rich perfume of various kind of all which the historian and other writer of that age treat at great length -lrb- 38 -rrb- pliny -lrb- 39 -rrb- on the authority of cornelius nepo say that one eudoxus fly from ptolemy lathyrus pass by sea through the gulf of arabium and sailing along the eastern coast of africa double the cape of bona sperana arrive by the atlantic at cadiz and it would appear that this navigation be as often use in those day as it now be caius caesar the son of augustus go into arabium find in the red sea certain piece of the ship which have go thither from spain long after these day it be usual to pass to indium by land this be do by the king of the sogdian the prince of bactrium and other famous captain and many merchant who travel thither and into scythium by land marcus paulus venetus write largely of these country and though he book at first be reckon fabulous yet what he and other have report be now find true by the experience of traveller and merchant who have since be to the same part it be report that the roman send a army by sea to indium against the great khan of cathaium 200 year before the incarnation which pass through the strait of gibraltar and run to the north-west find ten island opposite to cape finisterre produce large quantity of tin which perhaps may have be those afterwards call the cassiteride be come to 50 degree of latitude they find a strait pass to the west through which they arrive in indium and give battle to the king of cathaium after which they return to rome whether this story may appear possible or not true or false i can only say that i give it as i find it write in the history of these time in the year 100 after the incarnation of christ the emperor trajan fit out a fleet on the river tigri and euphrate whence he sail to the island of zyzara and pass the strait of persium enter into the ocean by which he sail along the coast to indium till he come to the place where alexander have be he there take some ship which come from bengal and learn the state of the country from the mariner but be in year and weary of the sea and because he find it difficult to procure necessaries for he army he return back to assyrium -lrb- 40 -rrb- after the roman have subdue most part of the world many notable discovery be make but then come the goth moor and other barbarous nation who destroy all ad 412 the goth take the city of rome thereafter the vandal go out of spain and conquer africa in 450 attilum destroy many city in italy at which time venice begin and in this age the frank and vandal enter into france in 474 the empire of rome be lose and fall from the roman to the goth in 560 the lombard come into italy about this time the sect of the arian prevail greatly and merlin the english prophet flourish in 611 the mahometan sect spring up and the moresco government which invade both africa and spain by this it may appear that all the world be in a state of war and all place so very tumultuous that traffic and merchandize cease no nation daring to trade with another by sea or land nothing remain stedfast neither in kingdom signory religion law art science or navigation even the record and writings of these thing be burnt and destroy by the barbarous power of the goth who propose to themselves to begin a new world and to root out the memory and knowledge of all other nation those who succeed in the government of europe perceive the great loss of the christian world by want of traffic and the stoppage of navigation begin to devise a way of pass into indium quite different from the route of the nile and the red sea and much longer and more costly -lrb- 41 -rrb- the goods of indium be bring up the river indus as far as it be navigable they be then carry by land in caravan through the country of parapomissus into the province of bactrium and ship on the river oxus which fall into the caspian and thence across that sea to the haven of citracan or astracan on the river rha or volga thence up that river and to the city of novogrod in the province of resan which now belong to the great duke of muscovy in lat 54  n the goods be carry thence overland to the province of sarmatium and the river tanai or don which be the division between europe and asia be there load in bark they be carry down the stream of that river into the paulus maeoti to the city of caffa anciently call theodosium which then belong to the genoese who come thither by sea in _ galliass _ or great ship and distribute indian commodity through europe in the reign of commodita emperor of armenia a better course be provide for this traffic : the goods be transport by land from the caspian through the country of hiberium now georgia and thence by the phasis into the euxine and to the city of trebisond they be thence ship for the various part of europe -lrb- 42 -rrb- it be record that demetrius nicanor determine or actually begin to open a canal of above 120 mile in length between the caspian and euxine for the greater convenience of the indian trade but he be slay by ptolemy cerauno and this famous enterprize fall to nothing -lrb- 43 -rrb- all other way be lose by reason of the war of the turk the spicery of the indian island particularly of java sumatra and the city of malacca be carry up the river gange in bengal to the city of agra thence they be carry by land to another city near the indus name boghar where they be discharge because the city of cabor or laor the principal city of the mogore stand too far within the land from thence they be carry to the great city of samarcand in bactrium in which the merchant of indium persium and turkey meet together with they several commodity as cloth of gold velvet camblet scarlet and woollen cloth which be carry to cathay and the great kingdom of china whence they bring back gold silver precious stone pearl silk musk rhubarb and many other thing of great value in after time these merchandize drug and spicery be carry in ship from indium to the strait of ormus and the river euphrate and tigri and be unladen at the city of basora from whence they be carry overland to aleppo damascus and baruttus and there the venetian galliass which transport pilgrim to the holy land come and receive the goods in the year 1153 in the time of the emperor frederick barbarossa it be say there come to the city of lubeck in germany a canoe like a long barge with certain indian who be suppose to have come from the coast of baccalao -lrb- 44 -rrb- which be in the same latitude with lubeck the german greatly wonder to see such a boat and strange people not know whence they come nor be able to understand they language especially as there be then no knowledge of they country although the boat be small in comparison with the sea it have to cross it be yet possible that it might have be convey by the wind and wave for in we day the _ almadia _ of the negro which be very small boat venture to navigate from quiloa mosambique and sofala around the cape of good hope even to the island of st helena a very small spot in the ocean at a great distance from land in the year 1300 after christ the great soldan of cairo restore the trade of spicery drug and merchandize from indium by the red sea at which time they unloaded the goods at the port of judea -lrb- 45 -rrb- and carry they to mecca whence they be distribute by the mahometan pilgrim -lrb- 46 -rrb- so that each prince endeavor to increase the honor and profit of he own country the soldan translate this trade to they own city of cairo whence the goods be carry to the country of egypt lybium africa tuni tremessen fez morocco and suz and some of they be carry beyond the mountain of atla to the city of tombuto and the kingdom of the jalopho till afterwards the portuguese bring the indian trade round the cape of good hope to lisbon as we propose to shew more at large in a convenient place ad 1344 peter iv reign in arragon and the chronicle of he reign report that don lewis de cerda grandson of don john de corda request he aid to go and conquer the canary island which have be gifted to he by pope clement vi a frenchman about this time too the island of madeira be say to have be discover by a englishman name macham who sail from england into spain with a lady whom he love be drive out of he course by a tempest and arrive in a harbor of that island now call machico after he name the lady be oppress with seasickness macham land with she on the island accompany by some of he people but in the mean time the ship weigh anchor and stand to sea leave they behind on this the lady die of grief and macham who be passionately fond of she erect a chapel or hermitage on the island which he name the chapel of jesus and there deposit she remains engrave both they name and the cause of they come to this place on a monumental stone after this he and he companion make a boat or canoe out of a large tree and put to sea without sail or oar get over to the coast of africa the moor among whom he arrive consider they passage as miraculous send he to they king who transmit both he and he company to the king of castile in 1395 while henry iii reign in castile in consequence of information give by macham respect this island many person of france and castile be induce to attempt its discovery and that of the grand canary those who go on this expedition be principally from andalusium biscay and guipuscoa who carry thither many man and horse but i know not whether this be do at they own charge or that of the king but however that might be these people seem to have be the first discoverer of the canary where they take 150 of the islander prisoner there be some difference among author respect the time of this discovery as some affirm that it do not take place till the year 1405 -lrb- 1 -rrb- August de civit dic i 15 c 20 -lrb- 2 -rrb- the cape of good hope and the island of
