-lrb- 105 -rrb- gomar hg iv xiv -lrb- 106 -rrb- probably morty the most north-easterly of the molucca -- e chapter ii the journey of ambrose contarinus ambassador from the republic of venice to uzun-hassan king of persium in the year 1473 4 5 and 6 write by himself introduction this relation of a journey into persium between the year 1473 and 1477 be from a collection of voyage and travels principally in asia make in the _ twelfth thirteenth fourteenth _ and _ fifteenth century _ which be publish at the hague in the french language in 1735 that collection usually go under the name of _ bergeron _ whose name appear on the title somewhat equivocally as the author but who be mention in the advertisement as a writer belong to the middle of the preceding century and the only part of the work that can be attribute to he be a _ treatise of navigation and of the modern voyage of discovery and conquest especially those make by the french & c _ which serve as a introduction to this compilement the editor of this collection give no account of himself or of the source from whence he have derive he different article and only say that the journal of contarinus be translate into french that it might be publish along with the other contents of he volume from the _ bibliotheque universelle des voyage _ by g boucher de la richarderie a new work of great research publish at paris in 1808 we learn that the journal of contarinus be publish in italian at venice in a duodecimo volume in 1543 so far as be know to we it now appear for the first time in a english translation this article might have be more aptly place towards the close of _ first _ part of the present collection but escape notice in proper time and it appear of too much importance both in itself and as a early document to be omit from punctilious attention to rigid systematic arrangement preface of the author the illustrious republic of venice have do I the honor to appoint I ambassador to uzun-hassan king of persium i accept the employment with much pleasure both that i might do acceptable service to my own country and for the general good of christendom i neither consider the difficulty nor the danger of the journey but place my trust solely on the assistance of god prefer the interest of my country and of the christian world to my own ease and safety on purpose to render my discovery useful to the public i have carefully and briefly record every circumstance deserving of attention that occur during my long and laborious journey as relative to the province city and place through which i travel and the manners and custom of the different nation among whom i sojourn in short i have omit nothing deserving of notice that occur during my three year journey have leave venice on the first day of lend in the year 1473 and have return to my beloved country on the 24th of February in the year 1476 -lrb- 1 -rrb- section i _ the ambassador after pass through germany poland russium and the tartarian desert or upper european sarmatium arrive at caffa or theodosium _ i leave venice on the 23d of February in the year 1473 accompany by the venerable priest stephen testa who act as my chaplain and secretary and by demetrius de seze my interpreter together with two servant maffei de bergamo and john ungaretti all of we disguise in ordinary german dress we money be conceal in the clothes of stephen testa we go by water in the first place to the church of _ st michael in murano _ where we hear mass and receive the benediction of the prior after which we mount we horse which be there in wait and reach treviso -lrb- 2 -rrb- the same day i anxiously wish to have procure some person to accompany we on the journey who know the road but could not meet with any nor could i even procure a guide for hire leave treviso on the 24th we arrive that day at cogiensus now call cornegliano -lrb- 3 -rrb- and know the danger and difficulty we must experience during we long journey we here confess and partook of the holy sacrament of the eucharist after which we resume we journey we fortunately overtake a german name sebastian who say he know I and the object of my journey and offer to keep we company to nuremburgh i gladly accept of this person as a companion of we journey inwardly thank god for afford we a guide we continue we journey to the frontier of germany pass through several city and castle belong to different prince and bishop vassal of the empire among which the city of augsburg seem one of the most beautiful not far from that place we german companion sebastian leave we take the road for francfort we part from he with many embrace give he thanks for he numerous attention and mutually wish each other a good journey have procure a new guide we arrive at nuremburg on the 10th of march this be a fine city have a river run through the middle of it and be defend by a excellent citadel while here i inquire of my landlord if there be any traveller go we way he inform I that there be two ambassador from the king of poland then in the city who he be certain would be happy to receive a visit from I i therefore send my chaplain stephen testa to inform these gentleman of my be in nuremburg and of the purpose of my journey and of my desire to pay they a visit they receive my message with much civility and i accordingly go to wait upon they these gentleman be counsellor of state to he polish majesty one of whom be a archbishop and the other a knight name paul after mutual compliment i inform they that i propose pay my respects to they sovereign and be furnish with a passport notwithstanding the sorry equipage in which i travel they receive I with much honor i remain four day in nuremburg during which i form a friendly intimacy with the polish ambassador and then resume my journey in they company be likewise accompany by a ambassador belong to the king of bohemia eldest son of the king of poland depart from nuremburg on the 14th of march now nearly sixty horseman in company we cross through germany always lodge in good city or castle some of which be extremely beautiful both in respect to they situation and the excellence of they fortification but i omit describe they as they be well know to traveller the journey across germany take we twelve day during which we pass through the greater part of the dominion of the maregrave of brandenburg and arrive at the imperial city of francfort a tolerably good and well fortified city on the oder we rest here till the 29th of march as this city be near the confines of poland we have a escort of cavalry belong to the maregrave of brandenburg which accompany we to the frontier these soldier be well mount and arm and march in good order on the last day of march we arrive at miedzyrzyez -lrb- 4 -rrb- which be a small city but strong and pleasant and be the first place on the frontier of poland from that place till we reach _ stragone _ or poznan which take we three day journey we see no place worth notice poznan be particularly remarkable on account of a great fair which be resort to by many merchant leave poznan on the 3d of April we arrive on the 9th at lenczycz -lrb- 5 -rrb- where casimir king of poland then reside in this journey we find neither city nor considerable castle and have much reason to remember germany with regret both on account of bad lodgings and every other circumstance when my arrival be announce to the king he send two of he gentleman to wait upon I who assign I a tolerably commodious lodging next day be easter when no business of any kind be transact i rest after the fatigue of the journey on the follow morning the king send I a robe of black damask accord to the custom of the country that i might go to court which i do accompany by several person of distinction and have the honor to pay my respects to the king accord to the ceremony of that court after which i present the letter of we illustrious republic to he majesty and explain to he the nature of my commission the king be please to invite I to dinner which be serve much in the same manner as with we the dish be in great abundance and well dress as soon as dinner be over i ask permission to retire which be accordingly grant two day afterwards i be again send for to court when the king give orderly answer to all the proposal which i have make in the name of we republic and with so much benevolent attention towards I that i learn by experience that he justly deserve the character of the best king who have reign in poland for a great many year he be please to appoint I two guide one of whom be to accompany I through poland and the other through lower russium to kiow -lrb- 6 -rrb- or magrano which be the key of the kingdom i humbly thank he majesty in the name of the republic and take my leave i leave lenczycz on the 14th of April on my journey through poland which be a flat country ornament with many forest but the great want of convenient lodgings be a sure proof that it be not very fertile nor much abound in the necessaries of life on the 19th i arrive at lublin a tolerable city defend by a citadel the three son of the king reside there at this time for they education the eldest of these prince be about fourteen year of age and the two other considerably younger learning that they wish to see I provide that they father have not forbid i wait upon they and be receive with much politeness the eldest converse with I in the most obliging manner and i observe that they behave with much respect to they preceptor i take my leave of they return thanks for they civility and they part from I with as much courtesy as i have experience in my reception leave lublin and continue we journey through poland we arrive on the 20th of April in lower russium which be subject to the king of poland in this part of we journey we travel five whole day through thick wood and except meeting with a very few castle we lodge for the most part in country house on the 25th we come to a town name _ jusch _ which be defend by a wooden castle we rest here for some time yet not without danger as the inhabitant be quite mad with drunkenness on account of celebrate certain marriage this country produce no wine but the native prepare a liquor from honey which be stronger and more intoxicate even than wine leave this place we come to another village name _ aitomir _ in which likewise there be a wooden castle during the whole of we journey of the 29th we travel through forest in constant danger of robber who infested all the road and we know not where to pass the night or to procure any refreshment insomuch that we have to sleep in the wood keep strict watch lest we might be surprise by the bandit on the 30th of April we reach _ belligraoch _ which signify the _ white _ fort where we be lodge in the royal palace and pass the night with much inconvenience on the first of may we reach the city of _ kiow _ -lrb- 7 -rrb- or magraman the governor of this city which stand beyond the frontier of polish russium be a polander and catholic name _ pamartin _ immediately on learn my arrival from the guide send along with I by the king he appoint I a lodging which be sufficiently small consider the size of the city he here visit I and send I a sufficient supply of provision this city serve as a barrier or frontier garrison against the tartar and be celebrate for a great fair to which the merchant bring rich fur and other goods from upper russium from hence the merchant travel in a large caravan to caffa or theodosium in the crimea but be often surprised and very ill treat by the tartar during they journey the country about kiow abound in grain and cattle the inhabitant of this place occupy the whole day in they affair till three o'clock employ all the rest till night in drinking and quarrel the natural consequence of drunkenness on the day of my arrival governor pamartin send some of he gentleman to invite I to dinner which i accept with as much politeness as i could express he receive I very honourably offer I every service in he power in the most obliging manner say that he be order by the king of poland to treat I in every thing as well as possible on which i thank he for he polite attention and endeavor to recommend myself to he friendship from he i be inform that he be in daily expectation of the arrival of a ambassador from lithuanium go with present to the prince of the tartar who be to have a escort of 200 tartar horse and if i be incline to take advantage of this opportunity by which mean i should travel in much greater safety i have better wait the arrival of this ambassador i accept of this offer most willingly and we then sit down to a magnificent entertainment at which the bishop of kiow who be brother to the governor and many other person of consequence be present we want nothing which could contribute to make the dinner pleasant good company good cheer and music during the repast the only circumstance i do not like be that it last too long as i have more need for sleep and rest after my fatiguing journey than of all the good cheer that could be offer in consequence as soon as dinner be end i take my leave and retire to my lodgings in the city the governor living in the castle which be only of wood the city of kiow stand on the river name anciently boristhene and danambre by the native which we italian call lerissa and which fall into the euxine on the 10th of may -lrb- 8 -rrb- the ambassador of lithuanium arrive and as he be to set out next day after mass i go to pay he my compliment accompany by m pamartin who direct he on the part of the king of poland to take care of I and to conduct I in perfect safety to theodosium to this the ambassador answer that he have every respect for the order of he majesty the sovereign arbiter of he life and death and would carefully obey he order i thank m pamartin for all he kindness as he have frequently visit I and have supply I with every thing i need for subsistence during my stay and as some token of my gratitude i make he a present of a tolerably good german horse which have carry I hitherto we here part with the rest of we horse which be quite unfit for we farther use and procure horse of the country for the remainder of we journey and on parting with the guide who have accompany we to kiow by order of the king i reward they for they attention and good conduct i leave kiow on the 11th of may along with the lithuanian ambassador and as i be unable to travel on horseback on account of pain in my foot i travel in a carriage which have serve I for that purpose ever since i leave the king of poland at lenczycz the first place we come to be _ cerca _ belong to the king of poland where we wait till the 15th for the tartar horse who come to escort we on we journey after they arrival we set out on we journey through the great desert of tartary and come to the boristhene which separate tartary from russium and which be some mile broad -lrb- 9 -rrb- as it be necessary to pass the river we tartar cut down some tree the stem of which they fasten together into a raft which be cover over by the branch and upon which the whole of we baggage be place they fasten they horse by the tail to this raft by which mean it be drag across the river they themselves swim along-side of they horse and hold by they mane we have likewise to swim we horse across in which we succeed by the blessing of god but in much fear and danger at this to we unusual mode of navigation when we get over we have to remain a whole day on the other side to collect and replace we baggage while among the tartar they officer eye I with much attention and suspicion and during we new journey through the desert beyond the river the lithuanian ambassador inform I by means of the interpreter that the tartar officer have come to a resolution to carry I to they prince as they could not allow a person of my appearance to go on to theodosium without he permission i be much alarm by this intelligence believe that i should incur considerable risk of have the purpose of my journey frustrate by this measure and therefore earnestly recommend to the ambassador to keep in mind the order he have receive on the part of the king of poland respect I and the promise he have make to pamartin and i promise to make a present of a sword to the interpreter if he succeed to extricate I from my embarrassment the interpreter report my fear and wish to the ambassador who succeed after drink with the tartar in persuade they that i be of genoa and by means of a present of fifteen ducat he obtain permission for I to go direct for theodosium we journey through the desert continue till the 9th of June during which we suffer many hardship have at one time be a whole day and night without water at length it become necessary for we to part company the lithuanian ambassador and he escort take the direct road to bachiseraus -lrb- 10 -rrb- at which place the prince of the tartar reside on this occasion a tartar be appoint to be we guide to theodosium and we part from the escort not without considerable apprehension of some sudden attack from the tartar yet much satisfied at get rid of that crew for they smell so abominably from feed on horse flesh that it be quite intolerable to come near they we whole company pass the ensue night in cart cover with skin in which we be soon surround by a great number of person inquire who we be on be inform by we tartar guide that i be of genoa they supply we with milk and leave we resume we journey next morning early we arrive that day which be the 16th of June at the suburb of theodosium otherwise call kaffa fill with gratitude for we preservation through so many danger we go privately into a church to give thanks to god for we safe arrival and from thence i send my interpreter to inform the venetian consul of my arrival he immediately send he brother to wait upon I advise I to remain where i be till night when he carry I privately to a house belong to he in the same suburb where i be exceedingly well receive i here find paulus omnibamus who have leave venice three month before I under the order of we illustrious republic -lrb- 1 -rrb- in the latter part of this journey the date of he return to venice be the 10th of at the western extremity of what be poland about sixty-seven mile from poznan it be call messaricie in the original -- e -lrb- 5 -rrb- lausicie in the original -- e -lrb- 6 -rrb- name chio in the original the second name magrano be afterwards call magraman by contarinus or he french translator -- e -lrb- 7 -rrb- name chio in the original but which must necessarily be kiow or kieu now belong to russia the three formerly mention stage jusch aitomir and belligraoch must either be village of too little importance to find a place in geographical map or they name be so corrupt as to be unintelligible the direct road from lublin to kiow pass through the palatinate of russium wolhynium and kiow province of ci-devant poland now annex to the russian empire -- e -lrb- 8 -rrb- the original say April but attention to the context distinctly point out this necessary correction -- e -lrb- 9 -rrb- from this circumstance it evidently appear that the journey from kiow have hitherto be on the right or west of the dnieper or boristhene through the country of the nogais tartar now form the western portion of the russian province of catharinoslau and we may suppose the wide part of that river they have now to cross to have be somewhere about cherson -- e -lrb- 10 -rrb- name arcercheriher in the french translation of contarinus but which must necessarily be some corruption of baschiseraus the residence of the khan of the crim tartar -- e section ii _ contarinus leave kaffa cross the euxine to the city of phasis whence he pursue he journey through mingrelium georgium and part of armenia into persium _ it be impossible for I to give any exact description of the city of kaffa or theodosium or of its government as the danger of incur suspicion oblige I to remain continually at home on which account i can only mention such particulars as i learn from other it be situate on the euxine and be celebrate for a great fair which be much frequent on which account the city be very populous and be say to be very rich and powerful i hire a vessel belong to anthony valdat which lay in the palus meoti to carry I to the city of _ phasis _ when i be ready to embark i meet with two armenian one of whom have be on a embassy to rome from uzun hassan and be persuade by they to prefer disembark at _ tina _ about a hundred mile from trebisond instead of phasis allege that from tina it be only four hour journey to a castle name _ arrius _ which depend upon the king of persium and promise to conduct we to that place in safety although i be by no means satisfy with this advice i allow myself to be guide by the consul and he brother who agree in opinion with the armenian i accordingly leave kaffa on the 4th of June -lrb- 1 -rrb- accompany by the consul who go with I to the river where we vessel be in wait i have formerly agree with the master for we passage to phasis at seventy ducat but on occasion of the change in we destination i be now oblige to pay a hundred be aware that i should not be able to meet with any person to serve we at the place we be go to i use the precaution to hire nine man from kaffa to assist the mariner of we vessel and to procure provision for we in we journey through georgium and mingrelium we embark on the 15th of June and make sail across the euxine direct for tina but have hardly get twenty mile on we voyage when a contrary wind spring up from the east observe the mariner consult together in a extraordinary manner i become curious to know the purpose of they discourse accordingly one bernard the brother-in-law of we captain say to I that he understand we propose go to tina but advise I by no means to do so as a certain _ subassa _ roam about that neighborhood with a band of cavalry who would certainly make we slave if we fall into he hand on this advice i change my purpose and the wind become more favourable we make sail for liasus and phasis and arrive at _ varsus _ on the 29th of June where i disembark my horse and baggage and send they from thence by land to phasis which be sixty mile from that place _ varsus _ be a castle with a small village in mingrelium belong to a lord name _ gorbolum _ to whom likewise _ caltichea _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- a place of small importance on the coast of the euxine be subject the inhabitant of this country be very miserable and the only production be hemp wax and silk on the 1st of July we arrive near phasis follow by a vessel fill with mingrelian who seem all to be fool or drunk quit the vessel we go up the river in a boat pass a island in the mouth of the river where oete the father of medea the enchantress be say to have reign on this island we spend the night and be sadly infested by midge next day we go up the river in the boat pass the city of asso which stand on its bank in the midst of a forest i here find one nichola capellum of modena who command in these part and a circassian woman name martha who have be the slave of a person of genoa but be now marry this martha receive I with much kindness and with she i staid two day phasis be a city of mingrelium subject to prince bendian whose dominion extend only about three day journey in length the country be very mountainous and full of forest the inhabitant be so fierce and savage that they might be account wild beast they principal drink be beer they have some corn and wine but in very small quantity boil millet be they ordinary food which be a very poor kind of nourishment they sometimes procure wine and salted fish from trebisond and import salt from kaffa without which they could not exist they only production consist in a small quantity of hemp and wax if they be industrious they might procure abundance of fish which be very numerous in they river they be christian accord to the greek ritual to which they have add many gross superstition i leave phasis on the 4th of July accompany by nichola capellum and cross the river _ mare _ on a float that day and the next we travel through a considerable portion of mingrelium always among wood and mountain towards the evening of the 5th we come to the habitation of prince bendian whom we find with all he court recline on a plain under the shade of some tree i send nichola capella to inform he of my quality and to ask permission to pay he my respects which be accordingly grant i salute he therefore with great respect as he sit on the ground with he wife and child and he make I sit down beside he after explain the purpose of my journey i request he would have the goodness to appoint I a guide he express he satisfaction at my arrival in he dominion and grant my request he afterwards send I some bread a piece of beef and the head of a sow but so under do that it require the extreme necessity in which we then be to induce we to eat of he provision but when we can not get what we like we must put up with what can be have we have to wait a whole day for the promise guide the plain in which we find prince bendian be surround by very fine tree resemble box but much more lofty the prince seem about fifty year of age and have a tolerably handsome countenance but he manners be perfectly ridiculous on the 7th of July we continue we journey always among wood and mountain and next day pass the river which divide mingrelium from georgium have to pass the night in the open air and what be worse we have nothing to eat on the 9th we arrive at a small city name _ cotachi _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- which be defend by a stone fort and where we see a temple that seem very ancient we have here to pass a bridge over a large river before reach the plain in which the hut of plangion king of georgium be situate the fort and city of cotachi belong to plangion i wait upon the commander of this place who invite I to dinner he be seat on the ground on which i and those of my suite who accompany I and some friend of the governor all sit down before we be lay a greasy skin on which they serve we with bread radish some flesh and other execrable article with which i be not acquaint they continually offer I wine in large goblet to fill I drunk accord to they abominable custom as they be as foolish and beastly as the mingrelian find that i would not join they in deep drinking they hold I in great contempt insomuch that i find it extremely difficult to get leave to retire and to continue my journey but at length they bring I a guide to conduct I to the king of georgium i leave cotachi on the 12th of July and after travel the whole day through wood and mountain we rest for the night in a meadow at the foot of a mountain near a castle name _ scande _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- in which king _ pangrate _ -lrb- 5 -rrb- reside my guide here leave I on purpose to inform the king of my arrival promise to return immediately with another guide to serve I during the rest of the journey we have accordingly to pass the whole night in the wood starve of hunger and full of anxiety the guide come back early in the morning accompany by two of the king secretary who inform I that the king be go to cotachi and have order they to make a inventory of all we baggage and of every thing we have about we after which we should be provide with a passport to travel free from payment of any duty through the whole country they proceed accordingly in they examination and inventory with the most rigorous exactness even note down the very shirt we then wear after this they order I to mount my horse and to go along with they to the king leave all my people behind i use my best endeavor to be excuse from this but instead of listen to I they load I with insolence and the only favor i could obtain and that with the utmost difficulty be permission to take my interpreter along with I we accordingly resume we journey without meat or drink and arrive much fatigue at cotachi towards night where my interpreter and I be leave all night to we repose under a tree where indeed they send we some bread and fish the remainder of my people be take to a miserable village where they be leave in charge of the priest and we mutual anxiety may be easily guess next morning i be carry before the king whom i find sit on the ground in a hut surround by several of he noble after pay my respects he ask I a great number of question and among the rest how many king there be in the world it come into my fancy to answer that there be twelve on which he signify that i be right and that he be one of the number and that he be much surprised that i should come into he dominion without bring he a letter from my sovereign to this i answer that when i leave my own country i do not expect to travel through he dominion otherwise my sovereign would assuredly have give I letter in charge for he majesty and with this answer he seem satisfied he ask many other extraordinary question from which i conjecture that my guide have maliciously represent I as carry many valuable thing and it be probable if this have be the case that i have never be allow to escape out of they hand the royal secretary endeavor to persuade I that i ought to make the king a present of any article that might strike he fancy among my small baggage but i get off without make any present except compliment and request he to appoint some one to conduct I through he dominion this he be please to promise as likewise to give I a free passport without pay any duty as i carry no merchandize accordingly i take my leave of the king on the 14th of July return to the tree i formerly mention as my lodging where the secretary bring I the promise passport and a guide i then return to my people at the village where they be keep in my absence and be receive with much joy as the priest have represent the king as the cruellest tyrant in the world my people could not contain themselves for excess of joy at my safe return and even the miserable priest be so touch at the scene that he provide we with something to eat and we sleep there that night as well as we could next day be the 15th of July we provide ourselves with some bread and wine to comfort ourselves on the way and resume we journey through thick forest and terrible mountain which continue for two day in the evening of the 16th we stopt near a spring where we remain during the night in the open air be oblige to light a fire on account of the coldness of the weather though in the middle of summer on the 17th of the same month we arrive at _ goride _ -lrb- 6 -rrb- which belong to the king of georgium this city be build on a plain water by a large river and be defend by a citadel which be build upon a rock we guide notify we arrival to the commandant who order we a house for we lodgings apparently for the purpose of extort a present for shortly afterwards he inform I that he have letter from the king by which he be order to receive twenty-six ducat from I for himself and that i should pay six to my guide i endeavor to evade this demand by say that the king have receive I favourably to whom i have already give seventy ducat and could not give any thing more and urge my free passport but he would listen to nothing i could urge and i be force to comply with he extortion he even detain I till the 19th of the month and even then i have extreme difficulty to get leave to depart the inhabitant of the city who deserve rather to be rank among beast look at we with as much astonishment as if they have never see any other man than ourselves they tell we that on the top of a high mountain in a neighbouring forest there be a great church in which be a image of the virgin which work many miracle and that the church be serve by forty monk whom they name _ calojerien _ -lrb- 7 -rrb- but we anxiety to get out of this abominable country prevent we from pay we devotions at that famous church georgium indeed be a somewhat better country than mingrelium but the manners of the people and they way of living be equally brutal and such be the distress and difficulty i encounter in travel through both that it would be tedious to relate they on the 20th of July we leave the abominable city of goride where we have suffer so many vexation and continue we journey through forest and over mountain occasionally fall in with village where we purchase provision we have always to pass the night on the ground near some spring or rivulet during most part of we journey through mingrelium and georgium -lrb- 1 -rrb- we have already see that it be the 16th of that month when contarinus arrive at kaffa much confusion have occur in the date of this journey which we have no means of correct and must therefore be contented with they as they be -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the name of place in this journal be so corrupt as to be often quite unintelligible varsus may possibly be vardon in the district to the northwest of mingrelium name abkha and caltichea may perhaps be sulhuali a sea port about 30 mile to the east phasis probably refer to some town on the river of that name perhaps subastei -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- probably cutai in imeritium on the river riene -- e -lrb- 4 -rrb- perhaps sarassan about forty mile s e from cutais -- e -lrb- 5 -rrb- apparently the same prince name plangion a little before -- e -lrb- 6 -rrb- gorus in georgium on the river kur the journey hitherto must have be through mingrelium then apparently subject to the prince or king of georgium -- e -lrb- 7 -rrb- probably caloyer -- e section iii _ arrival of contarinus at tauri or ecbatana the royal city of uzun - hassan and continuation of he journey through persium to ispahan where the king then reside _ on the 22d of July we begin to ascend a mountain of prodigious height insomuch that when night come on we have scarcely reach the top where we have to pass the night without water resume we journey in the morning we descend the other side of the mountain and enter the province of armenia which be under the dominion of uzun-hassan -lrb- 1 -rrb- in the evening we be conduct to a fort name reo which stand in the plain between a deep river and a high mountain and which be garrison by turk in the service of uzun-hassan but the neighbouring village be inhabit by armenian we rest in this place till the 25th of July wait the arrival of a guide to direct we in the remainder of the journey and be well treat by the inhabitant we reward they to they satisfaction the armenian who have join we at kaffa under pretence of be a ambassador from uzun-hassan to the pope be recognize by the inhabitant of this village as a impostor and a notorious robber and many be astonish how we have escape from he machination : i get rid of he therefore immediately and make he restore I a horse which i have lend he for the journey after which i procure a priest of a honest character to conduct I to tauri leave reo with my new guide on the 26th of July we ascend a mountain and come on the other side to a plain surround by hill where we find a village inhabit by turk near which we have to pass the night in the open air though the inhabitant treat we with decent civility next morning we depart before day have to pass another mountain on the side of which be a village inhabit by turk among whom we should have run extreme hazard of we life if they have see we but by use much diligence we avoid this danger and get down into a extensive plain full of fine pasture and travel with great expedition that we might pass the night at a respectable distance from the lawless inhabitant of the hill on the 29th we pass the mountain of noah or _ ararat _ which be so lofty that it be cover with snow the whole year we be tell that many who have attempt to reach the top of this mountain have never be more hear of while other on make the same attempt say on they return that it be quite inaccessible from this place forwards we travel through extensive plain intermix with hill and arrive on the 30th of July at a castle name _ chiagrus _ inhabit by armenian find abundance of bread wine and poultry in this place we rest here for a day and then set out with a new guide for ecbatana or tauris leave chiagrus towards evening of the 1st August we come next day to a armenian village at the foot of a mountain where we have to cross a river in boat and be inform that uzun-hassan have formerly gain a great victory near this place over the tartar have hem they into a corner where they army waste away with famine and disease the ruler of these tartar name sultan _ buzech _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- be make prisoner and be afterwards put to death we here see on we left hand eleven armenian village near each other who be catholic christian they bishop be under submission to the roman pontiff the country be extremely agreeable and be the most fertile of all the province of persium we arrive on the 3d of August at a large village call marerich near which we pass the night and have to ride all the next day through a plain country expose to great heat which be greatly aggravate as we could not procure a single drop of water for ourselves or we horse on the way we meet several turkman whose custom it be to encamp here and there about the country wherever they can find pasture for they cattle and to change they residence as the pasture become exhaust these people be abominable robber and look upon rapine as they highest glory and as we have great reason to be afraid of they i give order to all my people to tell whoever we meet that i be journey to wait upon they sovereign which be the only expedient for save we from they violence we arrive on the 4th of August at the city of ecbatana or _ tauri _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- which stand in a plain and be surround by a earthen rampart in bad repair there be high mountain in its neighborhood which be say to be the taurus of the ancient i here lodge with a very good man who give we two sleep chamber a convenience we have be long unused to he be quite astonished how we should have be able to escape the danger of we journey as all the road be block up and on ask he the reason he tell we that ogurlu mohammed -lrb- 4 -rrb- the eldest son of uzun-hassan have rebel against he father and have take possession of _ syla _ -lrb- 5 -rrb- or persepoli of which he have appoint he younger brother _ khalil _ -lrb- 6 -rrb- as governor uzun-hassan have assemble a army to reduce persepoli and he son to obedience but a certain satrap name _ zagarlus _ who command in the neighbouring mountain favor the cause of ogurlu and have ravage the whole country to the very gate of tauri with a body of 3000 horse owe to which all the road be obstruct and unsafe he farther inform we that the governor of tauri have one day issue forth to endeavor to put a stop to the marauder but have be defeat by zagarlus with the loss of most of he troops and have even great difficulty in escape back to the city i inquire why the inhabitant of tauri do not take arm in they own defense in a time of so much danger but he answer although they be obedient to the governor they be quite unused to war on learn the state of affair in this place i resolve to leave it as soon as possible that i might get to the king but i could neither procure a guide nor prevail on the governor to shew I any favor by the advice of my landlord i keep myself very much conceal and employ my interpreter and augustin of pavium whom i have bring with I from kaffa because he understand a little persian to purchase we provision in which employment they be expose to much ill treatment and be often in hazard of they life some day afterwards one of the son of uzun-hassan name masu-beg -lrb- 7 -rrb- come to tauri with 1000 horse to defend the city from the incursion of zagarlus i wait on this prince have great difficulty to obtain a audience tell he that i be send as ambassador to he father and have need of guide whom i pray he to provide I but it be quite ineffectual as he hardly deign to answer I and take no kind of interest in I or my affair so that i be oblige to return disappointed to my lodgings masu-beg endeavor to raise money from the inhabitant of tauri for the purpose of levying soldier but they resist he demand and all the shop of the city be shut up in this emergency be unable to procure provision i be oblige to quit my lodgings with all my people take refuge in a armenian church where they give we a small place in which to keep we horse and i order all my people to keep constantly within door to avoid meeting with injury my apprehension on this occasion may easily be conceive but god who have already protect we in so many danger be mercifully pleased to deliver we from that which now hang over we on the 7th of September _ bertonius liompardus _ -lrb- 8 -rrb- whom i have before see at kaffa and who have be send by we illustrious republic arrive at tauri he be accompany by he nephew name _ brancalione _ and have come by way of trebisond be a month later than I in reach tauri i now dispatch augustin de pavium of whom i have before make mention with letter to the republic of venice in which i give a account to the senate of all that have happen to we hitherto i send this man by way of alapium where he at length arrive in good health after have escape many danger although i remain in tauris till the 22d of September i be not able to acquire any exact knowledge of the city have be force to conceal myself the whole time it be a large city but its territory in some place be uncultivated and i believe nowhere very populous it abound however in all the necessaries of life but these be dear much silk be produce in this neighborhood which be export by way of alapia a considerable quantity of cloth be manufacture in the place which likewise abound in various merchandize but i do not hear of any pearl or precious stone fortunately for we a cadilaskir one of the counsellor of uzun-hassan arrive about this time at tauri who return from a embassy into turkey where he have unsuccessfully endeavor to negociate a peace between he master and the turkish government immediately on learn the arrival of this person i use every effort to procure a interview in which i succeed and by means of a present i prevail on he to admit I and my retinue into he suite he receive I with much civility and grant all i ask assure I that with the blessing of god he would conduct I in safety to the king among he slave there be two illyrian renegado who form a strict intimacy with my people to whom they promise to give every assistance in they power and to give we due notice of the departure of they master which they faithfully perform and for which i reward they on the 22d of September we depart from tauris with the persian counsellor accompany likewise by a great many merchant and other who take the advantage of travel under he protection from fear of be plunder by the rebel this country in which we now travel be quite level with very few hill so dry that we see no tree except along the side of river and have only a few small village in which we purchase what be necessary for we journey and always rest before mid-day in the open air be unable to travel during the height of the sun on account of the great heat travel in this manner we arrive at _ sultanie _ on the 27th of September this city appear to be very handsome surround by wall and defend by a good citadel we see here three most curious brazen gate which have be make at damascus the finest thing i ever behold which must have cost a great deal of money the city of sultanie stand in a plain at the foot of a range of mountain some of which be exceedingly steep and precipitous and the inhabitant of which be force to remove into lower situation during winter on account of the severity of the cold we remain there for three day and resume we journey on the 30th of September travel sometimes in plain and sometimes among hill but always take up we quarter for the night in the open air on the 6th of October we arrive at _ sena _ -lrb- 9 -rrb- a city without wall situate in a plain on the bank of a river and surround by tree in which city we pass the night in tolerably bad quarter we depart from thence on the 8th and stop accord to we usual custom in the field i be seize with a violent intermittent fever insomuch that i could hardly get on horseback next day and that with infinite distress we arrive early next day at kom where i be force to stop all my attendant be seize in a similar manner with myself except we priest stephen testa who take care of we all we fever be so malignant that we be all delirious during the height of the access or hot fit i be afterwards inform that the royal counsellor send to visit I beg my excuse that he could not wait for I because it be necessary for he to repair without delay to the king but that he have leave one of he attendant with I as a guide and that i need not now be under any apprehension as there be none in that part of the country to do I harm i remain here a long time sick the city of sena or sava be not large and have mud wall be situate in a champaign country which be well peopled and abound in every thing necessary to life on the 24th of October be much recover we resume we journey though i be still so weak as to find much difficulty in sit on horseback next day we arrive at the city of cashan -lrb- 10 -rrb- which very much resemble kom except that it be somewhat handsomer on the follow day we come to _ netha _ or nathan this city stand likewise in a flat country which produce much wine i remain here one day both to recruit my strength and because i feel some return of my fever on the 28th of October i prepare as well as i be able to finish my journey which be all on plain ground and arrive at ispahan where uzun-hassan then reside on the 3d of November have employ twenty - four day in we journey from tauris to this place i immediately seek out the dwelling of josaphat barbaro -lrb- 11 -rrb- the ambassador of venice and go to he he receive I with much joy and many embrace be mutually give and receive and we rejoice together on my safe arrival but as i have much need of rest i very soon go to bed when the king hear of my arrival he send some of he slave to congratulate I who present I with some refreshment send by he majesty early in the morning of the 4th November some of the king slave come to require that josaphat barbaro and i should come to court on be introduce to a audience we find the king attend by eight of he principal officer have make my obeisance after the manner of the country i present the letter of the republic and explain the subject of my mission -lrb- 12 -rrb- when i have finish speak he answer I in every point and in few word and among other thing he excuse he conduct in have be oblige to retire to this part of he kingdom after this we be order to be seat and he courtier give we a entertainment accord to the persian fashion which consist of many dish tolerably well dress after the repast we take leave of the king and retire to we quarter two day afterwards we be again send for to court when most of the royal apartment be shewn I the king then reside in a very pleasant country palace decapitation of _ busech _ be represent we be again invite to a entertainment at which many different kind of confection be serve up we remain at ispahan till the 25th of November during which period we be frequently invite to court the city of ispahan like the rest of the persian city be surround by earthen-rampart it stand in a plain and be abundantly supply with all the necessaries of life have rebel against the king it be besiege and suffer much injury for be obstinately defend it be subject to the resentment of the conqueror and the fury of the soldier persium be a very flat and arid country in many part of which there be salt lake in such part as can be supply with water grain and other fruit of the earth be produce in abundance and there be plenty of beast of all kind as it be everywhere intersect and surround by fertile mountain but every thing be very dear the venetian quart of wine be sell for three or four ducat but bread be not so dear in proportion a camel load of wood cost a ducat flesh be dearer than with we and seven hen cost a ducat but other article of provision be cheaper the persian be a civil and humane people and though mahometan they do not hate the christian the woman be very modestly dress and ride on horseback with even more grace than the man and judge from the good appearance of the man the woman be probably handsome -lrb- 1 -rrb- accompany uzun-hassan from ispahan to tauri where he find ambassador from the duke of burgundy and the prince of muscovy and get leave to return to venice _ the king leave ispahan with all he court on the 25th of November for tauris and we travel along with he pass through most of the place which we have see in go to ispahan in this journey we always sleep in tent in the field and the camp be well supply with provision as many merchant have receive order to provide grain victuals of all kind and all sort of necessaries on the 14th of November we arrive at kom where we remain two day under tent expose to extremely cold weather and experience much difficulty to procure a small house in which to shelter ourselves we continue at this place till the 21st of march 1474 during which interval we go frequently to court to pay we respects to the king on which occasion we be generally invite to dinner the persian court be very magnificent be attend by many high officer of state and every day 400 person dine along with the king these be all seat on the ground and be serve in copper bason with boil rice or some other mess make of flesh and grain boil together but the king be serve in great magnificence at a separate table with a great variety of dish of different kind of meat during he meal the king be often serve with wine and then the musician sing and play upon flute such song and tune as the king please to order the king be of a good size with a thin visage and agreeable countenance have somewhat of the tartar appearance and seem to be about seventy year old he manners be very affable and he converse familiarly with every one around he but i notice that he hand tremble when he raise the cup to he lip it be not needful that i should enumerate all the audience which i have on the subject of my mission of which i shall make occasional mention hereafter on the 21st of march the king and all the court leave kom on they journey towards tauris the baggage be carry by camel and mule each day we hardly exceed ten or twelve or at the most twenty italian mile and always stopt at each encampment till the forage in the neighborhood be consume the persian mode of travel be thus : the woman always arrive first at the new camp where they set up the tent and cook provision for they husband they be well clothed and ride upon good horse which they manage with much dexterity the persian nation be very magnificent and exceedingly fond of pomp and shew and it be very agreeable to see they march at some distance they be very careful of they camel of which they have great number even the poorest seldom travel with less than seven of these animal by this mean the prodigious train which attend the court appear to consist of many more person than it actually contain when the king enter ecbatana he suite consist of about 2000 person but many leave the camp on the march as it suit they fancy or convenience and the king never have above 500 horse along with he the royal tent be exceedingly beautiful and magnificent and he bed be ornament with scarlet hanging the merchant who attend the camp sell every thing at a high price all of we party be accommodate with tent as we belong to the suite of the king who often honor we with a invitation to supper and at other time frequently send we refreshment we be always treat with much civility and never receive any injury or affront on the 31st of may the king encamp about fifteen mile from tauris when a certain monk of the boulonnoi name loui who call himself patriarch of antioch and envoy from the duke of burgundy arrive at the camp attend by five horseman the king ask if we know he and we accordingly tell what we know without dissimulation next day the king give he a audience at which we be present by command this patriarch present to the king three robe of gold tissue three other of scarlet silk and some of fine cloth and open he commission make many great offer of service from he prince and many fine promise in very magnificent term which do not appear proper for I to repeat and which the king do not seem to care much about we be all invite to dinner during which the king start many question to which he give very pertinent answer himself after dinner we return to we tent on the 2d of June we arrive at tauri in which place lodgings be appoint for we six day afterwards uzun-hassan send for the patriarch and we to court and although he have three or four time inform I already that i must prepare to return into italy leave my colleague barbaro at he court i could not reconcile myself to the journey and have do every thing in my power to put off my departure when we go to court the king address himself first to the patriarch whom he order to return to he prince and to say from he that he the king would very shortly declare war against the turk have already take the field with that view and that he never fail in perform he promise he then turn to I say return to you country and tell you master that i shall very soon make war upon the ottoman and desire they to do they duty as i shall do mine i know no one better fit to carry this message than you who have accompany I from ispahan and have see my preparation so that you be able to inform the christian prince of all that you have see and of my good intention i offer several reason for excuse myself from obey these command which give I much vexation but the king look at I with a severe expression of countenance say it be my pleasure for you to go and i command you i shall give you letter for you master which will inform they of my sentiment and the reason of you return in this state of embarrassment i be advise by the patriarch and m josaphat to comply with a good grace on which i reply to the king as follow : my departure sir give I much distress but since you judge it proper i make no more objection and be ready to obey you order wherever i may go i shall speak of you great power and goodness and the honor i have receive from you majesty and shall exhort all the prince of christendom to join they force with you against the common enemy my speech please the king and he answer I kindly accord to he wonted manner after retire from this andienqe the king send some persian robe to the patriarch and I make of fine stuff and very beautifully ornament and present each of we with a horse and some money to assist we during we journey we remain two day at tauri after the king departure and set out on the 10th of June to rejoin the court which be then encamp in a pleasant spot among excellent pasture and plenty of fine well about twenty-five mile from tauris we remain there till the pasture be eat bare and then march about fifteen mile farther on the 27th of June the king give we we final audience at which he give we present for we respective sovereign that be to say to the patriarch for the duke of burgundy to myself for the republic and to one marcus ruffus who have come with a embassy from the prince of muscovy the present consist in certain piece of workmanship make in the european fashion two sword and certain ornament for the head which be usually fasten to bonnet there be two persian ambassador in the audience - chamber one of whom be destine on a mission into russium at length the king turn towards the patriarch and I address we nearly as follow : you will return with all speed to you master and will tell they and all the other christian prince from I that i have use all diligence in take the field to make war on the turk as it have be concerted between they and I the emperor of the turk be at present in constantinople and will make no enterprize of importance this year as for myself i propose send one part of my army to reduce my rebellious son and another against the turkish general while i shall remain here at hand to act against the enemy as occasion may require he give order both to we and to he own ambassador to report this to all the prince of christendom i do not receive these order with more satisfaction than i have do the former but i have no means of escape and must necessarily obey wherefore have take we leaf we prepare for we departure and be unexpectedly command to remain till next day in the mean time he convey a great part of he infantry during the night to the other side of a mountain next morning early the _ ruiscasson _ or conductor of ambassador carry we to the top of the hill as mean to confer with we on some important subject and on the appearance of the persian infantry under march he point they out to we as if he have be surprise at see so many additional troops come to the royal camp the better to favor this deception some of he slave exclaim as astonished that there be a great many soldier and that at least 10000 be come to reinforce the army but we easily see through the contrivance and be certain that these pretend new troops be merely the ordinary royal escort which have only change they position to impose upon we after this little comedy the _ ruiscasson _ give we the royal letter for we master and we return to we tent from the information of m josaphat and other the military force of this king can not exceed 20000 cavalry some of whom have wooden buckler about eighteen inch long other have a kind of cuirass make of very thin plate of steel which they wear over they ordinary habit they usual arm be bow and arrow and cimeter while some have small leathern target cover with silk and other carry helmet and cuirass they horse be beautiful and vigorous and very numerous in regard to the manners of the persian and the state of the kingdom i shall mention what i know of these subject as occasion may offer during the recital of my travels but i do not think it proper to weary my reader with any lengthen detail section v _ journey of contarinus from persium through georgium and mingrelium to the city phasis _ be entirely ready to depart on the 1st of July we take leave of m josaphat barbaro in he tent when we mutually shed tear in sincere grief at we separation have recommend myself to the protection of god i mount on horseback and begin my journey accompany by the patriarch of antioch marcus ruffus the muscovite and the two persian ambassador intend to return by way of phasis which be under the dominion of uzun-hassan to this route we be advise by certain bird of bad augury who be omen of the terrible danger we have to encounter in the sequel come to the village of the catholic armenian formerly mention we be well receive by they bishop and attend the mass regularly during three day that we have to remain here lay in a stock of provision for the journey from thence we come to the frontier of georgium travel through plain intersperse with hill and arrive on the 12th of July at _ typsus _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- which be subject to the king of the georgian this city stand upon a hill at the foot of which run the river _ tigre _ and it be defend by a good castle on the summit of a eminence it be formerly a celebrated place but be at present almost utterly ruin though begin to revive and contain many good catholic in this place we take up we lodgings with a person name arminius of the catholic faith in travel through georgium we find a few village compose of hut and some castle among the mountain but these be rare and distant on the 19th of July be near the frontier of mingrelium we chance to meet with pangratius king of georgium in the midst of a forest surround by mountain and go to pay we respects to he when he invite we to dinner we have to sit on the ground have a skin spread before we instead of a table-cloth and be serve with roasted meat and fowl very ill dress but by way of make amends they frequently present we with large goblet of wine as they seem to place all dignity and merit in deep drinking for this reason it be they custom at the conclusion of they meal to challenge one another to drink and he who empty the greatest number of goblet be hold in highest esteem as the turk drink no wine they presence be some restraint that day on they usual bacchanalian contest and as we neither could nor would compete with they we be hold in great contempt the king be about forty year old and of large make with a strong resemblance to the tartar countenance we part from the king of georgium next day and on the 22d of July on the confines of mingrelium we fall in with a georgian commander at the head of some troops both cavalry and infantry who be post in this place to prevent injury from the disorder that have break out in mingrelium in consequence of the death of bendian prince of that country these people stop and frighten we with many cruel menace but at length after be rob of two quiver full of arrow and have to gratify they with some money we escape from they and make the best of we way to a distance leave the public road we strike off into a thick wood where we pass the night in prodigious apprehension on the follow day while approach the city of _ cotatus _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- we meet some peasant in a narrow pass who prevent we for some time from go forwards and even threaten to put we to death after much altercation and many threat they seize three horse belong to the turk -lrb- 3 -rrb- which be with great difficulty redeem for twenty ducat on the evening we reach cutai which be a royal fortress while pass a bridge over a river early in the morning of the 24th of July we be again attack by robber who come upon we suddenly and after many threat force we to pay the full value of we horse before they would allow we to continue we journey after pass this bridge we enter mingrelium where we follow we wonted custom of sleep under the canopy of heaven though we have many worse inconveniency and danger to encounter : for on the 25th of July have pass over a river by means of raft we be conduct to the dwelling of a certain lady name _ maresca _ sister of the deceased prince badian who receive we at first with much civility and treat we with bread and wine after which we be conduct into a field belong to she which be close shut on all side on the morrow when we be about to depart we offer she a present of twenty ducat as a return for she hospitality which at first she pretend to refuse but we soon discover she treachery as she insist on we pay two ducat as a ransom for each of we horse we express we astonishment at this rapacity and endeavor to represent we inability to comply with such exorbitant demand but all to no purpose and we be force to comply be afraid that she might even have plunder we of every thing leave this rapacious dame we arrive at _ phasis _ on the 27th of July some on horseback and other in boat where we again lodge with _ martha _ the circassian lady whom i formerly mention after have run many risk in we journey we here learn a piece of most afflictive news that the turk have take possession of kaffa or theodosium in the crimea by which we be deprive of we last resource and shut out apparently from every hope of continue we voyage homewards we distress on receive this intelligence may easily be conceive and in fact we be so much cast down as not to know what measure to pursue or to which hand to turn we loui the patriarch of antioch resolve upon go through tartary and russium with which route he be acquaint it be to no purpose that i urge the promise we have mutually come under at the beginning of we journey never to separate on any account to this he answer that the unforeseen circumstance which have occur be a sufficient warrant to every one to consult he own individual safety i insist and beseech he not to treat I with such unfeeling cruelty but all in vain for he prepare to set off along with the turkish ambassador who have be send by uzun-hassan as he particular companion in this extremity i go to marcus ruffus and the turkish ambassador who be join with he by the king of persium to whom i mention my intention of return back to uzun-hassan they pretend to approve my plan and even to join I and we embrace as enter into promise of keep together but they secretly come to a determination of take they journey through the province of _ gorgore _ which be subject to _ calcicanus _ and to the city of _ vatus _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- which be on the frontier of the turk and pay tribute to the grand signior the patriarch set out on the 6th of August and the next day marcus ruffus follow he accompany by several russian partly on horseback and partly by means of boat they intention be to travel from vatus by shamakus anciently cyropoli and thence into tartary thus leave alone in a strange land i leave any reasonable person to think what be the embarrassment with which i be surround i be unacquainted with a single individual have no company but that of my domestic and have very little money remain in short i be reduce almost to despair of ever be able to get out of the country in this state of distress i fall into a violent fever and could get no other nourishment but bread and water and a pullet occasionally with much difficulty and my fever increase to such a degree that i become delirious all my domestic be attack soon after with the same fever the priest stephen only except who have to take care of we all my only bed be a wretched mattress which have be lend I by a person name john volcan and my life be despair of by every one till the 9th of September when by the care of stephen and of martha my good hostess or rather through the mercy of god the fever abate and i soon recover my former health to the astonishment of every one my domestic likewise recover and we begin again to consult on the best means of escape out of we present situation some propose to take the road of syrium but i deem this too dangerous and we at length come to the determination of go by shamakus into tartary and thence by russium poland and germany i get accordingly on horseback on the 10th of September but have hardly ride two mile when i be force to dismount and rest myself on the ground i be therefore oblige to return to my lodging in phasis where we remain till the 17th when be all of we restore to health and strength we again resume we journey after have implore the protection and assistance of god i now take a certain greek into my service who could speak the mingrelian language who occasion I a thousand georgium into media and pass the caspian arrive in tartary _ leave phasis as before mention on the 17th of September and take the road of mingrelium we come to _ cotatus _ or cutai on the 21st of that month extremely worn out through the consequence of we late illness and the fatigue of the journey and as the greek whom i have hire never cease to give I vexation i here part with he as handsomely as i could we remain two day at cutai among people who know we not and whose language we be quite ignorant of leave that place and trace back we former step we pass over several mountain in much fear and arrive at tifli on the 30th of September where we take shelter in the chapel of a certain armenian catholic who have more the appearance of a dead person than of a living man but who render we every possible service this man have a son who live with he and who unfortunately for we be seize with the plague which have rage in that part of the country this year from he one of my servant name maffeo of bergamo catch the distemper who still keep about I during two day though ill as he be my own particular domestic at length grow worse he have to take to he bed when the distemper shew itself and as he lay in the same room with I and the house could not afford I another i be force to take refuge in a hovel where some cow be keep at night and as the armenian refuse to allow maffeo to remain in he house i be constrain to take he into the same place with myself where stephen take care of he till god pleased to take he out of the world after the death of maffeo i experienced great difficulty to procure another stable for myself that i might get away from the morbid air of that in which my poor servant die in this extremity we be utterly abandon except by one old man who understand a little of we language and who serve we with much affection we remain at this place till the 21st October and on the evening before we intended departure the persian ambassador who have accompany the patriarch come to tifli he complain grievously of have be plunder through the fault of the patriarch with whom he have travel to _ lavgasia _ where he have leave he and be now on he road to complain to uzun-hassan we agree to travel in company from tiflis a city belong to pancrati -lrb- 1 -rrb- from thence in two day we enter the territory of uzun-hassan as we take the road towards shamakus or cyropoli which be situate in a fertile and pleasant country on the 26th of October we separate as the persian go to uzun - hassan at tauri and i take the road for the dominion of _ sivanse _ in which shamakus stand but by means of the persian ambassador i procurred a _ molah _ or mahometan priest to guide I on the road to shamaki this country be greatly more beautiful and more fertile than the dominion of uzun-hassan and be rule over by _ sivanse _ king of media -lrb- 2 -rrb- of this country shamakus be the capital at which place i arrive on the 1st November 1474 this city be not so large as tauri but as far as i could judge surpass that place in the goodness and abundance of every thing especially in excellent cattle it produce great quantity of excellent silk of which they manufacture various kind of very slight stuff while here i have the good fortune to be rejoin by marcus ruffus the muscovite ambassador who have part from I at phasis as formerly related immediately on learn that i be in the city he come to visit I and we embrace with cordiality i now earnestly entreat he to receive I and my domestic into he society for the remainder of the journey to which he very readily agree we leave shamakus on the 6th of November for the city of derbent which be call in the language of the country the caucassian gate or the iron gate this city be under the dominion of _ sivanse _ and stand on the frontier of tartary on we journey we travel sometimes over plain and sometimes on mountain and be tolerably well treat by the turkish inhabitant with whom we lodge by the way about mid-way between these two city we come to a large village where we find great abundance of excellent fruit particularly admirable apple we arrive on the 12th of November at derbent and be advise to pass the winter in that place as it be necessary in we way to russium to cross the desert of tartary which be much easier in the spring of the year and likewise because it be proper for we to cross over the caspian to the tartar city of citracan the city of derbent be situate on the shore of the caspian which the mardian call the sea of bachaan or bacou this city be say to have be build by alexander the great and be call the _ iron gate _ because it entirely close up the only passage from tartary into media and persium by means of a deep valley reach from circassium derbent be fortify with a thick well build wall reach from the castle at the foot of the mountain all the way to the sea but not above a sixth part of the space within the wall be inhabit all that end nearest the sea be in ruin among which be several tomb the country about this city produce abundance of all kind of fruit among which be plenty of grape from which the inhabitant make wine the caspian or sea of hircanium which have no communication whatever with the ocean be about the same size with the euxine or black sea and be very deep they catch in this sea great quantity of sturgeon and sea - wolf as they be call and there be prodigious quantity of sea - dog or seal have the head foot and tail like ordinary dog the only other remarkable fish be of a round form about a yard and a half in diameter with no perceptible head or other member from which the native extract a great quantity of oil which they use in they lamp and with which they anoint they camel the inhabitant of this country who be all mahometan be neither cruel nor barbarous and use we exceedingly well have once ask we who we be and be answer that we be christian they trouble we with no farther inquiry my dress at this time consist of coarse and much worn cloth line with lamb skin above which i wear a leathern robe and my hat be of skin in which dress i frequently go to the market to purchase flesh and other provision which i carry home myself on one of these occasion a person eye I attentively and turn to some of he comrade say this man be not bear to the employment of carry meat marcus ruffus who happen to be along with I explain what the man have say and i be astonish at be recognize in so shabby a dress which i think must have prove a sufficient concealment : but in truth as i have say before they be a very good kind of people during my residence in derbent i be anxious to learn some certain intelligence respect the state of affair at the court of uzun-hassan for which purpose i send demetrius de seze my interpreter with letter to josaphat barbaro at tauri which be twenty day journey from derbent he return at the end of fifty day bring answer from barbaro inform I that the king still remain at tauri but that he be utterly ignorant of he affair spring be arrive we begin to think of pursue we journey and marcus procure a boat for transport we to _ curere _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- the boat which be use in this country be draw up on the shore all winter as the sea be then too rough for they use they be sharp at both end and wide in the middle they plank be fasten with tree-nail and they bottom pay over with pitch and as the native use no compass or other maritime instrument they always creep along the coast these boat which be very crazy and dangerous be move forwards by means of oar and the people be very ignorant of navigation though they believe themselves the best mariner in the world on the 5th of April 1475 we embark and depart from derbent be thirty-five person in all include the master of the boat and the crew the rest of the passenger be merchant carry rice silk and silken goods to _ citrarchan _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- where they propose to sell they commodity to the russian and tartar or to barter they for other article have coast along during three day with a favourable wind always keep about fifteen mile from the shore the wind become contrary on the third evening and increase during the night to so violent a tempest that we expect to have be lose although we have all reason to believe we bark would be dash to piece on the shore we make every effort to gain the land and fortunately we vessel run into a kind of ditch or dock between sand bank very near the beach where she stick fast impel by the unite force of the wind and wave and of we oar between we and the shore there be a pool through which we have to wade carry we baggage on we shoulder and we be almost perish with cold owe to the wind and we be drench with water yet we unanimously agree to refrain from make a fire lest that circumstance might attract the notice of the tartar whom we fear to meet with at day light we notice trace of horse have be on the spot and the recent fragment of a ruin skiff from which we be lead to conclude that some person must have be here but some other circumstance give we reason to believe that the tartar be not near the shore we remain undisturbed at this place till the 14th of April when the wind and weather become favourable we get we bark from the creek and again resume we voyage and advance near thirty mile the same day towards evening the wind become again contrary but we avoid the danger of a impending storm by take refuge amidst some reed among which we mariner haul the boat so as to be out of danger from the wave and we make we way to the land through the reed in do which we be much fatigued and thoroughly drench in water we rest here all that night and the day follow which be easter day have nothing on which to commemorate that festival except some butter and a few egg which we fortunately gather on the sandy beach the mariner and passenger be often inquisitive to know who i be and pursuant to the advice of marcus ruffus i pass myself among they as the physician and servant of _ despima _ the consort of the grand duke of moscovy to whom i be go a short time after this one of we mariner happen to be afflict by a large boil and come to consult I in my assumed character and as i have the good fortune to discover some oil in we bark i make a poultice for he with bread and flour by which he be soon cure from this circumstance they actually believe I to be a physician and be very anxious that i should remain among they but marcus draw I out of this difficulty by say that i have no medicinal preparation with I but would soon return from russium with a proper assortment -lrb- 1 -rrb- this name be probably corrupt for bagration or bagrathion which be once the family name of the sovereign of georgium and if i
