and journey from thence through several danger among the tartar to muscovy along with some merchant _ on the 15th of April we put again to sea with a favourable wind and coast along a series of reedy island we arrive on the 26th of that month at the mouth of the wolga a large river which flow from russium into the caspian from the mouth of this river it be compute to be seventy-six mile to the city of citracan -lrb- 1 -rrb- which we reach on the 30th near this city there be excellent _ saline _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- from which all the neighbouring province be supply with salt the tartar who command in the city would not permit we to enter that evening so that we have to pass the night in a hut without the wall in the morning three broad - face tartar come and order we to go along with they to they prince they treat marcus with respect say that he be a friend of they sovereign but allege that i be he slave as they consider all the frank or christian as they enemy these news be most cruelly mortify for I and afflict I severely but i be oblige to submit in spite of I and marcus advise I to allow he to speak for I force in this manner to return disconsolate to my hut i be long expose to every indignity and danger to my great mortification and distress the tartar insist that i be possess of pearl and even plunder I of some merchandize i have purchase in derbent intend to have barter it in this place for a good horse to carry I during the rest of my journey they inform I afterwards by means of marcus that they intend to sell we all to certain people whom they wait for and who be to go into muscovy with other merchant after many mortification and distress it be resolve to hold a grand consultation concern we at a large village name _ alermus _ about two mile from the city where they lord reside at this time i be not possess of a single farthing and be oblige to borrow money from the russian and tartar merchant at a high interest to supply we urgent necessity for which marcus become my bondsman one day while marcus be absent the khan or prince of the tartar -lrb- 3 -rrb- break open the door of we hut and endeavor to compel I by threat to deliver up the pearl which he believe i be possess of and i have infinite difficulty to escape out of he hand and to persuade he not to put I to death the tartar use often to come to we hut in the night when drunk with mead demand with loud outcry to deliver up the frank to they and the bravest among we be terrify at the dangerous situation in which we be among these savage in this horrible situation we remain from the 1st of may to the 10th of August the city of citracan belong to three brother who be son to the brother of the tartar emperor and the inhabitant often make plunder inroad into the plain of _ cinassium _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- and along the border of the don during the height of summer they travel with they flock in search of pasturage to the northern part of russium and hardly spend above a month every year in citracan that city which stand on the bank of the wolga be by no means large its house be build of earth : it be surround by a slight wall and do not appear to have have any better building for a long time past it be say to have have a very considerable fair formerly and that the perfume and spicery which use to be bring to venice come first to this place from the east whence they be carry to the tanai or don which be only eight day journey from the wolga the prince of citracan whose name be _ casinach _ send every year a ambassador to the grand duke of muscovy on purpose to extort a present and on this occasion several tartar merchant accompany the ambassador carry silk silken vestment and other article of trade which they barter for saddle fur and other thing which be in request among they countryman the only way of travel into russium from this place be through extensive desert on which account traveller have to go in large band or caravan for mutual security and to carry provision for the journey the tartar care little for the latter precaution as they have always plenty of spare horse and kill one when need as they live entirely on flesh and milk without care for any other food they use no bread and only a few of they merchant who have be in russium know any thing of this article previous to the commencement of we journey -lrb- 5 -rrb- we provide provision for the journey as well as we could in this view we procure some rice with much difficulty which boil in milk and then dry in the sun make when afterwards boil in water a excellent and nourishing food we have likewise some onion a small quantity of biscuit and some other trifle and i buy during the journey the salted tail of a sheep -lrb- 6 -rrb- the usual road from citracan to russia lay between two branch of the wolga but the road be then exceedingly dangerous as the tartar emperor be then at war with he nephew who pretend a right to the throne as he father have once be emperor on this account it be propose to pass over to the other side of the river and to travel towards the strait between the don and the wolga which be about five day journey from citracan after which it be presume we should be out of danger we baggage be accordingly carry across the river on raft and marcus desire I to keep always along with he and the tartar ambassador name _ auchiolus _ i and my interpreter accordingly set out about mid-day along with the ambassador to go to the place where the boat wait for we which be about twelve mile from the city we other companion have already go there on we arrival about sunset while i prepare to go into one of the boat on purpose to cross the river marcus seem suddenly strike with a extraordinary panic and command the interpreter and I to take to flight instantly to avoid inevitable danger we mount therefore immediately have likewise a russian woman along with we and a tartar guide of a most horrible aspect and set out at full speed in this manner we follow we guide the whole of that night and part of the next day without be ever allow to stop i frequently ask we guide by means of my interpreter what be the reason of all this and where he propose to carry I at length he explain the cause of marcus have make we set off with such precipitation as the khan have send a order to examine all the boat and he be apprehensive they would have detain I as a slave if i have be find about mid-day of the 13th of August 1475 we arrive at the bank of the river and we tartar guide endeavor to find a boat in which to carry we into a island in which the flock of auchiolus be keep but not find one he cut down some branch which he tie together so as to form a raft on this he place the saddle of we horse and tie this raft to he horse tail he mount the horse on which he swim across the river to the island which lay a bow-shot from the shore he then come back with the raft on which he carry over the russian woman after which he come back for I and i strip myself naked before trust myself to the crazy raft that i might be in readiness to save myself by swim in case of any misfortune he afterwards return for we horse and my interpreter swim across the passage of the river be thus happily effect the tartar carry we to a wretched hovel cover by a miserable woollen cloth where he give we some sour milk which we find very refreshing as we have be long without food and be much fatigue immediately on we arrival in the island be know several tartar leave they flock to come and see we seem infinitely surprized and much gratify by the sight as we be probably the first christian who have ever be on the island be exceedingly fatigued and distressed in mind i do not care to speak with they yet we tartar guide treat I with much kindness and make I as good cheer as he be able next day be the eve of the festival of the virgin he kill a fat lamb to entertain I part of which he roasted and part be boil and though contrary to the rule of we religion to eat meat on that day i make a hearty meal notwithstanding that every thing be disgustingly dirty we have likewise sour milk to drink and the tartar drink mare milk of which they be very fond but i would not drink this though i could easily perceive my dislike do not please the tartar i remain here two day and at last on the 26th of August marcus and the rest make they appearance on the other side of the river and send a boat for I in which be two of he servant a russian and a tartar stephen testa and john ungaret my two attendant be very much rejoice at see I again as they believe I entirely lose and we rest two day at this place before enter upon the desert marcus have be so attentive as to provide a horse for I of which i stand in great need in this caravan which be under the command of the tartar ambassador there be about three hundred person russian and tartar who carry with they above two hundred -lrb- 7 -rrb- horse partly intend to serve as food by the way and partly for sale in russium we arrive in good order at night on the bank of the river and we rest every day at noon during the fifteen day of we journey as we be now consider to be out of danger from any attack by the tartar i do not recollect the name of the emperor of the tartar who inhabit this part of the country between the wolga and the tanai this nation have no fixed place of abode but shift they encampment from place to place wherever they can find pasture and water for they cattle on which they have they whole dependence as they subsist entirely on flesh and milk they have cow heifer and sheep of admirable beauty the flesh of which be excellent as they feed on fine pasture but these people prefer mare milk to every other delicacy though i have not be in the country of these tartar i have be inform that it be flat and agreeable have neither hill nor mountain but the inhabitant addict themselves excessively to robbery and plunder as they sole occupation and continually infest the border of russium and circassium by predatory incursion they horse be very wild and unmanageable and be never shoe we be tell that there be another tribe of tartar beyond the wolga name wild tartar who allow they hair to grow extremely long in the middle of winter they often make inroad to the very skirt of the city of citracan whence they carry off cattle but do no other damage these people like all the tartar shift they encampment in search of pasturage and water after travel for fifteen day along the eastern bank of the wolga we come to a small forest where the tartar and russian of the caravan cut down tree to construct raft for cross the river while they be at this work we discover a small bark which be by no means in good repair by means of which we company propose to convey we baggage across marcus cross over with a part of we baggage leave I in charge of the rest and send back the boat when he be land in my trip with the remainder of we baggage the boat begin to leak when we be about half way over the breadth of the river at this place be about two mile stephen and two russian accompany I in the boat leave demetrius my interpreter and john ungar in charge of the horse we have much ado to bale out the water but by the blessing of god we get over in safety after we baggage be land the russian put off to go back for the rest of we people and the horse but the boat fall to piece this necessarily delay we other servant and the horse from get over till next day during which interval they be badly off as all we provision be on we side it be fortunate that i now examine the state of we provision which i find diminish much beyond expectation so that we be under the necessity of abridge we allowance for the remainder of the journey that we might not run short altogether we principal food consist of millet with garlic and onion and some sour milk and we find some wild apple at this place which we roasted in the course of two day the whole baggage of the caravan be transport to the western side of the river by means of seven raft draw by horse and direct by the tartar the horse swimming and have the raft tie to they tail the sight of this be very amusing but seem very dangerous to those who be employ after rest some time we quit the bank of the river and resume we journey this river wolga be certainly the largest and deepest river in the world be as well as i could judge two mile broad and have very high bank -lrb- 1 -rrb- call citrarchan in the former section but certainly what we now call astracan then the capital of a tartar principality cross european sarmatium arrive at moscow the capital of white russium and be present to the grand duke _ after recommend ourselves to the protection of god we continue we journey through immense and terrible desert sometimes towards the north and sometimes westerly -lrb- 1 -rrb- always rest at noon and take up we quarter for the night on the bare ground without any protection against the weather to prevent we from be surprize in the night by the wander tartar outguard be place every night in three direction around we resting-place during the greater part of this long and dreary journey we be very ill off for water both for ourselves and we cattle and we never see any wild animal one day we see about forty horse which we be tell have escape from a caravan of merchant the year before we fall in one day with a small horde of tartar have twenty waggon but i be not able to learn where they be go as we provision decrease rapidly we be force to use the remainder very sparingly and be consequently reduce to a very short allowance on the 22d of September 1475 we enter russium and discover a few hut in the middle of a wood on the inhabitant learn that marcus they countryman be in we caravan they come to see he that he might protect they from the tartar and bring he a present of honey and wax a part of which he give to we this be a most providential supply as we be so much reduce by fatigue and spare diet that we be hardly able to sit on horseback the first city we come to in this country be _ rezan _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- the prince of which place have marry a sister of the grand duke of russium the castle and all the house of this city be build of wood we here procure bread and meat and mead in abundance to we great comfort and satisfaction the next city we come to be _ kolomna _ pass a very large bridge over the _ monstrus _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- which flow into the wolga at this place marcus quit the caravan which travel too slowly in he opinion and push on for moscow where we arrive on the 26th of September after a journey of forty-seven day through the desert from the 10th of August on which day we leave citracan in a great part of this journey we find no wood and be force to cook we victuals with fire make of dry cow dung we return thanks to god on we arrival for we preservation through so many and great danger on we arrival marcus procure a dwelling for we consist of a small stove - room and some chamber with stable for we horse though small and mean i feel as if lodge in a palace when i compare my present state of tranquil security with the danger and inconvenience i have be so long subject to marcus make I a visit two day afterwards and supply I with some necessaries exhort I as on the part of he sovereign to keep a good heart i return he visit next day and be very desirous to return home to venice i request he to introduce I to the grand duke which he promise to do as soon as possible and i soon afterwards be desire to go to court immediately on my get there i be conduct to a audience on which i make my obeisance in due form to the grand duke to whom i return thanks for all the attention i have receive from he ambassador marcus in the course of my journey by whose assistance and advice i have escape a thousand danger assure he highness that i attribute these mark of kindness as do to the republic of venice whose ambassador i be and that the republic would unquestionably evince a due sense of the obligation to which i owe my life and safety the grand duke interrupted my harangue by complain with much emotion of the conduct of _ john baptista _ of treviso and say a great deal on this subject which be not proper for I to report after a conversation of some length in which i speak to he highness about my departure he close my audience postpone he answer to my request to a future opportunity the grand duke be very shortly to quit moscow on purpose to visit several part of he dominion and particularly the tartar frontier where one of he officer be station with the command of 500 horse -lrb- 4 -rrb- to repress the incursion of robber on that side : i therefore endeavor to procure a answer about my departure and solicit a second audience for that purpose on this occasion i be very politely receive by the grand duke accompany by three of he principal baron at first they expatiate at some length on the subject of john baptista formerly mention but at length i receive liberty to remain or to depart as i think proper they dismiss I with this vague answer and the grand duke set out from moscow soon afterwards i owe a great deal of money to marcus which he have expend for I and my people as he have defray the whole expence of we journey and have supply I with many thing of which i stand in need i request permission from he to go away give he the most solemn assurance that i would transmit full payment to he immediately after my arrival at venice but he declare this be not in he power as he be under the necessity of repay the tartarian and russian merchant who have advance all these thing for we and to whom he have become security for payment finding every application to the duke and marcus on this subject ineffectual as i could not procure the necessary fund for my journey from either i be under the necessity of send stephen testa to venice to solicit a remittance from we illustrious senate by which i might be enable to pay my debt stephen left moscow on the 7th of October accompany by one _ nicola leopolitain _ -lrb- 5 -rrb- who know the country i become acquaint at moscow with one triphon a goldsmith a native of ascravium or cathara who be employ in make several article of silver plate for the grand duke i likewise form acquaintance with a very ingenious architect of bologna name aristotle who be build a new church in the market-place as the house in which i lodged be small and disagreeable i go to live with this person by the advice of marcus : but i be soon after oblige to change my quarter by order from court to a house near the castle in which i remain for the rest of my stay at moscow this city which be the capital of the russian dominion and the residence of the grand duke or sovereign be build on a small elevation on the bank of the mosqua over which there be several bridge the castle and all the house of the city be build of wood which be procure from several thick forest near the place the soil of this country be fertile and produce abundance of corn of all kind which sell here much cheaper than with we the country abound in cattle and swine and with incredible number of poultry duck goose and hare but they have no venison either because there be no deer or because the native be ignorant of the art of take they but they have no vine and they only fruit be cucumber wild apple and nut the country be extremely cold and the inhabitant be under the necessity of live for nine month of the year in stove they provide during winter for they living in summer -lrb- 6 -rrb- when the whole country be envelop in frost and snow they use sledge draw by horse which be very convenient and useful for travel and be even use in summer on account of the miry bad road which be exceedingly difficult and unpleasant the river ordinarily freeze over about the end of October when the merchant erect booth on the ice in which they expose they wares of all kind for sale as in a fair or market and they here sell great number of cattle and swine and great quantity of corn timber and all other necessaries of life every thing be procurable in great abundance all the winter about the end of November they kill all the cattle sheep and other animal that be require for winter provision and expose they for sale on the river in a frozen state and the rigor of the season preserve these provision for two or three month without any risk of spoil fish poultry and all other article of food be keep in the same manner the horse run with great ease and swiftness on the ice yet they sometimes fall and break they neck both man and woman of this country have very good face but they manners be exceedingly bad the russian church be rule over by a patriarch whose election or appointment be dependent on the grand duke and who do not acknowledge subjection to the roman pontiff and they hold all sectary in abhorrence as people doom to perdition the native be much addict to drunkenness and he who excel in drinking be much esteem among they they have no wine as i have say before instead of which they drink mead make of honey and water which be very pleasant when sufficiently keep it be not allow to every one to make this liquor for which purpose a license or permission must be have from the grand duke for if every person have liberty to make mead they would drink perpetually like so many beast and would kill one another from morning till noon they be employ in the market-place occupy in they various business and employment after which they adjourn to the tavern in which they spend all the rest of the day every winter great number of merchant come to moscow from germany and poland who purchase fur of all kind which be indeed exceedingly beautiful among these fur be the skin of fox wolf martin sable ermine and many other from scythium and the alpine region many day journey to the north of moscow many of these be likewise of don henry -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction the knowledge possess by the ancient respect indium will be the subject of discussion in a future portion of this work we have now to contemplate the tedious yet finally successful effort of the portuguese nation in its age of energetic heroism to discover a maritime passage to that long famed commercial region some general knowledge of which have be preserve ever since the day of the persian macedonian and roman empire of all the great event which have occur in the modern age previous to we own time the voyage and discovery which be make by the european in the fifteenth and sixteenth century of the christian era be justly entitle to preference whether we appreciate the vast improvement which they make in navigation and consequently in commerce -- the astonishing abundance of wealth which they bring into europe -- the surprising feat of bravery which be perform in they various expedition and conquest -- the extensive populous and valuable territory which be subdue or colonize -- or the extended knowledge which be suddenly acquire of the greater part of the earth till then either altogether unknown or very partially and erroneously describe by these discovery we allude to those of the southern and western hemisphere a new heaven and a new earth be open up to the astonishment of mankind who may be say to have be then furnish with wing to fly from one end of the earth to the other so as to bring the most distant and hitherto utterly unknown nation acquaint with each other in the ordinary course of human affair it have be observe that similar event frequently occur but the transaction of these time which we now propose to narrate be as singular in they kind as they be great surprising and unexpected neither can any such ever happen again unless providence be to create new and accessible world for discovery and conquest or to replunge the whole of mankind for a long period into the grossest ignorance the merit and glory of these wonderful achievement be unquestionably due to the portuguese nation and the first and principal share to the sublime genius of they illustrious prince the infant don henry _ duke of viseo and grand master of the order of christ _ whose enlarged mind first plan the fitting out of maritime expedition for discovery and by the imitation of whose example all subsequent discovery have be accomplish every thing of the kind before he time be isolate or accidental and every subsequent attempt have be pursue on scientific or known principle which he invent and establish although america be discover by columbus in the service of spain some year before the portuguese be able to accomplish they long seek route to indium and although the discovery of america be perform infinitely quicker than that of southern africa and the route to indium columbus have accomplish he design at the very first attempt and even without any previous knowledge of the country he go in search of while the endeavor of the portuguese occupy a great number of year in almost fruitless attempt and extremely tedious progression yet don henry first set on foot the navigation of the ocean through unknown sea and inspire other nation with the idea of make discovery of distant and unexplored region and ultimately great as be the discovery of columbus they may be say to have be accidentally make in the erroneous attempt to go by a nearer route to the region of which don henry and he successor have long be in search these attempt of the portuguese have be continue for nearly fourscore year before any of they neighbor seem to have entertain the most distant idea of engage in foreign discovery even view they endeavor as downright knight-errantry proceeding from a distempered imagination as well in the first promoter as in those who continue to prosecute he scheme in a word the relation of these discovery form one of the most curious portion of modern history as comprize a great number of the most extraordinary transaction that ever happen in any period of the world for this reason they be well worthy of be particularly narrate that the curious may be make acquaint with every successive step in such important enterprize and by what almost insensible degree such vast undertaking be ultimately accomplish and as the intercourse of european have operate a great change in the country to which they penetrate and upon they original inhabitant so that both now appear in a very different light from what they do before these expedition and discovery therefore every circumstance belong to these transaction deserve the most serious notice john 1 of portugal married philippa the eldest daughter of john of gaunt duke of lancaster son to edward iii of england by whom he have several son of whom don henry be the _ fifth _ after serve with great bravery under he father at the capture of ceuta he be raise to the dukedom of viseo and be send back with a large reinforcement to preserve the conquest to which he courage have largely contribute during he continuance in command at ceuta he acquire much information by occasional converse with some moor relative to the sea and coast of western africa which raise and encourage the project of maritime discovery and these become afterwards the favorite and almost exclusive pursuit of he active and enlarged mind from the moor he obtain intelligence respect the nomadic tribe who border upon and pervade the great desert and of the nation of the jaloof whose territory be conterminous with the portuguese discovery from cape non to cape bojador _ three year before the reduction of ceuta the duke of visco have send a vessel in 1412 to explore the western coast of africa be the first voyage of discovery undertake by the portuguese or by any other nation in modern time the commander be instruct to endeavor to follow the western coast of africa to the southward of cape chaunar call by the portuguese mariner cape nao non or nam which extend itself from the foot of mount atla have hitherto be the _ non plus ultra _ or impassable limit of european navigation and have accordingly receive its ordinary name from a negative term in the portuguese language as imply that there be no navigation beyond and respect which a proverbial say be then current of the follow import : whoe'er would pass the cape of non shall turn again or else be go the success of this earliest voyage fit out for the purpose of discovery be not record but don henry continue to send some vessel every year to the same coast with the same instruction of endeavor to explore the coast beyond cape non not daring to trust themselves beyond sight of land the mariner creep timorously along the coast and at length reach cape bojador only sixty league or 180 mile beyond cape non this cape which stretch boldly out into the ocean from which circumstance it derive its name -lrb- 1 -rrb- fill the portuguese mariner with terror and amazement owing to the shoal by which it be environ for the space of six league be perpetually beat by a lofty and tremendous surge which preclude they from all possibility of proceed beyond it in they ordinary manner of creep along the coast and they dare not to stretch out into the open sea in quest of smoother water lest lose sight of land altogether they might wander in the trackless ocean and be unable to find they way home it be not impossible that they might contemplate the imaginary terror of the torrid zone as hand down from some of the ancient with all its burning soil and scorching vapor and they might consider the difficulty of cape bojador as a providential bar or omen to warn and oppose they against proceed to they inevitable destruction they accordingly measure back they wary step along the african coast and return to portugal where they give a account of they proceedings to don henry in which of course the danger of the newly discover cape would not be diminish in they narrative -lrb- 2 -rrb- return from ceuta where he presence be no longer necessary and where he have mature he judgment by intercourse with various learn man whom he bounty have attract into africa and have enlarged he view by the perusal of every work which tend to illustrate the discovery which he project don henry fix he residence at the romantic town of sagre in the neighborhood of cape st vincent where he devote he leisure to the study of mathematics astronomy cosmography and the theory of navigation and even establish a school or academy for instruct he countryman in these science the parent of commerce and the sure foundation of national prosperity to assist he in the prosecution of these he favorite study he invite from majorca a person name diego or jame who be singularly skilful in the management of the instrument then employ for make astronomical observation at sea and in the construction of nautical chart some trace of nautical discovery along the western coast of africa still remain in ancient author particularly of the report voyage of menelaus hanno eudoxus and other from a attentive consideration of these don henry and he scientific coadjutor be encourage to hope for the accomplishment of important discovery in that direction and they be certainly incite in these view by the rooted enmity which have so long rankle among the christian inhabitant of spain and portugal against the moor who have formerly expel they ancestor from the greatest part of the peninsula and with whom they have wage a incessant war of several century in recover the country from they grasp section ii _ discovery of the madeira island _ after some time usefully employ in acquire and diffuse a competent knowledge of cosmopographical nautical and astronomical science don henry resolve to devote a considerable portion of the revenue which he enjoy as grand master of the order of christ in continue and extend those project of nautical discovery which have long occupy he attention accordingly about the year 1418 a new expedition of discovery be fit out for the express purpose of attempt to surmount the peril of cape bojador in this expedition juan gonzale zarco and tristan vaz texeira two naval officer of the household of don henry volunteer they service and embark in a vessel call a _ barcha _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- steer for the tremendous cape the portuguese be hitherto ignorant of the prevail wind upon the coast of africa and the cause by which they influence be varied or increase near the land and between the latitudes of 28  and 10  north a fresh gale almost always blow from the ne long sand-banks which extend a great way out to sea and which be extremely difficult to be distinguish in the morning and evening and the prevail current be powerful obstacle to the enterprise of these navigator about six league off cape bojador a most violent current continually dash upon the breaker which present a most formidable obstacle to the brave but inexperienced mariner though they voyage be short they encounter many danger and before they could reach the cape they be encounter by a heavy gale from the east by which the billow of the atlantic become too heavy to be resist by they small vessel and they be drive out to sea on lose sight of they accustomed head land and be force into the boundless ocean for the first time the ship company give themselves up to despair but on the abatement of the tempest they find themselves unexpectedly within view of a island situate about 100 league west from the coast of africa with extreme joy they behold the coast of this island extend about twenty mile in length to which they give the name of puerto santo because first discover upon the feast of all saint this be the smaller of the madeiras be only about two mile broad and as the only roadstead be upon the south-west side the portuguese probably anchor upon that side to be under the lee shelter of the island from the remnant of the tempest from which they have happily escape the island of _ puerto santo _ or of the holy haven be almost directly west from cape cantin whence it would appear that these portuguese navigator could hardly have pass much beyond cape de geer when drive off the coast by this fortunate easterly tempest have they even advance as far as cape non they would almost certainly have be drive among the canary it be perfectly obvious that they never even approach cape bojador in this voyage unless we could suppose after have be drive directly west from that cape that they shape a northern course after the subsidence of the tempest and fall in with puerto santo while on they return to portugal greatly pleased with the soil and climate of this island and with the gentle manners of the native whom they describe as in a intermediate state of civilization and entirely destitute of any appearance of savage ferocity zarco and vaz immediately return to portugal where they make a report of the incident of they voyage and to confirm they opinion of the value of they discovery they request permission from don henry to return for the purpose of establish a settlement in puerto santo by this discovery a advanced and favourable station be secure towards the south whence any discovery along the coast of africa might be prosecute with greater ease and safety and from whence the danger of the hitherto formidable cape bojador might be avoid by keep a southerly or s w course from puerto santo from these consideration don henry grant they request and yield to the adventurous spirit which this accidental discovery have excite he permit several person to join in a new project voyage among whom be bartholomew perestrello a nobleman of he household three vessel be soon fit out -lrb- 4 -rrb- which be place under the respective command of zarco vaz and perestrello these commander have order to colonize and cultivate the newly discover island and be furnish with a considerable assortment of useful seed and plant for that purpose they happen likewise to take with they a female rabbit great with young which litter during the voyage and which be let loose with she progeny multiply so rapidly that in two year they become so numerous as to occasion serious injury to the early attempt at cultivation and to baffle every hope of render puerto santo a place of refreshment for the portuguese navigator insomuch that a resolution be form to abandon the newly establish settlement after have land the different animal and seed which have be send out by don henry and see they properly distribute perestrello return into portugal to make a report to the prince and zarco and vaz remain to superintend the infant colony soon after the departure of perestrello the attention of zarco and vaz be strongly excite by observe certain cloud or vapor at a great distance in the ocean which continually present the same aspect and preserved exactly the same bearing from puerto santo and at length occasion a conjecture that the appearance might proceed from land in that quarter gonsalvo and vaz accordingly put to sea and sail towards the suspected land and soon discover that the appearance which have attract they notice actually proceed from a considerable island entirely overgrow with wood to which on that account they give the name of madeira -lrb- 5 -rrb- after bestow considerable attention upon the soil and other circumstance of this island which be utterly destitute of inhabitant gonzalvo and vaz return to portugal with the welcome intelligence and give so favourable a report of the extent fertility and salubrity of madeira that don henry determine to colonize and cultivate it accordingly with the consent of the king of portugal the island of madeira be bestow in hereditary property upon zarco and vaz one division name _ funchal _ be give to zarco and the other moiety name _ machico _ to vaz in the year 1420 zarco begin the plantation of madeira and be much impede in he progress by the immense quantity of thick and tall tree with which it be then everywhere encumber he set the wood on fire to facilitate the clearing of the surface for of the portuguese flore and corvo which lie seventy league west from tercera be not reckon among the aores by some writer in this latter island the portuguese pretend that there be discover a equestrian statue make from one block of stone the head of the man be bare he left hand rest on the mane of he horse and he right pointed towards the _ west _ as if indicate the situation of another continent in addition to all this a inscription appear to have be trace on a rock beneath the statue but in a language which the portuguese do not understand in the slow progress of discovery the peril endure by the officer and man employ by don henry from the moor and negro frequently occasion murmur against he plan of discovery but the several cluster of island the madeira cape verd and aores form a succession of maritime and commercial colony and nursery for seaman which take off from the general obloquy attend the tedious and hitherto unsuccessful attempt to penetrate farther into the southern hemisphere and afford a perpetual supply of navigator and a stimulus to enterprize the original prejudice against the possibility of navigate or exist in the torrid zone still subsist and although the navigator of don henry have gradually penetrate to within ten degree of the equator yet the last successive discovery be always hold forth by the supporter of ignorant prejudice as that which have be place by nature as a insurmountable barrier to farther progress in the atlantic in this situation the settlement of the aores be of considerable importance in 1457 don henry procure the grant of many valuable privilege to this favorite colony the principal of which be the exemption of the inhabitant from any duty on they commerce to the port of portugal and even of spain in 1461 a fort be erect in the isle of arguin on the african coast of the moor to protect the trade carry on there for gold and negro slave next year 1462 antonio de noli a genoese send by the republic to portugal enter into the service of don henry and in a voyage to the coast of africa discover the island which be know by the name of the cape de verd island though they lie 100 league to the westward of that cape in the same year pedro de cintra and suera de costa penetrate a little farther along the coast of africa and discover the river or bay of sierra liona or mitomba in lat 8  30 ' n this constitute the last of the portuguese discovery carry on under the direct influence and authority of don henry the founder and father of modern maritime discovery as he die next year 1463 at sagre in the sixty-seventh year of he age and for a time the maritime enterprise of the portuguese nation be palsy by he death thus during a long period of fifty-two year this patriotic prince devote almost he whole attention and the ample revenue which he enjoy as duke of viseo end grand master of the military order of christ in extend the maritime knowledge and consequently the commercial prosperity of he country the incident of the last seven year of the life of this distinguished prince be involve in uncertainty and we know very little with regard to the progress of he maritime discovery from 1456 the date of the second of the voyage of cada mosto of which we propose to give a separate account till the year of he death 1463 from the year 1412 when he begin he operation at which time he could scarcely exceed fifteen year of age the navigator who have be form under he auspices and direction and often instruct by himself in the theory of navigation and cosmography gradually explore the western coast of africa from cape nam or non in lat 28  15 ' certainly to rio grande in lat 11  n or rather to rio de nuno not quite a degree farther south but it be highly probable that the southern limit of discovery in he time extend to cabo verga in lat 10  n the northern boundary of the country usually call the sierra liona or the ridge of lion perhaps to the gulf of mitomba or bay of sierra liona in lat 8  30 ' n a extent of 29  15 ' of latitude or 1185 nautical mile a mere nothing certainly when compare with modern navigation but a wonderful effort in the infancy of the science when even coast voyage of any extent along well know shore and in frequented sea be look upon as considerable effort no brilliant discovery indeed reward the perseverance of don henry and the courage of he servant but a indestructible foundation of useful knowledge be lay for overthrow the ignorant prejudice of the age and by which not long afterwards he plan be perfect by complete the circumnavigation of africa and by the discovery of the _ new _ world dr vincent the learn editor and commentator of the periplus of the erythrean sea be dispose to limit the discovery of don henry to cape verd -lrb- 2 -rrb- but ramusio believe that the island of st thoma be settle in he time and the ingenious translator of the lusiad of camoen be of opinion that some of he commander pass beyond the equator -lrb- 3 in the island of st matthew or anabon in the _ second _ degree of southern latitude but this proof be quite inconclusive as the navigator long rear in the school of this great prince might naturally enough continue he impress upon the country they visit even after he lament death about seven year before the decease of don henry two voyage be make to the african coast by alvise da cada mosto a venetian navigator under the auspices of the duke of viseo but which we have choose to separate from the historical deduction of the portuguese discovery principally because they contain the oldest nautical journal extant except those already give in we first part from the pen of the great alfred and be therefore peculiarly valuable in a work of this nature they considerable length likewise and because they be not particularly conducive to the grand object of extend the maritime discovery have induce we to detach they from the foregoing narrative that we might carry it down unbroken to the death of the great don henry these voyage likewise give we a early picture of the state of population civilization and manners of the african not to be meet with elsewhere to this we subjoin a accompany cintra in he voyage the exact date of this voyage be nowhere give but as the death of don henry be mention in the narrative it probably take place in that year 1463 -lrb- 1 -rrb- so call cintra to the coast of africa the former in the year 1455 and 1456 and the latter soon afterwards -lrb- 1 -rrb- introduction alvise da cada mosto a venetian in the service of don henry of portugal inform we in he preface that he be the first navigator from the _ noble city of venice _ who have sail on the ocean beyond the strait of gibraltar to the southern part of negroland and lower ethiopium these voyage at cada mosto be the oldest extant in the form of a regular journal and be originally compose in italian and first print at venice in 1507 this first edition be now exceedingly scarce but there be a copy in the king library and another in the valuable collection make by mr dalrymple these voyage be afterward publish by ramusio in 1613 and by grynus in latin the latter be mislead in regard to the date which he have inadvertently place in 1504 after the death of prince henry and even subsequent to the discovery of the cape of good hope by bernal diaz even ramusio in he introduction to the voyage of cada mosto have make a mistake in say that they be undertake by the order of john king of portugal who die in 1433 ramusio imagine that the discovery of cada mosto might tend to great importance as he consider the river senegal and rio grande to be branch of the niger by which mean the european might open a trade with the rich kingdom of tombuto and mellus on that river and thus bring gold from the country of the negro by a easier safer and more expeditious manner than as convey by the moor of barbary by land over the vast and dangerous desert that intervene between the country on the niger and senegal river and barbary as by the account of leo salt be the most valuable commodity throughout the country of the negro ramusio propose that the ship should take in cargo of salt at the island of _ sal _ one of the cape de verd and thence supply the country on the niger which be report to be navigable for 500 mile into the interior and that they should bring back gold and slave in return the latter to be bring to market at st jago another of the cape de verd island where they would be immediately buy up for the west indy all this fine speculation however rest on mistaken foundation as the niger be altogether a inland river run to the east and have no communication with the senegal and gambium which run west into the atlantic yet time and the civilization of the native on the senegal and gambium may hereafter realize this scheme of a valuable traffic into the interior of africa but it be fervently to be hope that the trade in slave may never be revive in he preface after a apology for he performance and make a declaration of he strict adherence to truth in all the particulars he relate cada mosto give some account of the infant don henriquez or henry of portugal the great author and promoter of maritime discovery he praise he as a prince of a great soul and sublime genius and of great skill in astronomy and add that he apply himself entirely to the service of christ by make war against the moor while on death - bed in 1432 don john king of portugal exhort he son don henry to pursue he laudable and holy purpose of _ persecute _ the enemy of the christian faith which he promise to perform and accordingly with the assistance of he brother don duarte or edward who succeed to the throne of portugal he make war in fez with success for many year afterwards the more effectually to harass the moor he use to send he caravel or ship of war annually to scour the coast of azafus or al saffi and messa on the coast of africa without the mediteranean by which he do they much damage but have in view to make discovery along that western coast he order they every year to advance farther towards the south they accordingly proceed till they come to a great cape which put a stop to they progress southwards for several year be afraid to go beyond it whence it take the name it still retain of cape non -lrb- 2 -rrb- meaning that such as go beyond should never return don henry however be of a different opinion and add three other caravel to those which have be at the cape send they again next year to make the attempt they accordingly penetrate about 100 mile beyond that cape where they find only a sandy coast with no habitation and return back to portugal encourage by this commencement of successful progress don henry send the same fleet back next year with order to extend they discovery 150 mile farther to the south and even more if they find it proper and promise to enrich all who should embark in this navigation they go again and although they obey the instruction of the prince they could not improve the discovery yet firmly persuade by the strength of he own judgment that people and habitation would certainly be find at length don henry continue to send out he caravel from time to time and they come at length to certain coast frequent by the arab of the desert and to the habitation of the azanaghus a tawny race thus the country of the negro be discover and different nation afterwards which will be mention in the follow relation thus far the preface of cada mosto as give in the collection of astley from the edition of ramusio with which we must be satisfy in this work as that in the royal library be inaccessible for we use the present version have be carefully form by a comparison of astley with the original in ramusio and with the summary by the reverend jame stanier clarke in he curious work on the progress of maritime discovery which only give a selection of what he consider to be its most material part in this edition the narrative style of cada mosto in he own person be restore as much as possible it may be notice that alvise be the portuguese form of the name loui or lewi in addition to the two voyage of cada mosto himself there be a third voyage include in the present chapter perform by piedro de cintra to the same coast the service of don henry and set out for the new discovery : relation of the voyage to madeira and the canary with some account of these island and they inhabitant _ i alvise da cada mosto after visit many part of we mediterranean sea be in we city of venice in the year 1454 at which time i be about twenty-two year of age determine to return into flander a country which i have formerly visit as a merchant for my constant attention be in the first place to acquire wealth and secondly to procure fame on the 8th of August in that year 1454 i embark in one of the gally belong to the republic command by marco zen a venetian cavalier contrary wind detain we for some day off cape st vincent during which i learn that don henry the infant of portugal reside in the adjoining village of reposera or sagre to which he have retire in order to pursue he study without interruption from the tumult of the world hearing of we arrival the prince send on board of we galley antonio gonzale he secretary accompany by patricio de contus -lrb- 1 -rrb- a venetian who be consul for the republic in portugal as appear by he commission and who also receive a salary or pension from don henry these gentleman bring on board and exhibit to we sample of madeira sugar dragon blood and other commodity of the country and island belong to the prince which have be discover under he patronage they ask we many question and inform we that the prince have cause some lately discover and uninhabited island to be settle and cultivate as a proof of which they have shewn we the before-mentioned valuable production add that all this be next to nothing in comparison of the great thing which don henry have perform as he have discover sea which have never be navigate before and the country of diver strange and hitherto unknown nation where many wonderful thing be find they tell we farther that the portuguese who have be in these remote part have reap great advantage by trading with the inhabitant have gain as high as 700 or even 1000 per cent on the capital employ we be all much astonished at these thing and i cada mosto in particular be inflamed with the desire of visit these newly discover region inquire if the prince permit any person who might be so inclined to embark for these place to this they answer in the affirmative and they likewise state to I the condition on which any one would be allow to make the adventure these be either to be at the whole expence of fitting out and freight a vessel or at the expence of the freight only the prince provide a vessel in the former case the adventurer have to allow on he return one quarter of he cargo as duty to the prince the rest remain he own entire propriety in the latter case the homeward cargo be to be equally divide between the prince and the adventurer in case of no return the prince be at the entire expence of the voyage but that it be hardly possible to make the voyage without great profit they add that the prince would be much pleased to have any venetian in he service and would shew he great favor being of opinion that spice and other rich merchandise might be find in these part and know that the venetian understand these commodity better than any other nation influence by all this i accompany the secretary and consul on shore and wait on the prince who confirm all those thing which they have say and encourage I to embark in the voyage to he new country by promise of honor and profit be young and of a constitution to endure fatigue and desirous to visit those part of the world which have never be even know to any venetian and likewise in hope to advance my fortune i accept of the invitation have therefore procure information respect the commodity which it be proper to carry with I on such a voyage i return to the gally where i dispose of all the goods i have ship for the low country and carry to land such thing as be necessary for my intended expedition and leave the gally to pursue they voyage to flander i land in portugal the prince evince much satisfaction at my resolution and entertain I handsomely at sagre for a considerable time at length he order I to fit out a new caravel of about ninety ton burden of which vincent diaz a native of lago about sixteen mile from sagre be commander the caravel be in readiness and furnish with every thing necessary for the voyage we set sail on the 22d of march 1455 have a favourable wind at north-east and by north -lrb- 2 -rrb- and steer we course for the island of madeira on the 25th of that month we come to the island of _ puerto santo _ which be about 600 mile southward from cape st vincent whence we take we departure puerto santo be discover by the portuguese on all saint day about the year 1418 -lrb- 3 -rrb- and don henry first send inhabitant to settle there under bartholomew perestrello whom he appoint governor it be about fifteen mile in circuit -lrb- 4 -rrb- it bear good bread corn and a sufficiency of oats for its own use and abound with cattle and wild hog and innumerable rabbit -lrb- 5 -rrb- among other tree it produce the drago or dragon tree the sap or juice of which be draw out only at certain season of the year when it issue from cut or cleft make with a axe near the bottom of the tree in the preceding year these cleft be find full of a kind of gum which decoct and depurate be the dragon - blood of the apothecary -lrb- 6 -rrb- the tree bear a yellow fruit round like like a cherry and well taste this island produce the best honey and wax in the world but not in any quantity it have no harbor but a good road in which vessel may moor in safety be well sheltered on all side except the quarter between the south and east all of which wind make it unsafe to ride here at anchor there be plenty of excellent fish on its shore such as dentili gilded fish and other from puerto santo which be discover twenty-seven year before we sail on the 28th of march and come the same day to _ monchrico _ or machico one of the port of the island of madeira forty mile distant from puerto santo in fair weather these island may be see from each other this latter island be only inhabit within the last twenty-four year when the prince appoint two of he gentleman to be its governor tristan vaz have the government of that half of the island in which the port of monchrico be situate and the other district of the island in which fonzal fonchial or funchal stand be under the government of john gonzale zarcho the island of madeira be inhabit in four several place : monchrico santa cruz fonzal and camera-di-lupus which be its principal place though there be other minor establishment and be able to muster about 800 man able to bear arm of whom a hundred be horse there be about eight river which pervade the island in different place by means of which they have many saw-mill from which portugal and other place be supply with board of many different sort of these board two sort be in particular estimation and turn most to account the one be cedar which have a strong odoriferous smell and resemble the cypress tree of this they make fine large and long board or deal which they employ for build house and for various other purpose the other call nasso -lrb- 7 -rrb- be of a red-rose color and extremely beautiful of which they make excellent and very beautiful bow and cross-bow which be send into the west in order to clear the land the first settler set fire to the wood and the fire spread with such fury that several person with they family and gonzale zarcho among the rest be force to take shelter in the sea to save themselves from the flame where they stand up to they neck for two day and two night without sustenance though this island be mountainous its soil be rich and fertile and it produce yearly 30000 venetian _ staras _ -lrb- 8 -rrb- of bread corn at first the newly cultivate land yield seventy for one but have since be reduce to thirty or forty for want of good husbandry owe to the excellence of its soil and climate and the abundance of spring and river prince henry procure sugar cane from sicily which he send to this island where they have yield abundant produce insomuch that 400 cantaro of sugar each contain 112 pound large weight of venice have be make at one boil and the quantity be likely to increase -lrb- 9 -rrb- they have likewise good wine consider how shortly this culture have be introduce and in such abundance that large quantity be export among other kind of vine don henry send thither _ malvasium _ plant procure from the island of candium which have succeed well the soil have turn out so favourable for the vine that in general there be more grape than leaf and the bundle be very large even from two to four span long they have likewise the black _ pergola _ grape without stone in great perfection and so well be the climate adapt to this culture that they begin they vintage about easter or at least by the octave after we sail from madeira follow a southerly course and arrive at the canary island which be at the distance of about 320 mile from madeira there be seven of these island in all four of which have be settle by the christian lanerotta fuerteventura gomera and ferro over which herrera -lrb- 10 -rrb- a spanish gentleman be lord large quantity of a herb call _ oricello _ or orchel -lrb- 11 -rrb- be annually send from these island to cadiz and seville which be use in die and be send from these place to all part of europe great quantity of excellent goat skin be export from these island which likewise produce abundance of tallow and good cheese the original inhabitant of the four island that be subject to the christian be _ canarian _ -lrb- 12 -rrb- who speak various language or dialect not well understand between the different tribe these people have only open village without any fortification except on the mountain which be exceedingly high and there they have a kind of rude wall or redoubt to flee to in case of need the pass of these mountain be so difficult of access that a few resolute man might defend they against a army the other three island of this group grand canarium teneriffe and palma which be larger and better peopled than the other four be still unsubdued and possess by the aboriginal idolater grand canarium have between eight and nine thousand soul and teneriffe which be the largest of all these island be say to contain fourteen or fifteen thousand and be divide into nine separate lordship palma however have very few inhabitant yet it appear to be a very beautiful island every lordship seem to have its own mode of religious worship as in teneriffe there be no less than nine different kind of idolatry some worship the sun other the moon and so forth they practice polygamy and the lord have the jus primae noctis which be consider as confer great honor on the accession of any new lord it be customary for some person to offer themselves to die as a sacrifice to he honor on this occasion the lord hold a great festival on he accession day when all who be willing to give this cruel proof of they attachment be attend to the summit of a high cliff in a certain valley where after some peculiar ceremony and certain word mutter over they the victim precipitate themselves from the cliff and be dash to piece in reward of this sanguinary homage the lord consider themselves bind to heap extraordinary honor and reward on the parent of the victim teneriffe which be the largest of these island and the best inhabit be one of highest island in the world and be see in clear weather from a great distance insomuch that i be inform by some mariner that it have be descry at the distance of between sixty and seventy spanish league which make about 250 italian mile in the middle of the island there be a prodigiously high peaked mountain shape like a diamond which be always burn i receive this account from some christian who have be prisoner in the island who affirm that it be fifteen portuguese league or sixty italian mile from the bottom of the mountain to the top of the peak they have nine lord on this island who be call duke and who do not succeed by inheritance or descent but by force on which account they have perpetual civil war among themselves in which they commit great slaughter they only weapon be stone mace or club and dart or lance some of which be point with horn and other have they point harden in the fire they all go naked except a few who wear goat skin before and behind they anoint they skin with goat tallow mix up with the juice of certain herb which thicken the skin and defend they against the cold of which they complain much although they country be so far to the south they have neither walled nor thatched house but dwell in grotto and cavern of the mountain they feed on barley flesh and goat milk of which they have abundance and some fruit particularly fig as the country be very hot they reap they corn in April and may we learn all these thing from the christian of the four settle island who sometimes go over by night to the three other island and make prisoner of the native whom they send into spain to be sell as slave sometimes the spaniard be themselves make prisoner on these expedition on which occasion the native do not put they to death but employ they to kill and flea they goat and to cure the flesh which they look upon as a vile employment and therefore condemn they christian prisoner to that labor in contempt the native canarian be very active and nimble and be exceedingly agile in run and leap be accustom to traverse the cliff of they rugged mountain they skip barefoot from rock to rock like goat and sometimes take leap of most surprising extent and danger which be scarcely to be believe they throw stone with great strength and wonderful exactness so as to hit whatever they aim at with almost perfect certainty and almost with the force of a bullet from a musket insomuch that a few stone throw by they will break a buckler to piece i once see a native canarian who have become a christian who offer to give three person twelve orange a-piece and take twelve to himself engage at eight or ten pace distance to strike he antagonist with every one of he orange and at the same time to parry all theirs so that they should hit no part of he but he hand but no one would take up the wager as they all know he could perform even better than he mention i be on land in gomera and ferro and touch also at the island of palma but do not land there -lrb- 1 -rrb- in grynaeus the azanaghus and the country of tegazza _ leave the canary we pursue we course towards ethiopium and arrive in a few day at cape branco which be about 870 mile from these island in this passage steer south we keep at a great distance from the african shore on we leave as the canary be far-advanced into the sea towards the west we stand almost directly south for two-third of the way between the island and the cape after which we change we course somewhat more towards the east or left-hand that we might fall in with the land lest we should have overpass the cape without see it because no land appear afterwards so far to the west for a considerable space the coast of africa to the southward of cape bronco fall in considerably to the eastward form a great bay or gulf call the _ forna of arguin _ from a small island of that name this gulf extend about fifty mile into the land and have three other island one of which be name _ branco _ by the portuguese or the white island on account of its white sand the second be call _ garze _ or the isle of heron where they find so many egg of certain seabird as to load two boat the third be call _ curous _ or cori these island be all small sandy and uninhabited in that of arguin there be plenty of fresh water but there be none in any of the other it be proper to observe that on keep to the southwards from the strait of gibraltar the coast of exterior barbary be inhabit no farther than cape cantin -lrb- 1 -rrb- from whence to cape branco be the sandy country or desert call _ saara _ or _ saharra _ by the native which be divide from barbary or morocco on the north by the mountain of atla and border on the south with the country of the negro and would require a journey of fifty day to cross -- in some place more in other less this desert reach to the ocean and be all a white dry sand quite low and level so that no part of it seem higher than any other cape _ branco _ or the white cape so name by the portuguese from its white color without tree or verdure be a noble promontory of a triangular shape have three separate point about a mile from each other innumerable quantity of large and excellent fish of various kind be catch on this coast similar in taste to those we have at venice but quite different in shape and appearance the gulf of arguin be shallow all over and be full of shoal both of rock and sand and as the current be here very strong there be no sailing except by day and even then with the lead constantly heave two ship have be already lose on these shoal cape _ branco _ lie sw of cape cantin or rather s and by w behind cape branco there be a place call hoden six day journey inland on camel which be not walled but be much frequent by the arab and caravan which trade between tombucto -lrb- 2 -rrb- and other place belong to the negro and the western part of barbary the provision at hoden be date and barley which they have in plenty and the inhabitant drink the milk of camel and other animal as they have no wine they have some cow and goat the former be greatly smaller than those of italy but the number of these be not great as the country be very dry the inhabitant be all mahometan and great enemy to the christian and have no settle habitation but wander continually over the desert they frequent the country of the negro and visit that side of barbary which be next the mediterranean on these expedition they travel in numerous caravan with great train of camel carry brass silver and other article to tombucto and the country of the negro whence they bring back gold and _ melhegette _ or cardamom seed -lrb- 3 -rrb- these people be all of a tawny color and both sex wear a single white garment with a red border without any linen next they skin the man wear turban in the moorish fashion and go always barefoot in the desert there be many lion leopard and ostrich the egg of which i have often eat and find they very good don henry have farm out the trade of the island of arguin under the follow regulation no person must enter this gulf to trade with the arab except those who be licensed accord to the ordinance and have habitation and factor on the island and have be accustom to transact business with the arab on that coast the article of merchandize chiefly provide for this trade be woollen cloth and linen silver trinket _ aldtizelus _ or frock and cloak and other thing and above all wheat and the arab give in return negro slave and gold a castle have be build on the isle of arguin by order of the prince to protect this trade on account of which caravel or ship arrive there every year from portugal the arab of this coast have many barbary horse which they carry to the country of the negro which they barter with the great man for slave receive from ten to eighteen man for each horse accord to they goodness they also carry thither silken staff of granada and tuni with silver and many other thing in return for which they receive great number of slave and some gold these slave be bring first to hoden in the desert and thence by the mountain of barka into barbary whence they be transport across the mediterranean into sicily part of they be sell in tuni and in other place along the coast of barbary and the rest be bring to arguin where they be sell to the licensed portuguese trader who purchase between seven and eight hundred every year and send they for sale into portugal before the establishment of this trade at arguin the portuguese use to send every year four or more caravel to the bay of arguin the crew of which landing well arm in the night be in use to surprise some of the fishing village and carry off the inhabitant into slavery they even penetrate sometimes a considerable way into the interior and carry off the arab of both sex whom they sell as slave in portugal leave arguin we sail along the coast to the river senegal -lrb- 4 -rrb- which be very large and divide the people call azanaghus or azanhajus from the first kingdom of the negro the azanhajus be of a tawny color or rather of a deep brown complexion and inhabit some part of the coast beyond cape branco range through the desert and they district reach to the confines of the arab of hoden they live on date barley and the milk of camel but as they border likewise on the country of the negro they carry on trade with these people from whom they procure millet and pulse particularly bean owe to the scarcity of provision in the desert the azanhajus be but spare eater and be able to endure hunger with wonderful patience as a poringer of barley-meal make into hasty-pudding will serve they a whole day the portuguese use to carry away many of these people for slave as they be prefer to the negro but for some time past this have be prohibit by don henry and peace and trade have be establish with they as he be in hope they may be easily bring over to the catholic faith by intercourse with the christian more especially as they be not hitherto thoroughly establish in the superstition of mahomet of which they know nothing but by hearsay these azenhajus have a odd custom of wear a handkerchief round they head a part of which be bring down so as to cover they eye and even they nose and mouth for they reckon the mouth a unclean part because it be constantly belching and have a bad smell and ought therefore to be keep out of sight even compare it to the posterior and think that both ought alike to be conceal on this account they never let they mouth be see except when eat as i have often have occasion to observe they have no lord among they but the rich man be respect somewhat more than the rest they be of ordinary stature and very lean wear they black hair frizzle over they shoulder like the german and grease it daily with fish oil which give they a nasty smell yet they consider this as modish they be extremely poor egregious liar the greatest thief in the world and very treacherous they have never hear of any christian except the portuguese with whom they have war for thirteen or fourteen year in which many of they be carry off as slave as have be already mention many of these people inform I that when they first see ship under sail which have never be behold by any of they ancestor they take they for large bird with white wing that have come from foreign part and when the sail be furl they conjecture from they length and swimming on the water that they must be great fish other again believe that they be spirit who wander about by night because they be see at anchor in the evening at one place and would be see next morning 100 mile off either proceed along the coast to the southward or put back accord as the wind change or the caravel might happen to steer they could not conceive how human being could travel more in one night than they be able to perform themselves in three day by which they be confirm in the notion of the ship be spirit all this be certify to I by many of the azanhajus who be slave in portugal as well as by the portuguese mariner who have frequent the coast in they caravel about six day journey by land from hoden there be a place call teggazza -lrb- 5 -rrb- which in we language signify a chest or bag of gold in this place large quantity of salt be dig up every year and carry by caravan on camel to _ tombucto _ and thence to the empire of _ mellus _ which belong to the negro oh arrive there they dispose of they salt in the course of eight day at the rate of between two and three hundred _ mitigal _ or ducat for each load accord to the quantity and then return with they gold -lrb- 1 -rrb- this be erroneous as there be several town on the coast of morocco beyond this cape as saffium mogadore santa cruz and other cape cantin be in lat 32  30 'n and the river
