mellus and some curious particulars of the salt trade : of the trade in gold : of the azanhajus and concern swarm of locust _ the empire of mellus of which some mention have be make in the precede section be situate in a extremely hot climate and afford very bad nourishment for beast insomuch that out of a hundred camel which go from the desert into that country scarcely twenty-five return several even of the arab and azanhajus belong to the caravan sicken and die likewise every year there be no quadruped keep by the native of the country as indeed none can live there for any time it be reckon to be forty day journey on horseback from tegazza to tombuctu and thirty from thence to mellus -lrb- 1 -rrb- have inquire what use the merchant of mellus make of this salt the trader of the desert inform I that a part of it be consume in that country which lie near the line where the day and night be of equal length certain season of the year be so excessively hot that the blood of the inhabitant would putrify if it be not for the salt and they would all die they have no art or mystery in its use but every one dissolve a small piece every day in a porringer of water and drink it off which in they opinion preserve they health the remainder of the salt be carry a long way in piece on men head every piece be as large as a man can well bear as bring from teggazza the salt be in large piece as take out of the mine each camel be load with two piece and the negro break these down into smaller piece for the convenience of carry they on they head and muster a large number of footman for this yearly traffic these porter have each a long fork stick in they hand and when tire they rest they load on these stick they proceed in this manner till they arrive on the bank of a certain water but whether fresh or salt my informer could not say yet i be of opinion that it must be a river because if it be the sea the inhabitant could not be in want of salt in so hot a climate the negro be hire to carry it in this manner for want of camel or other beast of burden as already mention and from what have be say it may easily be conclude that the number both of the carrier and consumer must be very great when arrive at the water side the proprietor of the salt place they share in heap in a row at small distance set each a particular mark on he own heap and when this be do the whole company retire half a day journey from the place then the other negro who be the purchaser of the salt who seem to be the inhabitant of certain island but who will on no account be see or speak to come in boat to the place where the heap of salt be place and after lay a sum in gold on each heap as its price retire in they turn after they be go the owner of the salt return and if the quantity of gold on they heap be satisfactory to they they take it away and leave the salt if not they leave both and withdraw again in this manner they carry on they traffick without see or speak to each other and this custom be very ancient among they as have be affirm to I for truth by several merchant of the desert both arab and azanhajus and other creditable person -lrb- 2 -rrb- on inquire how it come to pass that the emperor of mellus whom they represent as a powerful sovereign do not find means by friendship or force to discover who these people be who would not suffer themselves to be see or talk to i be inform that this emperor not many year ago resolve to procure some of these invisible people and hold a council on the occasion in which the follow plan be devise and carry into execution before the salt caravan return the half day journey from they salt heap some of the emperor people make certain pit by the water side and near the place where the salt be leave and when the negro come to deposit they gold on the salt those who be conceal in the pit attack they suddenly and take four of they prisoner all the rest make they escape three of those who be thus take be immediately set free by the captor who judge that one would be quite sufficient to satisfy the curiosity of they emperor and that the negro would be the less offended but after all the design prove abortive for though speak to in various language the prisoner would neither speak or take any victuals and die at the end of four day on this account the mellus negro conclude that these other negro be dumb but other be of opinion that be endow with the human form they must necessarily have the power of speech but that find himself treat in this manner so contrary to ancient custom he refuse to speak from indignation this untoward result be much regret by the negro of mellus because it prevent they from gratify the curiosity of they emperor who on be inform of this person death be much dissatisfied yet ask what manner of man the prisoner be he be accordingly inform that they be of a deep black color well shaped and a span taller than the native of mellus that they under lip be thicker than a man fist of a very red color and hang down on they breast with something like blood drop from it but that they upper lip be small like those of other man that the form of the under lip expose they gum and tooth which be larger than they own have great tooth in each corner of they mouth with large black eye and altogether a terrible appearance as the gum drop blood continually as well as the great hanging under lip this cross accident prevent all the succeed emperor of mellus from make any farther attempt of the kind because from that time these negro forbear for three year from come to buy salt as usual it be believe that they lip begin to putrify through the excessive heat of the climate and be no longer able to endure a distemper of which some must have die for want of the effectual remedy which they have experience from the use of salt they return of they own accord to traffic for that commodity in the old way all this have establish a opinion that they can not live without salt the negro of mellus judge of the case of other by they own as for the emperor of mellus he care not whether these black will speak and be see or not so that that he have the profit of they gold -lrb- 3 -rrb- this be all i could learn on this subject which i think may be credit as so many person have vouch for its truth of which i who have both see and hear of many wonderful thing in this world be perfectly satisfy the gold bring to mellus be divide into three part one part be send by the caravan which go annually from mellus to _ kokhium _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- which lie on the road to syrium and cairo the other two part go first to tombuctu whence one of they go by _ toet _ -lrb- 5 -rrb- to tuni and other port of the barbary coast and the other portion be carry to hoden and from thence to _ oran _ and _ one _ -lrb- 6 -rrb- town in barbary which be within the strait of gibraltar and to fez morocco arzilum azafus and messa town on the african coast of the atlantic where the italian and other christian procure it from the moor in return for various commodity gold be the best and principal commodity which come through the country of the azanhajus and a part of it be bring every year from hoden to arguin where it be barter with the portuguese -lrb- 7 -rrb- no money be coin in the land of the _ tawny moor _ or azenhajus nor be any money use by they or in any of the neighbouring country but all they trade be carry on by bartering one commodity against another in some of they inland town the arab and azanbajus use small white porcelain shell or cowrie which be bring from the levant to venice and send from thence into africa these be use for small purchase the gold be sell by a weight name _ mitigal _ which be nearly equal in value to a ducat the inhabitant of the desert have neither religion nor sovereign but those who be richest and have the greatest number of retainer and dependent be consider as chief or lord the woman be tawny and wear cotton garment which be manufacture in the country of the negro but some of they wear a kind of cloak or upper garment call alkhezelus and they have no smock she who have the largest and longest breast be repute the greatest beauty on which account when they have attain to the age of seventeen or eighteen and they breast be somewhat grow they tie a cord very tight around the middle of each breast which press very hard and break they so that they hang down and by pull at these cord frequently they grow longer and longer till at length in some woman they reach as low as the navel the man of the desert ride on horseback after the fashion of the moor and the desert be everywhere very hot and have very little water and extremely barren they can keep very few horse and those they have be short live it only rain in the month of August September and October i be inform that vast swarm of locust appear in this country some year in such infinite number as to darken the air and even to hide the sun from view cover the horizon as far as the eye can reach which be from twelve to sixteen mile in compass and wherever they settle they strip the ground entirely bare these locust be like grasshopper as long as one finger and of a red and yellow color they come every third or fourth year and if they be to pay they visit every year there would be no living in the country while i be on the coast i see they in prodigious and incredible number -lrb- 1 -rrb- the distance between tisheet and tombuctu accord to we best map be about 560 mile e and by s in the same proportion suppose tisheet to be teggazza the distance between tombuctu and mellus ought to be about 420 mile of mellus we have no trace in we modern map but it may possibly be refer to _ malel _ the apparent capital of lamlem see pinkert geogr ii 917 as lay down from the arabian geographer nearly 1200 mile ese from tombuctu -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- this story be probably a fiction proceeding upon a trade of barter between party who do not understand the language of each other the succeed part of the story seem a mere fable without the smallest foundation whatever -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- few person perhaps will be dispose to think the credit of the african however positive or the belief of the author however strong sufficient evidence of the truth of this story yet it certainly be a common report of the country and not the invention of cada mosto jobson who be at the gambra or gambium in 1620 repeat the whole substance of this story and movette relate the circumstance of the black trafficking for salt without be see which he have from the moor of morocco he leave out however the story of the frightful lip every fiction have its day and that part be now out of date -- astl -lrb- 4 -rrb- mellus be itself unknown we can hardly look to discover the situation of kokhium or cochium but it may possibly be kuku a town and district to the ne of bornou which lie in the direction of the text or it may be dar kullum greatly more to the sw but still in lat 21  30 ' n -- e -lrb- 6 -rrb- call hona in grynaeus what part of barbary this name may refer to do not appear but the passage ought perhaps to run thus _ to oran by the mountain of wan _ as there be a range mountain of that name to the s e of oran which join the chain of atla or the ammer mountain -- e -lrb- 7 -rrb- this be the earliest account of the place from whence gold be bring and of the course of its trade through africa and thence into europe and be even more particular and exact than any that have be give by later author -- astl section iv _ of the river senegal and the jalof with some account of the manners custom government religion and dress of that nation _ leave cape branco and the gulf of arguin we continue we course along the coast to the river senegal which divide the desert and the tawny azanhajus from the fruitful land of the negro five year before i go on this voyage this river be discover by three caravel belong to don henry which enter it and they commander settle peace and trade with the moor since which time ship have be send to this place every year to trade with the native -lrb- 1 -rrb- the river senegal be of considerable size be a mile wide at the mouth and of sufficient depth a little farther on it have another entrance and between the two there be a island which form a cape run into the sea have sand - bank at each mouth that extend a mile from the shore -lrb- 2 -rrb- all ship that frequent the senegal ought carefully to observe the course of the tide the flux and reflux of which extend for seventy mile up the river as i be inform by certain portuguese who have be a great way up this river with they caravel from cape branco which be 280 mile distant the whole coast be sandy till within twenty mile of the river this be call the coast of _ anterota _ and belong entirely to the azanhajus or tawny moor i be quite astonished to find so prodigious a difference in so narrow a space as appear at the senegal : for on the south side of the river the inhabitant be all exceedingly black tall corpulent and well proportioned and the country all clothe in fine verdure and full of fruit tree whereas on the north side of the river the man be tawny meager and of small stature and the country all dry and barren this river in the opinion of the learn be a branch of the _ gihon _ which flow from the terrestrial paradise and be name the niger by the ancient which flow through the whole of ethiopium and which on approach the ocean to the west divide into many other branch the _ nile _ which be another branch of the gihon fall into the mediterranean after flow through egypt -lrb- 3 -rrb- the first kingdom of the negro be on the bank of the senegal and its inhabitant be call _ gilofi _ or jalof all the country be low not only from the north to that river but also beyond it as far south as cape verd which be the highest land on all this coast and be 400 mile from cape branco this kingdom of the jalof on the senegal be bound on the east by the country call _ tukhusor _ on the south by the kingdom of _ gambra _ or gambium on the west by the atlantic ocean and on the north by the river senegal and the azanhajus -lrb- 4 -rrb- the king who reign in senegal in my time be name zukholin and be twenty-two year old this kingdom be not hereditary but for the most part three or four of the principal lord of whom there be many in the country choose a king in the event of a vacancy but always fix they choice on a person of noble lineage who reign only as long as he give satisfaction to these great lord they often dethrone they king by force who on the other hand often render themselves so powerful as to stand on they defense this render the government unsettled and be productive of civil war similar to egypt where the soldan of cairo be always in fear of be kill or banish the people be savage and extremely poor have no walled town and they village be entirely compose of thatched cottage they use neither lime nor stone in building not know how to make the one or to form the other the kingdom of the jalof be small and as i be inform extend only 300 mile along the coast and about the same distance inland the king have no settled revenue but the lord of the country court he favor by make he yearly present of horse which be scarce be in high estimation together with horse furniture cow and goat pulse millet and other thing he likewise increase he wealth by means of robbery and by reduce he own subject and those of neighbouring province to slavery employ a part of these slave to cultivate the land which be assign to he and sell the rest to the arab and azanhajus trader who bring horse and other thing for sale as likewise to the christian since they have establish a trade in these part every man may keep as many wife as he please the king have always upward of thirty and distinguish they accord to they descent and the rank of the lord whose daughter they be he keep they in certain village of he own eight or ten in one place each have a separate house to dwell in with a certain number of young woman to attend she and slave to cultivate the land which be assign for she maintenance which they sow and reap and to tend she cow and goat when the king come to any of these village he bring no provision along with he as he woman be oblige to support he and he retinue whenever he visit they every morning at sunrise each of he wife in the village where he happen to reside prepare three or four dish of various viand such as flesh fish or other dainty cook in they fashion which be carry by the slave to the king pantry so that in less than a hour thirty or forty dish be provide and when the king have a mind to eat he find every thing ready at he command when he have eat of such thing as he like best the remainder be give to he retinue but as this diet be never very plentiful they be but poorly feed he travel about in this manner from place to place visit he several wife by which mean he have a very numerous issue and whenever one of he wife happen to fall with child he visit she no more the lord or chief of the country live in a similar manner these negro profess I mahometan religion but be not even so well instruct in it as the tawny moor more especially the common people the lord have always about they some arab or azanhajus for this purpose who inculcate on they mind that it would be disgraceful for man of they quality to live in ignorance of the law of god like the common people who have no religion they have become mahometan merely by means of they intercourse with the azanhajus and arab for since they become acquaint with the christian they be by no means so fond of the mahometan faith the generality of the negro go quite naked except a piece of goat skin before but the lord who be able to procure such wear cotton shirt which be spin and manufacture by they woman they web be only a span in width as they have not sufficient art to construct and use wider loom so that they be oblige to sew five six or more of these web together when it be require to make any large piece of work the shirt reach half way down the thigh and have wide sleeve which cover only half of they arm they wear also cotton drawer reach to the small of they leg and these drawer be make preposterously wide be often thirty-five or forty palm in circumference so that when tie on they be full of plait and though like a sack before the hinder part trail on the ground like the train of a large petticoat thus though make a most ridiculous appearance they think nothing come up to they dress for elegance and they often ask the european if they ever see a finer dress they woman both married and unmarried go naked from the waist upward and wear a piece of cotton which cover they from the waist to the middle of the leg both sex go barefooted and have no covering to they head and weave and tie they hair though short into neat tress the man often employ themselves in women work such as spin wash clothes and such like employment this country be extremely hot the month of January be not so cold as it be with we in italy in the month of April and the farther we go to the south the weather become so much the hotter both man and woman wash themselves four or five time a-day and be very cleanly in they person but be by no means so in regard of eat in which they observe no rule although very ignorant and extremely awkward in any thing to which they have not be accustom they be as expert as any european can be in they own business and in all thing with which they be acquaint they be full of word and extremely talkative and be for the most part liar and cheat yet they be exceedingly hospitable and charitably dispose as they will most readily give a dinner or a supper or a night lodge to any stranger who come to they house without expect any remuneration or reward the chief of these negro be often at war against each other or against the neighbouring tribe or nation but they have no cavalry for want of horse in war they only defensive armor be a large target make of the skin of a animal call _ danta _ which be very difficultly pierced and they principal weapon be _ azagay _ or light dart which they throw with great dexterity these dart be point with iron the length of a span and barb in different direction so that they make dangerous wound and tear the flesh extremely when pull out they have also a moorish weapon much-bent like a turkish sword or cimeter and make of iron without any steel which they procure from the negro on the river gambium as they either have no iron in they own country or want knowledge or industry in work it have but few weapon or rather no missile they war be very bloody as they soon come to close quarter and they stroke seldom fall in vain and be extremely fierce and courageous they will rather allow themselves to be slay as save themselves by flight neither be they dishearten by see they companion slay they have no ship nor have they ever see any before the portuguese come upon they coast but those who dwell upon the river senegal and some who be settle on the sea coast have _ zoppoly _ or canoe call _ almadias _ by the portuguese which be hollow out of a single piece of wood the largest of which will carry three or four man they use these almadia for catch fish and for transport themselves up or down the river the negro of this country be the most expert swimmer in the world as i can vouch from frequent experience of they dexterity -lrb- 1 -rrb- cada mosto be incorrect in the chronology of this discovery and even de barros be not quite decide as to the first discovery of the senegal he say that deni fernandez _ pass _ it in 1446 and that lancerot _ discover _ it in 1447 the latter of which be eight year before the visit of cada mosto -- clarke -lrb- 2 -rrb- the northern mouth of the senegal be in lat 16  40 ' the southern in 15  45 ' both n so that the distance between they or the length of the island mention in the text be about sixty-two mile -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- this fancy of all the great river in africa be branch from one principal stream be now know to be entirely erroneous -- astl -lrb- 4 -rrb- although the first kingdom or kingdom of the negro lie on the senegal senega or sanagha and other along the gambium yet there be not tribe of people and not under any one sovereign geographer however have since continue to propagate this first error -- astl the jalof and foulah inhabit the country between the senegal and gambium on name budomel with some account of he territory and the manners of he people _ have pass the river senegal we sail about 800 mile farther south along the coast which be all low land without mountain till we come to the territory or kingdom of budomel -lrb- 1 -rrb- as some portuguese who have deal with budomel represent he as a very just person who pay for any goods he might receive and might therefore be confide in i stop at he country that i might endeavor to dispose of some spanish horse i have on board which be in great request among the negro besides which i have some cloth moorish work silk and other commodity for sale we come therefore to anchor at a place on the coast call palma di budomel which be only a open roadstead and not a port i immediately dispatch my negro interpreter on shore to inform this lord of my arrival and of the goods i have on board for sale not long afterwards budomel come himself to the beach attend by about fifteen horseman and a hundred and fifty foot and send a message desire I to land with profession of a friendly disposition and promise to render I every attention and service in he power i go accordingly on shore immediately and be receive with great civility after some discourse i deliver to he seven horse with they furniture and every other article for which he express a inclination all of which have cost I 300 ducat trust to he honor for payment which be to be in slave and which he promise to deliver at he own residence which be twenty-five mile distant from the shore whither he invite I to accompany he to this invitation i readily agree induce as much by a desire of see the country as on account of receive payment before set out however budomel make I a present of a beautiful negress about twelve year of age who he say be mean to serve I in the cabin and i receive the gift and send she on board the caravel i be furnish by budomel with horse and every thing necessary for the journey and when we arrive within four mile of he residence he give I in charge to he nephew bisboror who be lord of a small town or village at which we stop bisboror take I to he own house where i be treat with much civility and attention during twenty-eight day which i tarry in that place this be in November 1455 in that time i go often to visit budomel accompany by he nephew and have many opportunity to observe the produce of the country and the manners of the inhabitant more especially as on account of the tempestuous weather i be under the necessity of travel back by land to the river senegal for find it impossible to get on board at the coast by reason of the surf i have to order the ship to return to that river and go there by land to re-embark on this occasion be very desirous to transmit instruction to those on board the ship to meet I at the river senegal i inquire among the negro if any one would undertake to carry a letter from the shore several of they readily offer they service though the ship lay three mile from the shore and owe to a strong wind the sea break on the shore with a tremendous surf insomuch that i think it impossible for any one to succeed in the attempt besides the surf there be several sand bank near the shore and other bank about half way to the ship between which there run a strong current sometimes one way and sometimes the other along shore so that it be extremely difficult for any one to swim through without infinite danger of be carry away by the stream and the sea break with such violence on the bank that it seem quite impossible to surmount such complicated obstacle yet two of the negro offer to go and only demand two _ mavulgy _ of tin for each of they one mavulgus be worth no more than a _ grosso _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- at which price they engage to carry my letter in safety to the ship i can not express the difficulty which they encounter in pass the sand bank they be sometimes out of sight for a considerable space so that i often think they be both drown at last one of they find himself unable to resist the violence with which the wave break over he turn back but the other be stronger get over the bank after struggle a whole hour and have carry the letter to the caravel return with a answer this seem to I very wonderful and make I conclude that the negro of this coast must be the most expert swimmer in the world it have be already observe that those who be call lord in this country have neither castle nor city the king even have nothing but village with thatched house budomel be lord of one part of this kingdom yet he place of residence be not a palace nor even a walled house these great man be not lord on account of they riches or treasure as they possess neither nor have they any coin in use among they but they be consider as such out of courtesy and on account of the great retinue by which they be always attend be more fear and respect by they subject than any of the lord in italy budomel have several village appoint for he own habitation and that of he wife as he never fix in one place the village in which i reside with bisboror be one of he habitation contain between forty and fifty thatched cottage build near one another and surround with ditch and strong pallisade have only one or two passage leave for enter and every house have a court-yard inclose by a hedge accord to report budomel have nine wife in this place and more or less in several other village each of these wife have five or six young negress to attend upon she with all of whom he might sleep when he please without give offence to the wife for such be the custom of the country both sex be extremely amorous and budomel strongly importune I for philactery in which he have be inform the european be very expert and offer any reward within he power for my compliance they be very jealous and suffer no man to enter the house which be inhabit by the woman not even they own son budomel be always attend by a retinue of at least 200 negro who be change from time to time some go away and other come back in they room besides which many people repair to wait upon he from the adjacent place which be under he government before arrive at he particular apartment there be seven large court one within the other have a tree in the middle of each where those wait who come to he on business he family be distribute in these court accord to they several rank the most considerable have they station in the court nearest he dwelling and the meanest in the outermost court of all few people be allow to approach he own particular apartment except the christian and azanhajus who have free admission and more liberty be allow to they than to the negro this lord affect great state and gravity in he deportment and do not allow himself to be see except a hour every morning and for a short while in the evening at which time he appear near the door of a apartment in the first court into which only person of note be permit to enter on these occasion of give audience every person who come to speak to he however high may be he rank be in the first place oblige to strip himself stark naked except the small cloth in front formerly mention and immediately on enter the court he fall down on he knee bow down he head to the ground and scatter dust with both hand on he own head and shoulder neither be even the nearest relation of the lord exempt from this humiliating expression of they duty and obedience the person who receive a audience continue in this humble posture a great while strew himself with sand and crawl on he knee till he approach the great man and when within two pace of he lord he stop and begin to relate he case still continue on he knee with he head down and throw sand a he head in token of great humility all the time the lord scarcely appear to notice he and continue to discourse with other person and when the vassal have relate he story the lord give he a answer in two word with a arrogant aspect such be they affected pride and grandeur and such the submission which be shewn he which in my opinion proceed from fear as they lord for every little fault they commit take away they wife and child and cause they to be sell as slave budomel treat I with the utmost attention and civility and use to carry I in the evening into a sort of mosque where the arab and azanhaji priest whom he have always about he person use to say prayer he manner on these occasion be as follow be enter into the mosque which be in one of the court belong to he residence and where he be attend by some of the principal negro he first stand some little time with he eye lift up as if it be to heaven then advance two step he speak a few word in a low tone after which he stretch himself on the ground which he kiss the azanhajus and the rest of he attendant do the same then rise up he repeat the same series of action repeatedly for ten or twelve time which occupy about half a hour when all be over he ask my opinion of they manner of worship and desire one to give a account of the nature of we religion on this i tell he in the presence of all he doctor that the religion of mahomet be false and the romish the only true faith this make the arab and azanhajus extremely angry but budomel laugh on the occasion and say that he consider the religion of the christian to be good as god alone could have gifted they with so much riches and understand he add however that in he opinion the mahometan law must be good also and he believe that the negro be more sure of salvation than the christian because god be just who have give a paradise to the christian in this world and would certainly give one to the negro in the next as they possess scarcely any good in this world in comparison in all he discourse he shew a good understanding and take great pleasure in hear the custom of the christian describe i firmly believe he might easily have be convert to christianity have it not be from fear of lose he power as i be often tell by he nephew with whom i lodged and he take great delight in hearing I discourse of we religion the table of budomel like all other lord and people of condition in this country be supply by he wife in the same manner as have be already mention in regard to zukholin the king of senegal each wife send he a certain number of dish every day he and the other lord eat on the ground without any regularity or company except the arab and azanhajus who be they teacher and priest and one or two of they principal negro attendant the inferior people eat in mess of ten or twelve each have a basket full of victuals set in the midst into which all put they hand at the same time they eat but little at one meal but repeat these four or five time a day -lrb- 1 -rrb- the text seem corrupt in give so large a distance between the senegal river and this country of king budomel as 800 mile to the south or rather s s e would carry we to what be call the _ grain _ or windward coast of guinea in lat 6  n and from the sequel cada mosto do not appear to have pass cape verd till after quit the country of budomel accord to brue as quote by clarke the king of kayor or kayhor be style damel kayor or cayor appear on we map above a hundred mile up the senegal and on its north side which therefore can have no reference to the place in the text i be dispose to believe that the distance in the text ought only to have be 80 mile and that the territory of budomel be in the country of the jalof between the senegal and cape verd at the mouth of a small river on which we chart place two town masaye and enibaul in lat 15  20 ' n -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the grosso or venetian groat be worth about three farthing -- astl section vi _ account of the country of budomel continue _ on account of the great heat in the kingdom of senegal and all the other country of the negro on the coast no wheat rye barley or spelt can grow neither be vine cultivate as we know experimentally from a trial make with seed from we ship : for wheat and these other article of culture require a temperate climate and frequent shower both of which be want here where they have no rain during nine month of the year from October to June both include but they have large and small millet bean and the largest and finest kidney bean in the world as large as hazle nut longer than those of the venetian territory and beautifully speckled with various color as if paint they bean be large flat and of a lively red color and they have likewise white bean they sow in July at the beginning of the rain and reap in September when they cease thus they prepare the soil sow the seed and get in the harvest all in three month but they be bad husbandman and so exceedingly averse to labor that they sow no more than be barely sufficient to last they throughout the year and never lay up any store for sale in cultivate the ground four or five of they go into a field with spade with which they turn up the soil about four inch deep yet such be the fertility of the soil that it make ample return for this slight culture without any farther trouble the liquor of the negro be water milk and palm wine which they call mighol or migwol which be take from a tree of the palm tribe very numerous in this country somewhat like the date tree but not the same and which furnish this liquor the whole year round the tree be tap in two or three place near the root and from these wound a brown juice run out as thin as skimmed milk into calabass that be place to receive the liquor which drop but slowly as one tree will only fill two calabass from morning till night this migwol or palm - wine be a exceedingly pleasant drink which intoxicate like wine unless mix with water immediately after it be draw from the tree it be as sweet as any wine whatever but the luscious taste go off more and more as it be keep and at length it become sour it drink better than at first after three or four day as it depurate by keep and be not so sweet i have often drink of it indeed every day that i remain in the country and like it better than the wine of italy this liquor be not so abundant as that every one may have it at discretion yet all may have some especially the chief as the tree be not plant in garden like vine and fruit tree in europe but be find wild in the forest and be consequently accessible to all in this country there be several sort of fruit which resemble those of europe though not exactly the same and which be very good though they grow wild and be they to be cultivate as ours be would prove much better than such as be produce in the northern climate the quality of the soil and air in this part of africa be more nutritive the whole country be plain and fertile abound in good pasture and be cover by a infinite number of large and beautiful tree that be not know in europe it contain several lake of fresh water none of they large but very deep and full of excellent fish which differ much from those that be catch in italy and many water serpent which the native call _ kalkatrici _ they use a kind of oil with they victuals which taste like oil of olive have a pleasant flavor of violet and tinge the food even better than saffron but i could not learn what it be produce from -lrb- 1 -rrb- there be likewise a plant which produce large quantity of small kidney-bean in this country there be many kind of animal but serpent be particularly numerous both large and small some of which be venomous the large one be more than two pace long -lrb- 2 -rrb- but have neither leg nor wing as have be report by some person but some of they be so very thick as to have swallow a goat at one morsel these serpent retire in troops as the native report to certain part of the country where white ant be find in prodigious swarm and which by a kind of instinct be say to build house for these serpent of earth which they carry in they month for that purpose resemble oven and often to the number of 150 in one place -lrb- 3 -rrb- the negro be great enchanter and use charm upon almost all occasion particularly in regard to serpent over which they have great power a genoese worthy of credit who be in this country the year before my arrival and who likewise lodge with bisboror the nephew of budomel tell I he once hear a load noise of whistle about the house in the middle of the night be awaken by the noise he see bisboror get out of bed and order two negro to bring he camel be ask where he mean to go at that time of night he say he have business which must be execute but would soon return on come back after some time and the genoese express curiosity to learn the object in which he have be engage bisboror ask if he have hear the hissing noise about the house during the night and say that it have be make by the serpent which would have kill a great many of he cattle if he have not send they back to they quarter by the employment of certain enchantment the genoese be astonish at this story but bisboror say he have no need to wonder at this small matter as budomed could do a great deal more extraordinary thing with the serpent than he could in particular when he have a mind to envenom he weapon he use to draw a large circle into which by means of he enchantment he bring all the serpent of the neighborhood from which he select those he think most poisonous and allow all the other to go away with the blood of these serpent mix up with the seed of a certain tree he infect he weapon with so deadly a poison that if they draw but the least drop of blood the person or animal wound by they be sure to die in a quarter of a hour bisboror farther offer to shew he a example of the efficacy of this art but the genoese decline witness the experiment this story of the serpent be the more probable that i have hear of person in italy who could charm they in a similar manner but i be apt to believe that the negro be the most expert sorcerer in the world the only tame animal in the kingdom of senegal be oxen cow and goat have no sheep which love a temperate or cold air and could not live in this hot climate nature however have provide mankind with necessaries fit for they various occasion have furnish the european with wool as they have need of warm clothing while the negro who live in such intense heat have be supply with cotton by the almighty owing to the heat in my opinion the cattle of this country be much smaller than those of italy it be a great rarity to see a red cow in this country as they be all black or white or mottled with black and white spot beast of prey such as lion leopard and wolf be numerous and there be plenty of hare wild elephant go about in troops like the wild swine in italy but can never be tame as they be in other part of the world as the elephant be a well-known animal i shall only observe in general that those of africa be of a very large size as may be easily conceive by the size of they tooth which be import into europe of these large tooth or tusk rather each elephant have two in the lower jaw the point of which turn down whereas those of the wild boar be turn up before my voyage to africa i have be tell that the elephant could not bend its knee and sleep standing but this be a egregious falsehood for the bend of they knee can be plainly perceive when they walk and they certainly lie down and rise again like other animal they never shed they large tooth before death neither do they do any harm to man unless provoke in that case the elephant make he attack with he trunk which be a kind of nose protrude to a great length he can contract and extend this proboscis at pleasure and be able to toss a man with it as far as a sling can throw a stone it be in vain to think of escape by run let the person be ever so swift in case the elephant pursue in earnest as he stride be of prodigious length they be more dangerous when they have young one in they company than at any other time of which the female have only three or four at a birth they feed on the leaf and fruit of tree pull down the large bough with they trunk and bring they to they mouth this trunk be compose of a very thick cartilage and be pliable in every direction there be many kind of bird in this country and parrot be particularly numerous which be much hate by the negro because they do much damage to they crop of pulse and millet there be say to be several kind of parrot but i never see more than two one of these be like the kind which be bring into italy from alexandrium in egypt but rather smaller the other kind be much larger have a brown head neck bill and leg with a yellow and green body i procure a considerable number of both sort particularly of the smaller kind many of which die but i bring 150 back to portugal where i sell they for half a ducat each these bird be very industrious in construct they nest which they build with bulrush and the small leaf of the palm and other tree in a very curious and ingenious manner choose the slenderest branch of a tree the parrot fasten a bulrush of about two span long to its outer extremity at the depend end of which rush it weave its nest in a most beautiful manner suspend like a ball and have only one passage for enter by this mean they contrive to preserve they young from be devour by the serpent as the small twig from which the nest be suspend be unable to bear the weight of the serpent there be likewise abundance of those bird call pharaoh 's hen -lrb- 4 -rrb- in europe which come to we out of the levant they have likewise other bird both large and small which be quite different from any that be know in italy as i be long on shore i go several time to see they market or fair which be hold every Monday and Friday in a meadow not far from where i reside the man and woman from four or five mile around come to this place with they various commodity and those who live at a greater distance go to other market nearer they habitation the great poverty of the native appear manifest in the goods they bring to these fair consist of small quantity of cotton cloth and cotton yarn pulse oil millet wooden tub palm matt and every thing else useful to life accord to they manners likewise arm and some small quantity of gold have no money or coin of any kind all they trade be carry on by way of barter or exchange of one thing for another sometimes two or three thing for one accord to they different value all these black use to gaze on I as if i have be a prodigy have never see a white man before some take hold of my hand which they rub with spittle to see if the whiteness be natural or artificial and express they wonder to find that my skin be not paint they be as much astonished at my dress be clothe in the spanish fashion with a black damask waistcoat and a cloak over it : they seem much surprised at the waistcoat and greatly admire the woollen cloth which they have never see any of before my chief purpose in go to these fair be to see what quantity of gold be bring thither horse be very scarce and of great value in the country of the negro be bring all the way from that part of barbary which lie nearest to europe by the arab and azanhajus owe to the great heat horse do not live long here for they grow so fat that they can not stale and so burst they be feed with bean leave which be gather after the bean be bring from the field and be dry like hay be cut small and give to the horse instead of oats they give millet also which contribute greatly to make they fat a horse and he furniture sell for from nine to fourteen negro accord to he goodness and beauty and when a negro lord buy a horse he send for he horse sorcerer who cause a fire to be kindle of the stalk of certain herb and hold the horse head by the bridle over the smoke while they repeat over some few word by way of incantation they afterwards have he anoint all over with fine oil and have keep he eighteen or twenty day without allow any one to see he they affix some moorish charm to he neck which have the appearance of small square billet of write fold up and cover with red leather and affirm that they will go into battle with greater safety by means of these scroll or annulet the woman of this country be very pleasant and merry especially the young one and delight in singing and dancing take this diversion only at night by moonlight and they manner of dancing be very different from that of the italian many thing in we ship seem wonderful to the negro particularly we cross-bow but much more we artillery when some of they be on board my ship i cause one of the gun to be fire off which throw they into a dreadful panic and they terror be much increase on be tell that one cannon-shot could kill a hundred man on which account they allege that it must be something belong to the devil they be likewise greatly astonish at a bag-pipe which one of we sailor play upon to divert they and on examine the several part and ornament of the instrument they conceive that it be a living animal which sing in different voice observe they simplicity i tell they it be a musical instrument and put it into they hand unblown to examine they then perceive that it be a work of art but believe that it be something supernatural and could only have be devise by a superior be it sound so sweetly and in so many different tone have never hear any thing which could be compare to it in they estimation the ship also and its various contrivance as its anchor mast sail and shroud afford they great subject for admiration and wonder they look upon the port-hole in the stern as real eye by which the vessel be able to find she way in the sea and observe that traveller on land find difficulty to find the road from one place to another while we be able to travel along the trackless ocean and that the whites must therefore be the greatest of sorcerer not inferior to the devil himself they shew great admiration on see a light candle in a candlestick have themselves no other artificial light but that proceed from a fire they have honey-comb but when they find these they suck out the honey and throw away the empty comb as useless at one time i buy some honey-comb from a negro and shew he how to extract the honey after which on ask he if he know what remain he say it be good for nothing : but he be greatly astonish on see it make into candle and light in he presence say that the european know every thing they only musical instrument be two one of which they have from the moor which be like a large drum -lrb- 5 -rrb- the other be somewhat like a fiddle have only two string which they play on with they finger but give no sound that can be call harmonious -lrb- 1 -rrb- this be almost certainly palm oil the origin of which will appear in another division of this work -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the text must be here erroneous as two pace or ten foot will scarcely suffice in describe the boa constrictor sometimes near thirty foot long -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- a account of the termite or white ant of africa will appear hereafter the circumstance of serpent take up they abode in the large anthill must be entirely accidental -- e -lrb- 4 -rrb- probably the pintado or guinea fowl -- e -lrb- 5 -rrb- this in ramusio be call tabacche and sambuka in grynaeus -- astl section vii _ continuation of the voyage from senegal by cape verd the river barbasinus and to the river gambium and return to portugal _ have see a considerable part of the dominion of budomel and receive the slave which be bargain for in exchange for my horse and other merchandize i resolve to proceed on my voyage round cape verd and to prosecute discovery along this dangerous coast and in particular to go in search of the kingdom of gambium or gambium which don henry have point out on the information of a person who be well acquaint with the country of the negro as not far from senegal and from whence it be report that considerable quantity of gold might be procure longing to go in quest of this gold i take my leave of budomel and repair to the river senegal where i go on board the caravel and get under weigh as soon as possible soon after leave the river senegal as we be stand onward with a press of sail towards cape verd we descry one morning two ship in the offing on join company we find that one of these belong to antonio a experienced genoese navigator and the other to some gentleman in the service of don henry and that they have sail in company with the intention of pass cape verd to explore the coast beyond it in search of new discovery we intention be similar i offer to join company and we accordingly proceed together along the coast to the southward in sight of land we come in sight of that cape next day be about thirty italian mile from we last anchorage -lrb- 1 -rrb- cape verd be so name by the portuguese who discover it about a year before -lrb- 2 -rrb- because it be cover with tree which continue green all the year this be a high and beautiful cape which run a considerable way into the sea and have two hill or small mountain at its outer extremity there be several village of the senegal negro or jalof upon and about this promontory which be compose of thatched cabin close by the shore and in sight of those who sail past there be also some sand bank which extend about half a mile into the sea -lrb- 3 -rrb- have double the cape we come to three small uninhabited island full of green tree -lrb- 4 -rrb- and be in want of water we anchor at that which seem the largest and most fruitful in hope of meeting with a spring but could find none to answer we purpose we meet however with the nest and egg of several kind of bird such as we have never see before this be in the month of July 1456 and we continue here all day fishing with line and large hook catch a prodigious number of fish among which be _ dentali _ and gilded fish -lrb- 5 -rrb- some of which weigh from twelve to fifteen pound each on the next day we proceed in we course keep always in sight of land and find a kind of gulf form by the coast on the south side of the cape -lrb- 6 -rrb- this coast be all low and full of fine large tree which be continually green as the new leaf grow before the old one fall off and they never wither like those in europe and the tree grow so near the shore that they seem to drink as it be the water of the sea the coast be most beautiful insomuch that i never see any thing comparable to it though i have sail much both in the levant and the western part of europe it be well water every where by small river but these be useless for trade as they do not admit ship of any size beyond this little gulf the coast be inhabit by two negro nation call barbasinus and serrerus which be not subject to the king of senegal neither have they any king or lord of they own but one person be more honor than another accord to he condition or quality they be great idolater without law and live in almost a state of nature and extremely cruel and refuse to become subject to any lord that they wife and child may not be take from they and sell as slave as be the custom among all the negro nation which be under subjection to king or lord they use bow and poison arrow the wound from which be incurable if even the smallest blood be draw and the wound person or animal soon die they color be jet black and they person be well make the country be full of wood lake and stream from which they derive great security as they can only be invade through narrow defile by which mean they set the neighbouring lord at defiance in former time the king of senegal often attempt to reduce these two nation under obedience but be always worst owe to the natural strength of the country and they arrow run along the coast to the south with a fair wind we discover the mouth of a river about a bow-shot wide but not deep to which we give the name of the _ barbasinus _ river and have mark it on the chart which i make of the coast as sixty mile from cape verd -lrb- 7 -rrb- in sailing along the coast we only make sail at sun rise have a man continually on the top and two other on the prow or head to look out for breaker and always come to anchor at sun set about four or five mile from the land in ten or twelve fathom water proceeding on we voyage in this cautious manner we come to the mouth of a river which appear to be as large as the senegal -lrb- 8 -rrb- and strike by the fineness of its appearance and its rich wood which come down to the very shore we cast anchor and determine to send one of we negro interpreter on shore to endeavor to establish a friendly intercourse with the native every ship which sail from portugal for the coast of africa be supply with some of these negro interpreter who consist of slave that have be sell by the lord of senegal to the first portuguese who touch on the coast and who have learn the portuguese language and become christian these be hire from they master in portugal who receive for they hire a prime slave from the cargo on return from the voyage and when any of these interpreter have thus earn four slave for they master they become free have cast lot to determine which of the three ship should send a interpreter on shore it fall on the ship command by the genoese gentleman on which he send a armed boat order the man not to touch the shore but to push off as soon as they have land the interpreter who be charge to inform himself respect the condition and government of the country and to inquire whether it produce gold or any other commodity worth come for no sooner be the interpreter land and the boat shove off to some distance as order than several native come out of the wood who have be in ambush with bow arrow and other weapon from the time they see we ship approach the coast as if they have be in hope that some of we people might land upon the coast after a short parley with we interpreter they furiously assault he with they _ gomy _ or short moorish sword and slew he we people in the boat be unable to give he any assistance this intelligence be bring to the ship where it excite much surprise and conclude that these people must be extremely barbarous who could treat one of they own race with so much barbarity and would consequently use we cruelly if in they power we immediately weigh anchor and stand on we voyage farther to the south which improve in the beauty and verdure of the tree as we advance always sailing within sight of the coast which be everywhere low land cover with tree we come at length to the mouth of a very large river which be not less than six or eight mile wide at the entrance and narrow a little way within to three or four mile and find that it could be safely enter we determine to cast anchor for the night and to endeavor to learn next day if this be the river and kingdom of gambra or gambium of which we be in search -lrb- 9 -rrb- we judge however from its noble river that we have now attain the so anxiously desire country of gambium and flattered ourselves in the hope of find a country of vast riches where we might make we fortune at once by return laden with gold and other rich commodity next day have but little wind we send on the small caravel before well man with direction as they ship be small and draw little water that they be to proceed as far as possible up the river observe whether there be any bar or sand bank at its mouth and to take the sounding with great care and if the river be find navigable they be to return and make signal to that effect find four fathom water at the entrance the caravel bring to and make the concerted signal on which it be think proper as that caravel be small to send another boat well arm along with she up the river and they be strictly enjoin in case the native be hostile to enter into no conflict with they but to return immediately to the other ship as the object of we voyage be to cultivate friendship and trade with the country which could only be accomplish by policy not by force the boat accordingly proceed up the river for two mile leave the small caravel at anchor and find the bank everywhere beautiful with sixteen fathom water but as the river above this make several return or reach they do not think it prudent to venture any higher when on they way back they see three _ almadia _ or canoe near the mouth of a small river which run into the large one these almadia resemble the skiff use in italy which be call _ zoppoli _ and be hollow out of one large piece of wood although we boat be strongly armed yet in obedience to they order and for fear of be attack with poison arrow which the negro of senegal have tell we be use by all the native of gambium they take to they oar and make all possible haste back to the ship by the time they get on board the almadia which follow they close be within arrow flight there be about twenty-five or thirty negro in these three almadia who stop for some time gaze at the caravel which be quite a new sight to they but would neither speak nor come nearer notwithstanding every endeavor by sign to induce they to approach and at length they return to the shore about three next morning the other three caravel that have remain at anchor without the river sail with the rise tide and a light breeze into the river to rejoin the small caravel and to proceed up the river hope to meet with a more civilized people than have be see in the almadia in this way we sail up the river one after the other the small caravel lead and when we have get about four mile up we perceive ourselves to be follow by a number of _ almadia _ without know whence they come on this we tack about and bear down towards the almadia have first fortify ourselves in the best manner we could to defend we against they poison arrow and make every thing ready for battle in case of need though by no means well provide with arm we order of sailing be now reverse and my ship be foremost in go down the river we soon come to the almadia which separate into two division have my ship between they when i have a opportunity to count they number as they give over rowing raise they oar and gaze in wonder at we ship : there be in all fifteen almadia of considerable length have from 130 to 150 negro all well make of a good size and very black they wear white cotton shirt have white cap like those worn by the german on they head but with a wing on each side and a feather in the middle which i suppose to be a distinguishing mark of they be soldier there stand a negro on the prow of each almadium have a round target apparently of leather on he arm and for some time they neither attack we nor we they when they see the other caravel bear down upon they they drop they oar and take up they bow send a flight of arrow on board see this attack we ship discharge four piece of cannon at they and they be so stupified by the report that they throw down they bow and stare about in amazement at the effect which the stone from the cannon make on the water around they they continue in this astonishment for some time but see that the cannon cease to fire they pluck up courage and renew the fight advance within a stone throw of the ship on this we sailor begin to use they cross-bow and the first shot which be make by the natural son of the genoese gentleman hit a negro on the breast who instantly fall down dead those in the almadium where he fall take up the dart and gaze at it with wonder yet they continue the attack with great vigor and be courageously oppose by we caravel insomuch that many of the negro be soon kill without the loss of one man on we side the negro now change they mode of attack and make a furious united attack on the stern of we smallest caravel which be both ill manned and insufficiently arm on observe this i bring up my ship to she assistance and the other large caravel do the same we place the small one between we and we all vigorously ply we cannon and cross-bow against the almadia which be at last force to retire we now link all the three caravel together and drop one anchor which be sufficient for we all as it be calm weather and the current by no means strong we next endeavor to enter into some conversation with the negro and often hail they by means of we interpreter at length one of the almadia draw near and on be ask the reason of they hostility to stranger who come among they only to trade in a friendly manner as they have already do with the negro of the kingdom of senegal and be desirous of be on the same friendly term with they if they think proper and be come from a far distant country with present for they king or lord from the king of portugal who be desirous of peace and friendship with they we interpreter also entreat the negro to inform we what country we be in who be they king and what be the name of the river and desire they to come freely on board and take what goods they please add that they might make a return in any commodity they think proper and in any quantity they please or might have we goods for nothing to all this they make answer that they have some intelligence of the christian already and of they dealings with the negro of senegal who must be very wicked people for enter into friendship with they as they be well assure the christian be meneater who buy the negro only to devour they and for this reason they be resolve to have no correspondence with they except to destroy they and then to send they effect to they lord who dwell three day journey up the country they add that the name of they country be gambra but i have forget the name they give the river -lrb- 10 -rrb- at this time a brisk breeze spring up and as we now thoroughly know the hostile disposition of the negro we bear down upon they almadia but they flee to the shore and we dropt down to the mouth of the river while we remain off the mouth of this river we only once see the north star in clear weather and it be then so low as hardly to appear above the height of a lance above the sea -lrb- 11 -rrb- we likewise observe in about the same elevation due south by the compass a constellation of six large bright star in the figure of a cross in this form : \* \* \* \* \* \* we conjecture this to be the _ southern chariot _ but could not expect to observe the principal star as we have not yet lose sight of the north pole in this place on the _ first _ of July we find the night to be eleven hour and a half long and the day twelve hour and a half the climate be always hot and i be tell that even the rain in the inland part fall warm in consequence of the great heat of the air it be true that there be some difference of the heat at different season and when the heat be a little diminish the native call it winter the rain begin in July and continue till the end of October and fall every day about noon at which time certain cloud arise in the ne by e or ene which be accompany by prodigious thunder and lightning and vast torrent of rain in this season which be in the beginning of July the negro sow they grain in the same manner with the people in senegal they provision consist of millet pulse flesh and milk there be not so much dawn at break of day in this southern latitude as with we in italy for within half a hour after the darkness of the night begin to dispel the sun appear and during all that dawn the atmosphere be turbid as if fill with smoke and the moment the sun appear this mist be dissipate i could only account for this phenomenon by attribute it to the low and flat surface of this country which be destitute of mountain and my companion be of a similar opinion on hold a consultation among the commander of the three caravel we come to a resolution of proceed about a hundred mile up the river in hope of meeting with a less ferocious and better disposed people in the interior than those we have encounter at the mouth of this river : but the sailor be impatient to return home without incur any farther danger and unanimously and loudly refuse they consent to we determination declare that they have already do enough for the present voyage upon this be make know to we and be well aware that seaman be of headstrong and obstinate disposition we concede to they clamor and steer next day for cape verd on we return to portugal -lrb- 12 -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- cape verd be about 100 mile from the southern mouth of the river senegal so that the voyager probably anchor every night within
