portuguese -- clarke section viii _ the second voyage of cada mosto in 1456 to the coast of africa in which the cape de verd island be discover _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- as i could say little or nothing about the condition of the country of gambium on my return to portugal on account of be oblige to leave it so suddenly partly owe to the intractable and fierce disposition of the native and partly through the perversity of we sailor who refuse to proceed in explore the river the genoese gentleman antonio who have be with I in the former voyage and i resolve next season to fit out two caravel in order to return to the river gambium and don henry who be much pleased with we intention determine to send one of he caravel along with we every thing be make ready for we voyage we sail from lago near cape st vincent with a favourable wind in the beginning of may and steer for the canary which we make in a few day but as the wind continue favourable we do not touch there and continue we course to the southward and as we be favor by a current setting to the s w we sail on at a great rate at last we come in sight of cape branco keep well out at sea and on the follow night we be assail by a great storm from the s w which occasion we to steer w by n for two day and three night in order to weather the tempest rather than turn back on the third day to we great joy and surprise we descry land be much astonished to discover land in a quarter where no person could have expect it -lrb- 2 -rrb- two man be immediately send aloft who cry out that two large island be in sight this news be communicate through the ship to we great satisfaction as we be sensible these island be unknown in portugal judge it probable that these island might be inhabit and eager to try we fortune we steer towards one of they which we soon come up with and sail round a part of it till we find safe anchorage the weather be now much calm we send we boat on shore well man and arm the man land and have examine some part of the island bring back word that they could meet with no sign of inhabitant whatever next morning to clear up all doubt i send ten man to land on the island well arm with gun and cross-bow whom i order to go to the top of some mountain within sight and to look from thence not only for people but for more island these man execute my command but find no appearance of any inhabitant they find however a incredible number of pigeon which be so tame be stranger to man that they readily allow themselves to be catch and we people bring great number of they to the caravel but what be of much more importance they bring intelligence of have discover three other island one of which be to leeward towards the north could not be see from the ship while the other two lay to the south all within sight of each other these man likewise notice something resemble island towards the west but at so great a distance that they could not be clearly distinguish neither do i think proper to sail in that direction lest i should lose time in visit uninhabited island like this at which we have touch the fame of my discovery of these four island bring other navigator afterwards to explore this group who round they to be ten in number both large and small include and altogether uninhabited except by pigeon and other bird and have a fine fishery -lrb- 3 -rrb- leave the first island we come in sight of the other two and search for a anchoring place near one of they which be full of tree discover the mouth of a river and be in want of water we come to anchor and send we boat on shore to supply we want some of we people go a little way up the river where they find some small lake contain remarkably fine white salt of which they bring large quantity to the ship lay in what store be think necessary as we do likewise of water we find here great number of tortoise or turtle the shell of which be larger than a target the sailor cook these into different dish as they have do before in the gulf of arguin where these animal be find in plenty but not so large as here out of curiosity i eat some of the flesh of these tortoise which seem very good have a good smell and taste and be not inferior to veal we salt a great number of they which prove a valuable addition to we stock of provision during the voyage we catch likewise a prodigious quantity of fish both off the mouth of the river and in the stream and though we know not the kind they be large and well-flavoured the mouth of this river be a good arrow-shot across and it be deep enough to admit a vessel of 150 ton we remain two day in this place for refreshment take in a good stock of tortoise and fish and large quantity of pigeon which we kill without number to the first island at which we anchor we give the name of _ bona vista _ as be the first we get sight of and to this other which seem the largest of the four the name of st jago have cast anchor there on the day of st philip and st jame every thing be in readiness for pursue we voyage we take we departure from these island and shape we course for cape verd we arrive at _ spedegar _ and keep within sight of land we come to a place name the _ two palm _ which be between cape verd and the river senegal be perfectly acquaint with the coast we double the cape next day and come once more to the river gambium into which we immediately enter and find no opposition from the negro or they almadia we sail up the river always by day and continually sound such of the almadia as we see on the river keep at a distance close to the bank of the river and never venture to approach about ten mile up the river we cast anchor on a Sunday morning at a island where one of we sailor be bury who have die of a fever and as he name happen to be andrew we call it the island of st andrew -lrb- 4 -rrb- leave this island we proceed up the river follow by some of the negro in they almadia yet always keep at a considerable distance we interpreter often hail they and shew they various trinket which be offer for they acceptance and endeavor to entice they to come near by tell they that we be good-natured civilized people from whom they have nothing to fear work upon by these representation the negro at length approach and come up with my caravel and at last one of they who understand the language of we interpreter come on board he be greatly surprize at every thing he see in and about the caravel especially with the sail and rig have no other idea of move a vessel on the water but by means of oar he be no less amaze at we color and dress as he nation mostly go stark naked or with a single white cotton shirt as they sole dress we be exceedingly kind and attentive to this negro and make he many present of trinket and other thing of small value with which he be much delighted i ask he many question respect the country through we interpreter and at length learn that we be in the country of gambium of which forosangolus be chief lord and by what we could learn from he the residence of forosangolus be at the distance of nine or ten day journey in a direction between the south and the southwest he say that forosangolus be tributary to the king of mellus who be the great emperor of the negro that there be many inferior lord who dwell near the river on both side and if we please he would conduct we to the residence of one of these lord name battimansa and would endeavor to negociate a treaty of peace and friendship between he and we be much pleased with this offer we carry this negro along with we and treat he with much attention and sailing up the river we come to the place where battimansa reside which in my opinion be above forty mile from the mouth of the river in go up the river into which several lesser river fall we sail to the eastward and at the place where we come to anchor we find it much narrower than at the mouth be not above a mile in breadth by we estimation -lrb- 5 -rrb- on come to this place we send one of we interpreter and the native negro to battimansa with a present of a handsome garment call a _ alzimba _ make of moorish silk in the form of a shirt and they be desire to inform he of the reason of we come into he country signify that the christian king of portugal have send we thither to enter into a treaty of friendship and peace with he and that if he have any call for we commodity we king would supply he with they every year as soon as we messenger have discharge they commission battimansa send some of he negro to the caravel with whom we enter into friendship and barter several thing for negro slave and some gold but gold be by no means to be have in any thing like the plenty we expect from the account give of this country by the native of senegal who be themselves extremely poor consider that to be a large quantity which we think very trifling the negro value they gold as a very precious thing even at a higher rate than the portuguese yet we get it in barter very reasonably for thing of very small value we continue here eleven day during which the caravel be continually resort to by great number of negro from both side of the river who come to see the novelty and to sell they goods among which there be a few gold ring part of they commodity consist of cotton cloth and cotton yarn some of the piece be all white some striped blue and white and other again with red blue and white stripe all very well work and color they likewise bring civet for sale the skin of civet-cat monky large and small baboon of various sort and these last be very plenty they sell they cheap or for something not exceed ten _ marquet _ in value for each and the ounce of civet for what be not worth more than forty or fifty marquet not that they sell they commodity by weight but i judge the quantity to be about a ounce other negro bring various sort of fruit for sale among which be many small wild date which they seem to think much of but which we people think not good as the taste be different from those of europe : as for I i would not venture to eat any of they lest they might have give I the flux or some other distemper we ship be every day crowd with people of different aspect and language -lrb- 6 -rrb- and the native be continually go up and down the river from one place to another both man and woman in they almadia they have no sail and propel they almadia entirely with oar which they use on both side all the rower stand up one man stand at the stern who row sometimes on one side sometimes on the other to keep the almadium steady in she course they have no pin or row - lock to steady they oar but hold they fast with both hand they oar be a pole like a half lance seven foot and a half long with a round board like a trencher fasten to one end and with these they row with great safety and swiftness in the mouth of they river which be very numerous but they seldom go out to sea or to any distance from they own coast lest they should be take by they neighbor and sell for slave -lrb- 1 -rrb- there be some difficulty respect the date of this second voyage in the former cada mosto sail from portugal in march 1455 in the course of he proceedings the month of November be mention and some subsequent transaction be say to have happen in July which on this arrangement must necessarily have be of the year 1456 if therefore the date of the former voyage be accurate the second ought to have be date in 1457 -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- this part of the narrative be involve in difficulty and most be erroneous a storm from the s w off cape branco almost in lat 21  n and a n w course could not possibly lead to the discovery of the cape verd island almost six degree farther south and at least six degree farther west this difficulty may be solve by suppose the storm from the ne and that the ship drive to the sw from off cape branco -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- this passage allude to the voyage of antonio de noli in 1462 and it may be remark that de faria who mention the discovery of these island by noli take no notice of the actual discovery by cada mosto -- astl -lrb- 4 -rrb- the editor of astley collection consider this as have be st jamese island which be about twenty mile up the gambium : but there be a small island near the northern bank now call charle i which exactly correspond with the distance in the text -- e -lrb- 5 -rrb- accord to we best map or chart of the gambium this river be never less than four mile broad and generally above five till we get near 100 mile up the river to the reach which encircle the devil point where it still be two mile wide it be possible that the original journal of cada mosto may have have league of three marine mile each in which case the residence of battimansa may have be at or near the devil point above 100 mile up the river -- e -lrb- 6 -rrb- though this country will be amply describe in other voyage in we collection it may be proper to remark that both side of the river gambium be inhabit by a mixed population of three nation the feloop foley and mandingo each of whom have they own separate village intersperse this population be divide into many state lordship or little kingdom as joallus barrah kolar badibu barsallus & c on or near the northern bank kumbo fonium kaen jagra yamini & c on the southern -- e section ix _ some account of the manners and custom on the gambium and of the elephant and hippopotamus _ it now remain for I to relate what i observe and be inform of concern this country during my short stay the religion of the negro of gambium consist of various kind of idolatry they place great reliance on sorcery and other diabolical thing yet all believe in god there be many mahometan among they who trade to many country yet be not settle in house because the native be ignorant -lrb- 1 -rrb- they live very much in the same manner with the native of senegal and have the same kind of provision but they cultivate more sort of rice they eat dog flesh which i never hear of be use anywhere else they be clothe in cotton garment and have great abundance of cotton in they country which may be the reason of the gambian not go naked as those of senegal do where cotton be very scarce the woman dress in the same manner and when they be very young take great delight in delineate figure on they neck breast and arm with the point of a hot needle which be never obliterate and which resemble the flower and ornament which be work on silk handkerchief the country be excessively hot and the heat increase as we go to the south besides which we find it much hotter up the river than at sea owe to the immense number of tree with which the country everywhere abound some of these tree be of very great dimension near a spring where we sailor be in use to fill we water cask not far from the bank of the river there grow a exceedingly large tree but its height be by no means proportional to its thickness for though it measure seventeen cubit in girth near the ground its height by estimation be only twenty pace this tree be hollow but the branch be very large avid extend to a great distance form a thick and ample shade but there be many other tree much larger than this by which the richness and fertility of the soil may be easily conceive and the country be intersect by numerous stream there be many elephant in this country but the native be ignorant of the art of tame these animal as be practice in other country one day while we lay at anchor in the middle of the river we observe three elephant come out from the wood and walk by the river side on which we send we boat with some of the people towards they but they immediately return into the wood these be all i ever see alive but sometime afterwards guumi-mensa -lrb- 2 -rrb- one of the negro lord shew I a dead young elephant which he have kill after a chase of two day the negro hunt on foot in the wood use only arrow and assagay or javelin which be all poison when they hunt the elephant they conceal themselves behind tree and even sometimes mount to they top leap from one tree to another in pursuit of the elephant which be a large unweildy animal be often wound in many place before it can turn round or place itself in a posture of defense but in a open field no person dare attack one nor could even the swiftest escape from they pursuit as i have be inform by many of the negro the tooth of this dead elephant which be shewn I by guumi-mensa one of which still remain in the jaw do not exceed three span long which distinctly shew that it be quite young in comparison of those whose tooth be from ten to twelve span in length yet small as it be for a elephant we compute that the weight of its carcass be equal to five or six oxen guumi-mensa make I a present of what part of this elephant i like best and give the remainder to he huntsman to feast on understanding that elephant flesh be eat by the negro i have some both roasted and boil of which i taste that i might be able to say that i have feed upon the flesh of a animal which have never be eat by any of my countryman but i find it hard and of a unpleasant relish i bring one of the leg and a part of the trunk on board we caravel together with some of the hair from its body which be a span and a half long of a black color and very thick on my return to portugal i present this hair to don henry together with a part of the flesh salt up for that express purpose which he receive with much satisfaction as it be the first of the kind that have be bring from the country that be discover under he auspices the foot of the elephant be round like that of a horse but without hoof instead of which it be cover by a very thick hard black skin and defend by five nail on the fore part which be round and of the size of a _ grossone _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- though young the foot of this elephant measure a span and a half in diameter from the same negro lord i receive the foot of a full-grown elephant the sole of which be three span and a inch in diameter which together with a tooth of twelve span long i present to don henry on my return who send it afterwards as a great curiosity to the dutchess of burgundy in the river gambium and in other river on this coast besides the _ calcatricus _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- and other animal there be one call the _ river horse _ or hippopotamus of the same nature almost with the sea cow and which live both on land and in the water this animal be as large in the body as a cow with very short leg and cloven foot have a large head like that of a horse and two huge tooth like the tusk of a wild boar some of which i have see upward of two span long this animal when it get out of the river walk on the land like any other fourfooted beast and so far as i know be never before discover by any christian traveller except perhaps in the nile we see likewise a number of bat or rather owl upward of three span long and many other bird quite different from those of we country both in appearance and taste yet very good to eat -lrb- 1 -rrb- the meaning of this expression be obscure perhaps it imply that they mahometan teacher have no mosque because the negro be ignorant of the means and method of construction the knowledge of god among the northern negro be assuredly due exclusively to the mahometan missionary -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- call gnumi-mensa in grynaeus accord to jobson mensa or mansa signify a king in the mandingo language -- astl -lrb- 3 -rrb- a venetian silver coin not exceed a silver penny -- astl -lrb- 4 -rrb- this animal be nowhere explain perhaps the crocodile or alligator -- e section x _ continuation of the voyage from the gambium to the river kasa-mansa cape roxo the river of st ann and st domingo and the rio grande _ have continue eleven day in the river gambium and many of we people become affect by acute fever we dropt down the river on the evening of the eleventh day depart from the country of batti-mansa -lrb- 1 -rrb- and get out of the river in a few day so stock with commodity as to encourage we to proceed farther and indeed have be so far successful and have a plentiful supply of provision and every thing necessary for prosecute the voyage we consider as incumbent on we to attempt some farther discovery towards the south we accordingly steer southwards with a favourable wind but find the land to run a considerable way to the ssw from the mouth of the gambium to a certain point which we take for a cape -lrb- 2 -rrb- we stand out to the west to gain the open sea the whole coast to the south of the gambium be low and cover with tree to the water edge on gain a offing we find that the beforementioned point be no actual cape or promontory as the shore appear perfectly straight on the other side yet we keep at some distance out to sea as we observe breaker for several mile out to sea -lrb- 3 -rrb- on this account we have to proceed with great caution keep always two man at the head of the ship and one in the main-top to look out for shoal and breaker and as a farther precaution we sail only during the day and come to anchor every night in this cautious progress we caravel sail always one before the other have fix the order of sailing by lot and change the leader every day in order to avoid all dispute at the end of two day sail in this manner always in sight of land we discover on the third day the mouth of a river about half a mile wide -lrb- 4 -rrb- and towards evening we observe a little gulf or inlet which we suppose might be the entrance of another river but as it grow late we come to anchor for the night next morning we sail into this gulf and find that it be the mouth of a large river not a great deal less in my opinion than the gambium and both its bank be full of very beautiful tall tree we cast anchor within the mouth of this river and agree to send two armed boat on shore with we interpreter to get intelligence respect the country accord to we usual practice this be do accordingly and we interpreter bring back word that the river be call kasamansa from a negro lord of that name who reside at a place about thirty mile up the river but who be absent from he residence on a warlike expedition against the lord of a neighbouring territory on receive this intelligence we sail from this river next day without attempt any traffic with the native this river of kasamansa be twenty-five league or 100 mile to the south of the gambium -lrb- 5 -rrb- standing on about twenty-five mile farther we come to a cape which be a little more elevated than the rest of the coast and as its front have a red color we name it cape _ roxo _ or _ rosso _ proceed forwards we come to the mouth of a pretty large river about a crossbow-shot wide which we do not enter but to which we give the name of the river of st ann farther on still we come to the mouth of another river not less than the former which we name st dominic or st domingo -lrb- 7 -rrb- distant from cape rosso by we estimation between fifty-five and sixty mile in another day sailing we come to a very large river which at first appear to be a gulf and be judge to be about twenty mile in breadth but we could observe the beautiful tree on the south side and it take we a considerable time to sail across to that side on get over to that side we observe several island in the sea and as we wish to procure some intelligence concern the country we come to a anchor next morning two almadia come off to we from the land one of which be as long as a caravel and carry about thirty hand the other be smaller and be man by sixteen negro they come towards we with great eagerness and not know what might be they design we take to we arm and wait they approach as they draw near they fix a interpreter speak to they in order to learn the name of the country but could not understand a word of they language which be a great mortification to we as we be oblige to leave the place without get any intelligence but we purchase a few gold ring from one of the negro agree about the price by sign find ourselves in a country where we interpreter be of no use and consider therefore that it would be to no purpose for we to proceed any farther we determine to return we stay two day in the mouth of this large river which we therefore name rio grande -lrb- 8 -rrb- and where we find the north pole very low -lrb- 9 -rrb- in this place we find great irregularity in the tide for whereas at venice and all other place in europe the flux and reflux be each of six hour continuance the tide here only flow four hour and ebb eight and the violence of the flow tide be quite incredible insomuch that we have great difficulty to stem it with three anchor a-head nay such be its impetuosity that we be sometimes oblige to hoist we sail and even then it exceed the force of the wind take we departure from the mouth of this vast river on we way back to portugal we direct we course to two large island the inhabitant of this coast be idolater worship wooden image in the shape of man before which they make offering of victuals as often as they eat or drink these people be more of a tawny color than _ progress of discovery from cape verga to cape st catherine from the death of don henry to that of king alphonzo v _ after the decease of don henry the illustrious father of maritime discovery the progress of the portuguese along the coast of africa receive a considerable check as the military ardor of alphonzo the fifth be principally direct to the support of he pretension to the throne of castile the circumstance of which be unconnected with the plan of this work king alphonzo be not however entirely inattentive to the trade for gold and slave which he illustrious uncle don henry have commence with that part of africa which be now call guinea the origin of this name of guinea or _ ghinney _ be unknown it be not in use among the native and seem to have be impose by the portuguese from the appellation of _ ghenchoa _ give to a country on the south side of the senegal we first mention by leo and afterwards by marmol ever since the year 1453 as already mention considerable importation of gold have be make to portugal from the coast of africa but little or no progress have be make in extend the discovery farther south for some time previous to the decease of don henry in 1470 king alphonzo sail with a considerable army in a fleet of above 300 ship and carry the strong fort of _ arzilum _ on the atlantic coast of africa a little way to the south of the strait of gibraltar but of he military exploit in africa from which he acquire the appellation of _ africanus _ and assume the additional title of _ lord of the coast on both sea _ we present purpose do not call for any recital in 1479 the dispute between the crown of portugal and castile be compromise by a treaty enter into by alphonzo v king of portugal and ferdinand king of castile by which the trade of guinea and the navigation of its coast with the propose conquest of _ fez _ be guarantee to portugal and the canary island be annex to the crown of castile from the want of any accurate history of the progress of the portuguese discovery it be utterly impossible to determine the date or circumstance of many of the progressive discovery along the western coast of africa and of its island in 1469 from signior hieronimo fracastro of verona that on my arrival at conde i would send he a account of my voyage to san thome to which island we ship often sail for cargo of sugar the passage of the equinoctial line under which that island be situate appear to that gentleman so extraordinary a circumstance as to merit the attention of man of science and you likewise make I a similar request i begin therefore immediately after my return to draw up a account of my voyage from those note which we pilot usual keep of all occurrence and i compare it in my progress with the journal of some friend who have formerly make the same voyage when i afterwards attentively peruse my manuscript it do not appear to I worthy of be communicate to a gentleman of such scientific character as signor hieronimo whose talent i have duly appreciate by the perusal of he publication which i receive from you before my departure from venice i therefore lay my manuscript aside not wish that any one might peruse it but as you have again urge the performance of my promise i now anxiously obey a request which as come from you i must always consider a command apprehensive likewise of appear forgetful of you polite attention i prefer the danger of expose my ignorance to the possibility of be charge with ingratitude or want of attention be a sailor and unused to composition i pretend to little more than copy the remark of those who have sail from we continent to _ ethiopium _ without attempt to reduce my narrative into lucid order or to embellish it with fine write you will therefore have the goodness to destroy this account after its perusal that the error i have commit by compliance with you command may not draw upon I the imputation of presumption the portuguese ship which sail to the island of st thoma from lisbon for cargo of sugar usually put to sea in February though some vessel make this voyage at every period of the year they course be ssw until they reach the canary island after which they steer for the island of palma which be opposite to cape bojador on the coast of africa and be about ninety league from the kingdom of castile this island have plenty of provision and abound in wine and sugar the north - west wind prevail most and a great sea rage continually on its coast particularly in the month of December -lrb- 2 -rrb- if the ship which be bind for the island of st thoma find it necessary to obtain a quantity of salt after have take on board a sufficient supply at the island of _ sal _ they steer for the coast of africa at the rio del oro and if they have calm weather and a smooth sea they catch as many fish in four hour with hook and line as may suffice for all they want during the remainder of the voyage but if the weather be unfavourable for fishing at the rio del oro they proceed along the coast to cape branco and thence along the coast to the island of arguin the principal sort of fish on this coast be _ pagro _ call _ albanus _ by the venetian likewise _ corvus _ and _ onero _ which latter be only a larger and darker-coloured species of _ pagro _ as soon as take the fish be open and salt and serve as a excellent supply of provision to navigator all the coast of africa from cape bojador otherwise call _ cabo della volta _ as far as cape branco and even to arguin be low and sandy at arguin which be inhabit by moor and negro and which be situate on the confines between these two nation there be a capacious harbor and a castle belong to we king of portugal in which some portuguese always reside with the royal agent on leave the island of sal we ship steer next for st jago another of the cape verd island this island be situate in _ fifteen degree on the equinoctial and thirty league towards the south _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- it be seventeen league long and have a city on the coast with a good harbor call _ ribiera grande _ or the great river now st jago from two high mountain one on each side a large river of fresh water flow into the harbor and from its source full two league above the city its bank be line on each side with garden have fine grove of orange cedar pomegranate several sort of fig and the cocoa-nut palm which have be long plant on this island it produce all kind of vegetable in great abundance and perfection but they do not afford good seed so that it be necessary to procure these every year from europe the city be on the south coast of the island and be well build of stone be inhabit by about 500 family of distinction portuguese and castilian its government be entrust to a corregidor or governor appoint by the king of portugal and two judge be choose annually one for the determination of naval and maritime cause and the other for regulate the police this island be very mountainous and be very barren in many part which be entirely destitute of wood but its vally be fertile and well cultivate in June when the sun enter cancer the rain be so incessant that the portuguese call that month _ la luna de las aquas _ or the water month they seed-time begin in August when they sow maize call _ miglio zaburo _ this be a white bean which be ready to be gather in forty day and be the chief food of these islander and of all the inhabitant of the coast of africa -lrb- 4 -rrb- they also sow much rice and cotton the latter of which come to great perfection and be manufacture into striped cloth which be export to the country of the negro and barter for black slave to give a distinct view of the commercial transaction with the negro it be proper to inform you that the western coast of africa be divide into several country and province as guinea _ melegote _ -lrb- 5 -rrb- the kingdom of benin and the kingdom of manicongo over all this extent of coast there be many negro king or chief whose subject be mahometan and idolater and who be continually at war with each other these king be much respect by they subject almost to adoration as they be believe to have originally descend from heaven when the king of benin die he subject assemble in a extensive plain in the center of which a vast pit or sepulchre be dig into which the body be lower and all the friend and servant of the decease be sacrifice and throw into the same grave thus voluntarily throw away they own life in honor of the dead on this coast there grow a species of _ melegete _ extremely pungent like pepper and resemble the italian grain call _ sorgo _ it produce likewise a species of pepper of great strength not inferior to any of that which the portuguese bring from calicut under the name of _ pimienta del rabo _ or _ pepe dalla coda _ and which african pepper resemble _ cubbeb _ but so powerful that a ounce will go farther than a pound of the common sort but its exportation be carry on for the king 's account all the trade of this coast to the kingdom of _ manicongo _ exclusively be farm out every four or five year to the highest bidder great negro caravan bring gold and slave to the station on the coast the slave be either prisoner take in war or child whom they parent have part with in the hope of they be carry to a more fertile country for above ninety year after the first discovery of this coast the portuguese merchant be accustom to enter the large river by which the country be everywhere intersect trading independently with the numerous tribe inhabit they bank but now the whole of this commerce be in the hand of stationary licensed factor to whom it be farm on quit st jago we steer southerly for the rio grande which be on the north of ethiopium beyond which we come to the high mountain of sierra liona the summit of which be continually envelop in mist out of which thunder and lightning almost perpetually flash and be hear at sea from the distance of forty or fifty mile though the sun be quite vertical in pass over this mountain and extremely hot yet the thick fog be never dissipate in we voyage we never lose sight of land yet keep always at a considerable distance carefully observe the declination of the sun and keep a southerly course till we arrive in _ four degree on the equinoctial _ -lrb- 7 -rrb- when we suddenly change we course to the south-east keep the ethiopian coast always on we left hand in we way to the island of st thoma on this coast between the tropic and the equinoctial we never meet with any hard gale as storm be very rarely find within the tropics on near the land the sounding in many part of the coast do not exceed fifty _ braccium _ but farther out the depth rapidly increase and the sea usually run high at a distance from the land when we arrive at rio del oro as mention before we observe four star in the form of a cross of a extraordinary size and splendor elevated thirty degree above the antarctic pole and form the constellation call _ il crusero _ while under the tropic of cancer we see this constellation very low and on direct we _ balestra _ -lrb- 8 -rrb- to the lowermost of these star we find it to be directly south and conclude that it must be in the center of the antarctic polar circle we observe the same constellation very high when we be at the island of st thoma and remark that the moon after rain produce a rainbow similar to that occasion by the sun during the day except that the color be dim and ill-defined on leave the strait of gibraltar i do not observe any sensible change on the ebb and flow of the sea but when we approach rio grande which be eleven degree to the north of the equinoctial we observe a considerable tide at the mouth of that river and the rise in some place be much the same as on the coast of portugal whereas at the isle of st thoma it be nearly the same as at venice the island of st thoma be discover above eighty -lrb- 9 -rrb- year ago by some captain in the royal navy of portugal and be altogether unknown to the ancient its horizon or parallel pass at a equal distance between the arctic and antarctic pole and its day and night be always equal the arctic polar star be there invisible but the _ guardianus _ be see in some measure to revolve and the constellation which be know by the name of _ il crusero _ be see in the heaven at a high altitude to the eastward -lrb- 10 -rrb- of st thoma and at the distance of 120 mile the small island call _ il principe _ be situate this latter island be inhabit and cultivate the produce of its sugar cane belong to the revenue of the king eldest son from which circumstance the island derive its name to the s s w or s and by w and in the latitude of almost 2  s be the uninhabited island of annobon on which number of crocodile and venomous serpent be find its rocky shore abound in fish and be much resort to by the inhabitant of st thoma on that account when first discover the island of st thoma be a entire forest contain a variety of tree which though barren be extremely verdant these tree be all remarkably tall and straight they branch all draw close to the stem and not spread out as with we after clear away a great part of the forest the inhabitant build a principal town call _ pouoasan _ which have a excellent harbor the principal dependence of the settler in this island be upon they sugar which they exchange yearly with the merchant who trade thither for flour in barrel wine oil cheese leather sword glass bead drinking-cup pater-noster and _ buzio _ which be a small kind of shell call by the italian _ white porcelain _ and which pass in ethiopium as money the european who reside on this island depend much for provision on the ship as they can not subsist on the fare use by the negro the slave employ in they sugar plantation be procure from guinea benin and congo and some rich planter have from 150 to 300 negro these work five day in every week for they master and be allow the saturday to themselves when they cultivate various article of provision as the _ miglio zaburo _ a species of bean formerly mention a root call _ igname _ and many species of culinary vegetable the seed of which must be import from europe as they do not come to perfection in this climate -lrb- illustration : chart of north western africa -rrb- the soil of st thoma consist of a red and yellow marl or clay of great fertility which be keep soft and mellow by the heavy dew which fall nightly contribute greatly to vegetation and prevent it from be dry up by the great heat and so great be the luxuriant fertility of the soil that tree immediately spring up on any spot leave uncultivated and will grow as high in a few day as would require as many month with we these sprout be cut down and burn by the slave and they ash be use as manure for the sugarcane if plant in January the cane be ready to be cut in June and those which be plant in February become ripe in July and in this manner they keep up a succession throughout the whole year in march and September when the sun be vertical the great rain set in accompany with cloudy and thick weather which be of great service to the sugar plantation this island produce yearly above 150000 aroba of sugar each contain thirty-one of we pound of which the king receive the tenth part which usually produce from 12000 to 14000 aroba though many of the planter do not pay this tythe fully there be about sixty _ ingenio _ drive by water for bruise the cane and press out the juice which be boil in vast chaldron after which it be pour into pan in the shape of sugar-loaves holding from fifteen to twenty pound each in which it be purify by means of ash in some part of the island where they have not stream of water the cane be crush by machine work by the negro and in other by horse the bruised cane be give to the hog which hardly get any other food yet fatten wonderfully and they flesh be so delicate and wholesome as to be prefer to that of poultry many sugar refiner have be bring here from madeira on purpose to endeavor to manufacture the sugar of st thoma more white and harder than its usual produce but in vain this be allege to proceed from the extreme richness of the soil injure the quality of the sugar just as with we wine produce in soil of too great fertility be apt to have a peculiar flavor another cause of this be suppose to proceed from the climate of the island be too hot and too moist except in the month of June July and August at which season a fresh dry wind blow from ethiopium to this island and they then make they best sugar the planter be oblige to ship off they sugar as soon as they can procure shipping because they would become liquid if attempt to be keep for a length of time at present not above two-third of the island be appropriate to the cultivation of sugar but any person who come to this island for the purpose of settle whether from spain or portugal or any other country may procure from the royal intendant as much land as he be able to cultivate and at a moderate price the esculent root which be know in the spanish island by the name of _ bata _ be here name ingame by the negro and be they principal food either boil or roasted under the ash there be different kind of this root produce on the island but that which be know by the name of _ igname cicorero _ be prefer by the merchant vessel all of which purchase considerable quantity as a sea-stock for they homeward voyage and the negro cultivate they largely for the express purpose of supply the ship -lrb- 11 -rrb- this island be distinguish by a high mountain in the middle thickly cover by tall straight and verdant tree and its summit be continually envelop in cloud whence water be diffuse in numerous stream all over the island a large shallow stream flow through the city of pouoasan supply it with abundance of excellent water which the inhabitant reckon of a medicinal quality and allege that st thoma would not be habitable if it be not for this river and its other numerous spring and rivulet the native tree be chiefly barren and though some olive peach and almond be plant by the early settler which soon grow with great luxuriance they never bear any fruit and this have be the case with all stone fruit that have be try but the cocoa-nut palm bring hither from ethiopium have thrive satisfactorily repeat attempt have be make to cultivate wheat but always unsuccessfully though try at different season of the year as the ear would never fill but always run up to straw and chaff only in march and September the sky be always overcast with cloud and mist and continual rain prevail which season be consider by the inhabitant as they winter in may June July and August which they call _ mesi di vento _ or windy month the prevalent wind be from the south southeast and southwest but the island be sheltered by the continent from the north northeast and northwest wind the summer month be December January and February when the heat be excessive and the atmosphere be continually load with vapor occasion the air to feel like the steam of boiling water the shore of this island abound in many kind of fish and during the month of June and July the inhabitant catch a kind which they name _ le chieppe _ which be singularly delicate in the sea between this island and against all weather -- clarke section iii _ continuation of portuguese discovery from cape st catherine to the kingdom of congo _ we be still oblige to continue the account of the portuguese discovery historically from the want of any regular journal of they early voyage along the african coast in the original effort of the illustrious don henry although the progress be extremely slow we have much to admire in the character of that prince who possess genius to stretch beyond the trammel of custom and authority boldly think for himself point out the way of extend the knowledge of we globe by maritime discovery and persevere nobly in he renew effort in spite of the timid ignorance of he unexperienced pilot and mariner but it be not easy to explain the continuance of that slow progress which be even retard during the year which elapse between the demise of that prince of mariner in 1463 and that of alphonso in 1481 when the increase experience of the portuguese in they frequent voyage to the new discover atlantic island and african coast ought to have inspire they with fresh vigor and extend view of discovery and commerce the military character of alphonso may however explain this in a great degree as all he energy be direct towards the extension of dominion in the moorish kingdom of fez and the business of discovery be devolve as a burdensome and unprofitable task on the farmer of the trade to the coast of africa which appear to have become extensive and lucrative after the discovery of guinea and its island and the establishment of the sugar colony in these island we learn likewise from the precede voyage of the portuguese pilot to the island of st thoma that the mariner still confine themselves almost entirely to creep along the coast from cape to cape and from island to island not daring to trust themselves to the trackless ocean under the now sure guidance of the heavenly luminary but which they then do not sufficiently understand nor do they possess sufficient instrument for direct they course in the ocean it would appear that they have then no other method of compute the longitude but by means of the log or dead reckoning which be liable to perpetual uncertainty from current and lee-way and which a storm even of short continuance must have throw into total confusion they instrument and method for determine even the latitudes appear to have then be imperfect and little understand in the sequel of this deduction we shall find the first portuguese squadron which sail for indium conduct across the indian ocean by a moorish pilot on the accession of john ii to the throne of portugal in 1481 the discovery along the coast of africa be resume with a new spirit while infante or hereditary prince he principal revenue be derive from the profit of the guinea trade and of the importation of gold from the haven of mina and among the first measure of he reign he turn he attention to the improvement and extension of that valuable branch of commerce for this purpose he give order to make all necessary preparation for build a fortress and church at the port of mina all the requisite material even to stone and tile be accordingly ship from lisbon in a squadron of ten caravel and two transport with 500 soldier and 200 labourer or workman of various kind this expedition be place under the command of don diego d'azumbuja a experienced officer under whom be the follow naval captain gonalez da fonseca ruy d'oliveira juan rodrigue gante juan alfonso diego rodrigue inglez bartholomew diaz pedro d'evora and gomez aire this last be a gentleman belong to the household of pedro king of arragon all the other be nobleman of the household of king john pedro de cintra and fernam d'alfonso command the transport and a small vessel attend the squadron as a advice-boat this squadron sail on the 11th December 1481 and reach they destination on the 19th January 1482 at a african village name _ aldea _ where they find juan bernardo who have previously sail for the coast in quest of gold bernardo be immediately send by azumbuja to inform camarana the negro chief of the district with the arrival of the portuguese armament and to desire a conference with direction to endeavor to impress that chief with a high sense of the rank and character of the portuguese officer and of the irresistible power of the armament now upon he coast early next morning azambuja land with all he follower who be secretly arm in case of meeting with any hostility from the native and move forwards in great form to a large tree not far from the negro village of aldea on a spot which have be choose as a convenient situation for the intended fortress a flag bear the royal arm of portugal be immediately display upon the tree and a altar be place under the shade of its bough at which the whole company unite in assist at the first mass that be celebrate in guinea offer up they solemn prayer to god for the speedy conversion of the idolatrous native and for the perpetual continuance and prosperity of the church which be to be erect on this spot the day on which this impressive ceremony be perform be dedicate to st sebastian that name be give to the valley on which the tree stand under which they be now assemble soon after the completion of this religious ceremony camarana approach with a numerous train azambuja sumptuously dress and ornament by a rich golden collar prepare to receive the negro chief seat on a elevated chair have all he retinue arrange before he so as to form a avenue the negro be arm with spear shield bow and arrow and wear a kind of helmet make of skin thickly stud with fish tooth give they a very martial appearance the subordinate chief be distinguish by chain of gold hanging from they neck and have various golden ornament on they head and even on they beard after the exchange of present and other token of mutual respect and confidence azambuja make a speech to camarana through the mediation of a interpreter in which he explain the purpose of he embassy and expedition and use every argument he could think of to conciliate the friendship of the negro chief to make he fully sensible of the power of the king of portugal and to reconcile he to the intended permanent establishment upon the toast camarana listen to the harangue and the explanation of it by the interpreter in respectful silence keep he eye steadily fix on the countenance of azambuja after which cast he eye for some time on the ground as if profoundly meditate on what he have hear he be say to have make the follow guard and judicious answer : i be fully sensible of the high honor do I on this occasion by you sovereign i have always endeavor to deserve he friendship by deal strictly with he subject and by constantly exert myself to procure immediate lading for they ship hitherto the portuguese who have visit my country be meanly dress and easily satisfy with the commodity we have to give they and so far from desire to remain in the country be always anxious to complete they cargo and to return whence they come this day i observe a wonderful difference a great number of person richly dress be eager for permission to build themselves house and to remain among we but assuredly person of such rank under the guidance of a commander who claim he descent from the god who create the day and the night would never be able to endure the hardship of we climate and could not procure in this country those luxury they have be accustom to in they own those passion which be common to all man will certainly produce dispute between we and it be much better that we should continue on the same footing as hitherto allow you ship to come and go as they have always do before in which case the desire of see each other occasionally and of mutual intercourse in trade will preserve peace between you and we the sea and the land which be always neighbor be continually at variance contend for the mastery the sea always violently endeavor to subdue the land which with equal obstinacy defend itself against the encroachment of the sea the prudential jealousy and distrust display on this occasion by camarana astonished and perplex the portuguese commander and it require the exercise of much address on he part to prevail upon the negro chief to allow the fulfilment of he order and to prevent the necessity of have recourse to violent measure when the workman be make preparation next day to lay the foundation of the intended fortress on the coast they observe a large rock which lay very commodious for serve they as a quarry and accordingly proceed to work it for that purpose this happen unfortunately to be venerate by the negro as one of they god and they immediately fly to arm in opposition against the sacrilegious violation of the sanctify rock and many of the workman be wound before the native could be pacify by numerous present at length after the constant labor of twenty day the fort begin to assume a formidable appearance and receive the name of _ fortaleza de san jorge da mina _ or fort st george at mina in a church construct within its wall a solemn mass be appoint to be celebrate annually in honor of don henry duke of viseo of illustrious memory azambuja continue governor of this place during two year and seven month and be honor on he return to portugal with particular mark of royal favor in 1486 king john bestow on this new establishment all the privilege end immunity of a city impressed with the great advantage that might be derive to he kingdom through discover towards the east with a strict prohibition against the interference of any european state in that immense field of discovery commerce and colonization the pope concede this enormous grant probably without the most distant idea of its extent and importance : not only prohibit all christian power from intrude within those prodigious yet indefinite bound which he have bestow upon the crown of portugal but declare that all discovery that be or might be make in contravention should belong to portugal hitherto the portuguese navigator in the course of they discovery along the shore into the east for the discovery of the country of _ presbyter _ or _ prester john _ and to trace the step of the lucrative commerce then carry on with indium by the venetian for spice and drug part of they instruction be to endeavor to ascertain the practicability of navigate round the south extremity of africa to the famed mart of indian commerce and to make every possible inquiry into the circumstance of that important navigation some writer have place this journey as prior in point of time to the voyage of diaz and have even imagine that the navigator be direct or instruct by the report which covilham transmit respect indium of the relation of this voyage by alvarez which purcha publish in a abbreviated form from a translation out of the italian in the collection of ramusio find among the papers of hakluyt purcha give the follow character : i esteem it true in those thing which he saith he see : in some other which he have by relation of enlarge traveller or boast abassine he may perhaps sometimes rather _ mendacium dicere _ than _ mentirus _ to _ tell _ lie rather than _ make _ they covilham or covillan be bear in a town of that name in portugal and go when a alphonso who make he a man-at-arms after the death of that king he be one of the guard of king john who employ he on a mission into spain on account of he knowledge in the language he be afterwards employ in barbary where he remain some time and acquire the arabic language and be employ to negotiate a peace with the king of tremesen he be a second time send into barbary on a mission to king _ amoli-bela-gegi _ to procure restitution of the bone of the infant don fernando in which he be successful after he return he be join in commission as before-mentioned with alphonso de payva and these adventurous traveller leave lisbon in may 1487 covilham be furnish with a very curious map for these time by the prince emanuel afterwards king of portugal which have be copy and compose with great care and secrecy by the licentiate calzadillum afterwards bishop of viseo assist by doctor rodrigo and a jewish physician name mose which map assert the practicability of pass by sea to indium round the southern extremity of africa on some obscure information which have be collect by those who construct it with a supply of 500 crown in money and a letter of credit or bill of exchange covilham and
