ii 1091 -lrb- 2 -rrb- el tor be on the arabian coast of the red sea near the mouth of the bahr assuez or gulf of suez in lat 28  10 ' n long 33  36 ' e -- e chapter vi history of the discovery and conquest of indium by the portuguese between the year 1497 and 1525 : from the original portuguese of herman lope de castaneda introduction although in strict conformity to chronological arrangement the discovery of america by columbus in 1492 ought to precede we account of the discovery of the maritime route from europe to indium by the portuguese which do not take place until the year 1498 it yet appear more regular to follow out the series of portuguese navigation and discovery to its full completion than to break down that original and vast enterprise into fragment we might indeed have stopt with the first voyage of de gama which effect the discovery of indium : but as the contents of this chapter consist of what may be consider a authentic original record and carry on the operation of the portuguese in indium to the year 1525 it seem preferable to retain this curious original history entire it be obvious that castaneda must have use the original journal of de gama and other early portuguese commander or of some person engage in the voyage and transaction as he often forget the historical language and use the familiar diction of a person actually engage as will appear in many passage of this chapter the title of this original document now first offer to the public in modern english be _ the first booke of the historie of the discoverie and conquest of the east india by the portingal in the time of king don john the second of that name by hernan lope de castaneda translate into english by nichola lichefield and dedicate to sir fraunce drake imprint at london by thoma east 1582 _ though the transaction here record be limit in the title to the reign of john ii they occupy the reign of he immediate successor emmanuel or manuel and of john iii castaneda history be print in black letter at coimbra in eight volume folio in the year 1552 1553 and 1554 and be now exceedingly scarce in 1553 a translation of the first book be make into french by nicolas de grouchy and publish at paris in quarto a italian translation be publish at venice in two volume quarto by alfonso uloa in 1578 -lrb- 1 -rrb- that into english by lichefield employ on the present occasion be in small quarto and black-letter the voyage of de gama be relate by de barros in he work entitle da asia and have be describe by osorius ramusio maffeus and de farium purcha give a brief account of it i ii 26 the beautiful poem of the lusiad by camoen the portuguese homer be dedicate to the celebration of this important transaction and be well know through a elegant translation into english by mickle in the present chapter the curious and rare work of castaneda so far as he first book extend be give entire and the only freedom employ in this version besides change the english of 229 year ago into the modern and more intelligible language have be to prune a quaint verbosity mistake by lichefield for rhetorical eloquence the dedication of the early translator to the celebrated sir franci drake be preserve in its original dress as a sufficient specimen of the language of england at the close of the sixteenth century dedication _ to the right worshipfull sir fraunce drake knight n l g wisheth all prosperitie _ they haue a auncient custome in persium -lrb- the which be also observe throughout all asia -rrb- that none will enterprise to visit the king noble man or perticularly any other person of countenance but he carieth with he some thing to present he with all worthy of thanks the which be not onely do in token of great humilitie & obedience but also of a zealous loue & friendly affection to they superior & welwiller so i -lrb- right worshipfull follow this persian president -rrb- hauing take vpon I this simple translation out of the portingale tongue into we english language be bold to present & dedicate the same vnto you as a signification of my entire good will the history conteineth the discouerie and conquest of the east india make by sundry worthy captaine of the portengale in the time of king don manuel & of the king don john the second of that name with the description not onely of the country but also of every harbor apperteining to every place whervnto they come & of the great resistance they find in the same by reson wherof there be sundry great battle many time fight and likewise of the commodity & riches that euery of these place doth yeeld and for that i know you worship with great peril and daunger haue past these monstrous and bottomlesse see be therfore the more encouraged to desire & pray you worship patronage & defense therof request you with all to pardon those imperfection which i acknowledge to be very many & so much the more by reason of my long & many year continuance in foreine country howbeit i hope to have truly observe the literal sence & full effect of the history as the author setteth it forth which if it may please you to peruse & accept in good part i shall be greatly embolden to proceede & publish also the second & third booke which i be assure will neither be vnpleasant nor vnprofitable to the reader thus alwaie wish you good worship such prosperous continuance and like fortunate successe as god have hitherto send you in you dangerous trauaile & affayre and as maye euery waye content you owne hearte desire doe euen so take my leaue from london the fifth of march 1582 you worship alwaye to commaund _ nichola lichefild _ -lrb- 1 -rrb- bibl des voyage v 2 \* \* \* \* \* dedication by castaneda _ to the most high and mighty prince john iii king of portugal and algarve & c _ it have seem to I most high and mighty prince we dread king and sovereign so important and weighty a matter to undertake a history of the great and valiant action which we portuguese have perform in the discovery and conquest of indium that i often think to relinquish the attempt but as these noble deed be principally undertake and perform for the glory of almighty god the conversion of the barbarous nation to the christian faith and the great honor of you highness and as by the power and mercy of the omnipotent such fortunate success have be grant to these famous enterprise i have be encourage to proceed i therefore trust entirely to the aid and comfort of the divine goodness in publish this work give the glory thereof to god alone and its earthly praise to you excellent highness and the king don manuel you father of famous and happy memory although these glorious deed be well know and spread abroad over the world they yet can not be sufficiently make manifest unless set forth in write by means of which they memory may endure for ever and remain always as if present to the reader as history have perpetuate the action of the greek and roman which be of such high antiquity of other transaction nothing inferior to theirs perhaps even far greater which have be perform by other nation there be little or no memory because these do not remain record by history : such be those of the assyrian mede and persian of the african against the roman of the suevus against julius caesar of the spaniard in recover they country from the moor and principally of these invincible and pious king of portugal you glorious ancestor don alonso henrique don sancho he son and don alonso who acquire the kingdom of portugal and algarve by great and wonderful deed of arm of all which there hardly remaineth any memory for want of have be duly record by write so likewise of those action which have be perform in indium only as it be of yesterday the exact memory of they be confine to four person and if they be to die all remembrance of these transaction must have end to they great dishonor consider these thing i resolve to record these noble deed which the subject of you highness have perform in the discovery and conquest of indium which have never be surpass in valor or even equal in any age or country leave all mention of the conquest of cyrus and other barbarian and even take into the account the deed of alexander so famous over all the world which be as nothing compare to what have be perform since indium become frequent by the portuguese no more than a dead lion can be liken to one alive the conquest of alexander be all by land and achieve by himself in person against nation who be little trained or accustomed to feat of arm but the portuguese conquest of indium be perform by the captain of you highness after a voyage by sea of a year and eight month go almost around the globe from the utmost limit of the west through the vast and bottomless ocean see only the heaven and the water a thing never before attempt by man and hardly even imagine after surmount hunger and thirst and daily exposure to furious storm and a thousand danger in the voyage they have to encounter great and cruel battle on they arrival in indium not against man arm only with bow and spear as in the time of alexander but with people of stout and try courage and experience in war have ordinance and fire-worker more numerous even than the portuguese besides many other excellent weapon the power of these man against whom the subject of you highness have to contend be infinitely greater than that of king porus against whom alexander have to encounter yet the portuguese though few in number uniformly have the victory and never retire from the war as be do by alexander leave the action of the greek and consider what be perform by the roman with they innumerable army and vast fleet which seem to cover the face of the sea and by means of which they think to have conquer the whole earth yet they never adventure beyond the red sea neither be the greatest of they famous victory comparable to those battle which have be fight by we man in indium in which most invincible prince the great prosperity of you father and you be well know as without move from you palace discovery and conquest have be achieve by you captain more extensive than ever be discover or conquer by any prince in person there never be any conquest either by the barbarian greek or roman of any thing like equal difficulty with this of indium neither any king or captain of any of these nation equal in valor and conduct to those of you father and yourself as will manifestly appear from the whole tenor of the following history the great action which the subject of you highness have worthily accomplish must be deem to have be permit and appoint by the providence of god that so those barbarian with they vain idol and the false sectary of mahomet might be bring into the catholic faith as at this time great number have be add to the christian religion for since these great exploit you highness as a most godly and christian prince have take especial care and have give command that the christian doctrine of the _ brotherhood of the company of jesus _ should be teach in indium which you order to be bring from rome and have always support at you expence thus likewise you have erect and found the noble and sumptuous university of coimbra to augment the honor and reputation of you kingdom where besides many divine and college of poor beg friar to expound the evangelical law there be temporal man also to instruct those of you subject that defend and enlarge the commonwealth by deed of arm and those who adorn the same by means of learn all these heroic virtue of you highness be well know to I have encourage I to publish this work and other which have some taste of learn that they may remain a perpetual memorial of the noble deed of so many gentleman and knight of portugal you subject in this i have be much forward by have be in indium where i sojourn with my father who be send into that country by you highness as a judge i spend all my youth in the pursuit of learning and in the study of ancient historian be in indium i set myself with all diligence to learn and understand all that have be do in regard to the discovery and conquest of that country by the portuguese with the intention of make the same known and common to all man by my inquiry and through the information derive from sundry gentleman and captain both such as be actually present in the various transaction and employ in they execution as by other who be engage in counselling and prepare the means of they be perform i have derive much authentic information as likewise by the perusal of many letter and memorial which be write by man of credit and reputation all of which i have examine as evidence of the authenticity of my work both while in indium and since my return into portugal as the matter i mean to write of be many so it become necessary for I to acquire information from many source and as those whom i examine be upon oath it be lawful for I to bring they forward as sure evidence in these research some of these man have to be seek after in almost every part of portugal and be separate in sundry place my inquiry have occasion great travel of my person and much expence to which i have devote the greater part of my life and have constitute the preparation for this work my sole recreation since my residence in the university of coimbra in the service of you highness i have join together all these information which together with the duty of my office have cause much toil both of body and mind have now accomplish the composition of this book and other i most humbly offer the same to you highness and after many and most fortunate year of govern i pray god to take you from the transitory seignory of this earth and to receive you into the perpetual joy of heaven _ hernan lope de castaneda _ section i _ previous step take by the king of portugal john ii preparatory to the discovery of indium _ don john the second of that name and thirteenth king of portugal consider that all spice drug precious stone and other riches which come from venice be bring out of the east and be a prince of great penetration and high emprize he be greatly desirous to enlarge he kingdom and to propagate the knowledge of the christian faith to distant region he resolve therefore to discover the way by sea to the country whence such prodigious riches be bring that he subject might thereby be enriched and that he kingdom might acquire those commodity which have hitherto be bring by way of venice he be much encourage to this enterprise by learn that there be christian in indium govern by a powerful monarch call presbyter john who be report to be a christian prince and to whom he think proper to send ambassador that a intercourse of friendship might be establish between they and they subject he consult therefore with the cosmographer of the time whom he direct to proceed accord to the example already give in sailing along the coast of guinea which have be formerly discover by command of the prince he uncle master of the order of christ accordingly bartholomew diaz one of the officer of the royal storehouse at lisbon be send upon this expedition who discover that great and monstrous cape now call of good hope which be unknown to we ancestor find it both terrible and dangerous he yet pass 140 league beyond to a river which he name _ rio del infante _ whence he return into portugal in this voyage diaz give those name which they still retain to the port harbor and river where he take in fresh water and erect certain mark with cross and the royal arm of portugal the last of which be place on a rock name _ el pennol de la cruz _ fifteen league on this side of the before mention river diaz return from this voyage without have procure any intelligence concern indium as all the inhabitant of the coast which he visit and discover be ignorant black savage on the return of diaz king john resolve to attempt the discovery of indium by land for which purpose he have formerly send friar antonio de lisboa by land in company with a lay person but as they be ignorant of the arabic language they could not travel into those part and go no farther than jerusalem whence they return into portugal without have acquire any knowledge of the object of they journey yet the king continue to prosecute this discovery of indium by land for which he employ two of he own servant pedro de covillian and alonso de payva both versant in the arabic language who be instruct to search out the dominion of presbyter john and the country whence the spice and drug be bring to venice and to inquire whether there be any navigation from the southern extremity of africa to indium to these man he give a chart which be extract from a map of the world by calsadillum bishop of viseo a eminent astronomer he give they likewise a general letter of credit and safe conduct require they to be assist and protect and supply with money in whatever kingdom or country they might travel order they to receive 400 crown from the chest of the orchard of almeryn for they charge of this sum they take what they deem necessary to bear they expence till they arrival at valentium in arragon place the rest in the bank of bartholomew of florence to be repay at valentium receive they audience of leave from king john in presence of don manuel duke of viseo afterwards king they depart from santaxen on the 7th may 1487 and come to naple on st john day of that year whence they be forward by the son of cosmo de medici and go to rhode and thence to alexandrium from this place they travel as merchant to cairo whence they go in company with certain moor of fez and tremesen to toro a harbor on the arabian coast of the red sea they here learn many thing respect the indy and of the trade from the red sea to calicut and go from toro to a place on the coast of ethiopium they go to the port of aden the traveller here separate alonso de payva passing over to the emperor of ethiopium erroneously call presbyter john : for he of whom marco polo speak under that title as govern all the indy and whose country join with the great khan of kathay be vanquish and slay in a battle by that sovereign at which time he kingdom be put a end to and no one of that race or title have since reign yet alonso de payva actually believe that the emperor of ethiopium be presbyter john have learn that he be a christian king over a christian nation as shall be more particularly declare hereafter at they separation they agree to meet again at cairo when each have execute he part of the royal order pedro de covillian sail from aden for the indy in a ship belong to the moor of cananor and go to calicut and the island of goa where he acquire complete information respect the spice of indium the commodity which come from other place and the town of the indy the name of all which he insert but ill write in he chart from indium he go to sofala where he procure information respect the great island of st lawrence call the island of the moon by the moor observe that the native of sofalum be black like those of guinea he conclude that all the coast between be under subjection to the negro and consequently that navigation be practicable from guinea to sofalum and thence to the indy return from sofala he go to ormus and thence to cairo where he learn that alonso de payva be dead and mean to have return to portugal he chance to meet at cairo two spanish jew rabbi abraham a native of viseo and joseph bear in lamego who after the departure of covillian and payva from portugal have tell the king that they have be in cairo where they have receive much information concern ormus and of its trade with the indy from these jew covillian receive letter from the king direct to he and payva order they to return along with the jew if they have see all that he have give they in charge if they have not execute all he original instruction they be now direct to send by the jew a exact account of all the knowledge they have acquire and to use they utmost effort to visit presbyter john and to give all the information in they power respect ormus to rabbi abraham who have swear by he law not to return to portugal without visit that place on receive these letter covillian change he intention of return into portugal and dispatch joseph there with letter to the king give a account of all that he have see and learn in indium and sofalum and transmit the chart on which he have insert all the place he have visit in these letter he inform the king that the emperor of ethiopium be assuredly the same with presbyter john but my opinion be that this be a error as this sovereign have no such name in he own dominion as i shall more clearly shew hereafter on the departure of joseph covillian and rabbi abraham go to ormus and thence back to the red sea whence covillian send abraham into portugal with letter to the king contain all the information acquire in this part of the expedition and intimate he determination to go into the dominion of presbyter john this he accordingly do and come to the presence of the then emperor of ethiopium name alexander to whom he deliver the letter with which he have be entrust by the king of portugal for that monarch alexander receive he courteously and seem much pleased with the letter of the king of portugal as be from so very distant a christian prince yet do not seem to attach much credit or importance to they but he give all honor and many gift to covillian when covillian be ready to depart from ethiopium and await leave for that purpose which he have solicit alexander die and be succeed by a new emperor name _ nahu _ who could never be prevail on to allow of he departure neither could he procure leave for that purpose from the next emperor david the son of nahu so that covillian have to remain in ethiopium and never return into portugal from that time king john never hear more of he and therefore conclude that he be dead nothing have ever be receive from he respect he travels except what be contain in the letter carry by the jew as before mention there come afterwards to lisbon a friar from this country of presbyter john who be receive courteously by the king and on whose report of great thing concern that country the king determine to proceed in make a discovery of the way to the indy by sea he accordingly give order to john de bragana he surveyor of the forest to cut down timber for build two small ship for that voyage but king john die and be succeed by king manuel of glorious memory who have be choose by divine providence to accomplish the discovery of these country by which the christian faith have be greatly extend the royal house of portugal much honor and the subject wonderfully enriched section ii _ narrative of the first voyage of vasco de gama to indium and back in the year 1497 1498 and 1499 _ on the death of king john he be succeed by don manuel a prince of a great mind bent upon high enterprise and prone to undertake and execute thing beyond the ordinary reach of human knowledge even more than be alexander the great be exceedingly desirous to prosecute the discovery of the indy which have be begin by he predecessor and proceeding upon the information leave he by king john relative to that navigation he command fernan lorenzo treasurer of the house of mina to cause construct two ship for this voyage from the timber which have be provide by king john these be name the angel gabriel and the san raphael the former being of the burden of 120 ton the latter 100 in addition to these a caravel of 50 ton call the berrio and a ship of 200 ton be purchase in the year 1497 the king appoint vasco de la gama as chief captain for the voyage a experienced navigator who have do great service and a man of great valor well fit for execute the great enterprize intend by the king paulo de la gama brother to the captain-general and nicholas coello both man of valor and enterprise be appoint the other captain of the squadron bartholomew diaz be likewise command to accompany the squadron of discovery in a caravel to the mirna : and as the three ship of war appoint for the voyage could not contain a sufficient supply of provision for they crew the ship of 200 ton which have be purchase from ayre correa be order to accompany de gama to a place call st blaze at which the squadron be to take in water where the victuals with which she be load be to be distribute to the other ship after which she be order to be burnt have receive they order vasco de la gama and the other captain take they leave of the king at _ monte mayor _ and depart for lisbon where he embark he company of 148 person at belem on Saturday the 8th of July 1497 at this embarkation all the religious belong to the church of we lady at belem go in procession in they cowl bare - head and carry wax candle pray for the success of the expedition accompany by almost the whole people of lisbon weep and deplore the fate of those who now embark as devoted to certain death in the attempt of so dangerous a voyage thus commend to god and good fortune the officer and crew embark and immediately set sail vasco de la gama the captain-general take the command in the angel gabriel of which pedro de alenquer be pilot who have be in the same capacity with diaz when he pass the cape of good hope and discover the _ rio del infante _ paulo de gama go captain of the san raphael nichola coello of the caravel berrio and gonsalo gome -lrb- 1 -rrb- a servant of vasco de la gama command the large victualling ship the captain-general give out instruction that in case of separation they should keep they course for cape verd which be appoint as they rendezvous proceed on the voyage they come in sight of the canary in eight day whence steer for rio de oro they be separate by a tempest during a exceedingly dark night on which they all shape they course for cabo verde paulo de la gama nicholas coello bartholomew diaz and gonsalo gome rejoin and sail together for eight day when they come in sight of the captain-general on Wednesday evening and salute he with many gun and the sound of trumpet all heartily rejoice for they safe meeting and good fortune in this they first essay of danger next day be the 20th of July -lrb- 2 -rrb- the fleet reach the island of st jago and come to anchor in the bay of santa marium where it remain seven day take in fresh water and repair the yard and other part of they rigging which have be damage in the late storm on Tuesday the 3d of August -lrb- 3 -rrb- the captain-general go on he voyage after take leave of diaz who now return to portugal proceeding for the cape of good hope with all he squadron de la gama _ enter the gulf into the sea _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- and sail all August September and October suffer many great tempest of violent wind and rain so that they often expect instant death at length on Saturday the 4th November they get sight of land at nine in the forenoon at which they be greatly rejoice and be all together the captain salute the general all dress in they best array and have they ship all decorate with flag not know the coast they sail along until the Tuesday follow when they have a perfect view of a low shore in which be a great bay that appear convenient for the ship to take in water into which they all enter and come to anchor this place be afterwards name _ angra de santa elena _ or st helen 's bay -lrb- 5 -rrb- the people of the country as we man afterwards find be small black ill-favoured savage clothe in the skin of beast somewhat like french cloak have curious work wooden case for they privity and in speak they seem always sigh these native be arm with oak stave harden in the fire point with the horn of beast somewhat burnt or harden with fire which serve they for sword they live on the root of herb and on sea wolf and whale which be very numerous in this country likewise on sea crow and gull they also eat of certain beast which they call gazela and other beast and bird which the land produce and they have dog which bark like those of portugal the general after the squadron be bring to anchor send coello in a boat along the shore in search of water which he find four league from the anchor ground at a place which he name st jago -lrb- 6 -rrb- whence all the ship provide themselves with fresh water next day the general with the other captain escort by some of the people go on shore to view the native and to endeavor to learn what distance the cape of good hope be from thence for the chief pilot who have be on the voyage with diaz have depart thence on return in the morning into the open sea with a fair wind and have pass it during the night and have not come near the shore when outward bind wherefore he do not certainly know its situation nor be he acquaint with its appearance but conjecture it might be thirty league from where they then be at the utmost when the general be on shore he overtake one of the native who be go to gather honey at the foot of a bush where it be deposit by the bee without any hive with this person he return to the ship think to have get a interpreter but no one on board the squadron could understand he language the general command this man to have meat and drink and set he on shore next day well dress that he might return satisfied to he countryman accordingly the day follow this man come down to the shore abreast of the ship with about fifteen more native and the general go ashore carry with he spice gold and pearl to try if these people have any knowledge of these thing but from the little estimation with which these article be view it be conclude that the native have no knowledge of they the general distribute among the native some small bell tin ring counter and such toy which they receive joyfully and from that time till next Saturday morning great number of the native resort to the fleet whence they go back to they town one fernan veloso crave leave of the general to accompany the native to they habitation that he might see they manner of live on go along with they the native take a sea wolf which they roasted at the foot of a hill for they supper after which they make veloso return to the fleet and it appear to he that the native have arm themselves mean to attack we people on he return veloso see that he be secretly follow wherefore he hasten to the shore and hail the ship on this the general who be then at supper look out towards the land where he see number of the savage follow veloso he therefore give order for all the ship to be in readiness against a attack and go himself on shore with several other unarmed not dread any harm on see we boat come towards the shore the savage begin to run away with much clamor but when we people land they return and set upon they furiously throw they dart and use other weapon which constrain we people to take to they boat in all haste take veloso along with they yet in this scuffle the general and three other be wound the negro return to they town and during four day after while we ship remain in the bay they never see any more of the native so that they have no opportunity to revenge the injury they have do some commerce take place between the portuguese and the hottentot native around st elena bay by means of sign and gesture when the fleet receive plenty of excellent fresh provision in exchange for clothes hawk bell glass bead and other toy but this friendly intercourse be interrupt through the imprudence of a portuguese young man name veloso delighted with the novelty of the scene and anxious to see the manners of the native more intimately he obtain permission to accompany they to they hut where a sea calf be dress in the hottentot fashion to he great astonishment disgust at they loathsome cookery he rise abruptly and be impatient to depart and be accompany by the native on he way back to the ship with the utmost good humor veloso however become apprehensive of personal danger and horridly vociferated for assistance on he approach to the shore coello boat immediately put off to bring he on board and the native flee to the wood these needless apprehension on both side be increase by mutual ignorance of each other language and lead to hostility while de gama be take the altitude of the sun with a astrolabe some hottentot spring from a ambush and throw they spear head with horn very dexterously among the portuguese by which the general and several other be wound on this occasion the portuguese deem it prudent to retreat to they ship -lrb- 7 -rrb- have take in fresh water and provision in st elena bay the squadron leave that place on the forenoon of Thursday the 16th November with the wind at ssw and steer for the cape of good hope and on the evening of the follow Saturday come in sight of that cape but on account of the wind be contrary he have to stand out to sea all day and turn towards the land as night set in in that manner he continue ply to windward until the follow Wednesday which be the 20th of November -lrb- 8 -rrb- when he double the cape with a fair wind sound the trumpet of all the ship and make every demonstration of joy but place the chief confidence in god that he providence would guide and protect they in accomplish the enterprise in which they be engage in this part of the voyage the greatest proof of courage and resolution be evince by de gama while endeavor to double this formidable and almost unknown cape owe to contrary wind and stormy weather the wave rise mountain high at one time he ship be heave up to the cloud and seem the next moment precipitate into the bottomless abyss of the ocean the wind be piercingly cold and so boisterous that the command of the pilot could seldom be hear amid the din of the war element while the dismal and almost constant darkness increase the danger of they situation sometimes the gale drive they irresistibly to the southward while at other time they have to lay to or to tack to windward difficultly preserve the course they have already make during any gloomy interval of cessation from the tempest the sailor exhaust by fatigue and abandon to despair surround de gama entreat he not to devote himself and they to inevitable destruction as the gale could no longer be weather and they must all be bury in the wave if he persist in the present course the firmness of the general be not to be shake by the pusillanimity and remonstrance of the crew on which a formidable conspiracy be enter into against he of which he receive timely information from he brother paulo with he assistance and that of a few who remain stedfast to they duty the lead conspirator and even all the pilot be put in iron whilst de gama and he small remnant of faithful follower remain day and night at the helm undismay at the danger and difficulty that surround they at length on Wednesday the 20th November all the squadron safely double the tremendous promontory -lrb- 9 -rrb- continue the voyage along the coast beyond the cape they see great number of large and small cattle as they pass all well grow and fat but could perceive no town as the village inhabit by the native be all farther inland the house be of earth cover with straw the native be all somewhat black clothe like those they have see at st elena bay speak the same language and use similar dart together with some other kind of arm both for defense and assault the country be very pleasant be diversify with wood and water and adjoining to the cape on the east side they find a great harbor now call false bay almost six league wide at the mouth and run about as much into the land have thus double the cape the squadron come on the Sunday after be st katherine 's day 25th November to the watering-place of st blaze -lrb- 10 -rrb- which be sixty league beyond the cape and be a very large bay exceed safe in all wind except the north -lrb- 11 -rrb- the native here resemble those already see in dress and arm the country produce many large elephant and numerous ox of vast size and extremely fat some of which have no horn on some of the fattest of these the native be see ride on pannel stuff with rye straw as be use in spain and have a frame of wood like a saddle such of they as they choose to sell they mark by means of a piece of wood like the shaft of one of they arrow put through the nose in this harbor about three cross-bow shot from the shore there be a rock much frequent by sea wolf as large as great bear very wild and fierce with long great tooth these animal be very dangerous and will attack man and they skin be so hard as not to be pierce with spear unless push with much force and valor these animal resemble lion and they young bleat like kid one day that we man go to this rock for amusement they see at least three thousand of these animal old and young on this rock also there be great number of bird as large as duck which do not fly have no feather in they wing and which bray like so many ass -lrb- 12 -rrb- have thus arrive at the bay of st blaze and lie there at anchor the general cause all the provision to be take out of the store-ship and divide among the other and then burn the store-ship as the king have order in this business and other needful employment for they safety in the remainder of the voyage they be occupy in that bay for ten day on the Friday after they arrival about ninety of the native make they appearance some on the shore and other on the hill on which the general and the captain go to the shore have they boat crew well arm and even take ordinance with they to avoid the same accident which have happen at st elena bay when near the shore the general throw some bell on the land which the negro pickt up and some of they come so near as to take the bell out of he hand he much wonder at this familiarity as diaz have inform he when he be in those part the native all run away and would never approach near enough to be see and converse with find they thus gentle contrary to he expectation he go on land with he man and barter red night - cap with the negro for ivory bracelet which they wear on they arm next Saturday the native come to the shore to the number of more than two hundred include they child and bring with they twelve ox and four sheep when we people go on shore some of the native begin to play on four flute in four several tone make good music on which the general cause the trumpet to be sound and the native dance with we people thus the day pass in mirth and feast and in purchase they ox and sheep on Sunday a still greater number of the native come down to the shore have several woman among they and bring a number of ox for sale after the sale of one of the ox some of we people notice some young negro hide among certain bush who have with they the weapon of the older people from which it be conjecture that some treason be intend upon this the general cause we people to remove to a place of greater security and be follow by the negro to the landing place the negro now gather together as if they mean to fight the portuguese on which the general be unwilling to harm they embark in the boat with all he people and then command two piece of brass ordnance to be fire off on which they be much amaze and scamper off in confusion leave they weapon behind after this the general order a cross or pillar have the arm of portugal to be set upon the shore but the negro pull it down immediately even before we people retire after remain ten day here as before mention the fleet set sail for the rio del infante on Friday the 8th December be the conception of we lady and during this part of the voyage there arise a great storm with _ forewind _ on the eve of st lucy 12th December that all the ship run under close reefed course during this storm they part company with nichola coello but rejoin the next night after on the 16th December when the gale abate they discover land near certain small rock sixty league from the harbor of st blaze and five league from the pennon de la cruz where diaz set up he last stone pillar -lrb- 13 -rrb- and fifteen league short of the rio del infante -lrb- 14 -rrb- this country be very pleasant and abound in cattle become more sightly and with higher tree the further we fleet sail towards the east as could be easily see from the ship as they sail along near the shore on Saturday they pass close within sight of the rock _ de la cruz _ and be loath to pass the _ rio del infante _ they stand out to sea till vespers when the wind come round to the east right contrary on this the general stand off and on ply to windward till Tuesday the 20th December at sunset when the wind change to the west which be favourable next day at ten o'clock they come to the before-mentioned rock be sixty league a-stern of the place they wish to have attain -lrb- 15 -rrb- this rock be the cause of the great current on this coast which be so powerful that the fleet have much ado with a brisk favourable wind to stem the current between that place and rio infante in three or four day but at length they joyfully pass these current without damage as diaz have do formerly and the general encourage by he good fortune give thanks to god say he verily believe it be the good pleasure of god that they should attain to the discovery of the indy thus continue the voyage till christmas day they have discover seventy league to the eastward and have arrive in the latitude in which indium be say to be in he instruction the fleet continue to sail for so long a time without go to land as to be in want of water insomuch that they have to dress they provision in sea water and be force to reduce the allowance of drink to one pint of water per man each day but on Friday the 11th January 1498 draw near the land the boat be send out to view the coast where they see many negro both man and woman all of whom be of great stature and follow we boat along the coast as these people appear quiet and civil the general call martin alonzo who could speak many of the negro language and desire he and another to leap on shore which they immediately do alonzo and he companion be well receive by the native especially by they chief to whom the general send a jacket a pair of breeches and a cap all of a red color and a copper bracelet of which he be very proud and return thanks to the general say that he might have any thing he wish for or need that he country produce all which as martin alonzo understand they language -lrb- 16 -rrb- he report to the general who be much pleased that by this mean a intercourse could be open with the native alonzo and another of we people be accordingly permit by the general to go for one night along with the native to they town where the chief dress himself out in he new garment and be behold with much admiration by he people in he finery clap they hand for joy this salutation be repeat three or four time on they way to the town and when there the chief make the circuit of the whole village that all the people might see and admire he new and strange attire when this ceremonial be end the chief retire to he own house where he command alonzo and he companion to be well lodge and entertain and give they for supper a hen exactly the same as one of ours and a kind of pap or porridge make of a yellow grain call _ mylyo _ -lrb- 17 -rrb- of which likewise they make bread many of the negro repair that night to they lodging to have a near view of the stranger and next day the chief send they back to the ship accompany by some negro laden with hen for the general who return thanks for the same by means of alonzo he interpreter during five day that we ship remain off this coast no kind of harm be do or offer by the inhabitant who seem quiet and gentle and to have many _ noble man _ for which reason he call this place _ terra da boa gente _ or the land of good people -lrb- 18 -rrb- the town in which martin alonzo be have its house construct of straw yet well furnished within the woman be more numerous than the man as in a company of forty woman there be only twenty man these people be arm with long bow and arrow and have dart head with iron have many copper bracelet on they arm and leg with copper ornament in they hair they have also iron dagger with pewter handle and ivory sheath so that it be manifest they have plenty of copper and tin they have likewise abundance of salt which they make from sea water which they carry in gourd to certain cave where the salt be make they be so fond of linen that they give a great quantity of copper in exchange for a old shirt and be so quiet and civil that they bring water to we boat from a river about two cross-bow shot from the landing which we people name rio do cobre or copper river osorius place the arrival of the portuguese on this part of the coast a day earlier than castaneda and give the follow additional information on the 10th January 1498 they discover some small island about 230 mile from they last watering-place have a very beautiful appearance and consist of verdant meadow intermix with grove of lofty tree where they could see the inhabitant walk on the shore in great number here de gama land and send one of he man who be well versant in the negro language to visit the king and who be receive with much civility receive present of the produce of the country on he dismissal before leave lisbon de gama receive ten malefactor on board who have be condemn to die but be pardon on condition of go on this voyage for the purpose of be leave wherever de gama please that they might examine the country and be enable to give he a account of the inhabitant on he return on set sail from this place de gama leave two of these exile on shore to inform themselves of the character and manners of the native -lrb- 19 -rrb- from this place we fleet depart on the 15th January and proceed on they voyage come to another country of very low land have very thick tall tree and proceed onward they find a river which be very open at the mouth near which he come to anchor on Thursday the 24th of January as the general deem it proper to examine this country and to try if any intelligence could be here procure concern indium that same evening he and he brother nichola coello -lrb- 20 -rrb- enter the river and at day-break next morning the land be observe to be extremely low and cover with water have many tree of great height thickly load with various kind of fruit the country appear very pleasant they see likewise certain boat with some of the native come towards the ship at which the general be well pleased as he conceive from they have some degree of maritime knowledge in these part that he could not now be very far from indium or at least should soon hear news of that country the native be negro of good stature all naked except each a small apron of cloth make of cotton on reach the ship they come on board without hesitation and behave themselves as if they have be long acquaint with we people they be well receive and be present with bell and other toy but do not understand any of the language speak by martin alonzo or any of the other interpreter on board so that the only intercourse be by sign they depart after good entertainment and afterwards they and many other return to the ship in they boat bring with they such provision as they country afford the native seem much satisfied with they reception and besides those who come to the ship by water many other come by land -lrb- 21 -rrb- among whom be several woman who be tolerably handsome especially the young maiden but all be as naked as the man they have three hole in they lip in which they wear small piece of tin by way of ornament the native take several of we man along with they to make merry at one of they town whence they bring water to we ship after the general have be three day in this river two of the noble or head man of the native come on board to visit he who be naked like the rest except that they apron be much larger and one of they have a handkerchief on he head embroider with silk while the other wear a nightcap of green satin -lrb- 22 -rrb- observe they cleanliness or civility the general treat these people courteously and give they victuals apparel and other thing of which they seem to make but small account and by certain sign shew by a young man it be understand that he country be at a considerable distance where he have see ship as large as ours this intelligence give great hope to we people that the indy be not far off which be much confirm by the chief who have be on board send off for sale certain cloth make of cotton on which there be mark of ochre in respect of all these encouraging token the general name this river _ ho rio dos bos sinaes _ or river of good sign and call the place san rafael after the name of he own ship -lrb- 23 -rrb- from the sign of the before-mentioned young man that the country of the head man who have be on board be far off where they have see large ship the general conclude that the indy be still at a great distance and therefore determine in consultation with the other captain to lay the ship aground to give they bottom a thorough repair which be do accordingly in this operation they employ thirty-two day during which we people be much afflict with a grievous sickness think to proceed from the air of the country they hand and foot become swell and they gum become so sore and putrid that they could not eat and the smell of they breath be quite intolerable -lrb- 24 -rrb- with this pestilent infection we people be much discourage and many of they die the survivor be in great trouble and perplexity but de gama take much care and use much diligence for they recovery and to comfort they affliction continually visit the sick and give they such wholesome and medicinal thing as he have provide for he own use through all which many recover who would have die and the rest be thereby greatly comfort and encourage have repair the ship and provide they with all necessaries that could be procure at the river of good sign the fleet depart from thence on Saturday the 24th of February at this period two accident occur which have nearly frustrated all the hope of this expedition de gama be along side of the ship command by he brother with whom he wish to speak have hold of the chain when the boat be carry from under he by the force of the current but by immediate assistance he and he boat crew be providentially save soon afterwards when the fleet be pass the bar of the river the ship of de gama ground on a sand bank and she loss be for some time consider as inevitable but she float again with the return of the tide and to they inexpressible joy receive no damage -lrb- 25 -rrb- as there be little or no wind the fleet stand out to sea to avoid the shore and about vespers on Sunday they descry three small island out to sea about four league distant from each other two of these be replenish with tree but the third be quite bare see no cause to delay the voyage in examine these island de gama hold on for six day come always to anchor at night on the evening of Thursday the first of march they come in sight of four island two of which be near the land and the other two farther out to sea and the fleet steer through the channel next morning the ship command by coello as be the smallest go first but endeavor to enter a certain harbor between the mainland and one of these island coello miss the channel and run aground on which the other ship put about and go back they soon perceive seven or eight boat under sail come from the island which be a good league distant from coello at which sight they be much rejoice and coello and he people receive they with much demonstration of friendship and satisfaction coello go along with these people to the general and present they say that here be a quite different kind of people from any they have see hitherto then the general command _ to let they go a seaboard with they boat _ -lrb- 26 -rrb- as he propose to go with they to they island to anchor with he ship that he might see what kind of a country it be and if he could learn any certain intelligence concern indium but the boat continue to follow we ship make signal and call to we people to wait for they wherefore the ship come to anchor and the boat come to we fleet the people on board be of good stature and somewhat black clothe in dress of cotton strip with sundry color some girdle to they knee while other carry they apparel on they shoulder like cloak they head be cover with kerchief somewhat work with silk and gold thread and they be arm with sword and dagger like moor in they boat also they have certain musical instrument name _ sagbut _ they come immediately on board with as much confidence as if they be long acquaint and enter into familiar conversation in the language of algarve and would not be know as moor -lrb- 27 -rrb- the general order these people to be well entertain and they eat and drink willingly of whatever be set before they after which by means of fernan alvarez who could speak they language he learn that the island to which they belong be call monsambicke or mozambique on which be a town full of merchant who trade with the moor of indium who bring they silver linen cloth pepper ginger silver ring many pearl and ruby and that from a country behind they procure gold they offer likewise to conduct we people into the harbor where they would learn the truth of these thing more fully on consult with the other captain the general determine upon go into this harbor to examine more accurately into these report and to procure pilot to carry they on they voyage as they have no one in the fleet who know the way nichola coello be therefore order to make the first essay and to take the sounding of the bar he ship be the smallest but in enter he touch on the point of the island where he break he helm and be in great danger of be lose but by good providence he get off with no farther injury he now find the bar be quite safe and get into the harbor where he anchor two cross-bow shot from the town which be in fifteen degree towards the south -lrb- 28 -rrb- the harbor be very good the town be plentifully supply with such provision as the country produce the house be construct of straw and the inhabitant moor who trade to sofala in large vessel that have neither deck nor nail they plank be sew together with _ cayro _ or twine make from the fiber of the cocoa nut rind and they sail of mat make of the leaf of a species of palm some of these vessel use compass of genoa and regulate they voyage by means of quadrant and sea chart with these moor the moor of indium trade as likewise do those from the red sea because of the gold which be to be have here on see we people the moor of mozambique think the portuguese have be turk whom they know of from the moor who dwell on the red sea and those who be first at we ship carry intelligence to the xeque or sheik which be the title of the governor of this island for the king of quiloa in whose territory it be situate though we shall afterwards have occasion to investigate this eastern coast of africa more fully in editing particular voyage to its shore some notice seem here to be proper -lrb- 29 -rrb- owe to he keep at a distance from the shore for security the present voyage give little knowledge of the eastern coast of africa and it be even difficult to assign the many station at which de gama touch between the cape of good hope and mozambique we have already notice the river of good sign as be probably the northern mouth of the delta of the zambeze now call _ quilimane _ from a fort of that name on its bank the mouth of this branch run into the sea in lat 18  25 ' s in he passage from the _ terra de natal _ or christmas land so name from have be discover on christmas day and name in this account of de gamas voyage _ the land of good people _ de gama miss cape coriente form the sw point of the channel of mozambique or _ inner passage _ as it be now call and overshoot sofalum the southern extremity of covilham discovery at which he be probably direct to touch as covilham chart might have be of some use to direct he farther progress to aden and thence to calicut or cananor on the malabar coast the eastern coast of africa be hitherto very little known to geography its trade be entirely confine to the portuguese who have settlement at sofalum the river zambeze mozambique quiloa and melinda and conceal all the circumstance respect they foreign possession with infinite jealousy it be say to have once be in contemplation by the british government to employ sir home popham to make a survey of this coast but this design be never execute commodore blanket remain on this station for a considerable time and much information may be expect from he journal some drawing of the coast have be already make for chart which be prepare under the order of the admiralty about the year 1782 a great mass of geographical information be collect on the continent of europe and lodge in the british museum from which information may probably be derive respect this coast when that collection shall have be arrange and submit to the public accord to d'apre all the eastern coast of africa for a great way south of the equinoctial be line by a range of island whence shoal extend to the distance of a league these islet form a of africa in lat 15 30 ' s and the portuguese universally assume mozambique as prasum by which classical name it be distinguish in the lusiad of camoen in reference to the voyage of de gama and the have always be accustom to name all the arabian moor wherever they find they and even give at first the name of _ black _ moor to the negro whence we old english term _ black-a-moor _ it be well know that the arab especially after they conversion to mahometanism be great colonizer or conqueror even the now half-christian kingdom of abyssinium be a early colony and conquest of the pagan arab and its inhabitant be consequently _ white _ moor in the most extended portuguese sense the arab or moorish kingdom along the african coast of the indian ocean be branch from the same original stem and the early mahometan missionary be both zealous and successful in propagate islaemism among the most distant pagan colony of they countryman as all zealous mussulman be enjoin the pilgrimage of mecca and commerce mix largely with religion in the holy journey by which the faithful from every distant region often meet at mecca and induce each other to extend they commercial adventure to new region it may possibly have be that some moor originally from spain may even have reach mozambique before the time of de gama but it be ridiculous to suppose that all the moor on the african coast have be mangale -lrb- 30 -rrb- when the moorish governor of mozambique -lrb- 31 -rrb- be inform of the arrival of the portuguese and that coello be come to anchor in the harbor he fully suppose that they be turk or moor from some distant place and immediately come to visit he apparel in fine silk with many attendant coello receive he very courteously but as neither he nor any in he ship could speak they language the governor soon retire coello give he however a red cap on which he seem to set little value and present he likewise with some black bead which he carry away in he hand both be give and to visit they in person the general in return send the governor a present consist of red hat short gown coral brass bason hawk bell and many other thing which he slight as of no value and ask why the general have not send he scarlet which he chiefly desire soon afterwards the governor come off to visit the general who be apprize of he come order all the ship to be dress out in they flag he likewise make all the sick and infirm man to be keep out of sight and bring a good many of the most alert man from the other ship whom he order to be secretly arm in case of any violence or treachery on the part of the moor the governor come on board accompany with many man all well apparel in silk have many ivory trumpet and other musical instrument on which they play almost without cease the governor be a lean man of good stature dress in a linen shirt down to he heel over which he wear a long gown of mecca velvet have a cap of silk of many color trim with gold on he head at he girdle he wear a sword and dagger and have silk shoe the general receive he on enter the ship and lead he to a awning trim up in the best manner they be able the general then beg he not to be offend that no scarlet have be send have bring none with he and that he ship only contain such merchandize as be fit to be barter for victuals for the people and that he only object at present be to discover the way to the indy for which purpose he have be send by a great and mighty king he master all this be convey through the interpretation of fernan martin -lrb- 32 -rrb- the general then order a entertainment of the best meat and wine which the ship afford to be set before the governor and he principal attendant of all which they partake willingly even drink wine with good will the governor ask whether they come from turkey as he have hear say that the turk be a fair people like they and desire to see we country bow and the book of we law to this the general answer that he and he man be not from turkey but from a kingdom in they neighborhood that he would most willingly shew he bow and other weapon but have not the book of we law as they be not need at sea then some cross-bow be bring which be bent and shoot off in presence of the governor also some of we harness or defensive armor with all of which he be much pleased and greatly astonish during this conference the general learn that the port of calicut in indium be 900 league distant from mozambique and as there be many shoal in the course that it be very necessary to have a pilot from this place he learn also that there be many city along the coast he likewise understand that the kingdom of prester john be far from this place in the inland country -lrb- 33 -rrb- consider the expediency of have a pilot the general request to have two from the governor who agree to the demand on condition that they should be well use the reason of wish to have two be lest one might die during the voyage and we people be much pleased with this promise the governor come a second time to visit the general and bring with he both the pilot whom he have promise to each of whom be give thirty crown and a coat each crown be worth five shilling under this condition that whenever one of they should go on shore the other should remain on board that one might always stay by the ship while in harbor notwithstanding these friendly meeting speech and assurance it soon appear after the departure of the governor that the moor have learn during they intercourse with we people that they be christian on which the former friendship and good will of the moor towards they be change to wrath and fury and they henceforwards use every endeavor to kill we man and to take possession of the ship the governor therefore and he people use every effort for this mischievous purpose and have certainly succeed if the almighty have not move the heart of one of the moorish pilot who have be receive into the portuguese fleet to reveal the same to the general who fear lest the infidel might suddenly execute they purpose as be numerous in comparison to he small company determine to remain no longer in the harbor wherefore on Saturday the 10th march 1498 be seven day after he arrival he quit the harbor of mozambique and cast anchor close to a island at the distance of a league from that place intend on Sunday to hear mass on shore that they might confess and receive the sacrament which have not be do since leave lisbon after the ship be come to anchor in this place of safety from be burn by the moor which the general greatly dread he determine to go he immediately come with the ship berrio under sail to he aid on see this the moor flee away in such haste that the general could not overtake they and therefore return with he brother to where the experience determine on carry the portuguese fleet to the island of quiloa which be all people with moor and as it seem intend to inform the king of that place that we ship belong to the christian Tuesday the fleet be still in sight of the land from which they take they departure and remain becalmed all that day and the next on Wednesday night a gentle breeze spring up from the eastward on would make no peace with the governor unless he send he the other pilot whom he have hire and pay with this answer the _ molah _ depart and never come back after this while still wait for a fair wind there come another moor on board accompany with he son a boy and ask the general to give he a passage to the city of melinda which he say be on he way to calicut he say that he be a native of the of April -lrb- 36 -rrb- stand to the north - west he come in sight before noon of a great land with two island near the coast around which be many shoal on near the shore the moorish pilot recognize while the ship remain thus dry and the people walk about on the sand they see two boat full of moor who come to we ship bring many sweet orange much better than those of portugal these man tell the present which they accept with many thanks and understand that we fleet intend to put in at mombaza they request to be carry thither the general grant they request and permit they to remain on board the other return from we ship to they own country -lrb- 37 -rrb- when it be full sea the st raphael float and get off the shoal and the fleet proceed on its voyage follow the coast to the north-eastward the fleet come to anchor outside of the bar of the harbor of mombaza about sunset of Saturday the 7th of April mombaza be on a island very near the shore of the continent and have plenty of provision such as millet rice and cattle both large and small all well grow and fat especially the sheep which be uniformly without tail and it abound in poultry it be likewise very pleasant have many orchard abound in pomegranate indian fig orange both sweet and sour lemon and citron with plenty of pot-herb and it have a abundant supply of excellent water on this island there be a city have the same name momabza standing in lat 4  s which be handsomely build on a rocky hill wash by the sea the entrance of the haven have a mark or beacon and on the very bar there be a little low fort almost level with the water -lrb- 38 -rrb- most of the house of this place be build of stone and lime have the ceiling finely construct of plaster and the street be very handsome this city be subject to a king of its own the inhabitant be moor some of whom be white and other brown -lrb- 39 -rrb- the trade of this city be extensive and its inhabitant be well dress especially the woman who be clothe in silk and decorate with gold and precious stone the harbor be good and much frequent by shipping and it receive from the african continent in its neighborhood great quantity of honey wax and ivory the general do not enter the harbor that night because it grow late but command to hoist the flag in compliment which the people do with much mirth and joy in hope that they have come to a island in which there be many christian and that next day they might hear mass on shore they have likewise great hope that the sick who be almost the whole crew might here recover they health though indeed they be much reduce in number many have die during the voyage soon after we ship come to anchor although night approach a large boat contain about a hundred man all arm with sword and target be see come they to be shewn ginger pepper clove and wheat give they sample of they all to be carry to the general with assurance that he have great store of all these commodity and would give he he load if he to we people as if they have be long and familiarly acquaint when the tide of flood be sufficiently advance on the follow morning the general give order to weigh anchor intend to carry the ship into the harbor but the almighty disposer of event not willing that he and he company should fall into the snare which the moor have lay for they destruction interpose to avert the danger and to work they safety for when the general ship have weigh anchor and be about to enter the port she touch on a shoal by the stern upon which he immediately let fall he anchor again which be likewise do by the other captain see this the moor who be on board conclude that he would not enter the harbor that day and instantly take to they boat which be alongside and make for the city : at the same time the pilot of mozambique leap from the stern of the admiral ship into the water and be take into the boat by the moor the admiral call out to they to bring he back but all in vain on which he begin to suspect that the moor and they king have evil intention towards he and he people and be thankful for the accident which have detain he from the harbor and preserve he from the purpose treachery after explain he apprehension to the other captain he command in the evening of this day that two of the moor who have be make prisoner at mozambique should be put to the torture to endeavor to ascertain whether any treachery be intend and to force they to disclose the same this be do by drop melted bacon upon they flesh and they immediately confess that treason be intend and that the pilot have escape by swim from the ship as fear the same have be discover on this confession the general resolve on no account to enter the harbor yet determine to put another moor to the torture to learn if he be in confederacy with the rest but this moor on see preparation make for the purpose although he hand be bind leap into the sea which be likewise do by another moor before day-light have thus discover the secret mischief which have be prepare against he the general give thanks to god by whose good providence he and he people have be deliver from imminent hazard of death among the infidel whereupon he and he company join in the _ salve regina _ with great devotion after this lest the moor might attempt any thing against they safety during the night he order a strong and vigilant armed watch to be keep it be worthy of notice that all the sick among we people who be indeed many begin presently to get well from they first come to mombaza so that in this time of they great necessity and danger they find themselves sound and strong beyond all human hope and far above the ordinary course of nature for which reason it can only be attribute to the marvellous and supernatural power of god miraculously do at this peculiar instant time of need for the preservation of these poor and distressed person whose only hope of safety be in he after the night watch be set those of the berrio feel the cable by which they lay at anchor swagging as if shake by a great tunny of which there be many in this place very large and excellent food : but on give more attention to the circumstance they perceive that this be occasion by they enemy the moor some of whom be swim about the cable and be cut it with knife or falchion that the ship might drift on shore and fall a prey to they on see this we man scare they away by cry out and give notice to the other ship to be on they guard against similar attempt some people from the san raphael go immediately to the assistance of the berrio and find some of the moor about the chain and tackling of the foremast who cast themselves into the sea and swam along with those who have attempt to cut the cable to certain boat that be in wait at a short distance in which as we people afterwards learn there be a great number of the moor who now row away to the city in all haste we fleet still remain off the harbor of mombaza all the Wednesday and Thursday follow during both of which night the moor come off in boat which always lay close by the shore whence some of they swim to the ship endeavor to cut we cable : but we man keep such strict watch that they be unable to succeed we people however be always in much fear and perplexity lest the moor might burn we ship and it be wonderful they do not make the attempt by means of the ship they have in the harbor which in all human probability they have succeed in killing and destroy we all it be conjecture that they be deter from make this attempt from fear of the ordnance in we ship but whatever might appear to we as the cause of they not use open force it be assuredly the good pleasure and favor of god that put they heart in fear against make a open attack by which we be preserve from the execution of they cruel purpose towards we the reason of the general remain during the two day off mombaza be that he might endeavor to procure two pilot from thence to carry he to calicut without which assistance the voyage would have be very difficult as we pilot have no knowledge of that country but find none be to be have he take he departure from that place on Friday morning though with a very light wind on leave the anchorage he be force to leave one of he anchor behind as the crew be so completely exhaust by haul up the rest that they be unable to weigh this one it be afterwards find by the moor and carry into they city where it be deposit near the king palace when don francisco de almeida first viceroy of the indy take this place from the moor this anchor be there find as i shall afterwards relate in the second book of this work depart thus from mombaza the fleet continue its voyage along the coast to the north-east and have very light wind be oblige to come to anchor in the evening near the shore about eight league from mombaza towards the dawn of next day two sambucco or little pinnace be see about three league to the leeward of the fleet and out at sea on which in hope of procure some pilot who could carry he to calicut the general order the anchor to be weigh and he and the other captain give chase to the sambucco the whole of that day towards vespers the general come up with and capture one of these pinnace but the other escape to the land in the capture pinnace there be seventeen moor among whom be a old man who seem master over the rest and have he young wife along with he in this boat there be great store of silver and gold and some victuals on the same evening the fleet come to anchor off melinda which be eighteen league from mombaza and be in lat 3  s this place have no good harbor be only a almost open roadstead have a kind of natural pier or reef of rock on which the sea beat with much violence owe to which the ship have to ride at a considerable distance from the shore the city stand in a broad open plain along the shore surround with many palm and other sort of tree which be green the whole year it have also many garden and orchard abound with all kind of herb and fruit and many fountain of good water they orange be particularly excellent very large and sweet they have also abundance of millet and rice plenty both of cattle and sheep and great store of fine poultry which be very cheap melinda be a large city with fair street and many good house of stone and lime contain several storey with window and have terraced roof make of lime and earth the native inhabitant be black of well proportioned body have curl hair but many stranger resort thither and dwell in the city who be moor from arabium who conduct themselves in a commendable manner especially the gentleman or better sort these from the girdle upward go naked but below the girdle they be dress in silk or fine stuff of cotton though some wear short cotton cloak after the old fashion on they head they wear certain cloth embroider with silk and gold they wear also rich dagger ornament with silken tassel of many color and very handsome sword they be all left-handed and go constantly arm with bow and arrow take great delight in archery at which they be very expert they account themselves good horseman yet there be a common say on this coast _ the horseman of mombaza and the woman of melinda _ as in mombaza they be excellent horseman and the woman of melinda be very handsome and dress richly in this city also there be many gentile from the kingdom of cambaya in indium who be great merchant and trade to this place for gold which be find in this country as likewise ambergris ivory pitch and wax all of which commodity the inhabitant of melinda exchange with the merchant of cambaya for copper quicksilver and cotton cloth to the profit and advantage of both party the king of this city be a moor who be serve with far more state than any of the king on this coast to the southward be arrive over against this city the general and all the people of the fleet be much rejoice at see a city resemble those of portugal and give thanks to god for they safe arrival be desirous of procure pilot to navigate the fleet to calicut the general command to come to anchor meaning to use he endeavor for this purpose for hitherto he could not learn from the moor he have lately capture whether any of they be pilot and though he have threaten they with the torture they always persist in declare that none of they have any skill in pilotage next day be easter eve the old moor who have be make prisoner in the pinnace tell the general that there be four ship belong to christian of the indy at melinda and engage if the general would allow he and the other moor to go on shore he would provide he as he ransom christian pilot and would farther supply he with every thing he might need well please with the speech of the old moor the general remove he ship to within half a league of the city whence hitherto no one come off to we fleet as they fear we man might make they prisoner for they have receive intelligence that we be christian and believe we ship be man of war on the Monday morning therefore the general command the old moor to be land on a ledge or rock opposite the city and leave there expect they would send from the city to fetch he off which they do accordingly as soon as we boat depart the moor be carry directly to the king to whom he say as instruct by the general what he chiefly desire to have he farther say that the general desire to have amity with the king of whom he have hear a good report hope by he aid and with the will of god he might be enable to discover the route to india the king receive this message favourably and send back the moor in a boat to the general accompany by one of he own servant and a priest say that he would most willingly conclude a treaty of amity with he and should supply he with what pilot he need these messenger likewise present the general from the king with three sheep and a great many orange and sugar cane which he thankfully accept desire the messenger to acquaint they master that he gladly agree to the profered amity and be ready to confirm the same between they and promise to enter they harbor next day he farther desire they to inform the king that he be the subject of a great and powerful sovereign in the west who have send he to discover the way to calicut with order to enter into peace and amity with all king and prince on whose territory he might happen to touch by the way that it be now _ two year _ -lrb- 40 -rrb- since he leave he own country and that the king he master be a prince of such puissance and worth as he be convince the king of melinda would be glad to have for a friend he then dismiss the messenger send as a present to they king a hat of the fashion of the time two branch of coral three brass bason two scarf and some small bell on the second day after easter the general remove he ship nearer the city the king know this and believe that the king of portugal must be a high-spirited prince and the general a worthy subject who have hazard himself in so long and dangerous a voyage become desirous of see such man wherefore he send a more honorable message to the general say that he propose next day to visit he in
