person intend that they meeting should be on the water and send he a present of six sheep with a considerable quantity of clove ginger pepper and nutmeg upon this message the general remove he fleet still nearer the city and come to anchor close to the four ship of the indy of which the old moor have make mention as belong to christian when the owner of these ship learn that we be christian they come immediately to visit we general who happen then to be in the ship of paulo de la gama these man be of a brown color but of good stature and well proportioned dress in long white cotton gown have large beard and the hair of they head long like woman and plait up under they turban or head-dress the general receive they with much kindness and attention asking by means of a interpreter who understand the language of algarve or arabic whether they be christian these man have some knowledge of that language though it be not they own tongue but have learn it in the course of they trade and conversation with the moor of melinda of whom they advise the general to beware lest they inward intention might be far different from they outward shew willing to make trial if these man be really christian the general cause a picture to be shewn they on which we lady be paint weep surround by some of the apostle but without inform they what this be mean to represent immediately on this be set before they they fall down and worship the picture pray for some time the general then ask if they be of calicut on which they answer they be of grangalor -lrb- 41 -rrb- still farther off and could give he no information respect calicut from this time so long as we fleet remain at melinda these people come every day on board the ship of paulo de la gama to pay they devotions before this picture offering to the image which it represent gift of pepper and other thing these indian christian accord to they own account eat no beef on the last day of the week after easter and in the afternoon the king of melinda come off in a great boat to we fleet he be dress in a cassock of crimson damask line with green satin and wear a rich cloth or turban on he head he sit in a chair of the ancient fashion very well make and work with wire have a silk cushion and on another chair beside he there lay a hat of crimson satin a old man stand by he as he page who carry a very rich sword with a silver scabbard in the boat there be many sacbut and two ivory flute eight span long on which they play by a little hole in the middle agree and accord well with the music of the sacbut the king be likewise attend by about twenty moorish gentleman all richly dress when the king have nearly attain we ship the general go to meet he in he boat gaily decorate with flag and streamer himself dress in he best apparel and attend by twelve of the principal officer of the squadron leave he brother in charge of the ship on the boat meet the two party make every demonstration of friendship and respect and the moorish king immediately offer to come on board the general boat that he might see he the better the general accordingly receive he with all respect and the king shew as much honor and courtesy to the general as if he have be likewise a king the moorish king after examine the dress and appearance of the general and he man with the utmost attention ask the general the name of he king which he command to be immediately write down he particularly inquire respect the power of the king of portugal and the general give the most satisfactory answer to all he question particularly detail the reason of he be send to discover calicut that portugal might be thence supply with spice which be not to be have in he own country the king after give he some information on these point and respect the strait of the red sea promise to furnish the general with a pilot to carry he to calicut and then earnestly solicit he to accompany he to the city where he might solace and refresh himself in the palace after the fatigue and danger of so long a voyage and promise if the general would do so that he the king would visit he on board to this the general prudently answer that he be not authorise by he instruction to go on shore and that he could not answer for deviate from the order of he sovereign on this the king observe that if he be to visit the ship he could not well answer for he conduct to the inhabitant of he city yet he be grieve that the admiral refuse to go into the city which should be at he will and pleasure and that of the king he master to whom he should either write or send a ambassador if the general would call in at melinda on he return from calicut the general give the king thanks for he politeness and promise to return that way and while this conversation be go on he send for the moor who have be take in the pinnace whom he present to the king say he would most gladly perform any other service that lay in he power to the king the king be greatly please with this gift which he value as much as if the admiral have give he another city equal to melinda have end they conversation and confirm they mutual friendship the king row through among we ship examine they with much pleasure and admiration and be salute in pass by many discharge of the ordnance at which he and he attendant seem much delighted on this occasion the general attend upon he in he own boat out of respect and the king observe that he never be so much pleased with any man as with the portuguese and would most gladly have some of they to help he in he war to this the general answer that if he highness be to have experience of what they be able to perform he would like the portuguese still better and that they should certainly give he aid if it should please the king of portugal to send any of he war ship to calicut which he do not doubt would be the case if it be god will to permit the discovery of that place after the king have satisfy he curiosity he request of the general since he would not go himself into the city to permit two of he man to go and see the palace offering to leave he own son and one of he chief priest which they name cais -lrb- 42 -rrb- in pledge for they safe return to this request the general consent and send two of we man along with the king : he at he departure request that the general would next day in he boat come close to the shore when he should be gratify with a sight of the native horseman go through they evolution after this they separate next day be Thursday the general and nicholas coello go in they boat well arm along the shore accord to the invitation of the king keep at a small distance from each other for mutual defense in case of need where they see many man skirmish on the shore as we boat approach the royal palace certain of the king attendant bring he in a chair down some stone stair which lead to the water and be then very near the general boat the king enter into friendly conversation with he and once more entreated he to land and go to the palace say that he father who be lame be exceedingly desirous to see he and even offer that while the general remain on shore he and he child would go on board the ship as hostage for he security but we general still dread that some bitter treachery might lurk beneath this honied speech continue to excuse himself from landing as he have not permission from he own prince to do so and must obey he in all thing after this take he leave of the king he row past the ship of the indian merchant which he salute in pass with he ordnance and when they see we pass they hold up they hand exclaim christe christe that night have obtain leave from the king we man make they a great feast with much diversion also of squib firing of gun and loud cry the fleet remain at anchor for two day without any message from the shore on which account the general be much distressed fear the king have take offence at he refusal to go on shore and might break the peace and amity between they and not send he any pilot but on Sunday the 21st of April a person who be in high credit with the king come off to visit the general who be much disappointed when this person bring no pilot and again begin to entertain suspicion of the king intention when the king learn this and that the general remain merely for the purpose of have a pilot he send he one who be a gentile call _ gosarate _ -lrb- 43 -rrb- in they language and whose name be _ canaca _ send a apology at the same time for not have send this person sooner thus the king and the general remain friend and the peace continue which have be agree between they de barro and farium give this pilot the name of _ malemo cana _ and say that he belong to one of the indian ship of cambaya then at melinda de barros add that he shew de gama a very small chart of the coast of indium lay down with meridian and parallel but without rhumb of the wind this pilot shew no surprise on see the large wooden and metal astrolabe belong to the portuguese as the pilot of the red sea have long use brass triangular instrument and quadrant for astronomical observation and that he and other who sail from cambaya and the port of indium navigate by the north and south star and the constellation of the eastern and western hemisphere and though they do not use these instrument in navigation they employ one make of three piece of board similar to the _ balhestillium _ or cross-staff of the portuguese in a collection of papers publish in 1790 call _ documento arabico _ from the royal archive of lisbon chiefly consist of letter between the king of portugal and the tributary prince of the east in the sixteenth century the _ zeque sheik _ or king of melinda with whom de gama afterwards make a treaty of alliance and whose ambassador he carry into portugal be name wagerage -lrb- 44 -rrb- have thus procure a pilot and provide all thing necessary for the voyage de gama depart from melinda for calicut on Friday the 26th of April 1498 -lrb- 45 -rrb- and immediately make sail directly across the gulf which separate africa from indium which be 750 league -lrb- 46 -rrb- this golf run a long way up into the land northwards but we course for calicut lay to the east -lrb- 47 -rrb- in follow this voyage we man see the north star next Sunday which they have not see of a long while and they see the star about the south pole at the same time they give thanks to god that whereas it have be represent to they that in this season which be the winter of the indy there be always great storm in this gulf they now experience fair weather on Friday the 18th of may twenty - three day after leave melinda during all which time they have see no land they come in sight of indium at eight league distance the land seem very high canaca the pilot try the lead and find forty-five fathom upon which he alter he course to the south-east have fall in with the land too far to the north upon the Saturday he again draw near the land but do not certainly know it as the view be obscure by rain which always fall in indium at this season be they winter on Sunday the 20th of may the pilot get view of certain high hill which be directly behind the city of calicut and come so near the land that he be quite sure of the place on which he come up with great joy to the general demand he _ albrycia _ or reward as this be the place at which he and he company be so desirous to arrive the general be greatly rejoice at this news and immediately satisfy the pilot after which he summon all the company to prayer say the _ salve _ and give hearty thanks to god who have safely conduct they to the long wished-for place of he destination when prayer be over there be great festivity and joy in the ship which come that same evening to anchor two league from calicut immediately upon anchor some of the native come off to the ship in four boat call _ almadia _ inquire whence we ship come as they have never before see any resemble they construction upon that coast these native be of a brown color and entirely naked except very small apron some of they immediately come on board the general and the guzerat pilot inform he these be poor fisherman yet the general receive they courteously and order he people to purchase the fish which they have bring for sale on converse with they he understand that the town whence they come which be in sight be not calicut which lay farther off and to which they offer to conduct we fleet whereupon the general request they to do this and depart from this first anchorage the fleet be conduct by these fisherman to calicut calicut be a city on the coast of malabar a province of the second indium which begin at the mount of delhus and end at cape comory be sixty - one league in length and fifteen league broad -lrb- 48 -rrb- the whole of this country be very low and apt to be cover with water have many island in its river which flow into the indian sea this country of malabar be divide from the kingdom of narsinga by a very high hill the indian report that this land of malabar be cover by the sea of old which then reach to the foot of the hill and thence to a hill where now the island of the maldive be find which be then firm land and that in after time it destroy that latter country and lay bare the country of malabar in which be many pleasant and rich city dependent upon trade which they carry on principally with calicut which exceed all city of we day in riches and in vice its foundation and rise be as follow : in ancient time this country of malabar be entirely rule by one king who dwell in the city of _ coulan _ in the reign of the last king of this race name _ saranaperimal _ -lrb- 49 -rrb- who die 600 year ago the moor of mecca discover indium and come to the province of malabar then inhabit by idolater and govern by a idolatrous king from the time of the come of these moor they begin to reckon they year as we do from the birth of we savior -lrb- 50 -rrb- after the come of the moor into malabar they insinuate themselves so much into the confidence of the before-mentioned king that he become a convert to they law renounce the religion of he country and embrace mahometism with such zeal that he resolve to go and end he day in the temple of mecca have thus resolve out of love to the mahometan sect to abandon he kingdom he call he kindred together and divide all he territory among they reserve only twelve league of country near the place where he intend to embark not then inhabit which he bestow upon one of he cousin who act as he page to this kinsman he give he sword and turban as ensign of dignity command all the other noble among whom he have distribute the rest of he territory to obey this person as they emperor the king of coulan and cananor only except whom also and all the other he debar from coin money which be only to be do by the king of calicut have thus give away he whole dignity and possession and set every thing in order he embark from the place where calicut now stand and because this king embark from that place on he pilgrimage to mecca the moor have ever since hold calicut in so high devotion that they and all they posterity would never take they lading from any other port from that time forwards they discontinue trade with the port of coulan which they have use formerly and that port therefore fall to ruin especially after the building of calicut and the settlement of many moor in that place -lrb- 51 -rrb- as the moor be merchant of most extensive dealings they have render calicut as the center of they trade the richest mart of all the indy in which be to be find all the spice drug nutmeg and other thing that can be desire all kind of precious stone pearl and seed-pearl musk sander aguila fine dish of earthen ware lacker -lrb- 52 -rrb- gilded coffer and all the fine thing of china gold amber wax ivory fine and coarse cotton goods both white and dye of many color much raw and twisted silk stuff of silk and gold cloth of gold cloth of tissue grain scarlet silk carpet copper quicksilver vermilion alum coral rose-water and all kind of conserve thus every kind of merchandize from all part of the world be to be find in this place which moreover be very quiet be situate along the coast which be almost open and very dangerous calicut be surround by many garden and orchard produce all the herb and fruit of this country in great abundance have also many palm and other sort of tree and abound in excellent water this part of indium produce but little rice which be a principal article of food in these part as wheat be with we but it procure abundance of that and all other kind of provision from other country the city be large but the dwelling consist only of straw hut they idol temple and chapel and the king palace except which be : build of stone and lime and cover with tile for by they law no other be permit to build they house of any other material than straw at this time calicut be inhabit by idolater of many sect and by many moorish merchant some of whom be so rich as to be owner of fifty ship these ship be make without nail they plank be sew together with rope of _ cayro _ make of the fiber of the cocoa-nut husk pitch all over and be flat-bottomed without keel every winter there be at least six hundred ship in this harbor and the shore be such that they ship can be easily draw up for repair the subject of the follow digression be so intimately connect with the first establishment of the portuguese in indium as to justify its introduction in this place which will greatly elucidate the narrative of castaneda and its length do not admit of be insert in the form of note it be chiefly due to the ingenious and reverend jame stanier clarke in he origin and progress of maritime discovery extract by he from various source the name of this country malabar be say to be derive from _ ulyam _ which signify in the original language of that part of indium _ skirt the bottom of the hill _ corrupt into maleyam or maleam whence probably come mulievar and mala-bar in a m account of malabar it be say that little more than 2300 year ago the sea come up to the foot of the _ sukien _ mountain or the western _ gaut _ the emerge of the country from the water be fabulously related to have be occasion by the piety or penitence of puresram rama who pray to _ varauna _ the god of the ocean to give he a track of land to bestow on the bramin varauna accordingly command the sea to withdraw from the _ gowkern _ a hill near mangalore all the way to cape comorin which new land long remain marshy and scarcely habitable and the original settler be force to abandon it on account of the numerous serpent by which it be infested : but they afterwards return be instruct to propitiate the serpent by worship they at first this country be divide into four _ tookree _ or province these into _ naadh _ or district and these again into _ khund _ or small precinct the bramin establish a kind of republican or aristocratical government under a few principal chief but jealousy and disturbance take place they procure a _ permaul _ or chief governor from the prince of chaldesh a sovereignty in the southern carnatic : yet it be more likely that this sovereign take advantage of the division among the chief of malabar to reduce they under he authority these permaul or viceroy be for a long while change every twelve year till at length one of they name sheo-ram cheruma perumal or shermanoo permaloo the sarana-perimal of castaneda become so popular that he set he master _ kishen rao _ the rajah of chaldesh at defiance and establish he own authority in malabar a army be send into malabar to reduce the country again to obedience but it be defeat and from this event which be say to have happen 1000 year ago all the raja chief _ nayre _ and other lord of malabar date the sovereignty and independence of they ancestor in that country after some time shermanoo-permaloo either become weary of he situation or from attachment to the mahometan religion resolve to make a division of malabar among he dependent from whom the present chieftain be descend such be the current story among the inhabitant of malabar yet it be more probable that he dependent chieftain disgust with he conversion to the religion of mahomet revolt from he authority and contrived this story of he voluntary surrender and division of he dominion to justify they own assumption after this division of he kingdom it be say that a _ erary _ or person of the cast of cow-herd originally from the bank of the cavery near errode in the carnatic who have be a chief instrument of the success of shermanoo-permaloo in the war against rajah kishen rao make application to shermanoo for some support have very little leave to give away shermanoo make he a grant of he own place of abode at calicut and give he he sword ankle-ring and other insignia of command and present he with water and flower the ancient symbol of a transfer of property it be say that this cowherd rajah be ordain principal sovereign over the other petty prince among whom malabar be divide with the title of zamorin and be authorize by shermanoo to extend he dominion over all the other chieftain by force of arm he descendant have ever since endeavor on all occasion to enforce this pretend grant which they pretend to hold by the tenure of possess the sword of shermanoo permaloo and which they carefully preserve as a precious relic from the period of the abdication of shermanoo to that of the arrival of the portuguese at calicut the mahomedan religion have make considerable progress in malabar and the arabian merchant receive every encouragement from the samoory or zamorin as they make calicut the staple of they indian trade and bring large sum of money yearly to that place for the purchase of spicery and other commodity as the raja of cochin and other petty sovereignty on the coast be exceedingly jealous of the superior riches and power of the zamorin and of the monopoly of trade enjoy by calicut they give every encouragement to the portuguese to frequent they port from whence arise a series of warfare by sea and land which have finally reduce they all under subjection to the european accord to a arabian author _ zeirreddien mukhdom _ who be suppose to have be send to assist the zamorin and the mahomedan in indium in they war with the portuguese malabar be then say to have be divide among a multiplicity of independent prince or raja whom he call _ hakim _ some of whom command over one or two hundred man and other one ten fifteen or even as high as thirty thousand or upward the three greatest power at that time be the _ colastrian _ -lrb- 53 -rrb- rajah to the north the zamorin of calicut in the center and a rajah in the south who rule from coulan kalum or coulim to cape comorin comprehend the country now belong to the rajah of travancore we now return from this digression to follow the narrative of the portuguese discovery and conquest of indium as relate by castaneda so great be the trade and population of calicut and the surrounding country and the revenue of its sovereign through these circumstance that he be able to raise a force of thirty thousand man in a single day and could even bring a hundred thousand man into the field completely equipt for war in three day this prince in the language of the country be style the zamorin or samoryn which signify emperor as he be supreme over the other two king of malabar the king of coulan and the king of cananor there be indeed other prince in this country who be call king but be not so this zamorin or king of calicut be a bramin as he predecessor have be the bramin be priest among the malabar it be a ancient rule and custom among these people that all they king must die in a pagoda -lrb- 54 -rrb- or temple of they idol and that there must always be a king resident in the principal pagoda to serve those idol : wherefore when the king that serve in the temple come to die he who then reign must leave he government of temporal affair to take he place in the temple upon which another be elect to take he place and to succeed in rule the kingdom if the king who be in possession of the temporal authority should refuse to retire to the pagoda on the death of the king who officiate in spiritual he be constrain to do so however unwilling the king and noble of malabar be of a brown complexion and go naked from the waist upward all the under part of they body be clothe in silk or cotton vestment yet they sometimes wear short gown on they upper part call _ basus _ of rich silk or cloth of gold or of scarlet splendidly ornament with precious stone of all which the zamorin have great store they shave they beard leave only the hair on they upper lip and do not shave the head like the turk in general the native of this country even of the higher rank use little state in they household and be very spare in they diet but the zamorin be serve with considerable splendor these king or noble never marry but every one have a mistress of the nayre cast which among the malabar be consider as the gentry even the zamorin have only a mistress who have a house of she own near the palace and a liberal allowance for the charge of she household and maintenance at she own disposal upon any dislike or difference he may always leave she for another the child be only consider as the offspring of the mother and have no right or title to inherit the kingdom or any thing else belong to the father and when grow up be only hold in that rank or estimation which belong to the blood or parentage of they mother brother succeed to brother and in lack of these the son of they sister who do not marry and have no certainty respect the father of they child as they be very free and dissolute in they manners choose paramour as they please these sister of the zamorin and other king of malabar have handsome allowance to live upon and when any of they reach the age of ten they kindred send for a young man of the nayre cast out of the kingdom and give he great present to induce he to initiate the young virgin after which he hang a jewel round she neck which she wear all the rest of she life as a token that she be now at liberty to dispose of herself to any one she please as long as she live when these king be at war with each other they often go personally into the field and even join personally in fight upon occasion when one of they die the body be carry out into the field and burn on a pile of sander and of another sweet smell wood call _ aguila _ all he brother and kindred and all the noble of the country be present at the ceremony which be uniformly postpone to the third day after death that all may have time to gather from a distance and may have a opportunity of be assure whether he death be natural or cause by violence : since if he die by the hand of any one all be bind to prosecute revenge after the body be burnt and the ash bury the whole company shave every part of they body even to the youngest child of these idolater this be they token of mourning and during the ensue thirteen day they all refrain from chew betel any one infringe this law be punish by cut he lip during this period of thirteen day he who be to succeed to the throne must abstain from all exercise of government that any one who please may have a opportunity of urge any valid objection why he should not acquire the vacant government after this the successor be swear before all the noble of the country to preserve and enforce all the law and custom of they ancestor to pay the debt of he predecessor and to use he utmost endeavor to recover any portion of the kingdom that may have be lose while take this oath have he sword in he left hand he hold in he right hand a burning candle on which be a gold ring which he touch with he finger after this they throw some grain of rice over he use many other ceremony and numerous prayer and then worship the sun three time when all these ceremony be go through all the _ caymayle _ or lord of noble birth take hold of the candle take a oath to be true and faithful subject to the new king after the end of the thirteen day mourn they all begin to chew betel and to eat flesh and fish as formerly the new king alone except he be bind to mourn for he predecessor during a whole year chew no betel eat no flesh or fish neither shave he beard nor cut he nail during all that time he must eat only once a-day wash himself all over before this single meal and devote certain hour of every day to prayer after the expiry of the year he use a certain ceremony for the soul of the king he predecessor much like we solemn dirge at which 100000 person be often assemble among whom he distribute large alms when this ceremony be end the prince be confirm as inheritor of the kingdom and all the people depart the zamorin of calicut and the other king of malabar have each one especial officer to whom the administration of justice be confide and whose authority in all matter of government be as ample as that of the king himself the soldier employ by these king be call _ nayre _ who be all gentleman and who follow no other office or employ but that of fight when need they be all idolater arm with bow arrow spear dagger of a hooked form and target and they march in a very regular and warlike manner but they go entirely naked and barefooted wear only a piece of paint cotton cloth which reach from the girdle to the knee and a cloth or kerchief on they head all these man live continually at the charge of the king and noble of the country from whom they have small stipend for they maintenance and they esteem themselves so highly on account of they gentility of blood that they will not touch a husbandman nor allow any such to enter into they dwelling when any husbandman go through the street they must continually call out aloud _ hoo hoo _ for if command by a nayre to make way they may be slay if they refuse the king can not raise any one to the rank of a _ nayre _ who be all such by descent these _ nayre _ serve very faithfully under those who give they they wages not spare by day or night to use they best endeavor to serve they chief nor make any account of want of food or sleep or of fatigue when they service be require or may be effectual they expence be so small that on half-a-crown which be they only monthly pay they can sufficiently maintain themselves and a boy whom each have as a servant by the law of this country these nayre can not marry so that no one have any certain or acknowledged son or father all they child be bear of mistress with each of whom three or four nayre cohabit by agreement among themselves each one of this confraternity dwell a day in he turn with the joint mistress counting from noon of one day to the same time of the next after which he depart and another come for the like time they thus spend they life without the care or trouble of wife and child yet maintain they mistress well accord to they rank any one may forsake he mistress at he pleasure and in like manner the mistress may refuse admittance to any one o # she lover when she please these mistress be all gentlewoman of the nayre cast and the nayre besides be prohibit from marry must not attach themselves to any woman of a different rank consider that there be always several man attach to one woman the nayre never look upon any of these child bear of they mistress as belong to they however strong a resemblance may subsist and all inheritance among the nayre go to they brother or the son of they sister bear of the same mother all relationship be count only by female consanguinity and descent this strange law prohibit marriage be establish that they might have neither wife or child on whom to fix they love and attachment and that be free from all family care they might the more willingly devote themselves entirely to warlike service and the more to animate these gentleman in the service of the war and to encourage they to continue in the order of nayre they be privileged from all imprisonment and from the punishment of death on all ordinary occasion except for the follow crime kill another nayre or a cow which be a object of worship sleeping or eat with a ordinary woman or speak evil of the king when the king have receive authentic information of any of these offence have be commit he issue a write mandate to one of the nayre command he to take two or three other nayre in he company and to slay the nayre who have commit this offence against the law in obedience to this warrant they attack he with they sword and put he to death where-ever they happen to find he and then affix the royal order upon he body that all may know the reason of he death it be not permit to any nayre to assume arm or to enter into any combat till he have be arm as a knight when a nayre become seven year old he be set to learn the use of all kind of weapon they master first pull and twist they joint to make they supple and then teach they to fence and handle they arm adroitly they principal weapon be sword and target and these teacher who be graduate in the use of the weapon be call _ panycae _ who be much esteem among the nayre and all they former scholar however advance in life or however high they dignity be bind at all time to give they due honor and reverence when they meet likewise every _ nayre _ be oblige to take lesson from these professor for two month yearly all they life : by this mean they be very skilful in the use of they weapon in which they take great pride when a nayre desire to be arm as a knight he present himself before the king accompany by all he kindred and friend and make a offering of sixty gold fannom -lrb- 55 -rrb- on which he be ask by the king if he be willing to observe and follow the law and custom of the nayre to which he answer in the affirmative then the king command he to be gird with a sword and lay he right hand on he head utter certain word as if pray in so low a voice that he be not hear the king then embrace the young nayre say aloud in they language take good care to defend the bramin and they kine on this the nayre fall down and do reverence to the king and from that time he be consider as a knight or member of the fraternity of nayre when any of the nayre enter into the peculiar service of the king or of any individual noble he bind himself to die with and for he and they keep they oath for if they master should happen to be slay in any war or otherwise they will fight till they be all slay and if they can not accomplish they purpose at the time or happen to be absent at the slaughter of they master they go afterwards in search of the person who have do the deed and never leave off till they be themselves slay the malabar be much give to soothsay and have lucky and unlucky day they worship the sun moon and star the fire cow and the first thing they meet on go out of a morning believe every manner of vanity the devil be often in they but they say it be one of they god or _ pagod _ as they call he but whosoever or whatsoever it may be it constrain they to utter terrible word which be believe by the king when the devil enter into a nayre he go with a naked sword before the king shake and tremble and give himself many wound say i be such or such a god and be come to tell thee such and such a thing cry out and behave himself like a madman or one possess if the king make any doubt of what he say he continue to roar still louder and to slash himself more severely till the king give credit to he assertion there be other tribe or lineage of people among the malabar of various sect and diver custom of whom it be too tedious to speak in this place who be all under obedience to the several king and noble the moor alone be exempt from this obedience on account of the large custom they pay for they merchandize owe to which they be hold in high estimation at calicut have come to anchor on the outside of the bar or reef of calicut the general send one of the portuguese convict on shore in one of the almadia which have conduct the ship to this port instruct he to see what kind of a place it be and to make trial of what kind of a reception might be look for see we be christian and as the general believe that the people be likewise christian when this man land he be immediately surround by great number of the native stare at he as a stranger these people ask of the fisherman what man this be whom they have bring on shore to which they answer that they suppose he to be a moor and that he belong to the three ship which be ride without the bar but the people of calicut wonder much to see a person who be clothe so very differently from the moor who come from the red sea some of these people who have knowledge of arabic speak to this man but he could not understand or answer they at which they be much astonished yet believe he to be a moor they conduct he to a house where two moor dwell who come originally from tuni and have establish themselves in calicut on he appearance one of these moor whose name be bontaybo -lrb- 56 -rrb- who could speak spanish immediately recognize he for a portuguese have often see people of we nation at tunis in the reign of king john in a ship name la reyna which often trade to that port as soon as bontaybo see the portuguese he exclaim in spanish _ devil take you what bring you here _ he farther inquire which way he have travel so as to arrive at calicut to this the banish man answer tell how many ship we general have bring with he at which bontaybo be much amaze wonder how they could possibly come by sea from portugal to indium he then ask what they seek at so great a distance from home and be answer that they come in search of christian and spice bontaybo then ask why the king of france and spain and the doge of venice have not send they ship likewise because say we man the king of portugal would not allow they to this bontaybo say he be much in the right after some farther conversation in this way bontaybo give he good entertainment command certain cake of wheat flour and honey call _ ape _ by the malabar to be set before he and then say that he would accompany he to the ship to wait upon the general bontaybo accordingly come on board we general whom he immediately address in spanish say good luck good luck many ruby many emerald thou art bind to give god thanks for have bring thee where there be abundance of all sort of spice precious stone and all the other riches of the world on hearing this the general and all the people be greatly astonish not expect to meet any one so far from home who understand they language and even shed tear of joy for this happy circumstance and they safe arrival they all then join in humble and hearty thanks to the almighty by whose favor and assistance alone this great happiness and good fortune have be accord to they the general embrace bontaybo whom he make to sit beside he and question he if he be a christian and how he come to calicut bontaybo tell he frankly that he be a moor from tuni in barbary and have come to calicut by way of cairo and the red sea and explain how he come to know the portuguese as have be already mention he farther declare that he have always be well disposed towards the portuguese nation have always find they worthy of confidence and friendship in all they dealings and have be a friend to they in time past he would not discontinue he good will and be ready and willing to do every thing in he power to serve they and to assist they in the object for which they have now come to calicut the general give he many thanks for he good will and promise to reward he liberally for the friendly aid he might give to he and he expedition express he extreme satisfaction at be so fortunate as to meet such a person in this place believe that god have send he here to promote the great object of this voyage for which he pass through so many and long continued danger be quite sensible that he must have reap little profit from all he labor without such friendly assistance the general then request information from bontaybo as to the character of the king or zamorin of calicut and whether in he opinion he would willingly receive he as ambassador from the king of portugal bontaybo represent the zamorin as a prince of good and honorable disposition who he be convince would gladly receive the general as ambassador from a foreign king more especially if the object of he voyage be to establish a trade with calicut and if the general have bring with he any merchandize proper for that purpose since the advantage which the zamorin derive from the custom upon trade form the chief source of he revenue he farther inform the general that the zamorin reside at this time at panane a village on the coast about five league from calicut and advise that the general should send a message there to notify he arrival and the reason of he come the general be well please with this advice and present certain gift to bontaybo along with whom he send two of he man to calicut request bontaybo to direct they on they way to panane which he do accordingly when these messenger come into the presence of the zamorin one of they name _ fernan martyn _ declare to he by means of a interpreter that he wait upon he highness on the part of he general who have arrive in the port of calicut with three ship have be send there by the king of portugal with letter to he highness which the general begged permission to present to he on hear this message and before give any answer the zamorin command each of the two messenger to be present with a piece cotton cloth and two piece of silk such as he use in he own apparel after which he inquire of fernan martyn what king it be who have send he these letter and how far he dominion be from thence fernan fully answer these inquiry add that he be a christian prince and that those whom he have send in the ship now at calicut be christian and related what great and numerous danger they have pass through during they voyage the zamorin be much amaze at the incident of the voyage which fernan related at some length and express he satisfaction that so powerful a prince of the christian should think of send a ambassador to he from so great a distance he then desire fernan to inform the general that he heartily welcome he and he people into he dominion advise he to bring he ship to anchor near a village call _ pandarane _ some way below where the ship then lay as a far better harbor than calicut which be a open and very dangerous road for ship the zamorin desire likewise that the general might come by land from that place to calicut where he would be ready to receive he after this the zamorin send a pilot to navigate the ship to the harbor of pandarane but on come to the bar of that port the general do not think it advisable to enter so far within the harbor as the pilot propose fear lest he might expose himself to danger by repose too great confidence in these people and place himself too much within they power in this he act with much prudent foresight by which he wisely avoid the injury which be afterwards attempt against he at this place on he arrival at pandarane the general receive a message from the kutwal -lrb- 57 -rrb- of calicut intimate that he and other noble await he on shore by order of the zamorin to conduct he to the city and that he have permission to land whenever he pleased -lrb- 58 -rrb- but as the day draw near a close the general return a answer excuse himself from land that night he immediately call a council of the other captain and principal officer of the fleet to take they advice on the present emergency to whom he intimate he intention of go to visit the king of calicut on purpose to settle a treaty of trade and amity paulo de gama he brother strongly object to he venture on shore allege that although the native of the place be christian as they still believe they yet there be many moor among they who be much to be fear as he mortal enemy since these people at mozambique and mombaza where they have only pass by they port endeavor to destroy they all they be much more to be fear at calicut where we have come on purpose to enter into competition with they in trade by which they profit would be diminish it be therefore the more probable that they would use every effort to destroy the general on whom we whole hope of safety and success depend and however much the zamorin might regret the commission of such a deed he could not restore he to life : besides which the moor be inhabitant of the place where they have much interest whereas the general be a utter stranger likewise it be quite impossible for they to be assure that the king of calicut might not have league with the moor for he death or captivity either of which would ruin they voyage and prove the destruction of they all and all the toil and danger they have pass through would prove in vain to prevent all this danger he strongly urge that the general should on no account go on shore but should depute one of the captain or some other person in the fleet in he stead allege that commander in chief ought never to subject themselves to personal danger unless in case of the most urgent necessity all the officer be of the same opinion but the general answer that even if he be perfectly assure that he landing be to occasion he instant death he would not refrain from go to visit the king of calicut to endeavor to settle amity and trade and that he might procure some spice and other commodity from the place by means of which they discovery of calicut might be prove on they return into portugal : as otherwise if we return without any of the production of the indy they discovery would be discredit and they honor and veracity call in question think not therefore say he but i will rather die than leave it in hazard that the long time we have already spend and may yet employ shall be lose and other send to ascertain the truth of we discovery while envious person may have it in they power to discredit we service neither do i run into such hazard of death nor expose you to such danger as you suppose see that i be go to a city inhabit by christian and to a king who wish the concourse of many merchant in he dominion as the more of these that frequent he port so much the greater must be he revenue from the custom upon trade it be not my intention to stay long on shore so as to give opportunity to the moor to complot against I as i propose only to talk with the king and to return in three day by which time you may have every thing in readiness for we departure if i should have the good fortune by the will of god to establish trade and amity with the king of calicut i would not exchange the honor and credit of that transaction for any treasure that could be give I neither can the king of calicut settle this affair so well with any other person as he will honor I the more for be the captain-general of this fleet and the ambassador of we king should any other go in my stead the king might look upon himself as slight and insult under a idea that i do not esteem he worthy to be visit by myself or that i do not trust he on he word and assurance besides it be not possible for I to give sufficiently ample instruction to any one i might send to enable he to do what may be necessary under every circumstance that may arise as i myself might do even if it should chance that they kill I it be better this should happen in the discharge of my duty than that i should preserve my life by neglect to perform it you my friend remain at sea in good ship : and if you hear of any mischance befall I my desire be that you shall immediately depart and carry home news of we discovery as for we present subject there need be no farther argument as i be determine with the blessing of god to proceed to visit the king at calicut when this determination be make know the captain make no farther objection and choose out twelve person to accompany he among whom be diego diaz he secretary fernan martinez the interpreter john de sala who be afterwards treasurer of the indy and nine other and paulo de gama he brother be appoint to act as captain-general during he absence the general before go on shore give pointed order that no person should on any account be permit to come on board the ship but that all who be desirous of any intercourse with they should remain in they boat or almadia he likewise direct that nichola coello should come every day with he boat well arm as near the shore as he could with safety on purpose to keep up a intercourse between the ship and himself all these thing be settle the general go on shore with he twelve attendant all in they best attire they boat furnish with much ordnance dress out with flag and streamer and sound trumpet all the way from the ship to the shore on landing the general be receive with every demonstration of respect by the kutwal attend by 200 nayre and a great concourse of native both of the country and from the city of calicut after compliment be pass the general be place in a _ andor _ or litter which the king of calicut have send for he use in this country it be not customary to travel on horseback but in these andor this vehicle be like a horse-litter except that they be very plain with low side and be carry by four man on they shoulder who run post in this manner carry the king or any noble person when on a journey and go at a great rate the person in the andor may either sit or lie as he please and certain servant carry umbrella which they call _ buey _ to shelter the person in the andor from the sun and rain there be other andor which have a curved cane over they like a bow and be so light that they can be carry by two man the general be mount in one andor and the kutwal in another they set out for a town call capocate -lrb- 59 -rrb- all the rest be on foot but the kutwal appoint certain people of the country to carry the baggage of we man which be restore to they at capocate where the party stop for refreshment the general and he people be in one house and the kutwal in another we people be here provide with boil fish with rice and butter and some of the country fruit which be very good though quite different from ours one of these fruit be call _ laca _ and another mango and they have fig likewise the water be excellent and as good as any in portugal after rest and refresh themselves at capocate the general and he suite be embark in a vessel call a _ ensangada _ consist of two almadia lash side by side the kutwal and he train embark in many other boat and the whole go up a river which discharge itself into the sea at this place the number of people that come to the river side to view we man as they pass be quite countless by which it appear that the country be well inhabit after go about a league up this river we people come to a place where many large ship be draw up on the shore the whole party here disembark and proceed by land the general and kutwal in andor as before be surround by thousand who be curious to see the stranger even many woman press into the crowd with they child sling at they back from this place the kutwal carry the general to one of they pagoda or idol temple into which they enter and which the kutwal say be a church of great holiness this the general believe to be the case fancy it to be a church of the christian which he the more readily believe as he see seven little bell hang over the principal door in front of this entry there stand a pillar make of wire as tall as the mast of a ship on the top of which be a weathercock likewise make of wire this church be as large as a moderate convent all build of freestone and cover or vault over with brick have a fine outward appearance as if its inside be of splendid workmanship we general be much pleased with this church as he actually believe himself in a christian country and gladly enter along with the kutwal they be receive by the priest who be naked from the waist upward have a kind of petticoat of cotton hang down from the girdle to they knee and piece of calico cover they arm-pit they head leg and foot bare they be distinguish by wear certain thread over they right shoulder which cross over they breast under they left arm much in the way in which we priest use formerly to wear they stole when they say mass these man be call kafr -lrb- 60 -rrb- and be idolater serve as priest in the pagoda of malabar and on the general go into the pagoda they take holy water with a _ sprinkle _ from a font and throw it over the kutwal and he and they attendant after this they give they powdered sandalwood to throw upon they head as use to be do amongst we with ash and they be direct to do the same on they arm but we people as be clothe omit this latter part of the ceremony comply with the other in this pagoda they see many image paint on the wall some of which have monstrous tooth project a inch from they mouth and some have four arm all of they so ugly that they seem like devil which raise doubt among we people whether they be actually in a christian church in the middle of the pagoda stand a chapel have a roof or dome of freestone like a tower in one part of which be a door of wire to which there lead a flight of stone step on the inside of this tower a image be observe in a recess of the wall which we man could not see distinctly as the place be somewhat dark and they be not permit to go near as none be allow to approach except the priest but from certain word and sign we people understand this to be a image of the virgin on which the general and he attendant go upon they knee to say they prayer -lrb- 61 -rrb- john de sala however be very doubtful that this be not a christian church owe to the monstrous image on the wall say as he fall on he knee _ if this be the devil i worship god _ on which the general look at he with a smile the kutwal and he people as they approach the chapel prostrated themselves three time on they face with they hand extend before they after which they arise and say they prayer stand from this place they go forwards to the city of calicut and be take at they arrival into another pagoda similar to the former after this on enter the city the crowd be so great that they could hardly make they way through the street the general be astonish to see such multitude and praise god for have bring he in safety to this city humbly beseech he divine mercy so to guide he on he way that he might accomplish the object of he expedition and return safely into portugal at length the pressure of the crowd become so great that the bearer be unable to get forwards and the whole company be force to take shelter in a house they be here join by the kutwal brother a nobleman who be send by the king to accompany the general to the palace and have many nayre along with he the procession again set out precede by many trumpet and sacbut sound all the way and one of the nayre carry a _ caliver _ which he fire off at interval after they be join by the kutwal brother the mob give way for the procession to pass and shew as much reverence as if the king himself have be present there go in the procession at least 3000 armed man and the multitude of spectator in the street at the door and window and on the roof be quite innumerable the general be well pleased at he honorable reception and say pleasantly to those of he company _ they little think in portugal how honourably we be receive here _ the procession arrive at the palace a hour before sunset though only construct of earth the palace be very extensive and seem a handsome structure have great number of tree intersperse among the different building with pleasant garden full of fine flower and odoriferous plant and many fountain as the zamorin never go out of the palace while resident in calicut on arrive at the palace several caymal and other nobleman come out to receive the general who lead he to a large square immediately in front of the gate whence they pass through four several court at the gate of each of which there be ten porter who be oblige to lay about they with stick among the people to clear the way on come to the gate of the house in which the king reside they be meet by the chief bramin or high priest of the royal household a little old man who embrace the general and conduct he and he people into the palace at this time the people press forwards with much eagerness to get a sight of the king which they very seldom do as he go very rarely out of the palace and the multitude be so great that some of they be stifle in the throng which would likewise have be the case with two of we man if they have not go on before with the assistance of the porter who severely hurt many of the mob and force they to make way on pass the last gate the general and he attendant enter along with the nobleman into a great hall surround with seat of timber raise in row above one another like we theater the floor be cover by a carpet of green velvet and the wall hang with silk of various color the king be of a brown complexion large stature and well advance in year he lay on a sofa cover with a cloth of white silk and gold and a rich canopy over he head on he head he have a cap or mitre adorn with precious stone and pearl and have jewel of the same kind in he ear he wear a jacket of fine cotton cloth have button of large pearl and the button-hole work with gold thread about he middle he have a piece of a white calico which come only down to he knee and both he finger and toe be adorn with many gold ring set with fine stone he arm and leg be cover with many golden bracelet close to he sofa there stand a gold shallow bason on a gold stand in which be _ betel _ which the king chew with salt and _ areka _ this last be a kind of fruit about the size of a nut and be chew all over indium to sweeten the breath and be suppose to carry off phlegm from the stomach and to prevent thirst the king have likewise a gold bason on a golden stand into which he spit out the betel when chew and a gold fountain with water for wash he mouth the king be serve with betel by a old man who stand close to the sofa all the other who be in the presence hold they leave hand to they mouth that they breath might not reach the king and it be think unseemly for any one to spit or sneeze in the presence when the general enter the hall in which the king sit he stoop or bow down three time accord to the custom of the country lift up he hand as one that praise god the king immediately make sign for the general to draw near and command he to be seat on one of the seat and the rest of the portuguese come forwards make similar reverence and be likewise command to sit down opposite the king water be then present to all the company to wash they hand which be very refreshing for though it be then winter they be very hot they be then present with fig and jaka and the king be much pleased to see they eat laugh at they and converse with the old man who serve he with betel we people be thirsty call for water which be bring to they in a golden ewer and they be direct to pour the water into they mouth as it be reckon injurious to touch the cup with they lip they accordingly do as they be direct but some pour the water into they throat and fall a cough while other pour it beside upon they face and clothes which much amuse the king after this the king desire the general by a interpreter to speak to those who be present as to the purpose of he come to calicut but the general be not satisfy with this and signify that he be ambassador from the king of portugal a powerful prince and that christian prince be not use to receive the embassy of other sovereign by means of a third person but by themselves in person in the presence only of a few of they principal person : and this be the usage of he country he choose to deliver he message only to the king himself the king agree to this and command the general and fernan martinez who act as interpreter to be conduct into another chamber which be adorn with as much magnificence as the first as soon as the king enter this chamber he take he seat on a sofa attend only by he interpreter the chief bramin the old man who serve he with betel and the comptroller of he household the king then ask the general from what part of the world he be come and what be he desire he answer that he be ambassador from the king of portugal the most powerful of the christian sovereign in the west both in extent of dominion number of people and riches that he and he predecessor hear that there be christian king and prince in the indy of which the zamorin of calicut be the chief be exceedingly desirous of send some of they captain to discover the way that they might enter into friendship with the king of this country as brother and for this reason he have be send to he highness : not that the king he master have any need of he riches have abundance already and more than be need both of gold and silver and other valuable thing that all the former captain who have be send at great charge upon this discovery after have employ a year or more in vain and have consume all they victuals have return again into portugal but that the present king don manuel be anxious to bring this great enterprize to a successful conclusion have entrust he with command of three ship well supply with provision command he not to return to portugal without discover the way to the christian king of calicut and would certainly order he head to be cut off if he return without fulfil he order the say king he master have give he two letter to deliver to he highness which he would present next day as it be now somewhat late when he would convince he highness that the king of portugal be he friend and brother and should request of highness in confirmation of friendship to send a ambassador to the king of portugal as be the custom among christian prince the zamorin express he satisfaction with this embassy and tell the general that he make he welcome to he capital and since the king of portugal desire to be he friend and brother he would be the like to he and should send a ambassador to he as desire the zamorin then make inquiry into many circumstance respect portugal how far distant it be from calicut how long the general have be upon the voyage and other thing : and as it grow late the king allow he to retire first ask he whether he would reside with the moor or the malabar but as the general choose rather to have a house to himself the king give order to a moor who be he factor to accompany he and to provide he with every thing necessary for he accommodation leave the palace late it be now towards ten o'clock the kutwal and the rest who have accompany he there escort he back to where he be to lodge and as they be on they way all on foot there fall such rain that the street run in torrent insomuch that the factor give order to some of the people to carry we general on they back the general be displeased at this and at the delay and ask angrily at the factor if he mean to carry he all night through the street the factor make answer that he could not do otherwise as the city be large and much scatter he then conduct he into he own house to rest for some time and procure a horse for he to ride but as the horse have no saddle the general preferred go on foot at length he be bring to a very good lodging to which he people have previously bring all he baggage next day be Tuesday the general be greatly rejoice to see so promise a commencement of he business and resolve upon send a present to the zamorin upon which he send for the kutwal and the king factor to whom he shew the present which he propose send this consist of four _ capota _ or cloak of scarlet cloth six hat four branch of coral twelve _ almasare _ a box contain seven brass vessel a chest of sugar two barrel of oil and a cask of honey the kutwal and factor laugh in derision at this present say that this be no fit present for they king the poorest merchant present one more valuable they desire he rather to send gold as the king would accept of nothing else the general be offend at this say if he have be a merchant he would have bring gold but be a ambassador he have bring none that what he now offer be he own goods and not belong to the king he master who be uncertain if he should ever reach calicut have give he nothing to offer as a present to the zamorin but at he next come know now certainly the route the king he master would send gold and silver and otter rich article to this they answer that these thing might be but it be the custom of this country for every stranger who have speech of the king to make he a present in proportion to the greatness of he rank the general reply it be very proper they custom should be observe and therefore he desire to send this present which he could not make more valuable for the reason already assign and if they would not suffer it to be carry to the king he should send it back to he ship they answer he might do so for they would not consent to have such a present send to the king the general much displeased say he would go speak with the king himself and would then return to the ship mean to have inform the king of all that have pass in regard to the intended present this they say be very proper but as they would be detain long at court in attend he they be oblige in the mean time to go upon other business and would return to escort he to court as the king would be angry if he go without they he be a entire stranger and besides he could not go in safety unaccompanied because of the great number of moor who reside in that city give credit to they word the general consent to this arrangement and say he would wait for they return which he expect would be without delay : but they do not return all that day as they have be gain over by the moor to thwart the purpose of the general the moor in calicut have receive information of the transaction of the portuguese at quiloa and of the taking of the _ sambuco _ off melinda and know that we be christian be very jealous of we arrival at calicut bontaybo have tell the moor that we purpose be not merely to discover calicut from curiosity but that spice be in great estimation in portugal which abound in gold and silver and to which all kind of merchandize be at present transport that go from calicut by way of the red sea and finally that the settlement of a direct trade by the portuguese with calicut would tend greatly to the profit of the zamorin all this the moor very well understand : but consider that we be christian they believe if we should establish trade with calicut that they own commodity would fall in price and most of they profit be destroy wherefore they consult together how to induce the zamorin to take the general prisoner to seize we ship and to kill all we man that they might not return into portugal with any intelligence concern calicut upon this they associate themselves with some of those who be in greatest credit with the zamorin to whom they procure access and represent to he that he ought not to be deceive by the christian for the general be no ambassador as he pretend but a pirate who go about to rob and plunder whereever he come they assert have receive undoubted intelligence of this from they factor in africa where after enter into a friendly correspondence with the _ xeque _ who even visit the general in he ship give he many present and provide he with a pilot to bring he to calicut he have batter the town with he ordnance and kill several of he subject that he have afterwards take some _ sambuco _ laden with merchandize treat the xeque and he subject like enemy in like manner they misrepresent the conduct of the general at mombaza and melinda turn every thing that have occur to he dishonor they reason from these misrepresentation that he could not be a ambassador send to maintain peace and amity as he would not in that case have be guilty of these base hostility and would assuredly have bring the king a present worthy of the sovereign he pretend to come from the king be much amaze at this discourse and tell the moor that he would consider and determine what be proper for he to do the moor also tell the kutwal of all that they have say to the king with whom he be in great credit and request of he to persuade the king not to listen to this embassage the kutwal then go to the king who tell he all that the moor have say and the kutwal advise he to do as the moor have request on this the king change he good intention towards the general yet endeavor to conceal he purpose the moor then wait on the general under pretence of friendship offering to instruct he how best to conduct himself say that it be customary for all person who come from other place to calicut on business with the king to bring he a present on this the general shew they the present he have propose make which the kutwal and the factor have make so light of and with whom they agree say it be by no mean a fit present and would rather seem a mockery and give offence even bontaybo agree in this opinion and ask the general why he have not bring better thing as he know that portugal abound in all manner of rich commodity but the general excuse himself as formerly by say that it be quite uncertain whether he might ever have come to calicut the general remain the whole of this day in he lodgings much displeased that the kutwal and factor have not return accord to promise and be at one time resolve to have go to court without they yet think it better to wait till next day in the afternoon of the Wednesday the kutwal and factor make they appearance when he mention he dissatisfaction at they long absence but they talk of other thing and give he no answer on that subject at length they accompany he to the palace but the king have greatly change he mind towards he make he wait three hour for admission and then order that only two of he people should be admit into the presence along with himself though the general consider this separation of he people as not look well he go into the presence attend by fernan martinez and diego diaz he interpreter and secretary the king do not receive he so well as formerly and say with a severe countenance that he have expect he all the precede day not willing to give he the true cause of he absence lest it might lead to a conversation respect the present the general say he have tarry at home to recover from the fatigue of he long voyage on this the king observe that he pretend to have be send on a embassy of friendship from a rich and powerful king and that he do not well understand what kind of friendship be intend since he have send he no present to this the general answer that it be not to be wonder that the king he master have send no present to he highness consider the extreme uncertainty of he be able to come to this place by a way never before attempt and unknown till now but now that the way be discover and god spare he to return to portugal he master would assuredly send he princely gift worthy of they both : and if he highness would have the goodness to give credit to the letter which he have bring from the king he master he would there learn the intention of the king of portugal in send he to calicut instead of desire to see the letter the king ask he whether he be send in search of stone or of man and if send to discover man how come it that the king he master have send no present and since it be manifest that he have bring he nothing he demand of he to send he the golden image of the virgin which he understand be in he ship the general much concerned to find the king so much change towards he on account of not bring he a present and amaze at this strange demand say that the image of the virgin mary of which he highness have be tell be only of wood gilt and not of gold and besides as this holy image have protect he during he long peril on the sea and have bring he so far in safety he be unwilling to part with it the zamorin make no reply to this but immediately demand that he should produce the letter from the king of portugal one of these be write in the portuguese language and the other in arabic and the general explain that this have be do because the king he master do not know which of these might be understand in the dominion of he highness : and since he now know that portuguese be not understand in indium whereas arabic be he request that some christian of the indy who understand arabic might be employ to interpret the letter because the moor be know to be enemy to the christian and he be afraid lest they might purposely give it a wrong interpretation the king give order to this purpose but no indian could be find who be able to read the letter or at least who would acknowledge that he could read they see that it be now necessary that it should be read by the moor the general request that bontaybo should be one of those appoint for the purpose place more reliance on he than the other as he be a acquaintance the king accordingly command the letter to be read by he and other three moor who have first read it over to themselves interpret it aloud to the king to the following effect : as soon as it become know to the king of portugal that the king of calicut be one of the mightiest king of all the indy and a christian he be anxious to establish a treaty of amity and commerce with he that he might procure spice which be in great abundance in he country and to procure which the merchant of many part of the world trade thither : and if he highness would give a licence to send for spice he would send many thing from he kingdom which be not to be have in the dominion of he highness or if these thing be not satisfactory of which the general could shew he some sample he be willing to send money both gold and silver to purchase the spice and finally refer he highness to the general for farther information on hearing this letter interpret and be desirous that he revenue might increase by the resort of many merchant to he dominion the zamorin evince he satisfaction at what he have hear and assume a more friendly deportment towards the general ask he what be the article of merchandize that could be have from portugal de gama name many different kind particularly mention such as he have sample of along with he and likewise they money and request permission to go on board he ship that he might bring these thing to he highness offer to leave four or five of he man in he lodgings during he absence give now more credit to the general than to what have be say by the moor to he prejudice the king tell de gama he might go on board when he please take all he man with he as there be no call for any of they remain on shore he likewise say the general might freely bring he goods on shore and sell they to the best advantage the general be greatly satisfy with this permission of which he have no hope at the first on see the unfriendly reception he have meet with at the commencement of he audience he go back therefore to he lodging accompany by the kutwal and the day be near a close he defer return on board that night de farium give a somewhat different account of what pass at this second audience -lrb- 62 -rrb- it be wonderful that the zamorin not know how to be properly assure of the truth should rely on the faith of he who be accuse by he minister for as if he have really know in what detestation the portuguese hold a lie although to they own advantage he send for de gama and tell he plainly that he have be inform he embassy be all a counterfeit and that he be some banish man or a fugitive : yet at the same time offer even if it be so to give he a kind reception and to make he handsome appointment in he service and promise to rely entirely on he word for information respect the truth of the whole story de gama hear the king to a end with a firm countenance and declare himself highly sensible of the confidence repose in he he then proceed to answer all that have be allege against he which he completely overturn by irrefragable argument in a long and eloquent speech preserve the utmost gravity and composure throughout the whole the zamorin eye he steadfastly the whole time hope to be enable to judge of the truth or falsehood of he assertion by he countenance and conclude from the unconcernedness of he look the eloquence of he word and the firm gravity of he whole demeanor that no deceit could lurk under such appearance of sincerity that the moor have accuse he maliciously and have impose on he minister he therefore frankly allow de gama permission to return to he ship and to land he merchandize if he have any : say that while that be do he would prepare a satisfactory answer to the letter of the king of portugal on the next day be the last of may the kutwal send a horse to the general to carry he to pandarane but have no furniture he request to be supply with a _ andor _ which be send accordingly when de gama immediately set out for pandarane all he people accompany he on foot the kutwal remain at calicut but a considerable number of nayre escort the general on he way when the moor learn that the general be go to the ship they go together to the kutwal make large offer of money to he if he would pursue the general and detain he a prisoner under some feigned pretence when they would take some opportunity of have he slay in such way that the blame should not attach to the kutwal and when he object that the zamorin might punish he for detain the general contrary to he order they engage so to deal with the zamorin as to obtain he pardon for that offence induce by a large bribe and encourage by this promise the kutwal follow de gama in such haste that he soon pass we man who lag behind on account of the great heat on overtake de gama he ask by sign why he be in such haste and where he be run to the general answer in the same manner that he be run to avoid the heat on come to pandarane as he man be not come up the general decline go into the town till they should arrive and go into a house to get shelter from the rain the people do not get to the town till near sunset have lose they way on which the general say if it have not be for they absence he would have be by this time on board the general immediately desire the kutwal to order he to be furnish with a almadium or pinnace to carry he and he people on board but the kutwal say it be now late and the ship so far away that he might miss they in the dark for which reason he have better stay till next day the general then say if he be not immediately furnish with a almadium he would return to the king and complain that he be detain contrary to he license and even mention as if he mean to return immediately to calicut to dissemble the more the kutwal say he might have thirty instead of one if he need they and pretend to send out to procure almadia while at the same time he command the owner to hide themselves that they might not be find in the mean time while messenger be dispatch on pretence to seek almadia the general have a strong suspicion that evil be intend towards he walk leisurely along the water side and send off gonzale perez and two other mariner to go on before and endeavor to find nicholas coello with he boat and to caution he to keep out of the way lest the kutwal might send off to seize he boat and man while perez and the other be absent on this errand it draw far into the night and not choose to go off till he learn what success perez have meet with he at length agree to stay all night have place de gama in the house of a moor for the night the kutwal pretend that he would go in search of the three mariner who be absent but he do not return till next morning the general then require to have a almadium to carry he and he people on board before answer the kutwal speak some word
