to he nayre in they own language and then desire the general to give order to have the ship bring near the shore oh which he should have leave to depart on this the general become still more afraid that some treachery be intend yet answer boldly that he would give no such order while he remain on shore as that would make he brother believe he be a prisoner and have issue this order under restraint on which he would immediately depart for portugal without he the kutwal then threaten stoutly that he should never be allow to go off unless he comply with this demand the general in return declare he should immediately return to calicut if not allow to go on board and make a complaint of he conduct to the king the kutwal even dare he to do this yet take care it should not be in he power as he have order the door to be keep shut and guard by armed nayre to prevent any of the portuguese from go out yet it be the will of god that the kutwal dare not to kill the general or any of he man although the moor have bribe he with a great sum of money and notwithstanding he great credit with the zamorin he anxiety to have the ship bring near the shore be that the moor might be able to board they and kill all they people and see it in this light the general be equally determine to prevent they nearer approach finding he could not prevail on the general to command the ship to be bring near the shore and have no pretence to justify either keep he prisoner or offer he any wrong the kutwal next endeavor to persuade he to order the sail and rudder on shore at which the general only laugh say the king have give full permission to go on board without any such condition and assure he the king should be fully inform of all he unjust proceedings the general and he people now pretend to be in want of necessaries from the ship and request leave to send some of he people on board while he should remain on shore but this the kutwal refuse and we people begin to be seriously alarmed at this time gonzalo perez return suppose the general at liberty and that he wait for he and he companion perez inform de gama that he have see coello who wait for he with the boat near the shore the admiral be exceedingly anxious that the kutwal should not know of this circumstance lest he might send out a number of armed almadia to capture they and therefore urge perez to return secretly to give coello warn to return to the ship and keep constantly on the alert for fear of a attack when coello get this intelligence he immediately set off and the kutwal cause he to be pursue by several almadia full of armed man but he make he escape the kutwal make another attempt to induce the general to order he brother to bring the ship near the shore but in vain for the general tell he he brother even if he command would be obey but no argument could prevail on the general to this measure which he be satisfy be mean for facilitate the destruction of the fleet to gratify the moor the whole of this day be spend in this manner and in the night we people be confine in a large paved yard surround with wall and under even a stronger guard than attend they during the day and even the general begin to fear as well as the man that they would be separate from one another yet he trust when the zamorin should come to know the usage they have receive he would give order for they release that night the kutwal come to sup with the general and send a supply of fowl and rice finding that he could not prevail over the constancy of de gama he determine at last to set he at liberty next day therefore be Saturday the second of June he desire the general since he have promise to the king to bring he merchandize on shore that he ought to do so as it be the usage of all merchant who come to calicut to land they goods and crew and not to return to they ship till all be sell and he promise when this be do to give he free liberty to depart although the general give very little credit to he fair word he yet say liberty on receive this letter and a circumstantial relation from the messenger of all that have happen on shore paulo de gama immediately send the goods but say in answer to the general that he could already past at this the moor be grievously vex as they think it more easy for they to have destroy he on land than on board the ship on purpose to entice he to land once more the moor make a mock of he goods pretend they be good for nothing and do all in they power to prevent they from sell think that the zamorin know nothing of all these transaction he send he a account of the whole five day would punish all those who have use he ill yet the kutwal remain unpunished the king likewise send seven or eight merchant of guzerate who be idolater to buy the goods accompany by a honest nayre to be station there by the king order if they do not love we before they hate we ten time worse now and when any of we man land they use to spit on the ground in contempt call out portugal portugal but by the especial order of the general we people take no other notice than merely laugh at they insolence as none of the merchant would buy we goods the general suppose that this be occasion by they be on shore after the portuguese merchandize be remove to calicut the general permit one man daily from each of the ship to go on shore to see the city and to purchase any thing they have a mind for always take especial care that one party return on board before another land we people be courteously receive and entertain by the native and be even lodge in they house occasionally they barter several thing on shore such as bracelet of brass and copper pewter and other european article for the production of the country as freely and quietly as if they have be in lisbon fisherman and other of the idolater come off to the ship sell fish cocoa-nut and poultry for biscuit or money while other come off with they child merely to have a sight of we ship on all these occasion the general command they to be well treat and to have food give they to conciliate the people and to secure the friendship of the zamorin this continue till the tenth of August during which time the ship have always some of the native on board see the quietness of the people and they familiarity with he man who never meet with any injury from the moor or nayre the general believe the zamorin be willing to preserve friendship and peace with the subject of portugal and determine upon establish a factory in calicut for the sale of he commodity although very little of what be land have as yet be sell by this mean he hope to lay a sure foundation for the establishment of trade against the next expedition which the king he master might send if god pleased to send he home with the intelligence of the nothing worthy of the acceptance of so great a prince that the time now draw near when it would be necessary to depart on he return to portugal and therefore if he highness mean to send a ambassador _ -lrb- 63 -rrb- accord to the custom of the country diaz on he return to the factory with the present intend for the king be accompany by many of the nayre which he think be from respect : but braga the other be fill with many of the native these people however be afraid to come on board and put diaz and braga into the boat which be astern of the general ship and then put off to a little which be write on a palm leaf by diaz and sign by the zamorin to the following effect : vasco de la gama a gentleman of thy house come to my country of whose arrival i be very glad in my country there be abundance of cinnamon clove pepper and precious stone the commodity i wish to procure from you country be silver gold coral and scarlet convinced of the duplicity of the zamorin de gama make no expect to be well reward by the king of portugal to this arrangement bontaybo gladly consent and have a good cabin assign he by order of the general about ten o'clock the same day three almadia full of man come off to the ship have some scarf lay on they bench as be part of we goods and these be follow by four other almadia one after the other the malabar pretend that they have bring off all the goods which they offer to put into he boat and require he in return to deliver up the rest of the prisoner but convinced this be a mere deception the general desire they to go away as he would have none of they merchandize and be resolve to carry the malabar to portugal as witness of he discovery he add if god spare he life he should convince they whether the christian be thief as the moor have make the king of calicut believe who have therefore treat he with so much injustice he now command several cannon to be fire on which they be afraid and make off it be certain if the king ship have be afloat that they would have be send to attack we ship but they be all haul upon shore on account of the winter season wherefore we may attribute it to providence that we ship happen to arrive here at this season that thereby they might escape and carry home news of have discover the indy to the great advancement of the catholic faith although greatly rejoice at have make the discovery of the route to calicut and the indy he be much distressed at the behavior of the zamorin believe that the next expedition that might be send out would be subject to great danger but as he be unable to do any thing more at this time he console himself with the knowledge he have thus acquire of the safe navigation and that he have procure specimen of the spice drug precious stone and other commodity which be to be procure at this place have now nothing to detain he here he depart from calicut carry with he the malabar whom he have make prisoner as he hope by they means a good agreement might be enter into with the zamorin on send out the next fleet from portugal on the Thursday after he departure be becalm about a league from calicut about sixty _ tony _ or boat of the country come off to the fleet fill with soldier expect to have take all we ship but the general keep they off by frequent discharge of he artillery though they follow he a hour and a half at length there fall a heavy shower of rain attend with some wind by which the fleet be enable to make sail and the enemy return to the land he now propose to direct he course for melinda but make little way along the coast by reason of calm at this time have in mind the good of the next ship which might come to calicut he think fit to send a soothing letter to the zamorin which be write in arabic by bontaybo in which he apologize for have carry off the malabar as evidence of he have be at calicut he say he be sorry that he have leave no factor lest the moor might put he to death and that he have be deter by the some cause from have frequently land himself that notwithstanding all that have happen the king he master would be glad to have the friendship of the zamorin and would assuredly send he abundance of all those commodity he might need and that the trade of the portuguese to he city would henceforth redound to he great profit this letter be entrust to one of the malabar who be set on shore and order to deliver it to the zamorin continue he course along the coast the fleet come on the ensue Thursday among certain rocky island from one of which that be inhabit there come off several almadia have fish and other victuals for sale the general treat these people kindly give they shirt and other article to they great contentment and with they approbation set up a cross on the island which be name _ el padron de sancta maria _ as soon as night approach and the wind begin to blow from the shore the fleet make sail always keep near the land on the Thursday after be the 19th of September they come in sight of a pleasant high land off which lay six little island where he come to anchor go here on shore in search of fresh water a young man be meet with who be or pretend to be a christian this person carry we man to a river where they find a spring of excellent water issue out of the rock and for he service they give he a red nightcap next morning four native come off in a small boat with many gourd and cucumber for sale these people say that they country produce cinnamon and two of we people be send onshore to see whether this be true who bring with they two green bough which be say to be cinnamon of which they have see a large grove but it turn out only to be the wild kind at they return these man be accompany by more than twenty native who bring hen gourd and cow milk for sale and who say if the general would send some of he man on shore he might have abundance of dry cinnamon hog and poultry : but he dread treachery and would not allow any of he people to go on shore next forenoon when some of we man go to a part of the shore at some distance from the ship to cut wood they suddenly come in sight of two boat lie close to the land and return with intelligence of what they have see but the general would not send to inquire what these might be until after dinner in the mean time one of the man in the top give notice that he see eight large ship out at sea which be then becalm the general give immediate order to have every thing in readiness in case of a attack and as the wind serve both fleet they soon come within two league of each other the enemy perceive we fleet approach flee towards the shore but one of they rudder break the man belong to that ship escape in they boat and coello immediately take possession expect to find it laden with rich commodity nothing be find however except cocoa-nut and a kind of sugar call _ melasus _ which be prepare from palm or date tree he also find on board many bow and arrow sword spear and target the other seven ship be run aground so that we ship could not get near they as draw too much water but we people follow in they boat and drive they out of they vessel by firing upon they with they ordnance next day while we fleet be at anchor seven man come off from the land in a almadium who report that these eight ship have be send by the zamorin from calicut to capture we fleet as they have be inform by some of the fugitive -lrb- 64 -rrb- from this place the general remove to the island of _ ansandina _ at a short distance where he be tell he might procure good water this island be very small and only a league from the continent it contain several wood and two cistern or conduit build of freestone one of which be six foot deep supply with excellent water from certain spring and the sea around have great quantity of fish before the moor trade with indium this island be well inhabit by the native idolater have many goodly building and especially some fine pagoda but when the moor resort to this coast from the red sea they use to take in they wood and water at this place and abuse the inhabitant so intolerably that they abandon the place and pull down most of they pagoda and all they other building these gentile be native of that part of the continent which belong to the king of _ narsinga _ and use often to repair thither to perform they devotions to three black stone which be in a chapel of one of the pagoda which still remain this island be call _ ansandina _ -lrb- 65 -rrb- in the malabar language which signify the five island and be so name because there be other four island round about come to anchor here the general send coello on shore with a armed escort to examine the country and to see if there be any convenient place for new-grave they ship bottom as they have be long at sea and have a long run before they every thing be find convenient and the measure approve of by all the captain it be determine to lay they ship successively aground for this purpose the ship call the berrio be first lay on shore and while occupy in repair and clean she bottom many of the native come off from the continent to sell victuals to we people while this be go forwards two small brigandine be see rowing towards we ship ornament with flag and streamer on they mast beat drum and sound trumpet and fill with man who ply they oar at the same time five similar vessel be see creep along shore as if lie by to help the other if needful the malabar who supply we people with provision warn the general to beware of these vessel which belong to pirate who roam about in these sea rob all they meet under pretence of peace -lrb- 66 -rrb- the general believe he might have take these two vessel if he have allow they to come close up with he ship but do not choose to run any risk wherefore as soon as they come within gun-shot he order all the cannon belong to the two ship which remain afloat to be fire at they on which call out in a loud voice _ tambarane tambarane _ which be they name for god they flee away nicholas coello who be in he boat follow after they firing off he ordnance but the general fearful of any mischance call he back by signal next day when the general and all he man be on shore at work upon the berrio twelve native who appear to be man of some consequence come to the island in two small _ parao _ and present a bundle of sugar cane these people ask permission to go on board the ship as they have never see any such before but the general be much offend with this fear they might be spy while engage in conversation with these man other two _ parao _ make they appearance have as many man but those who come first see the general displeased advise these new comer not to land when the berrio be repair the general ship be bring aground to receive the same attention while the general and the other captain be on shore busy in the repair of the san michael there come one day a man in a little _ parao _ seemingly about forty year old and not of that country as he be dress in a _ sabaco _ or gown of fine cotton reach to he heel he head cover with a kerchief or towel which partly cover he face and wear a faulchion or crooked cymeter at he girdle immediately on landing he go up and embrace the general as if he have see or know he before and treat the other captain with the same politeness he tell they he be a christian bear in italy and have be bring when a child into the indy that he now dwell with a moorish lord name _ sabayo _ who rule a certain island call goa about twelve league from thence and who have 40000 horseman on that island that as he dwelling be now among the moor he conform externally to they worship though in he heart a christian that learn certain man have come in ship to calicut such as have never be see before in the indy and that no one understand they language he immediately understand that they must be _ frangne _ -lrb- 67 -rrb- for so the christian be name in the indy that he be desirous of see they and have ask leave of _ sabayo _ to come and visit they which if he have not obtain he would have die of vexation that sabayo have not only grant he leave for this purpose but desire if he find the stranger to be from he country to offer they any thing they might stand in need of which he country produce particularly spice and provision and besides if they would come and live with he sabayo would entertain they honourably and give they sufficient to live on the general ask many question concern the country of sabayo and other thing to which he make answer after which he request to have a cheese from the general to send on shore to a companion as a token of have be well receive the general suspect some mystery in this man yet order a cheese and two new loaf to be give he which he send away to he companion he continue talk with great volubility and sometimes so unguardedly as to raise suspicion of he be a spy on this paulo de la gama who particularly suspect he inquire of some of the native if they know who this man be they immediately tell he he be a pirate who have board many other ship while lay aground on receive this information the general order he to be carry on board he ship then aground and to be whip well till he should confess whether all that he have say be true or false also what be he purpose in come thither and whether he be actually a moor or a christian he still insist that he be a christian and that all he say be true declare the information give by the native to be entirely groundless the general now order a more cruel torment to be inflict to extort confession cause he to be hoist up and down by the member : when at length he declare he would tell the truth he then acknowledge himself a spy send to discover how many man the general have and what be they weapon as he be much hate on all that coast for be a christian and that many _ atalaya _ or foist be place in all the bay and creek of the coast to assail he but dare not till they be join by forty large armed vessel that be get ready to fall upon he but he say he know not certainly when these vessel might be ready the general now order he to be confine under hatch intend to carry he into portugal as a fit person to give the king he master intelligence respect the indy and order he to get refreshing victuals and that he cure should be look well after on receive this information of the design of he enemy the general would stay no longer than be necessary for complete the repair of he own ship which be get ready in ten day about this time the general be offer 1000 _ fanon _ for the ship which have be take by coello but he refuse to sell any thing to he enemy and order she to be burn when the general ship be ready and the fleet have take in a supply of water they depart from the island of _ ansandina _ or anchediva on the 5th of October 1498 steer directly out to sea on they course for melinda after sail about 200 league from that island the moor -lrb- 68 -rrb- whom they have take prisoner see no prospect of escape now make a full and true confession he acknowledge that he live with sabayo the lord of goa to whom word be bring that the general be wander about in those sea like one who know not where he be upon which order be give to fit out a powerful fleet to make he prisoner in the mean time learn that the general be at the isle of anchediva sabayo command he to go thither to visit he to get intelligence of he strength and intention and to endeavor to entice he to goa where it be sabayos intention to make he and all he people prisoner and to employ they in he war against the neighbouring prince as they be report to be valiant man after this confession the general give this man better treatment allow he both clothes and money some time afterwards he become a christian by the name of gaspar de la gama take he name of gaspar from one of the three king of the magus -lrb- 69 -rrb- and he surname from the general who stand god-father at he baptism the general pursued he course for melinda where he propose to take on board a ambassador from the xeque of that place in the early part of this voyage he endure severe storm and contrary wind which be succeed by calm during which the heat of the sun be quite insufferable and the voyage much delay insomuch that water begin to grow scarce and the people have to be put on short allowance owe to these circumstance the people be afflict with the same disease in they gum from which they have formerly suffer such great distress in the river of good sign -lrb- 70 -rrb- on the outward voyage they arm and leg also swell and many tumor break out over they body proceed from a pestilent stink humor which throw they into a flux of which thirty person die from the continuance of calm and contrary wind and the mortality among the people the whole company become amaze and believe they should never be able to get out from they present distressing situation insomuch that they solicit the general to return to calicut or some other part of indium and submit to what god might appoint rather than to die on the sea of these terrible disease for which there be no remedy especially as both provision and water begin to fail de gama reason with they to little purpose as they have be now four month at sea and there hardly remain sixteen person in each ship able to do duty some of whom even be afflict with the disease of which the other have die it be even say that paulo de la gama and nicholas coello have agree to return to india if any wind should spring up that would have serve for the voyage at length a favourable wind spring up unexpectedly and in sixteen day they come in sight of land on Wednesday the 2d of February 1499 at which the mariner be much rejoice and soon forget all they past trouble and danger as they come near the land towards evening the general give order to keep they head out to sea during the night to avoid rock or shoal as there be no person on board who know where they be a moor allege they have steer direct for mozambique say there be certain island 300 league from the shore and directly over against that place where the native be continually subject to the disease which have be so fatal to we man when morning come they stand towards the land when they come before a large and goodly city surround with wall have fair and lofty house and a large palace on a height in the middle of the city seem to be a magnificent building this city be call magadoxo and stand on one side of the gulf of indium on the coast of ethiopium -lrb- 71 -rrb- a hundred and thirteen league from melinda the situation of which i shall explain hereafter know this to be a city of the moor he would not stop at this place but command many shot of ordnance to be fire as he sail past not be sure how far it be to melinda and fear to overshoot that port he lay too every night and on Saturday the 5th of February lie over against a village of the moor name pate -lrb- 72 -rrb- 103 league from magadoxo there come off eight _ terrada _ or boat of that country fill with soldier and make direct for we fleet from whence we shoot off so many piece of ordnance that they soon flee back to the shore and we people could not follow for want of wind next Monday be the 7th of February the fleet arrive at melinda the king immediately send off he congratulation to the general on he arrival with a present of fresh provision de gama send fernan martinez on shore to return the compliment of the king to whom he send a present on account of the great number of sick on board the fleet stop here for ten day during which time he cause a land - mark to be erect on shore with leave of the king as a token of friendship have provide provision and water for the ship at this place he depart on the morning of Wednesday the 17th of February take with he a ambassador from the king of melinda to negotiate a treaty of perpetual peace and friendship with the king of portugal consider that there be not sufficient man remain for navigate all the ship the general and the other captain agree to burn one of they and the san rafael be choose to be sacrifice because she be all open and have not be bring aground at anchediva when the other two be repair accordingly after take out all she store and merchandize which employ they during five day she be burn at certain shoal call the shoal of st raphael -lrb- 73 -rrb- during these five day the fleet procure a considerable quantity of hen from a village on the coast call _ tangata _ leave this place the two remain ship come on the 20th February to the island of zenziber which be in six degree of s latitude at ten league distance from the continent this be a considerable island have other two in its neighborhood one call _ pemba _ and the other _ moyfa _ these island be very fertile have abundance of provision and great quantity of orange the inhabitant be moor who be by no means warlike and have few weapon but be well clothe in silk and cotton vestment which they purchase at mombaza from the merchant of cambaya the woman be ornament with jewel of gold and silver the former be procure at sofalum and the latter from the island of st lawrence or madagascar each of these three island have a separate king who with all they subject be of the mahometan religion when the king of the island of zenziber be inform of the arrival of we ship he send immediately to compliment the general accompany with great present of the fruit and other production of the country and request he friendship to which the general gladly agree and send suitable answer after remain here eight day for refreshment the general depart on the 1st of march and come to anchor beside the isle of st george in the bay of mozambique next day he cause a mark to be erect on this island where he go on shore and hear mass and depart thence without any intercourse with the inhabitant of mozambique on the 3d of march he come to the island of st bla where the ship remain for some time to take in water and to provide a stock of sea wolf and _ solitario _ which be salt to serve as provision for the remainder of the voyage and for which they be most thankful to god depart from thence they be drive back by a westerly wind right contrary but providence send they a fair wind by means of which they double the cape of good hope with infinite pleasure on the 20th of march all the remainder of the crew be now strong and in good health with the cheer prospect of speedily return to lisbon they now have a fair wind which last they twenty day and speed they on towards st jago the fair wind now fail they and delay they voyage try the lead on Thursday the 25th of April they find twenty-five fathom and the least water they have all that day be twenty fathom on which account the pilot conclude they be on the shoal of the rio grande of the rest of this voyage till the arrival of the general at the island of st jago i have find no account except that when approach that place nichola coello part company one night with the general and make direct for portugal that he might carry the first intelligence to the king of the discovery of indium and arrive at _ cascai _ on the 10th of July 1499 -lrb- 74 -rrb- he go immediately to the king whom he inform of all that have befall the general in he discovery of the indy and of the commodity which have be bring from thence of which discovery and of the prospect which it hold out of a direct trade with indium by sea the king be as glad as when he have be proclaimed king of portugal after the separation of coello de gama pursue he voyage for the island of st jago both because he brother paulo be sick with consumptive complaint and because he ship be in very bad condition all she seam be open at that island he freight a caravel in hope of be able to get he brother home to portugal and leave john de sala in charge of he own ship to have she repair and new rig before proceed for lisbon the general and he brother leave st jago in the hire caravel for lisbon but the disease of paulo de gama increase so rapidly that he be force to put in at the island of tercera where paulo de gama depart this life like a good christian and a worthy gentleman when he have bury he brother vasco de gama set sail for portugal and arrive at belem in September 1499 have be two year and two month absent on this voyage of 108 man whom he have take with he only fifty -lrb- 75 -rrb- come home alive which be a large proportion consider the great and numerous danger they have go through when the general have return thanks to god for he preservation and success he send notice of he arrival to the king who send diego de sylva y menesis lord of portugalete and many other gentleman to conduct he honourably to court which they do through a prodigious concourse of people eager to see the man who have make so wonderful a voyage and whom they have long think dead be come into the presence the king honor he as one who by the discovery of the indy have do so much for the glory of god for the honor and profit of the king of portugal and for the perpetual fame of the portuguese name in the world the king make he afterwards a knight and give he and he heir permission to bear the royal arm of portugal as also to set at the foot of the escutcheon two do which be call gama in the portuguese language he also give he a perpetual pension or rent-charge of 300000 ree -lrb- 76 -rrb- yearly out of the tythe fish in the village of _ sini _ in which he be bear and a promise of be make lord of that village and till these grant be execute in form he allow he 1000 crown a-year which after the royal grant be make revert to the house of the _ contratation _ of the indy it be also grant that when the trade with indium should be establish he might bring home spice to the value of 200 ducat yearly without pay any duty he also give he other possession and rent and a note of remembrance or promise to make he a lord -lrb- 77 -rrb- nichola coello be promote to be a gentleman of the royal household and receive possession and rent to bear he charge -lrb- 78 -rrb- yearly -- astl i 40 section iii _ voyage of pedro alvarez cabral to indium in 1500 be the second make by the portuguese to indium and in the course of which brasil be discover _ the certainty of a navigable communication with indium and the vast riches that be to be have in that country be now ascertain the king resolve to prosecute the discovery on purpose to spread the gospel among the idolater and to augment he own revenue and the riches and prosperity of he subject for these purpose he determine to attempt the settlement of a factory in calicut by gentle means hopeful that they might be persuade to a friendly intercourse and might afterwards listen to the word of god he therefore command that a fleet of ten ship and two caravel should be get ready against next year to be well laden with all the commodity which de gama have report to have current sale in calicut there go other also to sofalum and quiloa where also he command factory to be establish both on account of the gold which be to be find there and that the ship might have a place to touch and refresh at in they way to and from indium over the fleet intend for calicut he appoint pedro alvarez cabral a gentleman of a honorable house to be captain-general sancho de toar be captain of he ship the name of the other captain so far as have come to my knowledge be nicholas coello don luis continho simon de myseranda simon leyton bartholomew diaz who discover the cape of good hope and he brother diego diaz who have be purser to vasco do gama in the former voyage of the caravel pedro de tayde -lrb- 1 -rrb- and vasco de silviera be captain aria correa be appoint supercargo of the whole fleet and be order to remain as factor in calicut have gonsalo gil barboso and pedro va caninon as he clerk two ship be to remain with the merchandize at sofalum where loriso hurtado be to be factor in the whole of this fleet there embark 1500 man -lrb- 2 -rrb- the general be instruct besides settle the factory that if the zamorin would not quietly consent or give sufficient lade to the ship he should make cruel war upon he for he injurious conduct to vasco de gama if the zamorin consent to the establishment of a factory and trade the general be secretly to request he not to allow any of the moor of mecca to remain or to trade in calicut or any other harbor in he dominion and to promise that the portuguese should hereafter supply all such commodity as use to be bring by the moor of better quality and cheaper than theirs that he should touch at melinda to land the ambassador who have be bring from thence by de gama together with a present for the king of that place along with this fleet the king send five friar of the order of st franci of whom fra henrique be vicar who be afterwards bishop _ siebta _ and who be to remain in the factory to preach the catholic faith to the malabar -lrb- 3 -rrb- the fleet be in full readiness the king go in procession on Sunday the 7th of march 1500 to hear mass at the monastery of belem accompany by the captain-general whom he take along with himself behind the curtain in the royal seat to do he the more honor after mass don diego orti bishop of viseu preach a sermon in which he give high praise to cabral for undertake the command of this expedition as serve not only the king he temporal master but the eternal god he spiritual lord draw many comparison in he favor from the grecian and roman history mass be end a banner of the royal arm of portugal be deliver to the bishop who solemnly bless it and return it to the king who deliver it to cabral that it might be display at he main-top the bishop then give a bonnet to the general which have be bless by the pope and place a rich jewel with he own hand on he head and give he he blessing when these ceremony be end the king accompany the captain-general to the water side where he and the other captain of the fleet take leave of the king kiss he hand the king give they god blessing and he own after which all go on board and the whole fleet salute the king by discharge all the ordnance of all the ship : but the wind be foul the fleet could not depart that day and the king return to lisbon next day be the 9th of may 1500 have a fair wind the fleet weigh by signal from the general and set sail at eight in the morning -lrb- 4 -rrb- _ the whole fleete have way do then begin to cut and spread they sayle with great pleasure and crie saieng altogether _ buen viage _ that be to say a luckie and prosperous voyage after all this they beganne all to be joyfull every man to use he severall office : the gunner in the midst of the ship hail the maine sheet with the capsteine : the mariner and ship boy some in the forecastell haling bolling brace and martnet : other belie the sheet both great and small and also serve in trim the sayle and other the netting and foretop sayle : other some ver the truss and also beley brase and toppe sayle sheet and coyle every sort of rope it be wonderful to see such a number of diversity of office in so small a roome as be the bredth and length of a ship _ go on they voyage with a quarter wind they come in sight of the canary on the 14th of march and pass st jago on the 22d on the 24th of the same month the caravel command by vasco de tayde part company and be never see afterwards -lrb- 5 -rrb- after wait two day for the miss ship the fleet proceed on its voyage and on the 24th of April come in sight of land this be cause of much joy as it be suppose to be a country which have not be discover by de gama because it lay to the west -lrb- 6 -rrb- of they course cabral immediately send off the master of he ship in a small boat to examine the country who report that it appear pleasant and fertile with extensive wood and many inhabitant the fleet be bring to anchor and the master send again on shore to examine more narrowly into the state of the country and its inhabitant he account be that the native be well proportioned and of a swarthy color arm with bow and arrow and all naked a storm arise at night the fleet weigh anchor and stand along the coast till they find a good harbor in which they all come to anchor name it _ puerto seguro _ or the safe port as it be quite secure in all weather we man take two of the native in a almadium or canoe who be bring to the admiral but no one could understand they language they have therefore apparel give they and be set on shore much pleased this encourage the rest of the native to mix with we people in a friendly manner but find nothing to detain he here the general determine to take in a supply of water not know when he might have another opportunity next day be in easter week a solemn mass be say on shore under a pavilion and a sermon be preach by fra henrique during service many of the native gather around who seem very merry playing and leap about and sound cornet horn and other instrument after mass the native follow the general to he boat singing and make merry in the afternoon we man be allow to go on shore where they barter cloth and paper with the native for parrot and other beautiful bird which be very numerous in that country and with whose feather the native make very shewy hat and cap some of we man go into the country to see the town or dwelling of the native and report that the land be very fertile and full of wood and water with plenty of fruit of various kind and much cotton as this be the country now so well know by the name of brasil i shall not say any more about it in this place except that the fleet remain here for eight day during which a great fish be throw ashore by the sea greater than any _ tonel _ and as broad as two it be of a round form have eye like those of a hog and ear like a elephant but no tooth have two vent under its belly and a tail three quarter of a yard broad and as much in length the skin be like that of a hog and a finger in thickness the general order a high stone cross to be erect at this place and name he new discovery _ la tierra de santa cruz _ or the land of the holy cross from hence he send home a caravel with letter to the king give a account of he voyage hitherto and that he have leave two exile -lrb- 7 -rrb- in this place to examine the country and particularly to ascertain if it be a continent as appear from the length of coast he have pass he send likewise one of the native to shew what kind of people inhabit the land consider the great length of the voyage he have to perform cabral do not deem it proper to spend any more time in examine this new country but depart from puerto seguro -lrb- 8 -rrb- on the 2d of may steer he course for the cape of good hope which be estimate to be 1200 league distant and have a great and fearful gulf to cross render dangerous by the great wind which prevail in these sea during most part of the year on the 12th of may a great comet appear in the heaven come from the east and be visible during ten day and night always increase in splendor on Saturday the 23d of may there arise a great storm from the north-east attend with a high sea and heavy rain which force the whole fleet to take in they sail on its abatement they again spread they foresail and fall calm towards night the ship astern spread out all they sprit-sail to overtake the rest on Sunday the 24th the wind again increase and all the sail be furl between ten and eleven o'clock of that day a water-spout be see in the north-west and the wind lull this deceive the pilot as a sign of good weather wherefore they still carry sail : but it be succeed by a furious tempest which come on so suddenly that they have not time to furl they sail and four ship be sink with all they man one of which be command by bartholomew diaz the discoverer of the cape of good hope the other _ seven _ -lrb- 9 -rrb- be half fill with water and have be all lose if a part of they sail have not give way to the tempest soon afterwards the storm veer to the south-west but still continue so violent that they have to drive all that day and the next under bare pole and the fleet much separate on the third day the wind become more moderate come round to the east and north-east attend by a heavy swell and the wave run higher than have ever be see before yet the fleet join again to they great joy this wind and high sea continue for twenty day during all which time the ship have to lie to and be so toss that no one think it possible to escape be swallow up during day the sea be black as pitch and at night it appear like fire the general with simon de myranda and pedro de tayde bear up to windward during this long continued gale while all the rest submit to the wind and go at god mercy when the storm abate the general find that with only two other ship in company he have double the cape of good hope without have see it on the 16th of July they fall close in with the coast of africa in lat 27  s but the pilot do not know the coast and the general would not allow any one to go on shore they could see great number of people on the land yet none come down to the shore to view the ship have no hope of procure provision from the native the seaman catch great plenty of fish at this place after which the general pursued he course close along shore where he constantly see many people and great number of cattle feed along the bank of a river which fall into the sea in that neighborhood -lrb- 10 -rrb- proceeding in this manner the general come to sofala with which the pilot be unacquainted near which lay two island -lrb- 11 -rrb- close by one of which two vessel lay at anchor these immediately make for the shore on see the portuguese ship and be pursue be take without resistance the principal person belong to these vessel be a near relation -lrb- 12 -rrb- of the king of melinda and be go from sofalum to melinda with gold the people be so much afraid on see we ship that they throw a great part of the gold into the sea and most of they escape on shore the general be much concern at he loss especially that it should have fall on the subject and relation of a prince who be in friendship with the king he master and after shew he every civility restore the two vessel with all the remain gold the moor ask cabral if he have any witch on board who could conjure up he gold from the bottom of the sea cabral answer that the christian believe in the true god and do not practice or give credit to witchcraft learning from this moor that he have overshoot sofalum and not be incline to turn back the general continue he voyage to mozambique where he arrive on the 20th of July and take in a supply of water and procure a pilot to carry he to the island of quiloa towards which he direct he course in this part of the voyage he see several fertile island belong to the king of quiloa who be a powerful prince he dominion extend from cape corientes almost to mombaza along nearly 400 league of coast include the two island near sofalum that city itself and several other to mozambique many more all the way to mombaza with a great number of island from all which he derive large revenue -lrb- 13 -rrb- yet he have few soldier and life in no great state he constant residence be in a island name quiloa near the continent of ethiopia a hundred league from mozambique this island be full of garden and orchard with plenty of various kind of fruit and excellent water and the country produce abundance of _ miso _ -lrb- 14 -rrb- and other grain and breed great number of small cattle and the sea afford great plenty of excellent fish the city of quiloa be in lat 9  25 's and long 40  20 ' e handsomely build of stone and lime and pleasantly situated between fine garden and the sea have abundance of provision from its own island and from other place on the continent the king and the inhabitant of the city be moor of a fair color use the arabic language but the original native of the country be negro the moor of quiloa be richly dress especially the woman who wear many golden ornament they be great merchant enjoy the principal trade in gold at sofala whence it be distribute over arabium felix and other country and many merchant resort thither from other place hence there be always many ship in this port which be all haul upon the beach when not in use these ship -lrb- 15 -rrb- have no nail but be sew together by rope make of _ cairo _ and have they bottom pay with wild frankincense as the country produce no pitch the winter here begin in April and end in may on arrive at quiloa and receive a safe-conduct for that purpose the general send alonso hurtado attend by seven of the principal officer to wait upon the king signify that cabral have come here with the fleet of the king of portugal to settle a trade in the city and have great store of merchandize fit for that purpose and to say that he be desirous to confer with he highness on this subject but have be forbid by the king he master to go on shore the king agree to give cabral a audience afloat and on the follow day cabral wait for the king in he boat which be cover over with flag and attend by all the other captain in they boat as now sancho de toar and other two ship have join company again the king come in a almadium accompany by many principal moor in other boat all deck with flag and with many trumpet cornet and sackbut make a great noise on the arrival of the king the whole portuguese ordnance be fire off by which the king and he train be much alarm not have be accustom to such a salute after mutual civility the letter from the king of portugal be read propose the settlement of trade between the two nation to which the king of quiloa assent and agree that alonso hurtado should wait upon he next day with a account of the kind of merchandize the portuguese have to dispose of for which he promise to give gold in exchange but when hurtado go next day on shore the king make many excuse for not perform he promise pretend to have no need of the commodity and believe that the general come to conquer he country the true reason be because he be a moor and we be christian and he be unwilling to have any trade or intercourse with we after this the general remain three or four day to see if the king would change he mind but he continue inflexible and strengthen himself with armed man as jealous of be attack find that nothing could be do here the general go on he voyage and arrive at melinda on the 2d of August at this port he find three ship at anchor belong to moorish merchant of cambaya but though laden with great riches he would not meddle with they out of respect for the king of melinda on come to anchor the general salute the king with all he ordnance on which the king send a complimentary message of welcome with a present of many sheep hen and duck and great quantity of fruit the general send a message in return intimate that he have come here by order of the king of portugal to know if he highness have any service which the fleet could perform for he and to deliver a letter and a rich present from the king of portugal which he would send whenever he highness pleased to give he command the king be much pleased with this message and detain the messenger all night most part of which he spend in make inquiry respect the kingdom of portugal as soon as it be day the king send two principal moor to wait upon the general declare he joy at he arrival and desire if he have need of any thing in the country to command all there as he own the general then send aries correa the factor-general of the fleet on shore to deliver the letter and present accompany by most of the principal officer and have all the trumpeter of the fleet sound before he the present be impossible to resist we next day one gaspar -lrb- 18 -rrb- be send on shore to the zamorin desire to have a safe-conduct for a deputation from the general to wait on he highness and along with
