low cast but he send for gaspar whom he receive with civility and whom he assure that we people might come on shore in perfect safety on receive this intelligence cabral send alonso hurtado to the zamorin intimate that the portuguese fleet have come on purpose to settle trade and friendship and that the general wish for a audience in which to arrange these matter with he highness but have order from the king he master not to go on shore without sufficient pledge for he security among whom he demand the kutwal of calicut and araxamenoca one of the chief of the nayre -lrb- 19 -rrb- on this occasion hurtado be accompany by a person who could speak the language to act as he interpreter the zamorin be unwilling to send the hostage require allege that they be old and sickly and offer to send other who be better able to endure the hardship of live on board yet he afterwards at the instigation of the moor be against send any hostage as they make he believe that the general shewed little confidence in he promise which be derogatory to he honor and dignity this negociation last three day as hurtado insist on this as a necessary preliminary at length desirous of have trade settle with we owe to the advantage which would accrue to he revenue the zamorin agree to give the hostage require on which leave the command of the fleet in he absence to sancho de toar cabral direct that the hostage should be well treat but on no account to deliver they to any one even although demand in he name on the 28th of December cabral go on shore magnificently dress and attend by thirty of he principal officer and other the king servant in as much state as if he have be king of portugal carry with he rich furniture for he apartment with a cupboard of plate contain many rich piece of gilt silver he be meet by many principal nayre send by the zamorin to wait upon he and attend by a numerous train among whom be many person sound trumpet sackbut and other musical instrument the zamorin wait for he in a gallery close by the shore which have be erect on purpose and while the general go towards the shore accompany by all the boat of the fleet dress out with flag and streamer the hostage be carry on board he ship where they be loath to enter till they should see the general on shore lest he might return and detain they but be at last reassure of they safety by aries correa on landing cabral be receive in great state by several _ caymal pinakal _ and other principal nayre by whose direction he be place in a _ andor _ or chair in which he be carry to the _ serame _ or hall of audience where the king wait he arrival the serame or gallery be all hung round with rich carpet call _ alcatifa _ and at the farther end the zamorin sit in a alcove or recess resemble a small chapel with a canopy of unshorn crimson velvet over he head and have twenty silk cushion under he and about he the zamorin be almost naked have only a piece of white cotton round he waist work with gold on he head he wear a cap of cloth of gold resemble a helmet in he ear he have rich jewel of diamond sapphire and pearl two of the latter be as large as walnut he arm from the elbow to the wrist be cover with golden bracelet set with numberless precious stone of great value and he leg from the knee to the ankle be similarly adorn he finger and toe have numerous ring and on one of he great toe he wear a ruby of great size and wonderful brilliancy one of he diamond be bigger than a large bean all these be greatly surpass by he girdle of gold and jewel which be altogether inestimable and be so brilliant that it dazzle the eye of the beholder beside the zamorin be a rich throne or state chair all of gold and jewel and he _ andor _ in which he have be carry from the palace be of similar richness and stand near he he be attend by twenty trumpeter seventeen of whom have silver trumpet and three of they gold all the mouth-piece be finely work and set with jewel although in full day the hall be light by many silver lamp in the fashion of the moor close by the king there stand a spit basin of gold and several silver perfuming-pan which produce a excellent odour six pace from the king he be attend on by he two brother who be the nearest heir to the kingdom and a little farther off be many nobleman all standing on enter the hall and see the splendid state of the zamorin cabral would have kiss he hand as be the custom of europe but be inform that this be not customary among they and therefore sit down in a chair near the king which be appoint for he as a especial honor he then deliver he letter of credit from the king of portugal write in arabic and then say that the king he master willing to cultivate trade and friendship with the zamorin and he subject have give he order to require permission to establish a factory or house of trade in calicut which should always be supply with every kind of merchandize that be in demand and request the zamorin to supply a sufficient loading of spice for the ship under he command which he be ready to pay for either by means of the commodity he have on board or in ready money the zamorin seem or affect to be please with the embassy and say that the king of portugal be welcome to every thing in he city of which he be in need at this time the present from the king of portugal to the zamorin be bring forwards which among other thing contain a richly work basin and ewer of silver gilt a gilt silver flaggon and cover of similar workmanship two silver mace four cushion two of which be cloth of gold and the other two of unshorn crimson velvet a state canopy of cloth of gold bind and fringe with gold a carpet of rich crimson velvet two very rich arras hanging one ornament with human figure and the other with representation of tree and flower the zamorin be much satisfied with this present and say the general might either retire to he lodgings for rest and refreshment or might return to he ship as he think best but as the hostage be man of high cast and could not endure the sea who could neither eat or drink while on board consistent with they custom it become necessary that they should come on shore wherefore if the general would return to he ship and send these man on shore and incline to come back next day to conclude all matter relative to the trade of calicut the same hostage should be again send on board as the general place confidence in these assurance of the zamorin he go on board leave hurtado and other seven of he people in charge of he valuable that be leave on shore when at the water side and ready to embark a servant of one of the hostage who be dispatch by the comptroller of the zamorin household go before in a almadium or small pinnace and give notice to the hostage that the general be come on board on which they leap into the sea mean to escape to land in the almadium with the servant : but aries correa go immediately with some of the portuguese mariner in a boat and retake two of the hostage with three or four of the malabar belong to the almadium : the rest of the hostage among whom be the kutwal get to the city when cabral come on board and learn what have happen he order the two remain hostage to be secure below deck and send a complaint to the zamorin against the conduct of the hostage lay all the blame on the comptroller he desire the messenger to inform the zamorin of the situation of the two remain hostage and to say that they should be liberate whenever the portuguese and the goods on shore be send back to the ship next day the zamorin come to the shore accompany by 12 000 man and send off the portuguese people and they commodity to the ship in thirty almadia with order to bring back the hostage but none of the malabar in the almadia dare to approach the ship be afraid of the portuguese and return therefore to the land without deliver we people and commodity next day the general send some of he own boat to land the pledge but at some distance from the almadia on which occasion araxamenoca one of the hostage leap into the sea with a intention to escape but be retake and while we people be busy in secure he the other hostage make he escape the general be astonish at the want of truth and honor in these people and give order to keep araxamenoca in strict custody but find at the end of three day that the zamorin do not send for he and that during all this period he refuse all sustenance cabral take compassion on he and send he to the zamorin request that two of we man who remain on shore might be send on board which be comply with after wait three day without any message from the zamorin the general send one francisco correa to inquire if he incline to confirm the agreement between they in which case he would send aries correa on shore to treat with he highness for whose safety he require hostage the zamorin answer that he be perfectly willing to have the trade establish and that the general might send aries correa or any other person on shore for that purpose and transmit two grandson of a rich merchant of guzerate as hostage aries correa go accordingly on shore and be accommodate by the order of the zamorin with a convenient house for himself and he goods which belong to the guzerate merchant who be likewise command to assist correa in regard to the price of he merchandize and all other thing relate to the trade and custom of the place but this man be a friend to the moor of mecca thwart he in all thing instead of give he assistance the moor be determine enemy to we people both for be christian and lest they credit and advantageous traffic in calicut might suffer by the establishment of we trade in that port wherefore by means of they confederacy with the guzerate merchant they take we goods at any price they please and intimidate the malabar from trading with we the moor conclude that the establishment of we factory would lower the price of such commodity as they have to sell and would inhance the value of the spicery drug and jewel which they take in exchange on this account they thwart correa in all he transaction offer higher price than ordinary for every article by which he be constrain to buy every thing at a very dear rate if at any time he wish a audience of the zamorin the moor always contrived to be present that some of they might speak against he in this conduct they be assist by _ samicide _ -lrb- 20 -rrb- a moor who be admiral of calicut who likewise hinder any of we people of the factory from go on board the fleet and detain any of we boat that approach the shore pretend to do this by command of the zamorin on learn this sinister conduct of the moorish admiral of calicut and suspect some intended treachery the general give order to the fleet to weigh they anchor and to remove out of the harbor lest they might be attack by the zamorin fleet and that he might take counsel with the other captain for the safety of the expedition on learn this the zamorin inquire the reason from correa who urge the injurious behavior of the moor and tell he all that they have do the zamorin immediately give order that the moor should discontinue they villanous conduct towards we and even remove the guzerate merchant from we factory appoint one _ cosebequin _ -lrb- 21 -rrb- in he place who though a moor be a very honest man and behave to we in a friendly manner this man be of great credit in calicut be the head of all the native moor of that country who be always at variance with the moor of cairo and of the red sea of whom the admiral samicide be the chief the zamorin give farther order that we factory should be remove to a house close to the shore which belong to cosebequin that we merchant might have greater freedom to buy and sell without any interruption from the moor for the greater security a deed of gift be make of this house by the zamorin to the king of portugal and he successor for ever a copy of which sign and seal by the zamorin be enclose in a casket of gold that it might be convey to portugal and permission be give to display a flag of the royal arm of portugal from the top of the factory -lrb- 22 -rrb- on receive intelligence of these favourable measure cabral bring back the fleet into the harbor of calicut and send he compliment of thanks to the zamorin for he gracious and favourable disposition after this we factory have tolerably good fortune in conduct its trade by the assistance of cosebequin : and the native find we factory favor by the zamorin behave so very civilly to we people that they could go about wherever they please with as much freedom and safety as in lisbon during the subsistence of this friendly intercourse a large moorish ship be descry from calicut on its voyage from cochin for cambaya and the zamorin request we general to make prize of the ship allege that it contain a peculiarly fine elephant which he wish to possess and which have be refuse to he although he have offer more than its value the general answer that he would do this willingly to gratify he highness but as he be inform the ship be large and well man both with mariner and soldier it could not be expect to surrender without resistance in which some man might be slay on both side and it be therefore necessary he should have the sanction of he highness to kill these people in case of resistance which be accordingly grant upon which the general send pedro de tayde in he caravel accompany by a valiant young gentleman name duarte or edward pacheco and by sixty fight man with order to take this ship along with they the zamorin send certain moor that they might witness the manner of fight use by the portuguese the caravel give chase to the moorish ship till night and then lose sight of she but in sailing along shore by moon-light they see she ride at anchor ready for defense judge she to be about 600 ton burthen and to contain 300 fight man pacheco accord to he order do not think proper to lay the moorish ship on board but command he ship to be bring to intend to sink the moorish ship by means of he ordnance in case of necessity the moor make light of we small force which they greet with loud cry and the sound of musical instrument after which they play they ordnance against we caravel they be bravely answer by we man and one of we ball strike they between wind and water so that the moorish ship take in much water and many of they man be kill and wound by we shot they bear away for the bay of cananor which be very near and come there to anchor beside other four moorish ship pacheco follow they and continue to batter they with he gun and have assuredly take they have not certain _ paroa _ belong to the moor come from the port of cananor to they assistance the night grow very dark pacheco quit the bay lest he caravel might be set on fire by the moor and come to anchor close to a island at a short distance have have nine of he man wound by arrow during the engagement next morning pacheco again attack the moorish ship which at last yield to the great displeasure of the native of cananor who have flock to the seaside intend to have succour the moor but on pacheco send a few shot among they they all disperse pacheco come next day to calicut with he prize where the zamorin come down to the water side to see the moorish ship give great praise to we people for they prowess be much astonished that so great a ship should be take by one so much inferior in size and number of man the general command this ship to be deliver to the zamorin together with the seven elephant that be on board which be worth in calicut 30000 crown he also send a message to the zamorin say that he need not be astonish at this action as he would perform much greater action to serve he highness the zamorin return thanks for what have be do and desire the brave man who have perform this gallant action to be send he that he might do they honor and reward they as they deserve and he bestow large present upon pacheco in particular some affirm that the performance of this gallant feat by so small a number of we man against such great odds raise fear and jealousy of the portuguese in the mind of the zamorin and make he anxious to get they away from he country for which cause he give he consent to the treachery which be use against they as i mean to shew in the sequel -lrb- 23 -rrb- the moor of calicut be more terrify than ever at the portuguese in consequence of the capture of this ship and be much offend by the favor bestow by the zamorin upon we man for they gallantry on this occasion they believe that all this be do out of revenge against themselves for the injury they have do we and be intend to induce they to retire from calicut especially as we people bring there as great store of merchandize as they do and buy as many spice take all this into consideration they procure a audience of the zamorin to whom one of they number make the follow oration in the name of all the moor _ emparather -lrb- 24 -rrb- _ of all the malabar as great as the mightiest sovereign of the indy and most powerful among the prince of the earth we be astonish that you should debase yourself by receive into you country these enemy of you law and stranger to the custom of you kingdom who seem pirate rather than merchant we should not wonder at you so do be you city in want of the commodity they bring or could not otherwise dispose of the spicery they purchase : but we whom you have long know and whose fidelity you be well assure of by experience have always do both to the great increase of you revenue you appear to forget all this by receive those whom you do not know into you favor and employ they to revenge you injury as if you own numerous and faithful subject be incompetent for the purpose in this you dishonor yourself and embolden these stranger to hold you power in contempt and to act as we know they will hereafter by rob and plunder all merchant ship that frequent you port to the ruin of you country and who will at length take possession of you city this be the true intent of they come into these sea and not to trade for spice as they pretend they country be almost 5000 league from hence and the voyage out and home be attend by many danger through unknown and stormy sea besides the great cost of they large ship with so many man and gun hence at whatever price they may dispose of they spice in portugal it be obvious such a trade must be carry on with great loss which be a manifest proof that they be pirate and not merchant who come here to rob and to take you city the house you have give they for a factory they will convert into a fort from whence they will make war on you when you least expect it all this we say more from the good will we owe you than for any profit for if you do not listen to we advice there be other city in malabar to which we will remove and to which the spice will be convey for we to this harangue the zamorin give a favourable answer say that he would give attention to all they have say of which indeed he already have some suspicion that he have employ the portuguese to seize the ship to try they courage and have allow they to load they ship that the money they have bring to purchase goods might remain in the country and finally that he would not forsake they in favor of the stranger the moor be by no means satisfy with all this because the zamorin do not order we to depart from calicut and do not stop we trade which be they chief purpose though disappoint in these view they continue to intermiddle in we affair particularly by buy up the spice and send they elsewhere in hope of irritating we people and bring on a quarrel that they might have a pretext to attack we this they be much inclined to bring about as be greatly more numerous than we man they hope the zamorin would take part with they against we they likewise use all possible means to draw over the common people of calicut to they side and to excite they to enmity against we by make they believe that we people have injure they through those device we factor be unable to procure more spice than suffice to load two ship in the course of three month from which the general be convince that the friendly assurance of the zamorin be little to be depend on and if he have not be afraid of not be able to procure a sufficient supply elsewhere he would have go to another port : but have already consume a long time and be at heavy charge he determine to remain at calicut and send a message to the zamorin complain of the delay which ill accord with the promise of he highness that the whole fleet should be load in twenty day whereas three month be now elapse and the loading of two ship only be procure he urge the zamorin promise that the portuguese ship be to be first loaded whereas he have assure information that the moor have buy up great quantity of spice at lower price and send they to other place and beg the zamorin to consider that it be now time for the ship to begin they voyage to portugal and that he anxiously wish for dispatch on receive this message the zamorin pretend to be much surprised that we ship be still unprovided with a loading and could not believe that the moor have secretly buy up and remove the spice contrary to he order and even give permission to the general to take those ship belong to the moor which be laden with spice pay the same price for the spice which have be give by the moor this intelligence give much satisfaction to the moor as a favourable opportunity for draw on hostility with the portuguese and accordingly one of the principal moorish merchant begin immediately to load he ship : openly with all kind of drug and spice and suborn several moor and indian who pretend to be the friend of we factor to insinuate that he would never be able to find a sufficient load for we fleet if he do not seize that ship correa listen to this insidious advice which he communicate to the general urge he to take that moorish ship as he have license from the zamorin to that effect the general be exceedingly unwilling to proceed to this extremity afraid of the influence of the moor with the zamorin and of produce hostility with the native but correa remonstrate against delay protest that the general should be responsible for all loss that might accrue to the king of portugal through he neglect over-persuaded by this urgency of the factor the general send all the boat of the squadron on the 17th of December to take possession of the moorish ship when this intelligence be receive on shore the moor think this a favourable opportunity of destroy we people and immediately raise a great outcry against the portuguese incense the people of the city to join with they in complain to the zamorin to whom they go in a tumultuous manner represent that we have buy and ship a much larger quantity of drug and spice than the value of all we merchandize and not contented with this be for take all like thief and pirate they blame the zamorin for permit we to trade in the city and request he license to revenge themselves upon we for the loss of they vessel the faithless and inconstant king save they the license they require on which they immediately arm themselves and run furiously to we factory which be surround by a wall eight or ten foot high and contain at that time seventy portuguese among whom be fra henrique and he friar of we people in the factory only eight be arm with crossbow all the rest be only arm with sword with nothing to defend they but they cloak on hear the tumult we people go to the gate of the factory and see only a few assailant they think to defend themselves with they sword against a mischievous rabble but the number of the moor soon increase and gall we people so severely with they spear and arrow that they be force to shut the gate after kill seven of the enemy hope to be able to defend themselves by means of the wall in this conflict four of we man be slay and several wound and all the remainder mount the wall to defend it by means of the crossbow judge that the assailant be at least four thousand man among whom be several nayre core now find himself unable to defend the factory against so great a force and therefore hoist a flag as signal to the fleet the general be at this time sick in bed have be just blood and be not therefore able to go in person to relieve the people in the factory but immediately send all the boat of the fleet well man under the command of sancho de toar but he be afraid to venture on land with so small a force against so great a multitude or even to approach too near the shore lest the enemy might assail he in they almadia and toni he lay off therefore at a considerable distance where he remain a spectator of the valiant defense make by we people at the factory whence they kill great number of the assailant but they enemy always increase in number and they at length bring up certain engine to beat down part of the wall in which they at length succeed on this we man issue out by a door which lead towards the sea side in hope of be able to fight they way to the boat in which attempt corea be slay and fifty more of we man be either kill or make prisoner twenty only escape who swim to the boat most of whom be much wound among these be fra henrique and antonio the son of aries corea then only eleven year old who have since do many noble feat of arm in the indy and other place as i shall afterwards declare in the _ fourth _ book of this history the general be much concern at this event not only for the loss of he man but on see how little confidence could be repose on the promise of the zamorin after all the present he have receive and the service which have be perform for he he have now spend three month at calicut during which he have only loaded two of he ship and know not how to procure load for the rest especially as he could not expect a favourable reception at cochin on account of have capture the ship with the elephant as before related consider the treason which have be practice on we man the general determine upon take a signal revenge if the zamorin do not make a ample excuse for what have take place and make a full reparation by immediately provide the rest of the ship with lade the zamorin however have no such intention be much pleased with what the moor have do and even order all the goods in we factory to be seize to the value of 4000 ducat he likewise order all of we people who have be take on shore to be make captive four of whom die of they wound see that no message or excuse be send by the zamorin all that day the general hold a council with he officer as to the proper step to be take on the present emergency when it be determine to take immediate and ample revenge without give time to the zamorin to arm he fleet on this order be issue to take possession of ten large ship which lay in the road or harbor of calicut which be do after some resistance many of they crew be kill or drown and other make prisoner who be reserve to serve as mariner on board we fleet some spice and other merchandize be take in these ship and three elephant which be kill and salt as provision for the voyage and it appear that 600 moor be slay in defend these ship after every thing of value be take from the moorish ship they be all burnt in sight of the city many of the moor embark in they almadia to attempt succour they ship but we man soon put they to flight by means of they ordnance the zamorin and the whole city of calicut be much mortified to see so many ship destroy and they unable to help but they astonishment and terror be much increase by the event of the ensue day during the night the general order all the ship of the fleet to be tow as near as possible to the shore by means of the boat and spread out at some distance from each other that they might be able to reach the city with they ordnance which as soon as day break be direct to play upon the city in every direction do vast damage among the house the native bring down to the shore such small piece of ordnance as they possess which they fire off against we but without be able to do we any injury whereas not a shot of ours miss take effect either among the multitude of we enemy which flock to the shore or on the building of the city both the house of the inhabitant and the temple of they deity receive incredible damage so great be the consternation that the zamorin flee from he palace and one of he chief nayre be kill by a ball close beside he part even of the palace be destroy by the cannonade towards afternoon two ship be see approach the harbor which immediately change they course on see how we fleet be employ on which the general cease firing against calicut and make all sail after these two ship to pandarane where they take shelter among other seven ship lie at anchor close to the shore and fill with moor find that we fleet could not get near enough to attack they owe to shallow water and consider that it be now late in the season for he voyage back to lisbon the general resolve to be contented with the revenge he have already take upon calicut and make sail for cochin where he be inform there be more pepper to be have than even at calicut and where he hope to enter into a treaty with the rajah of that place ' on he way towards cochin cabral take two ship belong to the moor which he set on fire after take out of they some rice which they have on board on the 20th of December the fleet arrive at cochin which be nineteen league to the south of calicut and be in nine degree towards the north -lrb- 25 -rrb- cochin be in the province of malabar on a river close to the sea and be almost a island so that it be very strong and difficult of access have a large and safe harbor the land in its neighborhood be low and intersect by branch of the river into many island the city itself be build much after the same manner with calicut and be inhabit by idolater with a good many moorish stranger who come hither to trade from many country two of whom be so rich as to have each fifty ship employ this country do not abound in provision but produce large store of pepper even calicut be mostly supply from hence : but as calicut be greatly more resort to by merchant it be therefore much richer than cochin the king be a idolater of the same manners and custom with he of calicut but he country be small he be very poor and have not even the right to coin money be in many respects subordinate to the zamorin who on he accession to the throne always go to cochin and take possession of that kingdom either retain it in he own hand or restore the rajah as he may think proper the rajah of cochin consequently be bind to assist the zamorin in all he war and must always be of the same religion with he paramount have come to anchor in the harbor of cochin the general send one michael jogue -lrb- 26 -rrb- on shore with a message to the rajah as he fear to send caspar on shore lest he might run away this person though a idolater and a stranger have come aboard we fleet with the intention of become a christian and of go into portugal and we general have he baptise by the name of michael he be order to give the rajah of cochin a account of all that have happen at calicut and that cabral have bring great store of merchandize to barter for the commodity of cochin or if the rajah be not satisfy with these he be willing to give ready money for what he want request to be furnish with load for four of he ship in either way as most agreeable to the rajah to this message the rajah -lrb- 27 -rrb- make answer that he be exceedingly glad of the arrival of the portuguese of whose power and valor he have already hear for which he esteem they highly and that they be welcome to purchase what spice he country afford either in barter for they goods or for money as they think proper he add that the general might freely send any agent he please on shore to make purchase and sale and send two principal nayre as hostage for they safety conditioning only that they might be change daily for other because any of that cast who chance to eat even once on shipboard could never appear again in the raja presence cabral be well please with this promising beginning and immediately appoint gonzalo gil barbosa as factor who have be assistant to aries correa give he laureno morena as clerk and madera de alcusia as interpreter with four of the banish man as servant on receive notice of the landing of barbosa the rajah send the register -lrb- 28 -rrb- of the city to meet he accompany by many of the nayre or principal man of the court who bring he to visit the rajah who be much inferior in dress and appearance of state to the zamorin even the hall of audience have only bare wall seat around like a theater in which the rajah sit with very few attendant barbosa present to the rajah in name of we general a basin of silver fill with saffron a large silver ewer fill with rose water and some branch of coral which the rajah receive with much satisfaction desire he thanks to be return to the general and after some conversation with the factor and interpreter he give order for they to be properly lodge in the city the general give especial order that no more than the seven person already mention should remain on shore think it imprudent to risk a greater number in case of experience a similar misfortune with what have lately happen at calicut but there be here no cause for distrust as the rajah of cochin be a person of truth and honor as appear by he good usage of we man the quick dispatch that be use in load we ship with spice and the order he give to he people to afford every assistance which they do with much alacrity and zeal : so that it seem ordain of god that the trade should be transfer from calicut to cochin for the advancement of the catholic faith in the indy and the enrichment of the crown of portugal -lrb- 29 -rrb- after the ship be laden two indian come to wait upon the general who say that they be brother and christian bear in cranganore near cochin who be desirous of go to portugal and thence to visit the pope at rome and the holy sepulchre at jerusalem -lrb- 30 -rrb- be ask by the general what kind of a city cranganore be whether it be entirely inhabit by christian and whether these christian follow the order of the greek or roman church one of they give the follow answer cranganore be a large city in the province of malabar on the mainland standing near the mouth of a river by which likewise it be encompass inhabit both by idolater and christian and by some jew who be hold in small esteem it be much frequent by stranger among whom be merchant from syrium egypt persium and arabium who come thither to purchase pepper a great deal of which commodity be gather in its territory it have a king of its own to whom all the christian inhabitant pay a certain tribute and have a quarter of they own in the city where they have a church resemble ours in which there be cross but no image of the saint and no bell be summon to prayer by the priest as in the greek church these christian hail they pope with twelve cardinal two patriarch and many bishop and archbishop all of whom reside in armenia to which country they bishop always go for consecration he have be there himself along with a bishop where he be ordain a priest that this rule be observe by all the clergy of the indy and of cathay who have to go to the pope or catholico of armenia for consecration of they two patriarch one reside in the indy and the other in cathay -lrb- 31 -rrb- they bishop reside in different city as it may seem convenient they tonsure be make in form of a cross the cause of they have a pope be say to have be on the follow account : ` when st peter be reside at antioch there happen a great schism occasion by simon magus on which peter be call to rome to assist the christian in overthrow that heresy and that he might not leave the eastern church without a shepherd he appoint a vicar to govern at antioch who should become pope after the death of peter and should always assist the pope of armenia but after the moor enter into syrium and asia minor as armenia remain always in the christian faith they come to be govern by twelve cardinal marco polo in write concern armenia mention this pope or catholico and say there be two sect of christian the nestorian and jacobite they pope be name jacobus whom this joseph name they catholico the priest of cranganore be not shave in the same manner with ours but shave the whole head leave a few hair on the crown and they have both deacon and subdeacon in consecrate the element they use leaven bread and wine make of raisin have no other in the country they child be not baptize till they be eleven day old unless they happen to be sickly they confess as we do and bury they dead after a similar manner they do not use the holy oil to the die but only bless they and when any one die they gather a large company and feast for eight day after which the obsequy be celebrate if any person die without make a testament they land and goods go to the nearest heir but the widow be entitle to she dower if she remain a year unmarried on go into church they use holy water they hold the writings of the four evangelist in great veneration they fast during lend and advent with much solemnity and on easter eve they neither eat nor drink the whole day they have regularly sermon on the night of holy Friday and they observe the day of the resurrection with great devotion likewise the two follow day and the ensue Sunday be particularly keep holy because on that day st thoma thrust he hand into the side of we savior ascension day trinity Sunday the assumption and nativity of the bless virgin candlema day christmas day all the day of the apostle and all the sunday throughout the year be keep with much devotion they sanctify in a particular manner the first day of July every year in honor of st thoma but they could give no reason why this be do they have also native friar and nun who live with much regularity they priest also live chastely as those who do otherwise be debar from execute they function they allow of no divorce between married people who must live together till death they receive the sacrament regularly three time in every year they have among they certain learn man or great doctor who keep school in which they teach the scripture and likewise some excellent interpretation which be leave in old time by they ancient doctor they dress be similar to that of the moor they day consist of forty hour and have no clock they judge of the time of the day by the sun and in the night by the motion of the star -lrb- 32 -rrb- the general be very glad to receive this joseph and he brother and give order to provide they with a good cabin in he ship while cabral remain at cochin he receive message from the king of cananor and coulan both considerable prince in the province of malabar request he to come to they port where he should be supply cheaper than at cochin and give he many offer of friendship he make answer with he hearty thanks that he could not now visit they port have already begin to take in he loading bet that he should certainly visit they on he return to indium immediately after the portuguese ship be laden a fleet of twenty-five great ship and other small vessel be descry in the offing and notice be send by the rajah of cochin to we general that this fleet contain fifteen thousand fight man and have be fit out on purpose to make he and all he people prisoner at the same time the rajah offer to send man to he assistance if he stand in need but the general answer he have no need of any such aid at the present as he trust with god 's blessing to convince he enemy they be ill advise in seek now to attack he have already give they a trial of he strength allude to what he have already do to they at calicut the enemy continue to hover off at sea but do not venture to come nearer than a league though they seem in fight order see this shyness the general weigh anchor and go out with all he fleet against they have on board the two nayre who be hostage for the factory on shore but he intention be to have return with they to cochin soon after leave the harbor a great storm arise with a foul wind so that he be force to come to anchor without attain to the enemy next morning be the 10th January 1501 the wind come fair and be desirous to attack the fleet of calicut the general make sail towards they but miss the ship command by sancho de toar who have part from the fleet in the night and that be the largest and best man ship of the fleet he deem it prudent to avoid fight with so large a force especially as many of he man be sick the wind likewise be now quite fair for begin he voyage home and be quite contrary for go back to cochin to land the hostage he determine therefore to commence he voyage and stand out to sea the enemy follow he during the whole of that day but return towards calicut when night draw on cabral now turn he attention to the forlorn nayre who have be five day on board without eating and by dint of much and kind entreaty he at length prevail on they to take food on the 15th of January the fleet come in sight of cananore which lie on the coast of malabar thirty-one league north of cochin this be a large city with a fine bay the house be build of earth and cover with flat stone or slate and it contain many moor who trade thither for many kind of goods the neighborhood produce hardly any more pepper than be necessary for its own consumpt but have plenty of ginger cardamom tamarind mirabolan cassia-fistula -lrb- 33 -rrb- and other drug in several pool of water near this city there be many very large alligator -lrb- 34 -rrb- similar to the crocodile of the nile which devour man when they come in they way they have very large head with two row of tooth and they breath smell like musk they body be cover all over with hard scale like shell in the bush near this city there be many large and very venomous serpent which destroy man by means of they breath there be bat likewise as large as kite which have head like a fox and similar tooth and the native often eat these animal the city of cananore abound in fish flesh and fruit but have to import rice from other place the king or rajah be a bramin be one of the three king of malabar but be not so rich and powerful as the zamorin or even as the rajah of coulan the general come to anchor at this port both because he have be invite by the rajah and because he wish to take on board some cinnamon of which commodity he have not as yet any on board he accordingly purchase 400 quintal and might have have more if he would but refuse it on which the people of the place conclude that he have no more money on this come to the knowledge of the rajah he send he word that he would trust he with any quantity he have a mind for of that or any other commodity till he return from portugal or the arrival of any other in he stead the rajah be induce to make this offer from he knowledge of the just dealings of the portuguese and they faithful performance of they promise the general send he hearty thanks to the rajah for he liberality promise to inform the king he master of he good will and assure he highness that he might depend on he constant friendship cabral now take on board a ambassador from the rajah of cananore for the king of portugal who be send to conclude a treaty of amity between they depart from cananore and standing across the gulf he take a great ship richly laden on the last of January : but on learn that it belong to the king of cambaya he permit it to proceed on its voyage uninjured send word to that sovereign that the portuguese do not come to the indy to make war on any one except indeed with the zamorin of calicut who have scandalously break the peace which have be make between they he therefore only take a pilot out of this ship to conduct he through the gulf between indium and africa while continue they voyage and approach the african shore a great storm arise on the 12th of February by which in the night the ship of sancho de toar be drive on shore and take fire be entirely burn the man only be save as the tempest still continue they be unable to stop at melinda or any other place till they come to mozambique where they cast anchor in order to take in water and to refit they ship the seam of which be all open from this place the general dispatch sancho de toar to discover sofalum with order to make the best of he way from that place to portugal with a account of its production the ship be refit cabral resume the voyage to the cape of good hope near which they again experience a violent storm in which one of the ship be separate from the fleet after firing signal of distress and be never see again during the voyage at length after many great storm and danger which it be tedious to recount cabral double the cape on whitsunday the 22d of may whence continue he voyage with a fair wind he come to anchor at cape verd where he find diego diaz who have separate from the fleet on the outward bind voyage diaz have be drive into the red sea where he winter and lose he boat and as most of he man die from sickness he pilot could not venture to carry he to india he endeavor therefore to find he way back to portugal but after leave the red sea he man be so consume with hunger thirst and sickness that only seven of he crew remain after remain some time at cape verd wait in vain for the miss ship cabral proceed on he voyage and arrive safe at lisbon on the last day of July in the year 1501 soon after he arrival the ship which have separate in a storm off the cape of good hope come in and shortly after that sancho de toar arrive from sofala he describe sofalum as a small island close on the continent of africa inhabit by a black people call caffre and report that much gold be bring to this place from certain mine on the adjacent continent on which account sofalum be much frequent by moor from indium who barter merchandize of small value for gold he bring along with he to lisbon a moor whom he have receive as a hostage or pledge for the safety of one of he own man whom he have leave there to acquire a knowledge of the country and its language and from this moor they get ample information respect the people and trade of those part of africa which i shall afterwards communicate include this last ship there return six to portugal out of the twelve which have sail on the voyage for indium the voyage of john de nueva be the third make by the portuguese to india _ be the same year 1501 suppose all difference to have be settle amicably at calicut by cabral and that a regular trade be establish both there and at sofalum and quiloa the king of portugal dispatch three ship and a caravel from lisbon under the command of john de neuva a native of galicium in spain who be account a valiant gentleman have under he order francisco de navoys diego barboso and hernando de la pyna as captain of three of the ship two ship of this fleet be destine to carry merchandize to sofalum -lrb- 1 -rrb- and the other two to calicut and all the four contain only eighty man -lrb- 2 -rrb- the instruction give to nueva be that he be to touch at the island of st bla where he be to wait ten day if any of he ship have separate he be then to proceed for sofalum where if a factory be settle he be to deliver the goods destine for that place before go to india if a factory be not already settle there he be to do every thing in he power for that purpose leave alvaro de braga there as factor with the merchandize embark in the caravel for that market from sofala he be to proceed to quiloa and thence directly to calicut he be farther direct in case of meeting with cabral to obey he as general and desire he to settle a factory at sofalum if he own attempt should fail nueva leave lisbon on this voyage in march four month before the return of cabral and arrive in safety at the isle of st bla where he find a letter in a old shoe suspend from the branch of a tree write by pedro de tayde -lrb- 3 -rrb- inform he that the fleet of cabral have pass this island on its way back to portugal and give a account of what have happen at calicut of the good treatment the fleet have receive at cochin where some of we man remain and of the friendly disposition of the king of cananor -lrb- 4 -rrb- on consult with the other captain it be judge improper to leave the caravel at sofalum in these circumstance as they whole force do not exceed eighty man wherefore they proceed directly for quiloa where they find one of the exile who have be leave there by cabral from whom they receive a particular account of all that have happen at calicut and of the loss of several of he ship all of which he have learn from some moor from quiloa nueva sail on to melinda where the king confirm the intelligence he have receive from the exile at quiloa -lrb- 5 -rrb- thus fully instruct in the state of matter nueva deem it prudent to keep all the ship of he small squadron and sail across from melinda to anchediva where he come to anchor in November intend to take in a supply of water at that place while here seven large ship belong to cambaya which be bind for the red sea appear off the anchor ground and seem at first disposed to attack we ship but be afraid of the portuguese ordnance they continue they voyage from anchediva nueva proceed for cananor where he have a audience of the rajah from whom he receive particular notice of all that have happen in calicut to cabral and of the offer which the rajah have make to load all he ship at cananor the rajah assure he of he earnest desire of do every thing in he power to serve the king of portugal and press he to take in he load at that port but nueva decline this offer for the present until he have consult with the factor at cochin for which port he take he departure from cananor on he way between cananor and cochin nueva take a ship belong to some of the moorish merchant at calicut after a vigorous resistance and set it on fire on he arrival at cochin the factor who have be leave there by cabral come on board with the rest of he company and acquaint he that the rajah be greatly offend with cabral for leave the port without see he and for carry away the hostage yet have always kindly entertain and the other member of the factory lodge they every night in the palace for security and always send a guard of nayre along with any of they who have occasion to go out during the day on purpose to defend they from the moor who seek they destruction and who have one night set fire to the house in which they lodge before they removal to the palace he also inform nueva that the moor have persuade the native merchant to depreciate the price of the portuguese merchandize and not to take these in exchange for pepper so that unless he have bring money for he purchase he would have little chance of procure a load on this intelligence and consider that he have not bring money nueva immediately return from cochin to cananor expect to procure he load at that port in consequence of the friendly disposition of the rajah towards the king of portugal -lrb- 6 -rrb- on he return to cananor he find that money be as necessary there for he purchase as at cochin : but when the rajah be inform of he difficulty from want of money he become he security to the native merchant for 1000 quintal or hundred weight of pepper 450 quintal of cinnamon and fifty quintal of ginger besides some bale of linen cloth -lrb- 7 -rrb- by this generous conduct of the rajah nueva procure a load for he ship and leave he european merchandize for sale at cananor under the management of a factor and two clerk on the 15th December while wait for a fair wind to begin he homeward voyage the rajah send notice to nueva that eighty _ paraw _ be see to the northward which be past mount _ dely _ and that these vessel be from calicut send expressly to attack the portuguese ship and the rajah advise he to land he man and ordnance for greater security : but the general be not of this mind and send word to the rajah that he hope with the assistance of god to be able to defend himself next day be the 16th of December before dawn about a hundred ship and paraw full of moor come into the bay send on purpose by the zamorin who be in hope to have take all we ship and man as soon as nueva perceive this numerous armament he hoist anchor and remove he squadron to the middle of the bay where he order all he ship to pour in they shoot against the enemy without intermission doubtless but for this the enemy would have board he ship and they be so numerous it would have be impossible for he to have escape but as the moor have no ordnance they could do we people no harm from a distance and many of they ship and paraw be sink with the loss of a vast number of man while they do not dare to approach for the purpose of board and not a single person be kill or hurt on we side the enemy towards evening hang out a flag for a parley but as nueva fear this might be intend as a lure he continue firing lest they might suppose he stop from weariness or fear but the moor be really desirous of peace owe to the prodigious loss they have sustain and they inability to escape from the bay for want of a fair wind at length most of he ordnance be burst or render unserviceable by the long-continued firing and see that the moor still keep up they flag of truce nueva cease firing and answer they by another flag -lrb- 8 -rrb- immediately on this a moor come to neuva in a small boat to demand a cessation of hostility till next day this be grant on condition that they should quit the bay and put out to sea which they do accordingly although the wind be very unfavourable nueva stand out to sea likewise which the enemy could hardly do as they ship and paraw can only make sail with a fair wind notwithstanding all that have happen nueva be constrain to come to anchor close to the fleet of the enemy and give order to keep strict watch during the night at one time they be hear rowing towards we fleet and it be suppose they intend set we ship on fire on which neuva order to veer out more cable to get farther off perceive that the boat of the enemy continue to follow he command a gun to be fire at they on which they make off and the wind come off shore and somewhat fair they make sail for calicut nueva after return thanks to god for deliverance from he enemy take he leave of the rajah of cananor and depart for portugal where he arrive in safety with all he ship -lrb- 9 -rrb- after the departure of nueva from cananor one of he man name gonsalo pixoto who have be make prisoner and carry to calicut come to cananor with a message from the zamorin to nueva make excuse for all that have be do there to cabral and for the attempt against he own fleet at cananor and offering if he would come to calicut to give he a full loading of spice and sufficient hostage both for he safety and the performance of he promise -lrb- 1 -rrb- it afterwards appear that one vessel only be destine for this particular trade : perhaps the second be mean for quiloa -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- accord to astley i 49 the crew of these four vessel distance from the land in the middle of the atlantic ocean -- e section v _ the second voyage of de gama to india in 1502 be the fourth make by the portuguese to the east indy _ as the king of portugal feel it incumbent upon he to revenge the injurious and treacherous conduct of the zamorin he give order to prepare a powerful fleet for that purpose the command of which be at first confide to pedro alvare de cabral but for certain just consideration be take from he and bestow on don vasco de la gama every thing be ready de gama sail from lisbon on the 3d of march 1502 have the command of thirteen great ship and two caravel -lrb- 1 -rrb- the captain of this fleet be pedro alonso de aguilar philip de castro don lewi cotinho franco de conya pedro de tayde vasco carvallo vincente sodre blas sodre the two sodre be cousins-german to the captain-general gil hernand cousin to laureno de la mina juan lope perestrello rodrigo de castaneda and rodrigo de abreo and of the two caravel pedro raphael and diego perez be commander in this powerful squadron they carry out the material of a third caravel which be direct to be put together at mozambique and of which hernand rodrigue badarsa be appoint to be commander besides this first fleet of seventeen sail a smaller squadron of five ship remain in preparation at lisbon which sail on the 5th of may under the command of stephen de la gama -lrb- 2 -rrb- when de gama have double the cape of good hope and be arrive at _ the farther end of the current _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- he go himself with four of the smallest vessel to sofala send on the remainder of the fleet to wait he arrival at mozambique this visit to sofalum be in consequence of order from the king to examine the situation of the city and to endeavor to find a proper situation for a fort that the portuguese might monopolize the trade in gold at that place he remain there twenty-five day during which he settle a treaty of amity with the king and have leave to establish a factory after which mutual present be interchange and de gama depart for mozambique in go out of the river from sofala one of the ship be lose but all the man be save at mozambique he make friendship with the king who have prove so unfriendly in the first voyage and even obtain leave to settle a factor with several assistant who be leave on purpose to provide victuals for such ship as might touch here on the voyage to or from indium here likewise the caravel destine for that purpose be set up and provide with ordnance and a sufficient crew and be leave for the protection of the factory on leave mozambique de gama sail for quiloa have order to reduce the king of that place to become tributary as a punishment for he unfriendly conduct towards cabral on he arrival in that port ibrahim the king come on board to visit the admiral afraid of be call to account for the injury he have do to cabral de gama know that he be not to be trust threaten to make he a prisoner under the hatch if he do not immediately agree to pay tribute to the king of portugal -lrb- 4 -rrb- the king from fear engage to pay 2000 mitical of gold yearly and give one mehemed aleone a principal man among the moor whom he hate as a hostage for the payment the reason of he dislike to meheme be this : ibrahim be himself a usurper have seize the government in prejudice to the right heir and be afraid that mehemed intend to dethrone he when the king find himself at liberty in consequence of this arrangement he refuse to send the promise tribute in hope that de gama might put the hostage to death by which mean he might get rid of he enemy : but the moor on find the tribute do not come be fain to pay the same himself by which mean he procure he own liberty while at quiloa the fleet be join by the squadron of five ship under stephen de gama leave quiloa de gama proceed with the whole fleet for melinda where he take in water and visit the king -lrb- 5 -rrb- go from thence for indium and be arrive off mount dely to the north of cananor he meet a ship belong to the moor of mecca and bind for calicut which be take by we man after a stout resistance -lrb- 6 -rrb- when the ship surrender de gama go on board and command the owner and all the principal moor to come before he whom he order to produce all they goods on pain of be throw overboard they answer that they have nothing to produce as all they goods be in calicut on which de gama order one of they to be bind hand and foot and throw into the sea the rest be intimidate by this procedure and immediately deliver up every thing belong to they which be very valuable all of which be commit to the charge of diego hernando correa the factor appoint for conduct the trade at cochin by whose direction they be transport into one of the portuguese ship de gama order all the child belong to the moor to be take on board one of he own ship and vow to make they all friar in the church of we lady at belem which he afterwards do -lrb- 7 -rrb- all the ordinary merchandize belong to the moor be divide among he own man and when all the goods be remove he order stephen de la gama to confine the moor under the hatch and to set the ship on fire to revenge the death of the portuguese who be slay in the factory at calicut soon after this be do the moor break open the hatch and quench the fire on which the admiral order stephen de gama to lay they aboard the moor render desperate by this inhuman treatment defend themselves to the utmost and even throw firebrand into we ship to set it on fire night come on stephen have to desist but be order to watch the moorish ship carefully that it might not escape during the dark and the moor all night long be hear call on mahomet to deliver they out of the hand of the christian when day appear the admiral again order stephen de la gama to set the ship on fire which he do accordingly after force the moor to retreat into the poop some of the moor leap into the sea with hatchet in they hand and endeavor to swim to we boat but all of these be slay in the water by we people and those that remain in the ship be all drown as the vessel sink of 300 moor of whom thirty be woman not one escape alive and some of we man be hurt de gama come soon afterwards to cananor where he send on shore the ambassador and give they a message for the king inform he of he arrival and craving a audience upon this the rajah order a platform of timber to be construct which project a considerable way into the water cover over with carpet and other rich cloth and have a wooden house or pavilion at the end next the land which be likewise cover like the bridge and be mean for the place of meeting between the rajah and the admiral the rajah come first to the pavilion attend by 10000 nayre and with many trumpet and other instrument play before he and a number of the principal nayre be arrange on the bridge or platform to receive the admiral in a honorable manner the admiral come in he boat attend by all : the boat of the fleet deck out with flag and streamer carry certain ordnance in they prow and have many drum and trumpet make a very martial appearance the admiral disembark at the outer end of the platform under : a general salute from the ordnance of the boat and be accompany by all he captain and a number of man well arm there be carry before he two great basin of silver gilt fill with branch of coral and other fine thing that be esteem valuable in indium the admiral be receive at the head of the platform by the nayre place there on purpose and be conduct to the rajah who wait for he at the door of the pavilion and welcome he with a embrace they then walk together into the pavilion in which two chair be place out of compliment to the admiral on one of which the rajah sit down though contrary to he usual custom and desire the admiral to be seat on the other at this interview a treaty of friendship and commerce be settle and a factory allow to be establish at cananor in consequence of this the admiral give order for some of the ship to load here while other be to do the same at cochin -lrb- 8 -rrb- have settle all thing to he mind at cananor and cochin the admiral proceed with he fleet to the harbor of calicut where he take several paraw in which be about fifty malabar who could not escape but he forbore make any farther hostility against the city till he might see whether or not the zamorin would send he any message soon afterwards there come a boat with a flag to the admiral ship a which be a person in the habit of a franciscan friar who be take at first sight for one of those who have accompany ayre correa and who they suppose have remain a prisoner on enter the ship he salute they say _ deo gratia _ but be immediately recognize as a moor he excuse himself for come in that disguise to secure permission of get on board and say that he bring a message from the zamorin to the admiral about settle a trade in calicut to this the admiral make answer that he would by no means treat on this subject unless the zamorin would previously satisfy he for all the goods which have be seize in the factory when he consent to the death of correa and the rest who be there slay on this subject three day be spend ineffectually in message between the zamorin and the admiral as the moor use every influence to prevent any friendly agreement at length perceive that all these message be only mean to gain time the admiral send notice to the zamorin that he would wait no longer than noon for he final answer and if that be not perfectly satisfactory and in compliance with he just demand he might be assure he would wage cruel war against he with fire and sword and would begin with those of he subject who be now prisoner in he hand and that the zamorin might not think these be only word of course he call for a hour-glass which he set down in presence of the moorish messenger say that as soon as the sand have run out a certain number of time he would infallibly put in execution all that he have threaten all this however could not induce the zamorin to perform he promise for he be of a inconstant and waver disposition and influence by the counsel of the moor the outward shew he have make of peace be only feigned or occasion by the fear he have of see so great a fleet in he port from which he dread to sustain great injury but the moor have now persuade he into a contrary opinion and have prevail on he to break he word when the time appoint by the admiral be expire he order a gun to be fire as a signal to the captain of he ship to hang up the poor malabar prisoner who have be distribute through the fleet after they be dead he order they hand and foot to be cut off and send on shore in a paraw accompany by two boat well arm and place a letter in the paraw for the zamorin write in arabic in which he signify that he propose to reward he in this manner for he deceitful conduct and repeat breach of faith and in regard to the goods belong to the king of portugal which he detain he would recover they a hundred fold -lrb- 9 -rrb- after this the admiral order three of he ship to be warped during the night as near as possible to the shore and that these should fire next day incessantly on the city with all they cannon by which vast injury be do and the royal palace be entirely demolish besides several other house belong to the principal inhabitant of the place the admiral afterwards depart for cochin leave vincente sodre with six well armed ship to command the coast who be to remain in indium when the rest of the fleet return to portugal and be likewise direct to go upon a voyage of discovery to the strait of mecca and the coast of cambaya -lrb- 10 -rrb- from calicut the admiral sail for cochin and immediately on he anchoring in that port the rajah -lrb- 11 -rrb- send on board certain hostage to remain as he surety and when the admiral land the rajah go in person to meet he at this interview the rajah deliver up to the admiral stephen gyl and other who have remain in he country and the admiral present a letter from the king of portugal to the rajah return thanks for the kindness he have shew to cabral and declare he satisfaction at the settlement of a factory for trade at cochin the admiral also deliver a present from the king of portugal to the rajah consist of a rich golden crown set with jewel a gold enamelled collar two richly work silver fountain two piece of figure arras a splendid tent or pavilion a piece of crimson satin and another of sendal -lrb- 12 -rrb- all of which the rajah accept with much satisfaction yet not know the use of some of these thing the admiral endeavor to explain they and particularly order the pavilion to be set up to shew its use under which a new treaty of amity be settle the rajah appoint a house for the use of the portuguese factory and a schedule of price be agree upon at which the various spice drug and other production of the country be to be deliver to the portuguese factor all of which be set down in write in form of a contract the rajah likewise deliver present for the king of portugal consist of two gold bracelet set with precious stone a sash or turban use by the moor of cloth of silver two yard and a half long two great piece of fine bengal cotton cloth and a stone as large as a walnut take from the head of a animal call _ bulgoldolf _ which be exceedingly rare and be say to be a antidote against all kipd of poison -lrb- 13 -rrb- a convenient house be appoint for a factory be immediately take possession of by diego would return to calicut to make a complete restitution of every thing that have be take from the portuguese and that a treaty of friendship and commerce would be immediately arrange between they after consider this message the admiral order the messenger to prison meaning to take revenge on he in case the zamorin should prove deceitful in this instance as he have already be in many other -lrb- 14 -rrb- after this precaution he go to calicut more for the purpose of endeavor to recover the merchandize than from any expectation of procure the friendship of the zamorin for this reason he take only he own ship -lrb- 15 -rrb- leave stephen de gama in the command at cochin in he absence the captain of the fleet be much averse to this rashness yet could not persuade he to take a larger force as he of the zamorin to be hang -lrb- 16 -rrb- the failure of this treacherous attempt against de gama give much concern to the zamorin who now resolve to try if he could induce the rajah of cochin to have admit into you city and supply with goods and provision it be possible you may not see the danger of this procedure and may not know how displease it be to I i request of you to remember the nation my desire be therefore that for the future you may neither receive they into you city nor give they spice by which you will both do I a great pleasure and will bind I to requite you friendship in whatever way you may desire i do not more earnestly urge these thing at the present be convince you will comply without further entreaty as i would do for you in any matter of importance the rajah of cochin answer in the follow term : that he know not how to expel the christian from he city whom he have receive as friend and to whom he have pass he word for trade and amity he deny that he friendly reception of the christian could be construe as any offence to the zamorin as it be the custom in the port of malabar to favor all merchant who resort thither for trade and declare he resolution to maintain he engagement inviolate to the portuguese who have bring great sum of gold and silver and large quantity of merchandize into he dominion in the course of they trade the zamorin to be move either by the persuasion or threaten of the zamorin and send a reply to he second letter in which he declare he should never be induce to commit a base or treacherous action by fear of the consequence and be resolve to persist in maintain he treaty of trade and amity with the portuguese finding that he could not prevail on the rajah of cochin to concur with he he command twenty-nine large ship to be fit out in order to assail the portuguese fleet when on its return homewards expect that he should be able to destroy they with more ease when fully laden the rajah of cochin give no condition the admiral engage on behalf of the king of portugal to defend the rajah in all war that might arise from this agreement conditioning for peace and friendship between the raja of cochin and sodre to protect the coast with he squadron till the month of February and if any war should break out or seem probable between the zamorin and trimumpara he be to winter in cochin for the protection of that city otherwise he be to sail for the strait of the red sea to make prize of all the ship belong to mecca that trade to the indy all these matter be properly arrange de gama depart from cananor for portugal on the 20th December 1502 -lrb- 19 -rrb- with thirteen ship richly laden three of which have take in they cargo at cananor and the other ten at cochin the whole fleet arrive in safety at
