or oceanic coast of yeman -- e section viii _ transaction of the portuguese in indium under duarte pacheco from the departure of alonso and francisco de albuquerque in January 1504 till the arrival of lope suarez de menesis with succor in September of that year _ after the departure of the albuquerque from cananor duarte pacheco who be leave with the command in indium remain there for some time to take in provision have along with he the caravel command by pedro raphael while the other ship of he small squadron under the command of diego perez be repair at cochin pacheco anchor with he own ship off the harbor of cananor and dispatch raphael along the coast to oblige all ship which pass that way to come to cananor in acknowledgment of pacheco as captain-general in the indy several be bring in by raphael and be constrain to give a full account from whence they come whither bind and what they be laden with in case of they contain any pepper more especially if bind for calicut he use to take that commodity from they and carry he command with so high a hand that he become the terror of these sea one night while thus at anchor a fleet of twenty-five ship come suddenly to the anchoring-ground where he lay which he suspect to have be send from calicut on purpose to attack he consider himself in imminent danger he immediately slip he cable not have time to weigh anchor and make sail to gain the windward of this fleet upon which he directly commence firing they be mostly small ship laden with rice and make off with all the haste in they power though some of they run aground one of the vessel of this fleet be a large ship belong to the moor of cananor have nearly 400 man on board who resist for some time shoot off they arrow and even endeavor to take we ship when day be near at hand and after have nine man slay in the action the moorish captain at length submit and tell pacheco that he belong to cananor after some time spend in this manner pacheco make sail for cochin and in the passage fall in with several ship belong to the moor take some and burn or sink other on landing at the fort of cochin he learn from the factor that the report of the zamorin make preparation for the renewal of the war be perfectly true and even that the moorish inhabitant of cochin be adverse to the rajah for have take part with the portuguese against the zamorin be inform likewise that the cochin rajah be in great fear of this new war he go next day to visit he carry all he boat well man and fence with raise side of board to defend he man from the missile weapon of the enemy they be likewise furnish with ordnance and all decorate with flag and streamer in a gallant manner hope thereby to inspire confidence in trimumpara who be much deject at the small force which have be leave for he defense in a conference between they the rajah say to pacheco that the moor assert he be leave in the indy for the sole purpose of remove the merchandize belong to the portuguese in the factory at cochin to cananor and coulan and not to defend he against the power of the zamorin which he be even dispose to think be true in consideration of the smallness of the fleet under he command pacheco feel indignant at the suspicion which the rajah entertain and endeavor to convince he that he have be impose upon by the moor out of enmity to the portuguese assure he that he would faithfully exert himself in he defense he point out to he the strength of the natural defence of cochin which be all narrow and defensible therefore by a few valiant man against any number of assailant the rajah be greatly relieve by these assurance and pacheco go to visit the different place by which the island of cochin might be assail all of which he diligently fortify more especially the ford which he strengthen with a row of stake both to prevent the enemy from wade across and to hinder any of they vessel from pass in the mean time he be inform by letter from rodrigo reynel that a principal moor in cochin in concert with several other be contrive to quit that city and have be twice secretly at calicut to confer with the zamorin on this subject pacheco be a good deal concern at this intelligence and propose to the rajah to have this moor execute for he treasonable intercourse with the zamorin but trimumpara would by no means consent to this measure say that it would occasion a mutiny among the moor by whom the city be furnish with provision in exchange for goods and be think it be better to dissemble with they all pacheco then say that he would have a conference with the moor mean to use policy with they since the rajah do not approve of violent measure and to this the rajah consent give order to he naire to obey the order of pacheco in pursuance of this plan pacheco go to the dwelling of this chief moor name _ belinamacar _ close by the river take with he a guard of he own man well armed and request that person to send for some other lead man among the moor whom he name say that he wish to consult with they on a subject of great importance to they all when they be all assemble he make they a speech to the following effect i send for you honest merchant that i might inform you for what purpose i remain in the indy it be report by some that i mean only to remove the factory and the goods belong to the portuguese to coulan and cananor : but my sole purpose be to defend cochin against the zamorin and even if necessary i will die in you defense i be resolve to meet he in cambalan by which way it be say he mean to invade you and if he have the boldness to meet I i hope to make he prisoner and to carry he with I into portugal i be inform that you intend to go away from cochin and to induce the rest of the inhabitant among whom you be the chief to do the same but i be astonished man of you wisdom should leave the country in which you be bear and where you have dwell so many year from fear of vain report such conduct be even disgraceful for woman and be therefore much more so for you who be man of wisdom and experience if you should be dispose to remove from hence when you shall actually be in danger i should hardly blame you : but to do so before that danger be apparent and even before a single battle have be fight must proceed either from cowardice or treachery you all well know that only a very short while ago a very small number of we portuguese defeat thousand of those same enemy who now threaten to invade we you may allege that we be then more in number than now which be assuredly the case but we then fight in the open field where number be necessary and we now propose only to fight in narrow pass in which a small number will suffice as well as a multitude you already know that i can fight as it be i who have do the greatest injury to the enemy in the late war which the rajah can well vouch as for I i shall never yield and i have more to lose be overcome than any of you put you trust therefore in I and my troops and remain where you be till you see the event of we defense you sovereign remains in he port and wherefore should you go away i and the portuguese who be with I remain in this far distant country to defend you king and you who be he natural bear subject : should you then desert he and you country you would disgrace yourselve and dishonor I by refuse to repose confidence in my promise to defend you against the zamorin and all he power be it even greater than it be wherefore i strictly enjoin that none of you shall remove from cochin and i swear by all that be holy in we faith that whoever be detect in the attempt shall be instantly hang it be my determine purpose to remain here and to have the port strictly watch day and night that none of you may escape let every one of you therefore look well to he conduct and be assure if you do as i require you shall have I for you friend but if otherwise i shall be you mortal enemy and shall use you worse even than the zamorin the moor endeavor to clear themselves from what have be allege against they but pacheco would not listen to they excuse and depart from they in anger and immediately bring he ship and one of the caravel with two boat which he anchor directly opposite the city of cochin with strict charge to let no one leave the city by water he likewise appoint a number of paraw to guard all the creek and river around the city and order every boat that could transport man or goods to be bring every night under the gun of he ship and return to they owner in the morning in consequence of all these precaution the people of cochin be so much afraid of he that not one of the moor or malabar dare to leave the city without he permission and henceforward continue quiet notwithstanding all these care pacheco use to make nightly invasion into the island of repelim where he burn the town slew the inhabitant and carry away much cattle and many paraw on which account the moor of cochin astonish that he could endure so much fatigue give out that he be the devil mean time the zamorin collect he force in the island of repelim where he be join by the lord of tanor bespur kotugan korin and many other malabar chief make altogether a army of 50000 man four thousand of these be appoint to serve by water in 280 vessel call _ paraw _ _ katur _ and _ tony _ with 382 piece of cannon intend to batter the portuguese fort at cochin and the rest of the troops be appoint to force a passage across the ford of the river under the command of naubea daring nephew and heir to the zamorin and elankol the lord of repelim -lrb- 1 -rrb- intelligence of all this be convey to cochin and that the zamorin propose to invade that city by the strait of cambalan rodrigo reynel who send this intelligence by letter lay then very sick and die soon after on which the zamorin cause all he goods to be seize on the approach of the zamorin the moor of cochin would very willingly have induce the inhabitant to run away but dare not venture to do so from the fear they be in of pacheco he on the contrary that all might know how little he esteem the zamorin and all he power make a descent one night on one of the town of repelim to which he set fire but on the come up of a great number of armed naire he be force to retreat in great danger to he boat have five of he man wound after kill and wound a great number of the enemy on they return to cochin the target of we man be all stick full of arrow so great be the multitude of the enemy who have assail they the rajah come to visit pacheco at the castle on he return from this enterprize and express he satisfaction at he success which he consider as a mighty affair especially as the zamorin and so great a army be in the island pacheco make light of the zamorin and all he force say that he anxiously wish he would come and give battle as he be not at all afraid of the consequence trust to the superior valor of he own man as the people of cochin remain quiet pacheco now prepare for defend the pass of cambalan leave therefore a sufficient force to guard the castle and twenty-five man in the caravel under the command of diego pereira to protect the city and watch the conduct of the moor take with himself seventy-three man in one of the caravel and several armed boat he depart for cambalan on Friday the 16th of April 1504 -lrb- 2 -rrb- on pass the city pacheco land to speak with the rajah whom he find in evident anxiety but make as if he do not observe he heaviness pacheco address he with a cheerful countenance say that he be just set out to defend he against the zamorin of whom he have no fear of give a good account after some conference the rajah order 500 of he naire out of 3000 who be in he service to join pacheco under the command of _ gandagora _ and _ frangera _ the overseer of he household and the caymal of _ palurta _ whom he direct to obey pacheco in all thing as if he be himself present on take leave of pacheco while he exhort he to use he utmost effort for defend cochin against the zamorin he desire he to be careful of he own safety on which so much depend pacheco arrive at the passage of cambalan two hour before day and see no appearance of the zamorin approach he make a attack on a town on the coast of the island about the dawn which be defend by 300 naire all archer and a small number arm with caliver or match-lock all of whom be embark in certain paraw and endeavor to defend the entrance of the harbor they be soon constrain by the cannon of the portuguese to push for the shore and quit they paraw but resist all attempt of the portuguese to land for near a hour when they be completely defeat after lose a great many of they number kill or wound and we man set the town on fire have take a considerable number of cattle at this place which he carry off with he pacheco return to defend the pass of cambalan at this time the zamorin send a message to pacheco offering he a handsome present and propose a treaty for a peace between they : but pacheco refuse accept the present and declare he would never make peace with he while he continue at enmity with the rajah of cochin next day the zamorin send a second message proudly challenge he for daring to obstruct he passage into the island of cochin and offer he battle declare he resolution to make he a prisoner if he be not slay in the battle to this pacheco make answer that he hope to do the same thing with the zamorin in honor of the day which be a solemn festival among the christian and that the zamorin be much deceive by he sorcerer when they promise he the victory on such a day then one of the naire who accompany the messenger say smile as if in contempt that he have few man to perform so great a exploit whereas the force of the zamorin cover both the land and the water and could not possibly be overcome by such a handful pacheco order this man to be well bastinado for he insolence and bid he desire the zamorin to revenge he quarrel if he could that same evening the rajah of cochin send a farther reinforcement to pacheco of 500 naire of whom he make no account neither of these who be with he before believe they would all run away he sole reliance under god be on he own man who feast themselves that night that the zamorin might learn how much they despise all he threat and how eager they be for battle early next morning pacheco make a short speech to he man exhort they to behave valiantly for the glory of the christian name and the honor of they country and promise they a assure victory with the assistance of god by which they fame would be so established among the native that they would be fear and respect ever after he likewise set before they the reward they might assuredly expect from they own sovereign if they behave gallantly on the present occasion he man immediately answer he that they hope in the ensue battle to evince how well they remember he exhortation they all then kneel down and sing the _ salve regina _ and afterwards a _ ave marium _ with a loud voice just at this time laureno moreno join pacheco with four of he man arm with caliver who be all anxious to be present in the battle and of whose arrival the general be extremely glad as he know they to be valiant soldier in the course of the night by the advice of the italian lapidary who have desert to the enemy the zamorin cause a sconce or battery to be erect directly over against the place where pacheco be station on which five piece of ordnance be place from which great service be expect in the ensue battle owe to the narrowness of the pass on the morning of palm Sunday the zamorin march forwards with 47000 man partly naire and part moor and accompany by all the raja and caymal who have join he in this war of these the rajah of _ tanor _ have 4000 naire the raja of _ bybur _ and _ curran _ whose country lay near the mountain of narsinga have 12000 naire the rajah of _ cotogataco _ which be between cochin and cananor close beside the mountain have 18000 naire the rajah of _ curia _ which be between panianus and cranganor have 3000 naire naubea daring the prince of calicut and he brother namboa who be particularly attach to that part of the army compose of the zamorin immediate subject have a large body of man whose number i do not particularize they warlike instrument be many and of diver sort and make a noise as if heaven and earth be come together before day the van of this prodigious army arrive at the sconce of the italian and begin immediately to play off they ordnance against the caravel which be so near that it be a absolute miracle that not a single shot do any harm but we cannon be better serve and every shot do execution among the enemy : and so well do they ply they gun that before sunrise above thirty discharge be make from we caravel at day-break the whole of the enemy fleet consist of 169 bark come out of the river of the island of repelim to attack we small force sixty-six of these be paraw have they side defend with bag of cotton by advice of the italian to ward off we shot and each of these have twenty-five man and two piece of ordnance five of the man in each paraw be arm with caliver or matchlock twenty of the foyst or large bark be chained together as a float battery to assault the caravel besides which there be fifty-three _ cature _ and thirty large bark each of which carry sixteen man and one piece of ordnance besides other weapon besides all these armed vessel there be a great many more fill with soldier so that the whole river seem entirely cover over of this numerous fleet which contain near 10 000 man naubea daring be admiral or commander in chief and the lord of repelim vice-admiral all these advance against the portuguese set up terrible shout which be answer alternately by sound all they military instrument of music the whole of these people be almost naked have target of various color and make a very gallant appearance on the approach of this prodigious fleet we caravel and boat be hardly discernible so completely do the enemy cover the face of the water terrify by so prodigious a multitude the naire of cochin all run away only grandagora and frangora remain who be on board the caravel or they would have do like the rest indeed they presence be of no importance except to serve as witness of the valor of we man we people ply they ordnance and small arm so incessantly that the air be quite darken with smoke and as the boat of the enemy be very numerous and without order they hinder each other and we fire do prodigious execution among they several of they paraw be tear to piece and great number of they man kill and wound without any hurt on we side the twenty-five paraw -lrb- 3 -rrb- which be chained together be now bring forwards and give much annoyance to we man who be now likewise much fatigue as the battle have continue a long time the captain-general give order to fire off a _ saker _ -lrb- 4 -rrb- which have not be hitherto use during the battle by the time this have be twice fire it do such terrible execution among the thick of the enemy as to sink four of they paraw and all the other make the best of they way out of the battle eighteen of the paraw be sink in all and vast number of the enemy slay and wound on the defeat of this squadron which be command by prince naubea daring elankol the lord of repelim who be vice-admiral come forward with a fresh squadron and give a proud onset command he paraw to lay the caravel on board but the malabar have not resolution to put this order into execution and hold off at some distance the zamorin also approach with the land army do he utmost to force the passage of the ford but all they effort be in vain although this second battle be more fiercely urge than the first though the battle continue from daybreak to almost sunset the enemy be able to make no impression and be know to have lose 350 man slay outright besides other which be above 1000 -lrb- 5 -rrb- some of we man be wound but none slay for the ball of the enemy though of cast iron have no more effect than as many stone throw by hand yet we barricade of defense be all tear to piece and one of we boat be very much damage which be entirely repair during the night the raja and other chief who be ally with the zamorin lose all hope of ever be able to get the victory over the portuguese and be sorry for have join in the war so greatly to they own dishonor be afraid the captain-general might burn and destroy they town and house which be all situate on the bank of river they be anxious to leave the army of the zamorin and to give over make war on the portuguese some among they withdraw privately from the camp of the zamorin to the island of vaipus with all they man and reconcile themselves with the rajah of cochin : these be _ maraguta muta _ caymal he brother and cousin the zamorin be exceedingly mortified by the discomfiture of he people and severely reprimand he chief for they pusillanimous conduct in allow themselves to be defeat by such a handful of man the two italian deserter while they acknowledge the valor of the portuguese in the late action represent that it would be impossible for they to continue to bear up long against such vast odds without reinforcement and recommend the frequent reiteration of assault under which they must necessarily be at last overthrow all those raja and chief who be for continue the war join in opinion with the italian the zamorin make a speech in which he recapitulate the defeat they have sustain and the defection of some of he ally who have enter into treaty with the rajah of cochin he state how short a period of the summer now remain for continue the operation of the war which must soon be lay aside during the storm and rain of the winter season when it be impossible to keep the field and that on the conclusion of winter a new fleet would come from portugal with powerful reinforcement to the enemy who would then be able to carry the war as formerly into he dominion to they utter loss and destruction he conclude by give he opinion that it be necessary for he to make peace with the christian naubea daring the prince of calicut make a long speech in which he defend the portuguese against the imputation throw upon they by the moor of they be thief and pirate he recapitulate all they conduct since they first arrival in indium show that they have always conduct themselves with good faith whereas they have be force into war against calicut by treachery and oppression he conclude by strongly recommend to negotiate peace with the christian as otherwise the city and trade of calicut would be utterly destroy to the irreparable injury of the zamorin revenue which be of more importance to he than the friendship of the moor whose only object be they own profit the zamorin be greatly move by this discourse and recommend to the other chief that they should concur with the prince in procure the establishment of peace this opinion be by no means relish by elankol the lord of repelim who have confederate with the moor to urge a continuance of the war and endeavor to impress upon the zamorin that he reputation would be destroy by propose peace at this time which would be imputed to he as a act of cowardice the principal moor likewise who be present in the council use all they art and influence to induce the zamorin to persevere and it be at length determine to continue the war one _ cogeal _ a moor of repelim who have be a great traveller and have see many warlike device propose a new invention for attack the caravel at the ford which be consider to be perfectly irresistible cogeal direct a float castle to be build of timber on two boat or lighter which be firmly secure by two beam at they head and stern over this the castle or square tower be strongly build of beam join together by bar of iron and large nail carry up to the height of a lance or spear and so large that it be able to contain forty man with several piece of ordnance it be propose that this castle should be bring up to grapple with the caravel by which the portuguese might be attack on equal term on see this machine the zamorin liberally reward cogeal for he ingenuity and give order to have other seven construct of the same kind by means of he spy pacheco get notice of the construction of these float castle and likewise that the enemy be prepare certain firework to set the caravel on fire -lrb- 6 -rrb- to keep off the fireship and float castle he construct a species of raft make of mast or spar eight fathom long and bind together with iron bolt and hoop several of these which be likewise eight fathom broad be moor with anchor and cable at the distance of a stone throw from the caravel likewise to prevent the caravel from be overlook by the float castle one peter raphael build certain turret on the deck of the caravel of spar set upright in each of which seven or eight man have room to handle they arm at this time the rajah of cochin visit pacheco whom he earnestly exhort to provide well for defense against the zamorin as he be well assure he own subject would desert he if pacheco be defeat pacheco upbraid trimumpara for he tear desire he to call in mind the victory which the portuguese have already gain over the enemy and request of he to return to he capital show himself confident among he people and to rest assure that he and the portuguese would keep the pass against every force the zamorin might bring against it in expectation of a immediate attack lorenco moreno return to the caravel with as many of he people as could be spare from the factory pacheco make all he people take rest early in the night that they might be able for the expect fatigue of the ensue day on which he have intelligence that the grand attack be to be make about midnight he small force be summon under arm when after confession and absolution he make a speech to he man exhort they to behave themselves manfully in the approach conflict they all answer that they be resolve to conquer or die about two in the morning some of the most advanced vessel belong to the calicut fleet begin to fire off they ordnance as they approach towards the pass the zamorin be himself along with the land army which exceed 30000 man accompany with many field piece elankol the lord of repelim who command the vanguard advance to the point of _ arraul _ which in some measure command the ford at which place he begin to throw up some rampart or defence of earth pacheco land secretly at the point with a detachment of he troops on purpose to prevent the enemy from throw up entrenchment and a sharp skirmish ensue in which many of the enemy be slay on the appearance of day pacheco retire to he boat though with no small difficulty owe to the vast number of the enemy who throng around yet get off with all he people unhurt have effectually hinder the propose intrenchment the land army of the enemy now bring they ordnance to the point where they begin a furious cannonade upon the caravel yet without do we any harm as we people be all effectually secure by means of high wooden defence on the gunwale of they vessel whereas every shot of ours make prodigious havoc among the enemy who be quite unsheltered the zamorin send order to he fleet to come on with all expedition to deliver he and he man from this imminent danger the calicut fleet now approach in most formidable order have several fire raft in front intend for set we caravel on fire after they come 110 paraw full of man and every one of they have ordnance many of these be fasten together by means of chain after these come 100 _ cature _ and eighty _ tony _ each of which have a piece of ordnance and thirty man in the rear of all come the eight castle which keep close by the point of _ arraul _ as the _ ebb be not yet altogether enter _ -lrb- 7 -rrb- the enemy come on with loud shout and the sound of many instrument as if to a assure victory and immediately begin a furious cannonade they fire raft advance burning in a most alarming manner but be stop by the _ canizo _ or raft of defense formerly mention by these likewise the paraw and other vessel of the enemy be prevent from close with we caravel and boat which they seem to have intend in this part of the battle many of the paraw and other vessel of the enemy be tear to piece and sink and a great number of they man be kill and wound on the turn of the tide the float castle put off from the point and be tow by boat towards the caravel in the largest of these castle there be forty man in other thirty-five and the smallest have thirty all arm with bow or matchlock besides ordnance and they seem quite a irresistible force in comparison of ours which consist only of two caravel and two armed boat when the largest castle come up to we float defense it immediately commence a tremendous fire of all its ordnance upon we caravel and at this time pacheco order a _ saker _ to be shoot off which seem to do very little harm even at a second discharge the remainder of the castle now come into they station and the battle rage with the utmost fury what with incessant flight of arrow and the smoke of so many gun we people could seldom see the vessel of the enemy in this extremity the saker be discharge a third time against the largest castle which have be somewhat shake by the two former discharge by this shot its iron work be break some of its beam be force from they place and several of the man on board be slay by two other discharge of the saker this castle be all tear in piece and be force to retire out of the battle still however the rest of the castle and the numerous fleet of small craft keep up the fight towards evening all the castle be much injure many of the paraw be sink and tear in piece and great number of the enemy slay so that at length they be constrain to retire on we side not one man be even wound : one only ball go through the caravel in which pacheco command and pass among many of he man without do any hurt on the enemy retire pacheco give chase in the two boat and some paraw and the caravel keep up a constant fire upon point _ arraul _ whence they force the zamorin and the land army to retire after have 330 of he man slay after this great victory the inhabitant of cochin become quite reassure and be no longer in dread of the power of the zamorin trimumpara come to visit pacheco whom he embrace and congratulate on he great prowess : many of the principal naire of cochin go to compliment he and even number of the moorish merchant bring he rich present hope to secure he favor the zamorin be greatly dishearten by the overthrow of all he mighty preparation and lose all hope of victory wish seriously to end the war in a council of he ally and great man they represent the great loss they have already endure in the war with the portuguese and propose to treat with they for peace he brother naubea daring who have always be averse to the war seem to believe that pacheco would refuse any treaty and advise rather to defer make a offer of peace till the arrival of the next captain-general from portugal this prince be likewise of opinion that the calicut army should still keep the field till the come on of the rainy season make it advisable to retire as it would look like flight to retreat at this time yet he recommend that no more attack should be make on the pass in which attempt they have already meet with so much loss elankol the lord of repelim urge the continuance of the war and to make reiterate assault on the christian which must be at last successful by which mean all the portuguese that be in cochin cananor and coulan would be destroy he advise likewise to send false intelligence to these place say that they have take we caravel and slay all we man on which news the people of cananor and coulan would put the people in we factory to death this be accordingly do but as the inhabitant of these place have already receive notice of the real state of affair they give no credit to this false story yet owe to the malice of the moor who dwell in these place we man be in great danger and durst not come out of they factory and one of we man be slay in coulan by the persuasion of elankol and the moor the zamorin reluctantly consent to try the event of another battle : and the castle be repair a fresh assault be make both by land and water with many more man and vessel than before this battle continue longer than the other and the enemy be overthrow with far greater loss than they have ever receive before in consequence of this new victory the inhabitant of cochin become quite confident in they security from the power of they enemy and the rajah who have hitherto be in much dread of the event become quite elated he now come to visit pacheco in a chair of state with far more splendor than he have ever assume since the commencement of the war when this be tell in the enemy camp the chief urge the zamorin to a fresh attack lest the rajah of cochin might hold he in contempt he desire they to cease they evil counsel from which he have already sustained great loss and which would still lead he into greater danger but to leave he to consider what be best to be do for revenge against he enemy the zamorin give order to some of he naire in whom he repose great confidence that they should go to cochin on some false pretence and endeavor to assassinate the general of the portuguese and such of he man as they could meet with but the naire be a inconsiderate people unable to keep any of they affair secret so that this shameful device become immediately know to pacheco who appoint two company of the cochin naire to keep strict watch for these _ spy _ one company at the ford and the other along the river wait by turn day and night by this mean these _ spy _ be detect and make prisoner the chief _ spy _ be a naire of cochin of the family or stock of the _ lecro _ who have certain other naire attend upon he who be stranger on be bring before he he order they to be all cruelly whipt and then to be hang the cochin naire remonstrate against this punishment because they be naire whose custom do not allow of this mode of execution but he would not listen to they argument say that they treachery richly merit to be so punish the portuguese officer represent to he the great trouble which the _ rajah _ of cochin have endure for give protection to they nation and how much this action might displease he when he be inform of naire have be put to death in he dominion without he authority besides that this might give occasion to some of those about the rajah who be know to be already unfriendly to the portuguese to insinuate that the captain - general have usurp the authority from the rajah and might in that way wean he affection from they pacheco be convince by these argument that he have act wrong and immediately send to countermand the execution two of they be already _ half-dead _ but _ those who be still live _ he send to the rajah inform he that they have deserve death but that from respect to he he have spare they life the rajah be singularly gratify by this mark of respect and the more so because there happen to be then present several of he principal noble and some chief from other place besides sundry of the chief of the moor of cochin who have endeavor to impress on he mind that the portuguese be willing to assume the command in he dominion -lrb- 8 -rrb- henceforward pacheco have such good intelligence that all the subtle device of the zamorin be counteract the month of June be now end and the rainy season or winter begin to come on from which pacheco naturally conclude that the zomorin would soon break up he encampment on which occasion he be fully resolve to give they a assault have sufficient experience of the pusillanimity of the enemy but the zamorin be afraid that pacheco might attack he at he departure give out that he intend to make another assault on the ford with a greater fleet than ever and even direct the float castle to be repair he even give out that he mean to assail the passage of _ palurte _ and the ford both at once that pacheco might occupy himself in prepare to defend both place and he might have the better opportunity to steal away unperceived accordingly on the evening of Saturday which be the eve of st john -lrb- 9 -rrb- the whole army of the enemy appear as usual and pacheco fully expect to have be attack that night next morning however he learn from two bramin that the zamorin have withdraw with all he army into the island of repelim pacheco be much disappointed at this news yet he make a descent that very day into repelim where he fight with many of the enemy killing and wound a great number of they and then return to the ford where he remain several day because the rajah be still afraid lest the zamorin might return and get across the ford into the island of cochin the zamorin be so crest-fallen by the great and repeated loss he have sustain in this war from a mere handful of man that he resolve to retire into religion seclusion that he might conciliate the favor of he god and dismiss he ally and chief to act as they think best he prince and noble endeavor to dissuade he from this resolution but he continue firm to he purpose and go into the _ torcul _ or religious state of seclusion accompany by some of he chief bramin or chaplain soon afterwards he mother send he word that great change have take place in calicut since he seclusion that many of the merchant have already desert the place and other be prepare to follow that the city be become ill provide with victuals as those who use to import they be afraid of the christian yet she advise he never to return to calicut unless he could do so with honor and that he should therefore continue in seclusion for a time and afterwards endeavor to recover he credit and reputation by victory or lose all in the attempt on this message which greatly increase he discontent the zamorin send for he brother to whom he confide the government of he dominion till such time as he should have complete he religious austerity in seclusion on this strange resolution of the zamorin the raja and noble who have join he in the war depart to they own country most of which lay on the coast and be under great apprehension that pacheco might reduce they dominion they endeavor to enter into treaty with he for peace and concord for which purpose they send message to trimumpara request that he would act as mediator between they and pacheco the rajah of cochin be a prince of a mild and forgiving disposition and forget all the past injury they have do he in these war he undertake the office of mediation and send they safe conduct to come to cochin to make they peace on they arrival he accompany they to wait upon pacheco and even become they advocate with he to accept of they profer friendship which he readily consent to at the desire of the rajah some of these prince be unable to come personally but send they ambassador to solicit peace which be accord to all who ask it several even of the great moorish merchant of calicut that they might quietly enjoy they trade forsake that place and come to dwell in cochin have previously secure the consent of pacheco other of they go to cananor and coulan by which mean the great trade which use to be carry on at calicut suddenly fall off owe to the great resort of moor to cochin in whom pacheco could not repose much confidence and because by the order of naubea daring the paraw of calicut frequently make excursion into the river the captain - general continue for a long while to defend the passage of the ford where he often fight with and do much injury to he enemy he make frequent incursion likewise into the island of repelim whence he carry off cattle and other provision and often fight with he enemy always defeat they with much slaughter -lrb- 10 -rrb- at length elankol the lord of that island wish to put a end to the misery of he country wait on first operation of the new commander-in-chief in indium be to cannonade calicut -- e section ix _ the voyage of lope suarez de menesis to indium in 1504 be the sixth of the portuguese expedition to the east indy _ learn the necessity of send powerful succor to protect the portuguese trade from the hostility of the zamorin the king of portugal fit out a fleet of twelve -lrb- 1 -rrb- large ship in 1504 of which the command be give to lope suarez de menesis who have be captain of the _ mina _ on the coast of guinea in the reign of john ii the captain of these ship be pedro de mendoza lionel cotinho tristan de la silva lope mendez de vasconcelles lope de abreu philip de castro alonso lopez de castro alonzo lopez de la cocta pero alonzo de aguilar vasco de la silvero vasco carvallo and pedro dynez de sutunell : all of whom be gentleman by birth or service have embark many valiant soldier the whole fleet leave lisbon on the 22d of April and arrive on the 2d of may near cape verd have observe during this part of the voyage that several of the ship be very irregularly navigate not keep in they proper course by which they have run foul of each other some push before while other lag behind and other stand athwart the order of the fleet suarez convene a assemblage of all the captain master and pilot of the fleet to whom he communicate the follow write instruction : 1 as soon as it be night every ship shall keep in regular order a-stern of the admiral and no vessel to carry any light except in the binnacle and in the cabin 2 the master and pilot to keep regular watch take special care not to run foul of each other 3 all to answer the signal of the admiral 4 as soon as day appear every ship shall come to salute the admiral and all be carefully to avoid get before he during the night the penalty for breach of any of these article be a fine of ten crown besides which the offender be to be put under arrest without be entitle to wages and so to remain to the end of the voyage as some of the master and pilot have be very negligent allow some of the ship to fall aboard of other he remove these to other ship by this attention to discipline the fleet be keep afterwards in good sailing order in the month of June at which time they reckon themselves off the cape of good hope the fleet be surprise by a heavy storm and have to drive for two day and night under bare pole in imminent danger of be cast away the weather during all this time be wonderfully dark so that the ship be in great hazard of run aboard of each other to guard against this danger the admiral cause gun to be fire at interval from all the ship to give notice of they situation and the better to keep company on the subsidence of the storm the ship command by lope mendez be miss and the admiral cause the fleet to lie to for some day in hope of she reappearance while in this situation two of the ship run foul of each other by which a large hole be break in the bow of one of the ship through which she take in so much water as to be in great danger of sulk the admiral immediately bear up to she assistance and encourage the crew to stop the leak and even send he boat on board to give every aid by great exertion they get the leak effectually stop by nail hide over the hole and cover the whole with pitch on st jamese day 25th July the fleet arrive at mozambique where they be well receive by the governor who supply they abundantly with fresh provision and send off the letter which pedro de tayde have write respect the state of affair in indium a short time before he death as formerly mention the admiral expedite the refit of the ship which have be so much injure as quickly as possible and depart from mozambique on the 1st of August the king of melinda send off one of he principal moor to visit the admiral to whom likewise he send sixteen of we man who have desert from pedro de tayde have stopt only two day at melinda for refreshment the fleet sail across for indium and come to anchediva where they find two portuguese ship command by antonio de saldanna and ruy lorenzo who be much afraid of we fleet suspect it to have belong to the rume -lrb- 2 -rrb- saldanna inform suarez that he have be send out the year before from portugal along with lorenzo as vice-admiral with order to explore the red sea and adjacent country that they be separate in a storm off the cape of good hope that lorenzo proceeding alone in the voyage have take a ship belong to the moor near sofalum out of which he have take a large quantity of gold and have leave the hull at melinda that saldanna prosecute he voyage to cape guardafuus where he have take many rich prize without have enter the red sea after which he have sail to indium and the winter come on have take shelter in anchediva where he be afterwards join by lorenzo at this place lope mendez de vasconcelle who have be separate in the storm off the cape of good hope rejoin the fleet the admiral use every expedition to get the fleet ready to proceed for cananor where he arrive on the 1st of September and be inform by the factor of the event in the war with calicut and how he and he companion in the factory have be often in great hazard of they life the day after he arrival the admiral go on shore in great state to visit the rajah of cananor attend by all the captain of the fleet in they boat decorate with flag and streamer and arm with ordnance all the boat crew be dress in they best apparel the admiral barge have a rich awning and be dress out with carpet on which stand a chair of state cover with unshorn crimson velvet and two cushion of the same for he foot he doublet and hose be of satin of diver color work diamond fashion he shoe of black velvet stud with gold he cap cover over with gold button over all he wear a loose robe or gown of black velvet in the french fashion trim all round with gold lace from he neck hang a triple chain of gold enamel from which depend a golden whistle he rapier and dagger which be bear by a page have handle of pure gold two lackey precede he in splendid attire and six trumpeter with silk flag he be also accompany by a band of wind instrument in a small boat in another boat be the present which he carry for the rajah from the king of portugal there be six bed of fine holland with they pillow of the same all work with gold embroidery two coverlet or carpet of unshorn crimson velvet quilt all over have three guard of cloth of gold that in the middle a span in width and the other two finger broad the bedstead be gilded all over have curtain of crimson satin fringed with cold thread on put off from he ship all the fleet salute he with they cannon then the trumpet and drum sound for a long time after which the organ never cease to play till the boat reach the shore where vast number of moor and gentile wait to receive the admiral on he landing the admiral be conduct into a _ sarame _ or house appoint for he reception and audience of the rajah in which he order the bed and all its rich furniture to be set up close to which be place a chair for the admiral to sit upon soon afterwards the rajah be bring to the house carry in a rich chair of state precede by three armed elephant three thousand nayre arm with sword spear and target and two thousand arm with bow and arrow the admiral apprized of the rajah 's approach by the fleet salute he with all they gun go to the door to receive he where they embrace then go together into the apartment the admiral present he with the bed already describe on which the rajah immediately lay down and the admiral sit down beside he in the place appoint they here confer together for two hour when they be interrupt by the bark of a greyhound belong to the admiral which want to attack one of the elephant soon afterwards a moor from calicut wait upon the admiral have along with he a portuguese boy who bring a letter from some of we man who be captive at calicut ever since the time of cabral be there this boy inform the admiral that the zamorin be so humble by the defeat he have sustain from pacheco that he have go into religious seclusion that many of the moorish merchant have go from calicut to other place as they could carry on no trade there owe to the war and that even provision have become extremely scarce that the zamorin and the prince of calicut and the magistrate of that place be exceedingly desirous of peace with the portuguese for which reason they have send he to the admiral and have allow the portuguese prisoner there to write he to that effect which they have do accordingly but chiefly in hope that he would free they from captivity after read the letter the admiral would have send a write answer mean to have send it by the moor but the boy tell he they have no permission to carry any letter and that he must return along with the moor as the people of calicut have threaten to put all they portuguese prisoner to death in case he do not return on this account the admiral give the boy a verbal message for the prisoner say that he would very soon come to calicut where he would anchor as near as possible to the shore and as the captive be allow to go about the city without iron they might find a opportunity to come off to the fleet either in boat or by swim suarez go accordingly with the fleet to calicut where he come to anchor on Saturday the 7th September and presently afterwards the boy who have be to visit he at cananor come on board accompany by a servant of cosebequin who bring the admiral a present from the tropic _ -lrb- 3 -rrb- they come to a great promontory call the cape of good hope which be almost 5000 mile distant from we country from thence they come to the cape anciently call _ prasum _ which be consider by ptolemy as the extremity of the southern region all beyond be unknown to the ancient after that they reach the country of the _ troglodite _ now call _ zaphalum _ or sofalum which we direct line be greatly shorter before pass the cape of good hope in consequence of be force out of they course by a sw wind they discover a new country to which they give the name of the _ land of parrot _ because they find there a incredible number of these bird of many beautiful color some of they a cubit and a half in length and more we have see two of these bird and can vouch for the truth of the description on explore this extensive coast the navigator believe that it must necessarily belong to a continent as they sail along it for the space of 2000 mile without have see either extremity its coast be inhabit by people of a tolerably handsome appearance who go quite naked -lrb- 5 -rrb- in this voyage they lose four ship two other be send to the gold mine which be not yet return and seven only reach calicut where they be honourably receive and have a house allot they by the prince and there they bring they ship to anchor soon afterwards there assemble many boat of the moor and other neighbouring people and some frigate belong to the great sultan all the people belong to which conspire together against the christian be exceedingly adverse to the come of the christian into these part lest they should diminish they profit they insist therefore to have they ship first load to the great dissatisfaction of the christian who immediately complain to the king of the insolence of the moor but soon discover that he favor they the king of calicut be a person of very doubtful faith and make the follow answer : that it do not seem equitable for the moor to be permit to finish they traffic before the christian and give order accordingly that the christian might carry on they trade the moor trangress this decree and take away the goods of the christian at pleasure upon which dispute arise between the christian and the moor in which the whole inhabitant of the city take part with the moor whereupon a great slaughter be make of the christian above forty of they be slay among whom be they principal factor when endeavor to escape by swim in revenge for this cruelty the christian make severe reprisal as they burn ten ship belong to the prefect of syrium that be the sultan and destroy a considerable portion of the city by means of they _ catapult _ and _ bombard _ -lrb- 6 -rrb- many house be burn to the ground as they be cover with thatch like cottage and exceedingly combustible after this the fleet leave calicut and go to another kingdom name cochin about forty mile distant be conduct thither by a jew who assume the christian faith the king of cochin hate the king of calicut exceedingly and on that account receive the christian with much kindness spice be in greater abundance at cochin than at calicut and the christian carry off such riches from cochin as i dare scarcely venture to report for they allege to have purchase a _ cantarus _ of cinnamon which be a considerable measure for one gold ducat the king of cochin give two hostage to the portuguese in assurance of they safety and send even ambassador to the king of portugal in the mean time the king of calicut fit out a immense fleet against the christian in revenge for have burn the ship in he harbor this fleet exceed 150 ship and carry 15000 man yet on account of a north wind which they be unable to contend with they dare not to attack the portuguese ship and withdraw from cochin as they great number be considerably formidable the portuguese ship go to a certain island in which the body of st thoma be inter the lord of which receive they kindly and give they some relic of that holy person in token of friendship : he even offer they greater quantity of spice than they have ever see before without money trust that they would pay for they on they return from europe : but be already laden the portuguese decline this friendly offer the portuguese fleet employ fourteen month in this voyage and return to lisbon in spring but they say that it may be make much sooner now that the course be well know and may even be accomplish in ten month all the ship that reach calicut return except one which be lose on certain rock but the crew save which ship be of six hundred ton burden as yet only one caravel have come into port but the rest be say to be not far off this lately arrive ship come into port on st john day 6th may at which time i happen to be with the king who address I in these word _ hah _ congratulate I good sir as my fleet be already in the river load with all kind of spice i receive the news joyfully as become I and make my compliment of congratulation to the king the tiding be welcome with exceed joy and all kind of festivity with the sound of trumpet cymbal and flute and the continual firing of cannon on the day follow there be a solemn thanksgiving at which all the people assist when i again wait on the king he desire I to apprize you serenity of he good fortune say that you may send you ship hither in safety to purchase he spice add that he should take such measure as to prevent the prefect of syrium that be the sultan -lrb- 7 -rrb- from procure spice in indium he found this hope assuredly on the success which he fleet have lately in contend with the numerous vessel of the moor and have no doubt of be able to reduce indium under he own authority the ship already arrive be command by a tuscan name bartholomew a native of florence she cargo consist of 300 _ cantarus _ or quintal of pepper 120 cantarus of cinnamon 60 cantarus of lac and 15 cantarus of castor and other perfume of that kind -lrb- 8 -rrb- they have no clove or ginger have be prevent by the moor as these could only be procure at calicut neither have they any of the lesser spice they have purchase many pearl of different sort which be all lose in the disturbance at calicut in which many of they man and much riches be destroy i must not omit to mention that there have lately arrive messenger from _ ubenus _ -lrb- 9 -rrb- king of ethiopium to the king of portugal bring gift of ivory and many other thing these be soon to return in two ship which be to go to indium after stop at the new gold mine while this ship which have first arrive be on its voyage home it meet two ship steer they course from the _ new gold mine _ -lrb- 10 -rrb- for indium these think themselves lose or that they would be plunder by the christian offer to pay they a ransom of 15000 ducat for leave to continue they voyage : but the christian though tempt by so much gold give these people many gift and permit they to continue they course that they might hereafter be allow a free trade with they country -lrb- 1 -rrb- this letter be date on the 20th of June 1501 and obviously refer to the voyage of cabral who have return from indium not long before the writer be describe as a native of crete and envoy from the lord of venice to the king of portugal -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- the strange geographical language here use be inexplicable probably because the idea of the writer be confuse he seem to mean the _ mina _ in guinea which be _ five or six _ degree _ within _ the equator or to the north but be at least 18 west from the meridian of sicily -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- mean the tropic of capricorn on which the sun be during we winter solstice -- e -lrb- 4 -rrb- the recession of the coast inwards from cape delgado to melinda which may be call the bay of zanzibar -- e -lrb- 5 -rrb- in the map of grynaeus already mention this _ terra psittacorum _ or land of parrot be place on the _ south-west _ coast of africa between the cape of good hope and congo yet there can be no doubt that the recent discovery of brazil on the _ eastern _ coast of south america be here allude to : consequently instead of the _ lebeccio vento _ or sw wind of the text it would naturally have require a s e wind to force the portuguese fleet so far to the westward of its intended course -- e -lrb- 6 -rrb- the author assuredly use these word to denominate two kind of ordnance or cannon then use in the portuguese ship of war -- e -lrb- 7 -rrb- by the sultan or prefect of syrium twice so design in this dispatch be evidently mean the mameluk sultan of egypt but who be soon afterwards defeat and slay by the turkish emperor the ineffectual exertion of the mameluk and turk instigate by venice to obstruct the portuguese trade in indium will be afterwards mention -- e -lrb- 8 -rrb- it be difficult to say what be mean by a _ cantarus _ in the text perhaps a quintal or 100 pound the castor of the text and other perfume may mean musk civet and ambergris -- e -lrb- 9 seem indicate as contradistinguish from the _ old _ gold mine of guinea the story of the two ship on they voyage to indium from sofalum obviously allude to the guzerate vessel more particularly mention already in the voyage of cabral -- e section ii _ letter from certain merchant and banker of spain -lrb- 1 -rrb- to they correspondent in the city of florence and venice respect a treaty of peace and league between the king of portugal and calicut _ we have be inform by those who be on board of the fleet which sail from lisbon to indium in may 1502 and return on the 15th December 1503 that the king of calicut have conclude a peace with we sovereign on the following condition as a compensation for the slaughter of we man he be to pay 4000 _ bahar _ of pepper equal to 12 000 quintal that the moor shall not be allow to trade there from any place whatever except only those who be native of calicut and that these even shall not be permit to trade with mecca that we king if so inclined may build a fort at calicut and shall be supply with a sufficient quantity of stone lime and timber for that purpose by the zamorin pay for these on delivery that the king of calicut shall aid and favor the portuguese in all thing and that it shall be competent for we king to appoint one of he own subject to administer justice among the portuguese resident in that city even with the power of life and death and without appeal to the zamorin that when any of we people shall revolt from or be disobedient to we commercial agent they shall immediately be deliver up to be judge by the aforesaid portuguese consul if any captive moor be detain they shall all be deliver up to we agent that the two milanese lapidary who have go from rome to indium and who there act as military engineer and shipbuilder in the european fashion to the disgrace of the christian profession and the vast injury of the christian should be deliver up in chain to the admiral of we fleet that the king or raja of cochin and cananore shall be include in this treaty as co-ally mutually share all danger and advantage with the other contracting party : so that if any one shall take arm against any of the party to this treaty he shall be declare a enemy to all the party hereby confederate if any of the party to this league shall act contrary to its stipulation the power of all the rest shall act against he as a perfidious person a traitor and a enemy to good faith all the contracting party use they utmost to preserve the present peace and alliance inviolate while the portuguese fleet might remain in the harbor of calicut all other ship whatever be to be refuse access at least until after ours be laden : but when there be sufficient goods for all who want they then all ship be to be at liberty to load provide always that the accustomed price should not be augmented and expressly that the profit to the vender should never exceed 8 per cent which be usual in that port these be the condition of peace and alliance which have be stipulate to the great honor and renown of we sovereign as must be evident to every one as henceforward he may not only be account sovereign of indium but have impose law on turkey and the prefect of syrium -lrb- 2 -rrb- since by this treaty all access to the city of calicut be debar to they trader we do not even doubt that in four year from hence through the vigorous measure of we king we sailor may safely navigate to constantinople and alexandrium the present most celebrated mart of eastern commerce and shall take signal vengeance on the moor by whom they have be infamously and frequently abuse for this purpose a fleet of twelve sail be fit out this year which find the rajah of cochin expel from he dominion have flee for refuge from the hostility of the king of calicut to a strong place in a certain island the only reason he could assign for the hostility of the zamorin be that faithful to he engagement he refuse to deliver we people to the king of calicut and choose rather to live in exile than to betray he trust in this extremity we fleet bring opportune aid to the friendly rajah and have land troops for he assistance they march boldly against the perfidious zamorin route he force with great slaughter and triumphantly restore the rajah of cochin to he dominion this kingdom be not far distant from the strait of the red sea where they have erect a very strong fortress -lrb- 3 -rrb- and be build another in the mouth of the bay of cochin provide with all kind of warlike artillery by which to repel the enemy and to provide a safe station for we fleet nor shall we recede from thence however adverse the native may be to we remain and when the same shall be do in the bay of calicut it will not then be difficult to defend these station and the adjoining coast against all aggressor we ship which remain in these sea last year make no small booty as they take one morning five ship bind from the kingdom of cambaya for mecca the shrine of mahomet in which they find 1000 _ cantarus _ or quintal of clean clove besides a large quantity of the same spice not free from the husk as be usual with we these ship have likewise castor and other perfume of that kind -lrb- 4 -rrb- sander wood amber purify lac and excessively fine linen and a large sum in gold and silver coin insomuch that the value of this prize exceed 200000 ducat have thus inform you of the wealth of that country which abound in almost every thing we now proceed to relate that two of we ship above mention have be cast away in a storm near the mouth of the red sea they commander vincentius and above six hundred man have perish but the other two be save -lrb- 5 -rrb- another vessel which escape that dreadful tempest be soon afterwards dash to piece against a rock so that the sea be cover with dead body and with rich merchandize of all kind : thus as the proverb say wealth ill acquire be ill lose of all these ship one small caravel only ride out the storm and bring intelligence of the destruction of the other we have now to inform you that we king have give permission to all who choose to proceed to indium and to carry on trade provide that he be pay a quarter part -lrb- 6 -rrb- of all return and that they purchase from he for the purpose such ship as he think proper and the price of these ship must be pay before set out on the voyage because consider the loss of ship which he have already sustain he be desirous that other should now bear the risk : it will therefore require large fund to embark in this trade so that we hardly believe the king will find any to engage on these condition but of this we shall inform you from time to time as it may occur it must not however be conceal that the circumstance of this trade be by no means establish on certain principle which can only be determine by future event a portuguese of the former fleet touch at a certain port in the kingdom of sofalum and visit a gold mine of which he relate wonderful thing he assure we that a ship of the christian have be there and speak of incredible quantity of gold to be find there on this account we king be resolve to erect a strong fort at that place to keep the barbarian under subjection and to keep away the indian and the inhabitant of cambaya lest they should make themselves master of the mine he will therefore immediately seize upon this mine for he own use which we certainly believe to have be the mine whence solomon derive such vast riches and where the queen of sheba dwelt who go to visit solomon as related in holy writ these thing be of such importance that they ought not to be conceal from you and we king be to be deem happy and fortunate because he have make the discovery of such vast riches it be believe by many that they will soon obtain permission from the king to go to indium pay he at the rate of 25 per cent and take he ship as before mention it appear to be he wish that the merchant should send out they own factor or supercargo with the care of they goods but without any authority as he wish to rule in all thing and that every thing may be direct by he officer even the expence of the merchant the trade in spicery be to remain exclusively in the viceroy and be not to be permit to the merchant for which reason it be not believe that this indian trade will be very profitable : but we shall give you due information of all these thing as they occur we have formerly write you that cairo fail in its commercial prosperity from the very same cause and if this great eastern trade shall be appropriate by the king it will certainly occasion a babylonian confusion in the state and very deservedly : for at cairo the moor be in use to maltreat the christian exceedingly and they be now perhaps suffer for that error as they will not any longer be allow to carry away any kind of spice or jewel of all kind or pearl and other valuable commodity as by means of the portuguese fort they will in future be debar from trade to calicut and sofalum for all which you will be thankful to god concern the gold mine of sofalum which we mention before and of which such wonderful thing be tell it be say we king will be the sole proprietor in two year which must prove of vast importance as from that place which be now possess by the idolater all indium and persium use to procure the whole of they gold although the mouth of the bay be under the dominion of a king of the chaldean -lrb- 7 -rrb- at which place the trade be carry on with the idolater by the moor who bring yearly they ship from cambaya laden with low-priced article which they barter for gold these goods be coarse cotton cloth silk of various fashion and many color but chiefly of the turkish fabric the king of quiloa a island about sixty league from sofala it be say will have to quit that place from fear of the idolater at quiloa all ship go to sofalum have to stop and pay tribute before go to the mine of sofalum when they get to sofala they have to remain there six or eight month before complete they affair carry from thence gold ivory and wax all of the best kind after this they have again to touch at quiloa and to pay a tax for they gold thence they go to cambaya or mecca in we ship there be twelve or fifteen agent of the king of quiloa who pay a tribute yearly to we king of 1500 _ metigal _ each of which metigal be worth 150 ducat or in all 225000 ducat that king depend so entirely on the king of portugal that we king may dethrone he whenever be please to send there a force of 1000 man which would oblige the king of quiloa to run away and it be believe this will be do shortly the thing be so easy and by this mean a yearly revenue of 500000 ducat would be secure if you have properly consider what those ship may bring which be daily expect you will find that they will at least import about 222 quintal of all kind of spice : and we shall ship for you of all these use we endeavor that you may never be in want of they even after the before mention treaty with the king of calicut no small risk still remain to those who navigate to the indy on account of a certain archipelago contain about 14000 island -lrb- 8 -rrb- and owe to the narrowness of a certain strait which be scarcely navigable we shall persist notwithstanding as by custom and experience these danger will become of no consequence at length we expect to have the glory of have discover almost the whole of the world and those part of it especially to which the ancient never penetrate it only remain for we to go to the island of taprobana or ceylon which accord to pliny be exceedingly rich in gold gem and ivory thus by we anxious endeavor we shall lay open the whole of indium to we trade by letter from thence it appear that we merchandize be not much value in these part and that _ crusado _ ought to be send out if we wish to have we affair speedily conduct as other goods remain long in hand : for the indian purposely procrastinate that they may beat down the value of we commodity the indian give a high price for brass and alum but this last must be white not red and in large piece as they despise the small they do not care for coral unless large and finely work which otherwise bear no value lead be value if in large bar quicksilver and amber be in no request work brass bear a low price as it be always manufacture over again in they own fashion so that the cost of manufacturing in europe would be throw away all other goods besides these mention be in no demand and will therefore bring small profit -lrb- 1 -rrb- this letter have no date but must have be very early in the sixteenth century probably in 1504 from the circumstance to which it allude at its commencement although say to be from _ spain _ there be every reason to suppose it be write from lisbon as we find portugal frequently consider as _ in _ spain which it actually be in the most extensive geographical sense -- e -lrb- 2 -rrb- this as formerly observe allude to the mameluk sultan of egypt through whose dominion the trade between indium and europe be entirely carry on before this era this treaty of peace and alliance between portugal and calicut may possibly have be propose at this period but certainly be not then agree to as there be long war with the zamorin before he power be reduce under the influence and dominion of the portuguese -- e -lrb- 3 -rrb- this be rather a anachronism as at this period the portuguese have no fortress on the red sea -lrb- 4 -rrb- the _ castor _ of the text be probably musk and its _ amber _ ambergris -- e -lrb- 5 -rrb- this allude to the misfortune of vincente sodre and he squadron already more distinctly relate in the precede chapter -- e -lrb- 6 -rrb- the expression of the original _ ex centenario lucro quadrugenarium _ be not easily understand : it be here translate a quarter part of the return cargo conformably with the regulation of don henry for the trade of guinea as already state in vol i p 204 from which the present be probably copy -- e -lrb- 7 -rrb- it be difficult to guess what bay and who may be the king of the chaldean here allude to perhaps the
